fact_check_explanation_title: Amazon virtual assistant Alexa does not predict the start of WWIII
fact_check_explanation_summary: In a viral audio clip, Alexa supposedly predicts that WWIII will start in November 2023.

fact_check_explanation_title: No investigation into football used in 2022 World Cup
fact_check_explanation_summary: Multiple posts on social media claim an investigation will be launched into the ball for being controlled using a remote.

fact_check_explanation_title: Missing girl hoax uses photo of kidnapped US child
fact_check_explanation_summary: The hoax post appeals for help to find a girl called Sofia who supposedly went missing in South Shields in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK’s tax revenue isn’t £40 billion less than it used to be “because of Brexit”.
fact_check_explanation_summary: A now-corrected article in The Guardian fails to make clear that a figure estimating the impact of Brexit on UK tax revenues is based on a counterfactual analysis.

fact_check_explanation_title: False claims of links between vaccines and HIV spread online
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media post falsely links Dr Anthony Fauci to the origins of the AIDS epidemic and repeats a long debunked theory that the smallpox vaccine causes HIV.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hoax missing boy post uses picture of animal rescue volunteer in Philippines
fact_check_explanation_summary: Fake appeals for information about a supposedly missing five-year-old have been shared in UK Facebook groups.

fact_check_explanation_title: Money spent on Test and Trace couldn’t fund 15% NHS pay increase for 35 years
fact_check_explanation_summary: A resurfaced claim that the money spent on the Test and Trace scheme would pay for a 15% pay rise for health service staff until 2058 is incorrect.

fact_check_explanation_title: Twitter community note about video of building collapsing in France is wrong
fact_check_explanation_summary: A community note on Twitter incorrectly claims a viral video of the aftermath of riots in France shows an unrelated incident in Paris from before the unrest began.

fact_check_explanation_title: Conservative and Labour claims on house building fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve seen a number of seemingly contradictory claims at the last two PMQs. Some are more accurate than others, but none tell the full story.

fact_check_explanation_title: Most renters do not live in buy-to-let properties
fact_check_explanation_summary: When the total number of renters is considered, only one third of rental properties have been purchased with this type of mortgage.

fact_check_explanation_title: No clear evidence of a significant fall in average waiting times
fact_check_explanation_summary: The health minister Maria Caulfield said that NHS England waiting times were falling “drastically”. The latest data does not support this.

fact_check_explanation_title: Picture of Nando’s ‘New World Order’ sign not taken in UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: What appears to be a tongue-in-cheek-sign about card payments has sparked calls for a boycott in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Google Meet is not introducing a button to turn on all cameras at once
fact_check_explanation_summary: An image that appears to show a screenshot of the alleged new feature is circulating on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: Minister wrong to claim small boat arrivals are down 20% in the first six months of 2023
fact_check_explanation_summary: The latest Home Office data actually shows the number of arrivals between January and June fell 10% year on year.

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS data doesn’t show 27,000 quit the health service for work-life balance reasons
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Observer reported that 27,546 staff had quit the NHS in England in 2022 citing work-life balance reasons, but the figures include staff moving to other health service jobs.

fact_check_explanation_title: French government has not restricted internet access to neighbourhoods in France
fact_check_explanation_summary: A fake press release appearing to be from France’s Interior Ministry is circulating online.

fact_check_explanation_title: Picture of Emmanuel Macron in front of fire is AI-generated
fact_check_explanation_summary: Full Fact has found numerous examples of AI images of the French president being shared widely online.

fact_check_explanation_title: Promotions on Facebook for £2 PlayStation consoles at Argos are fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: A spokesperson for the retailer told Full Fact the offers were not genuine.

fact_check_explanation_title: Government figures don’t show 140,000 children were ‘completely missing’ from formal schooling last year
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour MP Ian Mearns told us his claim was based on a Sky News report which said around 140,000 were “never in class”. But that’s not what the data shows, …

fact_check_explanation_title: Evidence doesn’t show sunscreen increases cancer risk
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media post falsely claims that sunscreens increase cancer risk, and makes assertions about endocrine disruption that aren’t borne out in the evidence.

fact_check_explanation_title: Riot video of Marseille library actually shows fire at Manila post office
fact_check_explanation_summary: This is one of several mislabelled videos we’ve seen claiming to show the outcome of riots in France.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook posts contain false claims about FDA product approval
fact_check_explanation_summary: Social media posts claim a “nasal herbal box” is FDA approved for weight loss and liver health. This is simply not true.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Foreign Office has not warned against travel to France
fact_check_explanation_summary: Multiple posts on social media claim that British citizens are being warned by the UK government not to travel to France because of the riots.

fact_check_explanation_title: Arc de Triomphe photo shows 2019 ‘gilets jaunes’ protest, not recent riots
fact_check_explanation_summary: An image shared on Facebook depicts flames and protesters in the centre of Paris.

fact_check_explanation_title: Picture of refugee banner wasn’t taken in France
fact_check_explanation_summary: A picture contrasting a pro-refugee protest with the recent riots in France has been shared hundreds of times online.

fact_check_explanation_title: A ‘Guardian’ opinion article supporting looting in France is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: A screenshot of a fake Guardian article has been widely shared on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: Diocese says attack on French priest was not because of his faith or to do with recent unrest
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that a priest was attacked by “Islamic race rioters” have been contradicted by the local diocese.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video of high rise on fire is from UAE, not France
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video of a recent fire in the city of Ajman in the United Arab Emirates has been shared to imply it comes from France.

fact_check_explanation_title: A grapefruit a day is no substitute for blood pressure medicine
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claims eating one grapefruit a day can replace high blood pressure medication. While the fruit might contribute to a healthy diet, it’s much less effective than conventional …

fact_check_explanation_title: Immigration minister’s claims about refugees in Scotland need clarification
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Home Office declined to comment on what Robert Jenrick MP meant when he said the SNP “does not house refugees in Scotland”. Whether he was exaggerating or not, it …

fact_check_explanation_title: Eiffel Tower ‘riot’ photo is actually from Euro 2016 final
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on Facebook claims that the photo shows riots taking place under the Eiffel Tower during recent protests.

fact_check_explanation_title: Zebras and lions filmed running through streets were not filmed during French riots
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts claiming that protesters have released the animals from Paris Zoo have circulated extremely widely online.

fact_check_explanation_title: Bill Gates-funded company did not cause malaria cases in Florida
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that a company happened to start releasing mosquitoes in the same places local-acquired malaria has been identified have been shared on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: Diane Abbott understated pay of NHS England boss
fact_check_explanation_summary: The MP said that Amanda Pritchard earns £86,000. But her annual earnings in 2021/22 were actually more like £255,000.

fact_check_explanation_title: Post comparing the UK today to 2010 has a number of errors
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post lists 53 claims that compare the UK today to 2010. Several of the comparisons we looked at were incorrect or misleading.

fact_check_explanation_title: The World Economic Forum isn’t planning the ‘end of national sovereignty’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post appears to make a number of claims about the WEF’s policies, including that it advocates for universal basic income, a cashless currency and a social credit system.

fact_check_explanation_title: Thousands share fake appeal for missing child ‘Sofia’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A picture of a different child has been used in a hoax appeal shared widely on Facebook.

fact_check_explanation_title: Could you be fined for driving in flip flops?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It is not illegal to drive in flip flops, but it is to drive carelessly or without control.

fact_check_explanation_title: False claims that Boris Johnson did not have Covid-19 circulate on social media again
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims from a satirical blog post about former Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s time in hospital with Covid-19 are being shared on social media as if they were true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour’s £2,900 ‘mortgage penalty’ figure refers to predicted rise for those remortgaging in 2024
fact_check_explanation_summary: The figure comes from the Resolution Foundation, but it’s not an estimate of the average increase in all mortgage payments, or an estimate for “this year”.

fact_check_explanation_title: 15 minute cities do not introduce digital IDs
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on social media makes multiple false claims about digital IDs and 15 minute cities.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Covid-19 vaccines were tested before rollout
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video on social media makes several false claims about the Covid-19 vaccines, citing a video from Canada.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are community diagnostic centres ‘cutting’ NHS waiting lists?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Diagnostic and treatment waiting lists have both grown, but the government says they’d be even longer without the additional checks and scans delivered by CDCs.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake missing man appeal uses picture of pet detective
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claiming a man is missing in Cookstown, Northern Ireland uses a picture of an Ohio-based pet detective.

fact_check_explanation_title: Titanic shipwreck far deeper than cropped video might suggest
fact_check_explanation_summary: The wreckage of the famous ship is almost four kilometres below sea level.

fact_check_explanation_title: Titan sub victim was not World Economic Forum vice chairman
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts on social media incorrectly claim Shahzada Dawood, a passenger on the Titan sub, was the vice chairman of the WEF.

fact_check_explanation_title: Genuine ‘get sterilised’ poster appeared in Islington in 2019
fact_check_explanation_summary: The poster, which was created by a street artist, appeared in Islington in 2019 but was soon replaced.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence audio clip is ‘banging’ noises from Titan sub
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook reel, shared hundreds of times, claims to feature audio from the lost submersible.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour MP’s child poverty claim uses figures which aren’t comparable
fact_check_explanation_summary: Kim Johnson MP tweeted that the number of children in poverty has increased from 2.6 million to 4.2 million since 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: Images falsely claim to show Titanic sub debris
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some images being shared are likely to be AI-generated while another was taken 19 years ago around the Titanic wreck.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video of ‘explosion in Paris’ was actually filmed in Russia in 2020
fact_check_explanation_summary: A dramatic video shared on social media shows a huge fireball rising over a busy road.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mirror wrong to say NHS standards ‘since Covid’ behind excess cardiovascular deaths
fact_check_explanation_summary: A print article claimed that poor NHS standards were the reason for almost 100,000 excess cardiovascular deaths since 2020, but it didn’t mention that Covid itself might have caused most …

fact_check_explanation_title: Greta Thunberg didn’t predict the world would end in June 2023
fact_check_explanation_summary: A since-deleted tweet shared by the climate campaigner in 2018 has been taken out of context.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence for MP’s claim 100,000 ‘ghost kids’ disappeared from school rolls in pandemic
fact_check_explanation_summary: Bob Seely MP made the claim during a debate in parliament.

fact_check_explanation_title: Missing grandma hoax posts use photo taken from a 2016 blog
fact_check_explanation_summary: Almost identical posts appeared in community groups for locations across the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: MailOnline corrects article on homeworking
fact_check_explanation_summary: The website said that a third of homeworkers don’t have their own workspace. But this was based on research looking at office workers in general.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson is not entitled to a ‘£115,000 pension’ as a former Prime Minister
fact_check_explanation_summary: Social media posts wrongly claim that Boris Johnson will receive a £115,000 a year pension.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour fails to back up claim that the NHS owns 10% of the world’s pagers
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim may stem from coverage of a 2017 report by a clinical messaging company. Other more recent figures suggest the NHS may account for far fewer than 10% of …

fact_check_explanation_title: Minimum wage earners haven’t seen a ‘£1,000 reduction in their tax’ compared to what they used to pay
fact_check_explanation_summary: A figure quoted by the Deputy PM actually refers to the difference between what a minimum wage earner pays now, and what they’d be paying if tax thresholds had risen …

fact_check_explanation_title: Looking at the sun can cause blindness
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral Facebook video claims looking at the sun directly is not harmful to the eyes if done at sunrise or sunset. This isn’t true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Nivea sunscreen does include ‘almond oil’ as an ingredient on the label
fact_check_explanation_summary: Thousands of people have shared Facebook posts warning that Nivea’s sunscreen for children does not include almond oil labelled on the package.

fact_check_explanation_title: Wetherspoons is not giving away free meals for two on Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: The company has confirmed that the post, shared more than 10,000 times online, is not genuine.

fact_check_explanation_title: Injured dog hoax uses photo of pet recovering from surgery
fact_check_explanation_summary: A widely-shared Facebook post claims that a dog was injured in a hit-and-run incident.

fact_check_explanation_title: Plea to help find missing grandma on Facebook is a hoax
fact_check_explanation_summary: The posts appear in community groups across the UK but use a photo from a genuine missing person appeal in the US, who has since been found.

fact_check_explanation_title: Police can’t automatically track your location if you press 55 during a 999 call
fact_check_explanation_summary: A claim about “new technology” has been shared more than 38,000 times, but isn’t correct.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook pages giving away Alton Towers tickets not associated with theme park
fact_check_explanation_summary: One of the posts has almost 3,500 shares.

fact_check_explanation_title: Wages are growing faster than before the pandemic, but have fallen in real terms
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister claimed his government was delivering “the fastest wage growth in years”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Steve Barclay wrong to claim the WHO has announced the Covid-19 pandemic is ‘officially over’
fact_check_explanation_summary: In fact, the World Health Organisation has said Covid is no longer a global health emergency, but that the pandemic is still ongoing.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photographs show a dead baboon not an alien
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post shows photos of what it incorrectly claims are aliens.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake Amazon iPhone deal advertised on Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: The post uses a similar video to other fake promotions we’ve checked before.

fact_check_explanation_title: Police don’t advise smashing car windows to rescue dogs in hot weather
fact_check_explanation_summary: Tens of thousands of people have shared inaccurate information about the law on rescuing dogs from hot cars.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sunken ice isn’t a reliable way to spot if your drink’s been spiked
fact_check_explanation_summary: Viral social media posts are warning people to watch for ice sinking in their drink—but if it’s been spiked, ice will usually still float.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has a Labour government ever left office with unemployment lower than when it came in?
fact_check_explanation_summary: While most Labour governments haven’t, historic unemployment data suggests there’s at least one exception.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sugar-free alkaline diets won’t ‘starve’ cancer
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video on social media claims that avoiding refined sugar and eating an ‘alkaline’ diet will have an anti-cancer effect. This isn’t supported by the evidence.

fact_check_explanation_title: Raw milk won’t cure lactose intolerance, but it might make you ill
fact_check_explanation_summary: An Instagram video claims that raw unpasteurised milk cures lactose intolerance. But raw milk still contains lactose and there’s no evidence it will prevent the digestive issues this causes.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post does not show a missing man with dementia named ‘Mr Jones’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post uses a photo from the US that has appeared in other hoax posts about missing elderly men.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook page offering free passes for Alton Towers is not associated with the theme park
fact_check_explanation_summary: Thousands of people commented on and shared the post in 24 hours.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hoax posts about dog bitten by rattlesnake shared widely online
fact_check_explanation_summary: The pictures used in the post have been circulating online for years.

fact_check_explanation_title: The overall NHS waiting list continues to rise
fact_check_explanation_summary: Rishi Sunak says the government’s “cutting waiting lists”. That’s true in the case of some specific NHS waiting lists, but not for the main list overall.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence viral appeal for information about ‘found’ cocker spaniel is genuine
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts about the dog have been shared thousands of times on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: England has fewer teachers relative to the number of school pupils than in 2010
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government’s announcement that there are a record number of teachers is missing important context.

fact_check_explanation_title: Chester Zoo is not offering a giveaway through ‘Chester Wildlife Park’ Facebook profile
fact_check_explanation_summary: Chester Zoo has warned the Facebook giveaway is not real.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour has received around £1.5 million from a Just Stop Oil donor, not the protest group itself
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no evidence of any donation from Just Stop Oil to the Labour party.

fact_check_explanation_title: The threshold for a recall petition to succeed is 10% of voters, not 10,000
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour MP Jonathan Reynolds claimed a recall petition requires 10,000 constituents to sign it, but in nearly all constituencies the threshold is lower.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson did not win the largest Conservative majority in 44 years
fact_check_explanation_summary: Lord Cruddas is also not correct to say Boris Johnson has never lost an election or campaign.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Missing’ child appeal featuring boy with a baby deer is a hoax
fact_check_explanation_summary: Many versions of the fake appeal have been shared in Facebook community groups both in the UK and US.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claims that Japan does not accept any refugees are false
fact_check_explanation_summary: Although the numbers have always been low, Japan does accept a small number of refugees.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post about Argos selling £2 PlayStation 5 consoles is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The retailer has confirmed the offer is not genuine.

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS dentist statistics don’t support PM’s claim that there are over 500 more ‘this year’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Rishi Sunak claimed NHS dentist numbers have increased by more than 500 “this year” compared with “last year”—but he appears to have been quoting figures for 2021/22.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence dog pictured at petrol station has been found in different English towns
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture of the dog appears to have been taken in a petrol station that does not have branches in Great Britain.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hoax posts about dog thief with gun use photos from US
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Facebook posts appear in community groups across the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake Greggs coupon deal shared hundreds of times
fact_check_explanation_summary: A deal offering free sausage rolls and hot drinks is too good to be true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Deputy PM fails to back up claim that government has provided over £3,300 in cost of living support for ‘every single family’
fact_check_explanation_summary: The figure quoted by Oliver Dowden appears to actually refer to the average amount per household provided by the government to help with rising bills.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video of explosion at Nova Kakhovka Dam is from 2022
fact_check_explanation_summary: The recent breaching of the dam has led to months-old footage being shared hundreds of times.

fact_check_explanation_title: Magna Carta doesn’t mean you can ‘legally overthrow’ a ‘tyrannical’ government
fact_check_explanation_summary: Online claims have been made about a section of Magna Carta that has been irrelevant for more than 800 years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claims about King Charles’s inheritance need context
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts on social media are making several claims about King Charles’s inheritance but they are missing vital context.

fact_check_explanation_title: The total asylum initial decision backlog has increased since December
fact_check_explanation_summary: The home secretary’s claim that the backlog is down by 17,000 refers only to applications made before 28 June 2022.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Pride installation' on Arc de Triomphe is animated video
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims suggesting that the iconic Paris monument has been decorated with a rainbow sculpture have been shared hundreds of times online.

fact_check_explanation_title: The US Air Force has denied that an AI-powered drone ‘attacked’ operators in a simulation
fact_check_explanation_summary: The airman who was the original source of the widely reported claims has since said he “mis-spoke” and had been describing a “thought experiment”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hoax posts about missing boy ‘Brandon Smith’ shared across England
fact_check_explanation_summary: Identical posts have appeared in social media groups for communities in Doncaster, Whaley Bridge and Gateshead.

fact_check_explanation_title: Millions did not vote in favour of the UK withdrawing from the ECHR
fact_check_explanation_summary: Brexit did not have any direct impact on the laws relating to human rights in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: You cannot be sent to prison just for failing to pay your TV licence
fact_check_explanation_summary: The only punishment available is a fine. Failure to pay the fine is a separate offence that can ultimately result in a prison sentence.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake missing child post uses photo of boy witnessing family pet being put down
fact_check_explanation_summary: The posts claiming the boy has gone missing in the UK use an image shared by a woman in the US in 2020.

fact_check_explanation_title: 5G is not triggering nanotechnology in the Covid vaccines
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video showing people collapsing claims to show deaths due to 5G activating ingredients injected into them.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Covid-19 vaccines saved many lives
fact_check_explanation_summary: A widespread meme on social media is clearly wrong when it suggests there is no evidence that the Covid vaccines saved any lives at all.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sun corrects net migration graph which didn’t reflect the latest data
fact_check_explanation_summary: A graph published on the newspaper’s website suggested a steeper recent rise in net migration than that shown by Office for National Statistics figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: Not all fish in the Channel belong to the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on Facebook also makes a misleading claim about small boat crossings to the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake birth parents appeal on Facebook uses US photographer’s picture
fact_check_explanation_summary: The image used in two posts was taken from a Seattle photographer’s website, despite the claim that the person searching was born in both Plymouth and Bristol.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hoax post about injured dog uses picture taken in Australia
fact_check_explanation_summary: A picture of a dog reported found in a County Durham Facebook group was actually taken in Australia in 2019.

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS Covid tracing app did not cost £37bn
fact_check_explanation_summary: Multiple Facebook posts have claimed that £37 billion was spent on the NHS Test and Trace app when it actually cost about £35 million in 2020/21.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hoax posts about missing dog use photograph that has appeared in blogs for years
fact_check_explanation_summary: The posts all have the same image and wording but appear in community groups across the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake Toby Carvery coupons shared thousands of times on Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: Edited coupons and a poorly spelt social media post are indications that all is not as it seems.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Lancet did not report 6.5 million migrants registered at GPs in the last decade
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post appears to have repeated an old claim that the Lancet medical journal said 6.5 million migrants had registered with GPs in the last 10 years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Appeal to find parents of man born in Warrington is a hoax
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no evidence that an appeal from “John Ederson” is genuine.

fact_check_explanation_title: Post appealing to find birth mother uses stock image with sepia effect
fact_check_explanation_summary: An appeal for someone’s birth mother claims the man searching was adopted in three different towns.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sadiq Khan did not have a ‘minor cardiac arrest’ at climate conference
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Mayor of London’s new book recounts a health scare in 2021 which may have been a heart attack. Some reports mistakenly called this a cardiac arrest, which is a …

fact_check_explanation_title: Reports of deadly rattlesnake found in UK and Ireland are false
fact_check_explanation_summary: Hoax Facebook posts claim the same snake has been found in multiple locations in the UK and Ireland.

fact_check_explanation_title: Spain’s High Court didn’t call Covid-19 a ‘bioweapon’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A document released by the Health Ministry in 2021 said that it did not have its own culture of the virus. This was misinterpreted in a blog and on social …

fact_check_explanation_title: Sunglasses don’t cause sunburn
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media post claims that sunglasses prevent melanin production, increasing the risk of sunburn. This is an incorrect description of the process of tanning.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence pictured dog has really been found at different locations across the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: The same image has been shared with similar text in local Facebook groups around the country and abroad.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Illegal immigrants’ don’t get an average £26,000 a year in benefits
fact_check_explanation_summary: An image shared on Facebook offers a misleading comparison between state pension payments and benefits given to “illegal immigrants”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hoax posts about missing ‘William Daniels’ shared widely on Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: Identical posts have been shared across the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Emergency alerts system set to cost £25 million over three years, government finally reveals
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Cabinet Office had previously declined to give any figures after claims about the cost of the emergency alerts test were made on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: False claims about cancer causing chemical in sunscreen
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media post claims that most sunscreens contain benzene, a chemical linked to cancer. It isn’t used as an ingredient, and the data on contamination doesn’t support these claims.

fact_check_explanation_title: Rishi Sunak’s GDP growth claim based on long-term forecasts
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister claimed the UK is forecast to have better growth than Italy, France and Germany—but this is only true when looking at long-term projections.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pfizer hasn’t been fined $2.3 billion for fraud relating to Covid vaccines
fact_check_explanation_summary: An out-of-context video has been liked more than 28,000 times on Instagram.

fact_check_explanation_title: Caravan shared hundreds of times on Facebook isn’t part of any giveaway
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post claiming social media users can win a free luxury caravan is too good to be true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Chelsea Clinton did not say children should be force-jabbed
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts on social media are attributing a false quote to Chelsea Clinton. She did not say that children in the USA should be forcibly vaccinated.

fact_check_explanation_title: Poster shared on Facebook misrepresents Agenda 21 and Agenda 2030
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post shows a photograph of a man with a poster that lists 22 alleged UN and WEF “goals”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can pharmacists prescribe medicines?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Pharmacy First service will mean people in England can get NHS prescription medicines for some conditions from a community pharmacy without seeing a GP. But some pharmacists can prescribe …

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Make England Great Again’ quote does not really come from Lee Anderson
fact_check_explanation_summary: The quote now circulating on social media is originally from a clearly labelled political sketch in the Guardian.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video showing ‘NATO soldiers now in Ukraine’ was filmed in Afghanistan in 2021
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video shared on social media was filmed during evacuations from Kabul in August 2021, not in Ukraine.

fact_check_explanation_title: The suicide rate may not have been rising in recent years
fact_check_explanation_summary: Sir Keir Starmer claimed the suicide rate is “going up”, based on a rise since 2007. But data for the last few years gives a mixed picture.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pictures of Elon Musk's ‘robot wives’ are AI-generated
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no evidence for claims that the billionaire plans to release “robot wives” for sale in September.

fact_check_explanation_title: HAARP research facility did not create distinctive clouds
fact_check_explanation_summary: The facility in Alaska does not produce water in the atmosphere and does not interact with clouds.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tim Schofield has not been stabbed in prison
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s been falsely claimed on social media that the brother of TV presenter Phillip Schofield has been stabbed in prison.

fact_check_explanation_title: Misleading caravan giveaway shared thousands of times on Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: Thousands of people have shared and commented on a post claiming to be offering a free luxury caravan.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland take their ‘fair share’ of refugees?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We looked into the figures after immigration minister Robert Jenrick recently claimed the devolved nations have “rhetorically welcomed refugees” but fail to take their “fair share”.

fact_check_explanation_title: President Zelenskyy is not wearing the same symbol worn by Hitler
fact_check_explanation_summary: Comparisons have been drawn between the insignia worn by the Ukrainian president and the military medal worn by Adolf Hitler, though they are not the same symbol.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video supposedly showing protests against Imran Khan’s arrest was filmed in 2022
fact_check_explanation_summary: A number of Facebook posts wrongly claim a video showed protests in London against the arrest of the former Pakistani Prime Minister earlier this month.

fact_check_explanation_title: Wrong man pictured in social media posts about Met Police shooting of two dogs
fact_check_explanation_summary: Thousands of people have shared posts which wrongly claim to have identified a police officer at the incident earlier this month.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence videos show ‘geoengineered’ skies
fact_check_explanation_summary: Thousands of people have liked an Instagram video claiming to show the difference between natural and allegedly engineered skies.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photograph of girls in white dresses does not show child brides
fact_check_explanation_summary: The photo shows young relatives of brides and grooms at a mass wedding in Gaza.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photos of Prince Harry and Prince William together at the coronation are AI-generated
fact_check_explanation_summary: The eight photos appear to show the brothers embracing and speaking to each other at the celebration.

fact_check_explanation_title: Would a 35% pay uplift for junior doctors cost £1 billion or £2 billion?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Labour MP quoted BMA figures claiming junior doctor “pay restoration” would cost £1 billion, but the health secretary said it would cost £2 billion.

fact_check_explanation_title: McDonald’s french fries are not made from potatoes treated with the pesticide Monitor
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim comes from a speech given in 2013 by an author, who has since admitted Monitor is no longer in use in the US.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many refugees does the UK resettle compared to other European countries?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Robert Jenrick said that the UK is second only to Sweden in the number of refugees accepted through resettlement schemes. This is true of European countries but doesn’t tell the …

fact_check_explanation_title: UK’s worst week for Covid-19 deaths far worse than viral post claims
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral claim on social media that 652 people died in the UK’s worst week of the pandemic is far too low. The true figure is almost 10,000.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake Amazon deal offering ‘£3’ Tefal set circulating on Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: Amazon confirmed that the offer shared on social media is not genuine.

fact_check_explanation_title: Social media posts falsely claim Nicola Bulley’s husband has been arrested and charged with murder
fact_check_explanation_summary: Thousands of people have shared baseless claims about Paul Ansell on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: The WHO has not declared the Covid-19 pandemic over
fact_check_explanation_summary: The World Health Organisation recently announced that Covid is no longer a global health emergency. But contrary to some reports, it says the pandemic is still ongoing.

fact_check_explanation_title: Argos is not selling PlayStations for under £2
fact_check_explanation_summary: Argos says the offer is not genuine.

fact_check_explanation_title: Monzo is not closing all customers’ accounts
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post which wrongly claimed the online bank is closing everyone’s accounts was shared over 1,500 times before being deleted.

fact_check_explanation_title: School statistics don’t show 140,000 children ‘never came back’ after pandemic disruption
fact_check_explanation_summary: A figure quoted in the Sun by Baroness Karren Brady is the number of pupils who missed at least 50% of sessions last summer, not the number who’ve disappeared completely.

fact_check_explanation_title: Abandoned baby hoax uses old photo from US
fact_check_explanation_summary: The photograph actually shows a baby that was found at Minneapolis Airport in 2022.

fact_check_explanation_title: Man pictured with caravan has not gone missing in Grimsby
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture used to show the man has previously been shared online in the US with claims the caravan in it has been stolen.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sand was not used to fill potholes along the coronation procession route
fact_check_explanation_summary: King Charles’s carriage passed patches of sand, which some claimed had been used to fill potholes.

fact_check_explanation_title: Four claims about GP numbers fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: The launch of the government’s new primary care plan prompted a raft of apparently contradictory claims about GP numbers.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photo of ‘chemtrails’ shows contrails made from water vapour
fact_check_explanation_summary: A picture of so-called “chemtrails” shows frozen trails of water vapour and not harmful chemicals being purposefully sprayed in the atmosphere.

fact_check_explanation_title: Errors corrected in Sun article about Ray Liotta’s cause of death
fact_check_explanation_summary: An online article in the Sun gave the wrong definitions for pulmonary oedema and respiratory insufficiency, and mixed up the link between diabetes and atherosclerosis.

fact_check_explanation_title: You can’t apply for asylum in the UK through the UNHCR
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UN’s refugee agency has clarified that there is no way for people to apply for asylum in the UK through the agency, after comments made by the Home Secretary.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photo shared on social media doesn't show King Charles with Dunblane gunman
fact_check_explanation_summary: A 1999 photo of the king and Jimmy Savile is real, but the third man in the picture is not the Dunblane shooter, who killed himself after the massacre three …

fact_check_explanation_title: Appeal for dog ‘found’ in Bexleyheath is not real
fact_check_explanation_summary: The pictures used were taken from reports about a dog found on a mountain in the US five years ago.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence video shows a real ‘fighting robot’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Viral footage supposedly showing a robot appears to be computer-generated and there’s no evidence it is associated with the robotics company Boston Dynamics, as has been claimed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Post about puppy with leg cast is a hoax
fact_check_explanation_summary: A fake appeal on social media features a picture of a very small puppy wearing a blue cast on its leg.

fact_check_explanation_title: Picture of ‘anti-Macron protest’ is actually from 2018 World Cup
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims the picture shows a protest against the “WEF globalist” French President are wrong.

fact_check_explanation_title: Image of plane underwater doesn’t show missing MH370
fact_check_explanation_summary: The plane in the picture is a Lockheed Martin aircraft that was purposely sunk off the coast of Jordan.

fact_check_explanation_title: Keir Starmer’s claim about first-time buyers’ deposits based on estimate of future increases
fact_check_explanation_summary: The £9,000 figure he quoted is actually a consultancy estimate apparently showing the extra savings required for a first-time buyer’s “typical” deposit by 2030.

fact_check_explanation_title: Comparison of junior doctors’ pay with baked beans prices lacks context
fact_check_explanation_summary: Most junior doctors are paid more than the equivalent of ten tins per hour, even if you only consider basic pay.

fact_check_explanation_title: Conservative claim that ‘overall crime’ has fallen 50% since 2010 excludes fraud
fact_check_explanation_summary: The PM and the policing minister have both made the claim in recent weeks, based on crime survey figures which don’t count fraud or computer misuse.

fact_check_explanation_title: Why can you use the 60+ Oyster card as voter ID, but not the 18+ Student Oyster card?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A number of social media posts highlight that one can be used as voter ID and the other can’t—but fail to explain that the 60+ Oyster card has more stringent …

fact_check_explanation_title: Transgender athlete did not win a female category of the London Marathon
fact_check_explanation_summary: Though biologically male, Glenique Frank participated as a female in the mass event but did not win.

fact_check_explanation_title: Missing girl Facebook post is a hoax
fact_check_explanation_summary: The photograph of a girl who’s supposedly just been found in a number of locations is at least seven years old.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hoax appeal for missing boy and dog uses images of a child in the US first shared in 2019
fact_check_explanation_summary: The post, which is similar to other hoax appeals we’ve written about recently, claims an autistic boy named Brandon Smith has gone missing with his dog.

fact_check_explanation_title: Missing girl hoax uses photos from US of two different children
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Facebook post uses photos of two different children who both went missing in the US.

fact_check_explanation_title: Miscarriages in Lanarkshire did not double in 2022
fact_check_explanation_summary: Data in a response to a Freedom of Information request contained a calculating error, which has since been corrected.

fact_check_explanation_title: Suella Braverman did not claim parliamentary expenses to pay her parents’ utility bills
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claims related to her London home and were within the rules governing such payments.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hoax alert about missing boy and dog uses stock image
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post about a boy named Brandon Smith has been shared in community Facebook groups.

fact_check_explanation_title: Free iPhone ‘from the government’ is not genuine
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK government doesn’t offer free iPhones to people on certain benefits though some claimants are eligible for low-cost tariffs for mobile and broadband.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook hoaxes about missing UK children use old photos from the US
fact_check_explanation_summary: The posts have appeared in community groups across the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook posts confuse ‘Apeel’ fruit and vegetable preservative with hard surface cleaner
fact_check_explanation_summary: A number of recent social media posts claim that an edible coating for fresh produce is hazardous to human health.

fact_check_explanation_title: British artists are due to perform at King Charles’s coronation concert
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video on social media falsely claims that the ‘entire British music scene’ has dismissed calls to perform at the coronation concert.

fact_check_explanation_title: How do junior doctors’ pay demands compare with MPs’ recent salary rises?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some claims made during the recent strike used a mix of cash-terms and real-terms figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: Government claims on police officer numbers don’t tell the whole story
fact_check_explanation_summary: Newly released figures show the government has reached its target of recruiting 20,000 more police officers since 2019. This is roughly the same number of officers lost between 2010 and …

fact_check_explanation_title: Infosys did not work on emergency alerts system
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that Rishi Sunak’s father-in-law’s company got the emergency alerts contract are going viral.

fact_check_explanation_title: Emergency alert doesn’t let government ‘take control’ of your exact location
fact_check_explanation_summary: The alert uses 4G and 5G technology to send out a warning to those close to danger.

fact_check_explanation_title: Advice to ‘NEVER’ give babies water is missing context
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video on social media, and written up in the Mail Online, warns against giving young babies water. But some babies may need some in hot weather.

fact_check_explanation_title: Using the herb comfrey on teeth could be dangerous for health
fact_check_explanation_summary: Social media videos claim that comfrey, a herb used in traditional medicine, can be used to improve teeth and gums. There is no good evidence for this, and using the …

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence the Rockefeller family wrote a ‘secret covenant’ to control the public
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook video with more than 175,000 views claims the Rockefellers are at the heart of an evil plot.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photos don’t show Asda staff member throwing water over a man
fact_check_explanation_summary: Asda says the staff member was watering the plants.

fact_check_explanation_title: The IMF has not launched its own Central Banking Digital Currency
fact_check_explanation_summary: A cryptocurrency calling itself a CBDC was launched at an IMF spring meeting but the IMF has not endorsed it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Study does not find ‘short breaks induce mental exhaustion’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Several publications incorrectly reported the findings of this study.

fact_check_explanation_title: FDA document does not say graphene oxide is in Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine
fact_check_explanation_summary: A blog has made false claims about a recently released Covid-19 vaccine document. The document does not say that the Pfizer vaccine contains graphene oxide.

fact_check_explanation_title: The numbers behind the PM’s maths claims fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve dug into the figures behind Rishi Sunak’s claims about the negative impact of poor numeracy.

fact_check_explanation_title: Thousands share hoax post about injured dog
fact_check_explanation_summary: Police in the US have recently warned that identical posts are connected to scams.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook posts about missing woman with dementia are hoaxes
fact_check_explanation_summary: The posts appear in community groups across the UK and even in the US.

fact_check_explanation_title: Official death data doesn’t tell us whether junior doctors’ strikes cost lives
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Telegraph article claimed that strikes were a factor behind a spike in deaths in England. But a similar spike occurred in Wales, where there were no strikes.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hoax alerts for missing pensioner shared thousands of times
fact_check_explanation_summary: Identical posts falsely claiming a man named Martin Jones has gone missing have been shared across the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: List of ‘Communist Rules for Revolution’ has been widely debunked
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s little evidence that the list, which was shared by Andrew Bridgen MP, is a genuine Communist document.

fact_check_explanation_title: Emergency alert won’t give government access to your location or personal data
fact_check_explanation_summary: The alert works via cell towers that send the message to all connected devices in their area.

fact_check_explanation_title: Emergency alert test is not an ‘activation signal’ for a vaccine ‘pathogen’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts on social media appear to claim the test will activate a “pathogen” in the Covid-19 vaccine.

fact_check_explanation_title: The HAARP research facility didn’t produce peculiar clouds
fact_check_explanation_summary: The clouds pictured in a social media post have nothing to do with the Alaskan research facility that is essentially a large radio transmitter used to study the upper parts …

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK is not being flooded with contaminated drugs
fact_check_explanation_summary: Former nurse and campaigner Kate Shemirani has wrongly claimed that contaminated drugs are “flooding the UK” and prescription medication is one of the top three causes of death.

fact_check_explanation_title: Police appeal for mother of abandoned  abandoned baby in Walsall is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: West Midlands police confirmed social media posts about an abandoned baby boy are not true.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence Bill Gates talked about putting ‘vaccines in our food supply’
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no record of him tweeting it and his foundation says he never did.

fact_check_explanation_title: AirPods haven’t been shown to be dangerous
fact_check_explanation_summary: An Instagram video, which was widely viewed before being deleted, claimed electromagnetic field radiation from Apple AirPods is dangerous. There is no good evidence that this is a risk.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence motorhome ‘giveaway’ is real
fact_check_explanation_summary: Hundreds of thousands of people have shared what appears to be a fake campervan giveaway on Facebook.

fact_check_explanation_title: Saunas not proven to reduce risk of death
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media video contains claims about the health effects of saunas, saying that regular use reduces risk of death. This is not backed up by science.

fact_check_explanation_title: Longer contrails aren’t ‘chemtrails’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on Facebook claims to compare contrails with an apparent “chemtrail”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hoax posts claim Facebook user is searching for their birth parents
fact_check_explanation_summary: Almost identical posts appear in community groups across the UK using the same black-and-white photo of a child.

fact_check_explanation_title: Vitamin D supplements aren’t ‘rat poison’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media video claims vitamin D is poisonous. At normal doses it is perfectly safe, and some people need to take it to ensure healthy bones and muscles.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Government is not expecting tree planting to almost halve by 2025
fact_check_explanation_summary: Projections for “afforestation in the UK” published by the Department for Energy Security and Net Zero actually show a mix of figures for both the UK as a whole and …

fact_check_explanation_title: Toby Carvery is not giving away free meals to people who comment on a Facebook post
fact_check_explanation_summary: The restaurant chain has confirmed it is not affiliated with the supposed offer or the page it appears on.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hoax posts about ‘missing’ man ‘Martin Jones’ recirculating on social media
fact_check_explanation_summary: False claims that an elderly man with dementia is missing are circulating widely in local Facebook groups.

fact_check_explanation_title: Prince William does not own Serco
fact_check_explanation_summary: Serco doesn’t ‘own’ Obamacare, the colloquial name for the US Affordable Care Act, either.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hoax ‘injured dog’ posts use old photo which appears to be from Ukraine
fact_check_explanation_summary: Facebook posts falsely claim a dog has been injured in a hit-and-run incident in various locations around the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Traffic cameras in Leeds city centre cannot ‘capture faces’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video on Facebook claims that “scanners” have been positioned on lamp posts in Leeds to capture pedestrians’ faces.

fact_check_explanation_title: New speed cameras with a limit of 72mph haven’t been set up on the M1 or M25
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that cameras enforcing a maximum speed of 72mph are being activated have been shared online.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video clips don’t show Buzz Aldrin admitting he never went to the Moon
fact_check_explanation_summary: Three out-of-context interview clips have been shared as apparent evidence the astronaut never walked on the Moon.

fact_check_explanation_title: London is not ‘55% non-white’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Data from the 2021 Census shows it’s closer to 46%.

fact_check_explanation_title: 5G isn’t going to activate Marburg virus hidden in vaccines
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no evidence for false claims on social media stating Marburg virus is hidden in the Covid-19 vaccine and will be activated by 5G.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Government did not spend £37 billion on the NHS Test and Trace app
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on Instagram has claimed that £37 billion was “wasted” on the NHS Test and Trace app when it actually cost about £35 million in its first year.

fact_check_explanation_title: How to spot AI-generated images
fact_check_explanation_summary: Full Fact’s guide on how to spot images created using Artificial Intelligence.

fact_check_explanation_title: Energy bills, retirement age and pensions in the UK compared to France
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claims people in France are “better off” because “they strike”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the police vetting code of practice legally binding?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Police chiefs in England and Wales are legally required to “have regard” to the code of practice, but aren’t legally required to follow everything in it—or more detailed associated guidance.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence John D. Rockefeller wrote ‘secret covenant’ about poisoning the public
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media video claims that the billionaire wrote of a secretive plan to harm the population.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tetanus jabs are not being used to sterilise people
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims in a Facebook video that the tetanus vaccine was being used to sterilise people seem to be a rehashing of an old theory that has previously been disproven.

fact_check_explanation_title: Magnetic antibiotic capsules don’t contain graphene oxide
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media post apparently shows part of an amoxicillin capsule being magnetic, and says this means it “most likely” has graphene oxide in it to poison us. This is …

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence Stanley Kubrick faked the moon landing
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video claiming to show the late director “confessing” to the fraud has been shared widely online.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Recent photo’ of Julian Assange was generated by AI
fact_check_explanation_summary: The fake image of him apparently taken in prison has been shared by users who apparently believe it’s genuine.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake missing autistic boy and dog posts go viral on social media
fact_check_explanation_summary: The image being used was taken from a video about an American boy being reunited with his lost pug.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral figures on benefit fraud and tax evasion are wrong
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts on social media make a series of specific claims about losses from benefit fraud and tax evasion, and the number of people investigating both.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post appealing to find missing dog’s owner is a hoax
fact_check_explanation_summary: The photo used in this post comes from a genuine post about a lost dog being found.

fact_check_explanation_title: Comparison of minimum wage and state pension incomes is out of date
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post comparing the amount someone paid minimum wage earns with the state pension uses figures which are out of date, and lacking important context.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mammogram radiation levels aren’t comparable with nuclear bomb
fact_check_explanation_summary: An old video contains false claims about the amount of radiation in mammograms and the effect of screening on death rates.

fact_check_explanation_title: Gorillas’ diet doesn’t mean protein does not exist
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video on social media falsely claims that protein doesn’t exist, based on the idea that a gorilla’s diet doesn’t include any. But gorillas do eat a large amount of …

fact_check_explanation_title: Photo of Suella Braverman looking at model Auschwitz is digitally altered
fact_check_explanation_summary: An edited picture of the home secretary’s recent trip to Rwanda has been shared hundreds of times.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are GP numbers rising or falling?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Earlier this month the PM claimed there are now a “record number” of GPs, while the Liberal Democrats say the number’s down since the last election.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video showing President Biden distracted by ice-cream van has been edited
fact_check_explanation_summary: A modified video circulating on social media appears to show President Biden getting distracted by an ice-cream van during a speech by the first lady.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do any European countries send asylum seekers to Rwanda?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that Denmark and other EU countries do so are missing context.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook ‘free meal’ at Harvester offer is not official
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post offering users a free meal for two is not affiliated with the restaurant chain.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video of woman stuffing seagull into bag is missing context
fact_check_explanation_summary: An out-of-context video has left social media users wondering if seagulls are being eaten due to the cost of living crisis.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence Covid-19 vaccines have killed thousands of children
fact_check_explanation_summary: An Instagram post wrongly claims that no “healthy” children have died from Covid-19, and that the vaccines have killed thousands.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral pictures of Pope Francis wearing puffer jacket are AI-generated
fact_check_explanation_summary: The apparent pictures of Pope Francis have been shared tens of thousands of times.

fact_check_explanation_title: Covid-19 is not a ‘simple flu’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post calling for an investigation into the Covid-19 pandemic falsely claims the government “knew” the virus was a “simple flu”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Emergency alert won’t ‘access personal data’
fact_check_explanation_summary: False claims about the emergency alert the government is testing in April are spreading online.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photo doesn’t show police finding six skeletons in Wales
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post falsely claims that at least six skeletons have been found by police in Wales.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photo doesn’t show interior of ‘chemtrail plane’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts claiming that a photo shows the inside of a “chemtrail plane” have circulated online for many years. It’s actually a system for fighting forest fires.

fact_check_explanation_title: Emergency Alerts won’t match personal data with information collected during the pandemic
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post falsely claims that the government’s new Emergency Alert service will collect data from someone’s phone.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are UK nationals a minority in the modern slavery statistics?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and Labour MP Jess Phillips clashed over the modern slavery figures during PMQs—but who was right?

fact_check_explanation_title: The government doesn’t spend £17 million a year subsidising food in Parliament
fact_check_explanation_summary: Thousands of people have shared a claim about cheap food in the House of Commons on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: Test and Trace app cost much less than £37 billion
fact_check_explanation_summary: Several posts on social media have wrongly claimed the NHS Test and Trace app cost £37 billion. It actually cost about £35 million in its first year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Emergency alert phone test on 23 April will not ‘breach GDPR’
fact_check_explanation_summary: This is based on a misunderstanding of how the system works. The alert neither uses nor collects any personal data.

fact_check_explanation_title: Outcome of Charles Bronson’s parole hearing has not yet been announced
fact_check_explanation_summary: Multiple Facebook posts have claimed Charles Bronson’s parole bid has been successful and that he is due to be released from prison.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour MP wrong to say ‘there are no safe routes’ to enter UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: Khalid Mahmood wrongly claimed in Parliament that routes for people from Hong Kong and Afghanistan have been closed.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Liberal Democrats, SNP and Plaid Cymru all pledge to immediately restore the overseas aid target
fact_check_explanation_summary: Liberal Democrat leader Ed Davey claimed his is “the only party” calling for spending on foreign aid to be restored to 0.7% of Gross National Income.

fact_check_explanation_title: Toby Carvery is not giving away free meals for two on Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media post falsely claims to be from the restaurant chain.

fact_check_explanation_title: You cannot get ‘half-ownership’ of a property you’ve rented for five years
fact_check_explanation_summary: A claim linked to Serco offering landlords six year, 11 month contracts is going viral.

fact_check_explanation_title: Eating bugs hasn’t been shown to cause cancer or lung disease
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media post claims that eating insects causes disease. But the evidence it cites does not support this.

fact_check_explanation_title: Misleading claims about ginger and cancer
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claiming ginger kills 91% of leukaemia cells omits some important details.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post falsely denies planes caused Twin Towers to collapse
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post denies that planes caused the Twin Towers to collapse.

fact_check_explanation_title: CEO of Center Parcs is not giving away a free holiday on Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post falsely claims the holiday firm’s CEO is offering a free stay to someone who likes, shares and comments on it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Police find ‘no criminality’ after reports of ‘child snatching’ in Lanarkshire
fact_check_explanation_summary: Thousands of people have shared a Facebook post claiming there have been three attempted kidnapping incidents in the Wishaw area.

fact_check_explanation_title: Asda tills don’t use facial recognition for targeted ads
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook video wrongly claims Asda’s self-service tills use facial recognition to collect data about customers for targeted advertising.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Human cages’ in California were used by prison service
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video claiming the police promised to destroy the cages is wrong.

fact_check_explanation_title: ONS release doesn’t show vaccines ‘killing in huge numbers’
fact_check_explanation_summary: An ONS bulletin about Covid-19 deaths by vaccination status does not show the vaccine is killing people in huge numbers.

fact_check_explanation_title: People crossing the UK border illegally do not automatically get jobs and benefits
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post makes several claims about the benefits of arriving in the UK illegally compared to other countries. Many of the claims are false or misleading.

fact_check_explanation_title: Instagram post's claims about myocarditis in children not supported by official data
fact_check_explanation_summary: Social media claims that 1 in 40 children now get myocarditis are based on limited evidence—and ignore official evidence to the contrary.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook hoax about missing child uses photo of girl believed to have been murdered years ago
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claiming to be a mother searching for her missing daughter is a hoax. It uses the photo of a girl who is believed to have been murdered …

fact_check_explanation_title: Youth unemployment no longer at historic low
fact_check_explanation_summary: The rate reached its lowest level last summer but has been rising ever since.

fact_check_explanation_title: Think tank figure does not show 100,000 children ‘never went back to school’ due to lockdown
fact_check_explanation_summary: Journalist Isabel Oakeshott twice claimed that 100,000 children left education permanently as a result of the pandemic.

fact_check_explanation_title: Post about man with dementia missing with his dog is a hoax
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claims that a man with dementia is lost with his dog and needs help getting home. It is a hoax.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Vitamin B17’ from apricot seeds does not cure cancer
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s been claimed on social media that amygdalin, a substance found in some nuts and seeds, kills cancer cells. The evidence for treating cancer is not there, and the substance …

fact_check_explanation_title: The average junior doctor gets paid more than £14 an hour
fact_check_explanation_summary: A BMA advertisement says that a junior doctor makes just £14.09 per hour. This might be true in some cases, but on average junior doctors earn much more.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ukraine’s Diia app is not connected to the ‘Great Reset’
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are also no official plans for Ukrainians to be paid a universal basic income through the app, as has been claimed on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: Research on long term effects of childhood infections misreported
fact_check_explanation_summary: Research showing increased risk of premature death from respiratory conditions in people who had chest infections as children has been reported on by the Sun–but with several errors.

fact_check_explanation_title: The asylum backlog is far higher now than when Labour left government
fact_check_explanation_summary: The home secretary told Parliament the current backlog bears “no comparison” to the situation in 2010, and that Labour would be “found wanting” in any comparison.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hundreds of people have been prosecuted for tax evasion in the last two years
fact_check_explanation_summary: A much lower figure tweeted by a Labour MP only included prosecutions for enabling tax evasion.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hoax posts about ‘missing uncle’ Martin Jones shared widely online
fact_check_explanation_summary: Hundreds of people have shared fake alerts about a missing pensioner with dementia.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK doesn’t have more job vacancies than unemployed people
fact_check_explanation_summary: A column by former work and pensions secretary Chloe Smith was corrected after we contacted the MP about the error.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence to support Rishi Sunak’s asylum backlog claim
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister said there were 6,000 fewer people in the “asylum backlog”—but the latest published figures show a large rise in the number of people waiting for applications to …

fact_check_explanation_title: Post about injured dog found on ‘side road’ in Northern Ireland is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture of the dog was actually taken from a 2020 news article about an incident in Pembrokeshire.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Illegal immigrants’ are not entitled to more benefits than pensioners
fact_check_explanation_summary: False information comparing benefits and other financial support has been circulating for more than a decade.

fact_check_explanation_title: Who are the 100 million displaced people Suella Braverman said could qualify for UK protection?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve looked into the figures after the Home Secretary claimed 100 million people could be eligible for protection under current UK laws.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post about dog ‘injured in a hit-and-run’ is a hoax
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post about an injured dog found in south-east London is a hoax. It uses a photo from a hit-and-run incident in New Jersey in 2020.

fact_check_explanation_title: Agenda 2030 will not enforce eating insects, banning cars or a global dictatorship
fact_check_explanation_summary: A cartoon on Facebook implies that Agenda 2030 will create a UN/WHO dictatorship and introduce several global policies.

fact_check_explanation_title: There is no free ‘mystery bus’ in Brussels
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral Twitter joke about a bus supposedly called ‘not the 48’ is being taken seriously by some.

fact_check_explanation_title: Asylum seekers do not receive £175 a week
fact_check_explanation_summary: Payments are significantly lower and reduced further if meals are provided.

fact_check_explanation_title: Aldi is not giving away free food packages to Facebook users
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook page is claiming to offer free Aldi food packages for users that engage with its posts, but Aldi has confirmed the page is not associated with them.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ed Sheeran lookalike isn’t on the run in Liverpool
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post claiming a man is wanted for posing as the singer has been shared more than 11,000 times online.

fact_check_explanation_title: Posts about venomous snakes in UK toilets are false
fact_check_explanation_summary: Images shared on local Facebook groups do not show a venomous breed, and an accompanying picture is from a 2019 incident in the US.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Tweet’ on Essex Police recruitment is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: Essex Police have confirmed the image being shared on social media is not a real tweet from the force.

fact_check_explanation_title: Countries did not pull their ambassadors out of Turkey 24 hours before the earthquake
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some consulates were previously shut to the public due to security concerns

fact_check_explanation_title: The Earth is not flat
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on Instagram claims that satellites are fake and the Earth is flat. This is not true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video of helicopter crashing ‘in Ukraine’ is actually from a video game
fact_check_explanation_summary: Footage from the military game has been falsely claimed to show footage from the war before.

fact_check_explanation_title: Was Rishi Sunak’s new claim about a house building record accurate?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister claimed house building has hit a record high under the current government.

fact_check_explanation_title: Conservatives’ estimate that Labour plans would create a ‘£90 billion black hole’ is unreliable
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Conservative Party claims that Labour has pledged £90 billion worth of unfunded spending commitments. We’ve looked into how it reached this figure.

fact_check_explanation_title: Zelenskyy’s ‘body double’ is really his head of security
fact_check_explanation_summary: The man was in a video of the Ukrainian and US presidents in Kyiv.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Free food box’ offer on Facebook is nothing to do with Aldi
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on a page called “ALDI Stores” claims those commenting will be sent free groceries.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence 5G can cause memory loss, nosebleeds or irregular heartbeat
fact_check_explanation_summary: False claims that 5G can cause worrying health conditions are widespread on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: The WHO is not working on vaccines to create ‘permanent sterility’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Clips from a 2009 TV show falsely claim the World Health Organisation wants to depopulate the world using vaccines.

fact_check_explanation_title: Dog supposedly hit by a car in south London actually died in the US in 2017
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post features an image of a dog that was fatally injured in Newport News, Virginia.

fact_check_explanation_title: Oxford residents won’t require a permit to ‘leave their district’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video making misleading claims about the city’s new traffic filter scheme has been shared widely online.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photo of newborn ‘found in Swansea dumpster’ shows a baby found in London in 2019
fact_check_explanation_summary: South Wales Police confirmed it has no record of an incident described in a Facebook post involving an abandoned baby.

fact_check_explanation_title: Kate Shemirani makes several false claims about childhood vaccines
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that children get almost 100 vaccines, that none are safe or effective, and that no vaccines have ever been trialled together are all false.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mark on Joe Biden’s forehead during Poland trip isn’t a ‘bruise’
fact_check_explanation_summary: The mark is actually an ash cross, given during the Ash Wednesday Mass.

fact_check_explanation_title: The NHS Test and Trace app did not cost £37 billion
fact_check_explanation_summary: £37 billion was the total budget for the NHS Test and Trace programme over its first two years, only a fraction of which was spent on the app.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook posts about Samsung S23 and iPhone giveaways are fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts on social media falsely claim that Argos and Amazon are selling Samsung S23 phones for £3 and that Amazon is also selling iPhone 14s for the same price.

fact_check_explanation_title: Newspapers and health minister understate junior doctors’ pay demand
fact_check_explanation_summary: Junior doctors are asking for a pay rise of about 35%—not 26%, which is how much their union says their pay has fallen by since 2008-9.

fact_check_explanation_title: Posts about an Adidas shoe giveaway are fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The company says it is not involved in any such offer.

fact_check_explanation_title: Posts about a lost woman with dementia are a hoax
fact_check_explanation_summary: The posts claim to need help identifying an elderly woman with dementia who has arrived at a local shelter with her dog, but they appear in many different places.

fact_check_explanation_title: Daily Express claim on Scotland’s ‘deficit’ needs context
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s true that Scotland technically has a large budget ‘deficit’, but the level of the deficit is mainly due to decisions made by the UK Government not the Scottish Government.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mouth cancer rates not increased by Covid-19 test swabs
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media post incorrectly claims mouth cancer rates are their highest ever due to Covid-19 test swabs. Ethylene oxide on swabs is very low risk.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video doesn’t show Joe Biden falling down stairs of Air Force One in Poland
fact_check_explanation_summary: A White House spokesperson confirmed that the person filmed falling was not the US President.

fact_check_explanation_title: Public consultation was held on ULEZ expansion proposals
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on social media claims that plans to expand the ULEZ to cover all of Greater London had “no public consultation and no mandate”.

fact_check_explanation_title: King of Bahrain does not have a robot bodyguard
fact_check_explanation_summary: Viral videos on social media show a robot created by an entertainment company and hired to amuse crowds.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook ‘M&S golden ticket giveaway’ is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The post uses misleading imagery to promote a fake giveaway.

fact_check_explanation_title: Net Zero pledge doesn’t commit councils to implementing ‘15 minute cities’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Social media posts have wrongly conflated a climate pledge made by several UK councils with plans to create “15 minute cities”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hearse being impounded during funeral is actually scene from TV comedy
fact_check_explanation_summary: The photo depicting a hearse being impounded in front of pallbearers is actually a scene staged for a BBC programme.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do Rishi Sunak’s claims about hospital discharge funding stack up?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve looked into the figures after Rishi Sunak said a new discharge fund was “already making a difference”, and the number of people unnecessarily in hospital was reducing.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘WEF protest’ in Spain was actually over health system
fact_check_explanation_summary: A TikTok account claimed the video showed a protest against “the effects of WEF globalism”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Naz Shah did not say quote about grooming gangs
fact_check_explanation_summary: The comment is sometimes falsely attributed to her as a direct quote, but it was actually a retweet that she later deleted and said had been retweeted by accident.

fact_check_explanation_title: How does the government’s minimum service level legislation compare to strike laws in other European countries?
