fact_check_explanation_summary: Rishi Sunak and Grant Shapps have compared the new Bill to laws in France, Spain, Italy and Ireland.

fact_check_explanation_title: PA Media corrects error in reporting on research for prostate cancer test
fact_check_explanation_summary: Reports on research for a new prostate cancer test contain errors and may not represent the true nature of the findings.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral ‘average energy cost’ Europe price list is not what it seems
fact_check_explanation_summary: The list, which has been retweeted by a Labour MP, shows wholesale prices of electricity for a single hour in December 2022.

fact_check_explanation_title: Amazon parcel giveaway is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts promoting a pallet of uncollected Amazon parcels for £2 are fake

fact_check_explanation_title: SNP's claim that Liz Truss’s government cost UK economy £30bn is not reliable
fact_check_explanation_summary: This figure represents an old estimate of the likely cost to the Treasury. The cost to the economy cannot be reliably measured.

fact_check_explanation_title: Posts about missing boy use stock photograph of child model
fact_check_explanation_summary: The image has been available online since 2015.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence Sadiq Khan said people should ‘create harmony by learning Arabic’
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve found no evidence for a widely shared social media claim that the Mayor of London said people should learn Arabic.

fact_check_explanation_title: Baby ‘found in dumpster’ actually rescued in Syria after earthquake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The baby pictured in multiple Facebook posts shared to local groups was not found in a dumpster having been abandoned by its mother.

fact_check_explanation_title: Liberal Democrat analysis of Rishi Sunak’s first 100 days contains several flaws
fact_check_explanation_summary: The party claimed that an average household got £1,200 poorer during the Prime Minister’s first 100 days. But the calculation that produced this figure is not reliable.

fact_check_explanation_title: Article claiming studies show Covid-19 vaccines increase infection risk is false and misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: Blog reports on three studies to show Covid-19 vaccines don’t work–but the findings don’t support this claim

fact_check_explanation_title: Cholesterol treatments can save lives and don’t cause dementia
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media post lays out a number of common false claims against the scientific consensus on cholesterol. Stents, angioplasty and statins all save lives.

fact_check_explanation_title: Vaccine boosters post wrongly says people not offered Covid-19 vaccine ‘declined’ it
fact_check_explanation_summary: Young children were not offered the vaccine at all, and most people were not offered the autumn booster. There are problems with the total population estimates too.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake social media appeals for a missing boy called James Peltier
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts about this supposedly missing boy have appeared on Facebook groups all over the world, using a picture of a girl who has appeared on many fake appeals before.

fact_check_explanation_title: Dog pictured by rubble was not taken in Turkey earthquake aftermath
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture is being shared in good faith but is a stock photo created years ago.

fact_check_explanation_title: How does the UK’s GDP growth compare to the G7?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We looked into comparisons between the UK and the world’s largest economies after the Conservative party tweeted that it had the highest growth in the G7.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence French president called England ‘oppressive’, ‘murderous’ and ‘cruel’
fact_check_explanation_summary: The quote has previously been shared by a local SNP Facebook group.

fact_check_explanation_title: Egg yolks not shown to fight Covid-19
fact_check_explanation_summary: Social media posts claiming egg yolks could be a key in fighting Covid-19 infections misinterpret the research and falsely link it to egg shortages.

fact_check_explanation_title: Letter telling male Ukrainian refugees in UK to visit embassy is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The letter threatens hosts with a lower financial benefit if they don’t urge refugee residents to visit the Ukrainian embassy.

fact_check_explanation_title: No plans to restrict the use of cars by creating 20-minute neighbourhoods in Ealing
fact_check_explanation_summary: A notice shared on Facebook claims that Ealing council plans to divide the borough into “7 Local Zones”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video does not show last moments of Turkish family during earthquake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The footage, which appears to have been created with special effects, was uploaded to TikTok in 2020.

fact_check_explanation_title: Express overstates impact of UK joining trans-Pacific trade bloc
fact_check_explanation_summary: The paper claimed joining the CPTPP would see over 99% of UK goods exports to members “become” tariff-free—but 85% already are.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video does not show Turkish nuclear plant exploding due to earthquake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The footage shows the Beirut port in August 2020.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tsunami video was filmed in 2018 in Indonesia, not Turkey
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video which has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times on social media shows a Tsunami hitting an island in Indonesia in 2018, not Turkey, as claimed by some.

fact_check_explanation_title: Footage claiming to show recent earthquake in Turkey actually shows 2015 earthquake in Nepal
fact_check_explanation_summary: The clip, which has been viewed more than 77,000 times on Facebook, appears to have been filmed during a major earthquake in Nepal almost eight years ago.

fact_check_explanation_title: Vaccine did not cause young woman to lose both her legs
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claire Bridges’ legs were amputated as a result of complications from a Covid-19 infection and her heart condition. Being vaccinated had nothing to do with it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video claiming to be from this week’s earthquake in Turkey actually from 2020
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video spreading on social media claiming to be from the recent 7.8 magnitude earthquake in Turkey and Syria is actually from three years ago.

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC says story Clive Myrie racially attacked in Ukraine ‘completely false’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A false claim is spreading on social media that the veteran BBC journalist was the victim of a racially motivated assault while reporting in the country.

fact_check_explanation_title: Not true that 85% of over-65s play video games every week
fact_check_explanation_summary: The survey only polled those who were already playing games or interested in doing so.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral video does not show tsunami in Turkey following 2023 earthquake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The footage is from Durban, South Africa, in 2017.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence that Just Stop Oil ‘bankrolls’ the Labour Party
fact_check_explanation_summary: Although a key benefactor of Just Stop Oil has also donated to Labour, this does not mean the campaign group is giving money to the party itself.

fact_check_explanation_title: £7 million daily cost of hotel accommodation includes cost of housing Afghan refugees
fact_check_explanation_summary: Articles in the Daily Express and Daily Mail wrongly claimed that almost £7 million a day is being spent on hotels for people who either arrived in the UK illegally …

fact_check_explanation_title: Daily Mail corrects column on opposition to ULEZ expansion
fact_check_explanation_summary: A column published in the Daily Mail which stated that a public consultation on the planned expansion of London’s ultra low emission zone found 80% opposition has since been corrected.

fact_check_explanation_title: Cannabis has not been shown to definitively cure cancer
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media post repeats the common claim that cannabis cures cancer. There is not enough strong evidence to support this claim.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claims 18 million Americans ‘seriously injured’ by Covid-19 vaccines are misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: Serious adverse reactions to Covid-19 vaccinations are rare.

fact_check_explanation_title: Government fails to back up PM’s claim that A&E patient flow is 'faster than ever'
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister recently claimed the flow of patients through emergency care and the discharge rate were at record highs.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence Diane Abbott said quote about ‘the problem with Britain’
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no record of her having said the problem with Britain is “white people”.

fact_check_explanation_title: UKIP wrong that half of unaccompanied children seeking asylum are found to be adults
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures mentioned by the UKIP deputy leader on GB News likely refer to the proportion of age dispute cases where the applicant is found to be an adult, not the …

fact_check_explanation_title: Police quash Facebook rumours of missing boy named Brayden
fact_check_explanation_summary: Multiple police forces have confirmed there is no one with that name missing in their areas.

fact_check_explanation_title: Installing defibrillators in schools is not proof that Covid-19 vaccines are unsafe
fact_check_explanation_summary: Defibrillators were being installed in schools prior to the pandemic and there is no evidence linking vaccines to cardiac arrest.

fact_check_explanation_title: Police Scotland says it hasn’t renamed paedophiles as ‘minor attracted people’
fact_check_explanation_summary: It clarified its use of the phrase after it appeared in a report produced by the force.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tilted perspective weather maps are no longer used by the BBC
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post which claims TV has “shrunk Scotland and grown England” by changing its weather maps shows an image of graphics which were replaced in 2018.

fact_check_explanation_title: Aspen card does not give asylum seekers £175 a week
fact_check_explanation_summary: Not every asylum seeker is eligible for support payments, and those that are receive much less than has been claimed on Facebook.

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC didn’t ‘censor’ footage of Brexit march
fact_check_explanation_summary: Thousands of people have shared claims that the BBC censored footage of a People’s Vote march.

fact_check_explanation_title: Vaping harms overstated in viral video
fact_check_explanation_summary: A widely shared video on TikTok and Instagram exaggerates and misrepresents the risks of vaping.

fact_check_explanation_title: How wages and pensions in the UK and France compare
fact_check_explanation_summary: A tweet shared more than 5,000 times makes a number of comparisons between France and the UK, many of which need context or are not quite right.

fact_check_explanation_title: Jeff Bezos couldn’t give every Amazon worker £90,000
fact_check_explanation_summary: A bonus suggested by the Labour MP Zarah Sultana would cost more than Mr Bezos’s reported total wealth, let alone any wealth he gained during the pandemic.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Earth’s core has not stopped rotating
fact_check_explanation_summary: A study in Nature Geoscience said that the Earth’s inner core might no longer be spinning faster than the rest of the planet—not that it might have stopped spinning altogether.

fact_check_explanation_title: Lines reportedly seen in the sky around Heathrow are contrails, not chemtrails
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media post has shared a number of images showing vapour lines from aeroplanes in the sky, and claims that these are in fact “chemtrails”. They aren’t—they’re contrails.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Kraken’ Covid-19 subvariant linked to baseless claims about 5G harms
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media post claims that 5G is “harming and killing people”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook offer of free sausage roll and drink at Greggs is not genuine
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post shared hundreds of times on social media is not from the bakery chain.

fact_check_explanation_title: Haringey Council says cost of Black Boy Lane name change ‘highly unlikely to exceed £100,000’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims it has cost £186,000 appear to stem from a 2021 estimate made by the council.

fact_check_explanation_title: Large asteroid is not set to collide with the Earth
fact_check_explanation_summary: NASA says the object is small and will miss the planet by 2,500 miles.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video does not show Rishi Sunak’s staff celebrating Hindu festival in Downing Street
fact_check_explanation_summary: The footage was filmed in Canada, not London, and features officials from Ontario.

fact_check_explanation_title: Posts about a missing man with Alzheimer’s are hoaxes
fact_check_explanation_summary: These posts claim that a man has gone missing in several different UK locations, but use photographs of different men from the US.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim trans activists found Aretha Franklin song offensive based on joke tweet
fact_check_explanation_summary: Despite initially sharing media coverage of its tweet, the account then claimed it was a parody.

fact_check_explanation_title: Argos £3 AirPod Max deal is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claims the deal is related to Argos being fined for not paying tax, which is also not true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photo does not show mine worker with zero body fat
fact_check_explanation_summary: The image shows a professional fitness model with very low body fat.

fact_check_explanation_title: False claim persists that flu vaccine caused strep A in mice
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s based on a misreading of a paper that found a different bacteria in the upper respiratory tract of vaccinated mice.

fact_check_explanation_title: Current flu vaccines don’t use mRNA technology
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on Facebook wrongly suggests that mRNA technology used in two Covid-19 vaccines has also been used in the flu vaccine.

fact_check_explanation_title: Test and Trace spend wouldn’t fund a 15% pay rise for NHS staff until 2058
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral claim on social media wrongly suggests that the amount spent on the NHS Test and Trace scheme would fund a 15% pay rise for all NHS staff until …

fact_check_explanation_title: Insufficient evidence fenbendazole cures cancer says Cancer Research UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: Although studies have been done in cancer cells in the lab, and in mice, there isn’t sufficient evidence that it can cure cancer in humans.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post offering free Toby Carvery meals isn’t genuine
fact_check_explanation_summary: The post claiming to be giving away free meals to those who share and comment on it has been shared thousands of times on Facebook.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many excess deaths are A&E delays causing?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Earlier this month the Royal College of Emergency Medicine estimated delays are causing 300-500 deaths a week - but NHS leaders say they “don’t recognise these numbers”.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much money does Labour receive from the RMT and other trade unions?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Conservatives have tweeted Labour is in the pocket of union ‘paymasters’. A high proportion of Labour’s income comes from trade unions, but only a small amount from the RMT …

fact_check_explanation_title: Flu is not responsible for all ‘flu and pneumonia’ deaths
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Mirror suggested that flu was responsible for about one in 10 deaths at the beginning of this year. But these are deaths from flu or pneumonia—not necessarily both.

fact_check_explanation_title: The WEF hasn’t required unvaccinated pilots for Davos delegates
fact_check_explanation_summary: The false claim that delegates had to be flown to Davos by unvaccinated pilots has been circulating on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: A road sign showing Oxford is being divided into ‘districts’ is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: Oxfordshire County Council has confirmed there are no plans to introduce such road signs in the city, contrary to posts on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: Which regions receive the most levelling up funding?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims about the disproportionate allocation of funding have circulated in the wake of the new levelling up awards.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mice study didn’t show flu vaccine causes strep A
fact_check_explanation_summary: A 2014 study has been repeatedly used to falsely claim that nasal flu vaccines can cause strep A infections.

fact_check_explanation_title: £95k average headteacher salary refers only to state secondary schools
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Daily Express repeated a claim made by education secretary Gillian Keegan last month about headteacher salaries, which failed to clarify the figure referred only to those in secondary schools

fact_check_explanation_title: MP wrong to claim UK offers 52 weeks maternity pay
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s statutory maternity leave that can be a year long, but statutory maternity pay only covers 39 weeks.

fact_check_explanation_title: Brandon Lewis misleading to compare voter ID to picking up parcel or library book
fact_check_explanation_summary: The MP and former cabinet minister said needing ID to vote was the same as needing it to pick up a parcel at the Post Office.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are more dentists now working in the NHS?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at conflicting claims about the state of NHS dentistry made by the Prime Minister and the British Dental Association.

fact_check_explanation_title: Electoral Commission has no evidence of tellers engaging in voter fraud
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claims tellers outside polling stations are collecting information to enable people to commit voter fraud. There’s no evidence this is actually happening.

fact_check_explanation_title: Covid-19 vaccines are not being used to treat strep A or scarlet fever
fact_check_explanation_summary: In a Facebook video, Chris Preddie made a number of inaccurate claims about the Covid-19 vaccines.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post about missing autistic boy and his dog is a hoax
fact_check_explanation_summary: The post includes a picture of a boy who it says is from Derbyshire and called Brayden. In fact the picture shows an American boy called Kai seven years ago.

fact_check_explanation_title: Instagram post misrepresents study linking climate change and diseases
fact_check_explanation_summary: Research linking climate change to strokes, dementia and migraines is not a cover up for Covid-19 vaccine harms, as Instagram user claims.

fact_check_explanation_title: Image of dog ‘hit by truck’ in Worthing was taken in 2018
fact_check_explanation_summary: Image of dog ‘hit by truck’ in Worthing was taken in 2018

fact_check_explanation_title: Buzz Aldrin didn’t ‘admit’ he never went to the Moon
fact_check_explanation_summary: A clip from a 2015 interview has been liked more than 40,000 times on Instagram.

fact_check_explanation_title: Excess deaths would be higher without Covid-19 vaccines
fact_check_explanation_summary: Dr Aseem Malhotra told the BBC that mRNA vaccines were “a likely contributing factor” to excess deaths in the UK. But the vaccines will have limited them, by preventing tens …

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim ‘nine in 10’ teachers voted to strike is misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: Teaching union NASUWT claimed that nine in 10 of its members voted to strike.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake appeal to identify woman in ‘coma’ circulating on Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media post falsely claims an unidentified young woman was “mugged, stabbed and left for dead on the roadside”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Diane Abbott misquotes statement from Michelle Donelan
fact_check_explanation_summary: A tweet from the Labour MP implies the opposite of what the culture secretary actually said.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake post about child ‘missing’ after baseball practice circulating online
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post about an allegedly missing child named Tyler Miller in Lincoln has been shared on social media using a picture of an Australian girl.

fact_check_explanation_title: A 7pm sunset in the UK is more than 39 days away
fact_check_explanation_summary: The sun will set after 7pm when the clocks go forward on 26 March.

fact_check_explanation_title: Public opinion in Scotland does support EU membership
fact_check_explanation_summary: Alister Jack told the House of Commons that there is “no desire in Scotland” for EU membership. Opinion polls suggest otherwise.

fact_check_explanation_title: Andrew Bridgen wrong to call mRNA vaccines gene therapy
fact_check_explanation_summary: Gene therapy has a specific definition which does not include the mRNA vaccines.

fact_check_explanation_title: Nothing has been ‘added’ to the children’s flu vaccine to cause strep A
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claims something’s been added to the nasal flu mist to make children sick. This is false.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Cor ona virus’ doesn’t mean ‘heart attack virus’ in Latin
fact_check_explanation_summary: A screenshot from Google Translate appears to show the translation, but this isn’t the meaning of the words in Latin.

fact_check_explanation_title: The World Economic Forum has not called for paedophilia to be decriminalised
fact_check_explanation_summary: Quotes attributed to the WEF and its co-founder Klaus Schwab circulating on Facebook have been denied by a WEF spokesperson.

fact_check_explanation_title: UN soldiers are not forcing the unvaccinated into camps
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim is being made on Facebook but there is no evidence it is happening.

fact_check_explanation_title: Cat injured in Middlesbrough is really a viral 2018 picture from California
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post falsely claims the cat was hurt and picked up earlier this year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Covid death rates were not a ‘lie’
fact_check_explanation_summary: While different measures of death rates have their own strengths and limitations, they all broadly concur that, in the UK, sadly, around 200,000 people have died of Covid-19.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sodium bicarbonate is not ‘lethal’ to all cancers
fact_check_explanation_summary: because there’s no evidence sodium bicarbonate can be used to cure cancer. Some studies have looked at its use in reducing tumour pH levels, but none have suggested it could …

fact_check_explanation_title: Campervan shared in Facebook post not part of so-called giveaway
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media post offering a camper van to one lucky winner isn’t quite what it seems.

fact_check_explanation_title: Westminster does not control the amount Scotland spends on its NHS
fact_check_explanation_summary: Although Scotland receives funds from the UK Government, it can spend them on any devolved services.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim about vaccine deaths wasn’t ‘discussed in House of Commons’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A claim that daily vaccine deaths were higher than Covid-19 deaths was not discussed in the House of Commons.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mask mandates did not immediately control a Covid-19 wave in 2020
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is evidence that masks work to reduce the spread of Covid-19, but making them compulsory did not reverse a wave in the summer of 2020.

fact_check_explanation_title: French writer Jacques Attali did not advocate for depopulation through a pandemic
fact_check_explanation_summary: Mr Attali has denied the quote, which has been circulating for several years, and it does not appear in one of his books.

fact_check_explanation_title: The World Economic Forum is not cancelling Christmas
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video claims that the WEF has launched an initiative to stop Christmas traditions—but no such initiative exists.

fact_check_explanation_title: Posts celebrating the birthday of a 105-year-old grandmother are fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture in the post is of a younger woman with a different name.

fact_check_explanation_title: Toby Carvery meal giveaway is not official
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook giveaway falsely claims to be affiliated with a restaurant brand.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pelé’s feet will not be displayed in FIFA museum
fact_check_explanation_summary: The organisation denies any plans to do so, with many online users spreading the claim without an official source.

fact_check_explanation_title: Keir Starmer’s New Year speech fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve taken a look at some of the Labour leader’s claims in his first speech of 2023 covering burglaries, regional inequality and funding for more NHS training.

fact_check_explanation_title: Rishi Sunak’s New Year speech fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve looked at some of the claims made by the PM in his first speech of 2023.

fact_check_explanation_title: Strep A deaths are not dangerous new strain caused by flu vaccines
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post makes false claims about strep A cases in the UK—the infection is not linked to the nasal flu vaccine, and current fatality rates are not unusual.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake posts about a missing elderly neighbour are circulating on Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: The posts, which are nearly identically worded, feature an image of a man taken in the United States in 2016.

fact_check_explanation_title: Nasal flu vaccines don’t contain ‘mice bred streptococcal bacteria’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claims that the nasal flu vaccine contains strep bacteria and aluminium, that Covid-19 tests cause cancer and masks cause deoxygenation. None of these are true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Misleading post suggests vaccinating babies involves injecting them with ‘neurotoxins’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Childhood vaccines do not contain dangerous levels of harmful substances.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence ‘trails’ are deliberately put into the sky by planes
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on Instagram claims to show trails from planes turning the sky cloudy.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the NHS Pay Review Body ‘independent’?
fact_check_explanation_summary: With many NHS workers on strike, some unions have challenged the independence of its pay review body. We take a look at the facts behind some of the main claims.

fact_check_explanation_title: Near-identical posts about a missing child called Tyler are fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: Several of the posts feature almost identical text, with the name of the child and the accompanying image changed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Study didn’t link children’s flu vaccine to strep A infections
fact_check_explanation_summary: A 2014 study has been widely shared as alleged proof nasal flu vaccines are linked to strep A infections.

fact_check_explanation_title: Police warn against interacting with posts about missing Surrey boy
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media post about a supposedly missing child has been shared hundreds of times.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake lost dog post uses old stock image
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture was originally taken in the Philippines in 2016.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tampering with electricity meters to try and save on energy bills is illegal and dangerous
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post has suggested it’s possible to save on electricity bills by bypassing your meter with a piece of wire. This is illegal and can also be dangerous.

fact_check_explanation_title: Oxford traffic scheme won’t ‘confine’ residents to specific neighbourhoods
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some have claimed on social media that a controversial plan to reduce congestion in Oxford constitutes a “climate lockdown”.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Facts’ in a graphic about UK Muslims are mostly wrong
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Facebook post makes a number of false claims about Muslim mayors, mosque numbers, Sharia councils and other information about Muslims in Britain.

fact_check_explanation_title: Appeals about injured and lost dogs are fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: Facebook posts from users claiming to have found a missing or injured dog are fake.

fact_check_explanation_title: Instagram post wrongly links nasal flu vaccines to strep A outbreak
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no evidence that nasal flu vaccines are driving increased rates of strep A, and the timing of the outbreak doesn’t mean this is the case.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video does not show ‘immigrants’ catching seagulls to ‘feast’ on
fact_check_explanation_summary: It actually shows volunteers ‘ringing’ a bird for research purposes.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hoax posts about missing grandfather circulating on local Facebook groups
fact_check_explanation_summary: The posts, which claim to be from someone looking for their missing grandfather, feature an image of a man who passed away earlier this year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake KFC deal shared by thousands on Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post claiming social media users can get a voucher “for nothing” has been shared widely.

fact_check_explanation_title: The lowest paid nurses aren’t getting a 9% pay increase
fact_check_explanation_summary: Oliver Dowden MP said multiple times that the lowest paid nurses were given a 9% increase. A newly qualified nurse in England has seen their pay increase by around 5.5% …

fact_check_explanation_title: Health minister’s claims on nurse pay fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: Maria Caulfield MP made a number of claims about how much nurse pay increases would cost during multiple media appearances.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook posts claiming to be searching for birth parents are fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: Full Fact has spotted a number of similar posts using the same black and white image of a child, claiming to be searching for a woman called Cathy M Evans.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla hasn’t resigned
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that the Pfizer CEO resigned after admitting mRNA vaccines were not safe are inaccurate.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook promotions offering free Center Parcs holidays for sharing posts are false
fact_check_explanation_summary: The promotions are not linked to Center Parcs.

fact_check_explanation_title: Andrew Bridgen's vaccine debate claims fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Conservative MP made a number of claims about vaccine safety and effectiveness—we’ve fact checked four of them.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post makes harmful claims about treating scarlet fever without antibiotics
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media post claims that symptoms of strep A infections can be treated with homeopathic remedies alone.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post about dog found ‘freezing’ in Falkirk is a hoax
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture accompanying the post was taken from an article about a dog attack in Northern Ireland.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post claiming lemons treat cancer better than chemotherapy is false
fact_check_explanation_summary: A social media post that has circulated many times in recent years states that lemons are proven to treat and prevent cancer—but this is not true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Unemployment in the UK is currently low by historic standards
fact_check_explanation_summary: The shadow chancellor Rachel Reeves claimed that Britain has “high unemployment” after 12 years of Conservative government. But by historic standards, the unemployment rate is currently very low.

fact_check_explanation_title: You can still pay for Amazon Prime on a monthly basis
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve looked into claims that Amazon is moving Prime members in the UK to annual subscriptions.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour’s analysis on five million ‘denied’ GP appointments fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: This widely reported figure is an estimate, based on several assumptions that may not be right.

fact_check_explanation_title: Post seeking help to identify unconscious man in hospital is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: Several posts using different pictures are in circulation but their identities are all known.

fact_check_explanation_title: Survey didn't find one in ten young people plan ‘never’ to work
fact_check_explanation_summary: The figure used by Rod Liddle in a Sun column only describes the percentage of those who are already not working. The true proportion is more like one in 25.

fact_check_explanation_title: Government’s £28 billion public sector pay increase figure doesn’t factor in money returned in tax
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government says it would cost £28 billion, or £1,000 per household, to increase public sector pay in line with inflation next year. But many of the current disputes are …

fact_check_explanation_title: Aldi is not giving away free boxes of food to users who like Facebook posts
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook account claiming to belong to the supermarket chain Aldi has shared posts promising free food packages for users who share or comment on the post.

fact_check_explanation_title: 8% pay offer for rail workers covers a longer period than the deal offered to nurses
fact_check_explanation_summary: The 8% offer made to rail workers covers a two-year period, whereas the pay increase given to nurses and other NHS staff covers only 12 months.

fact_check_explanation_title: Samaritans no longer operates a text-based support service
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts on social media claiming you can text Samaritans for support are using out of date information.

fact_check_explanation_title: Andrew Bridgen wrong to say Covid-19 mRNA vaccines aren’t recommended while pregnant or breastfeeding
fact_check_explanation_summary: Conservative MP Andrew Bridgen made a series of claims about the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines, which use mRNA technology, during Prime Minister’s Questions.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook posts wrongly link nasal flu vaccines to increase in strep A infections
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no evidence that nasal flu vaccinations are driving increased cases of strep A infections, despite widespread claims on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video of football fans singing for Palestine is not from World Cup
fact_check_explanation_summary: The footage was shot in Morocco and dates back to 2019.

fact_check_explanation_title: Post about child cyclist injured in ‘hit and run’ is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The two photographs in the post were taken many years apart in Australia.

fact_check_explanation_title: Nadhim Zahawi includes extra earnings in figure for nurse ‘starting salary’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Nadhim Zahawi claimed that the starting salary of a newly qualified nurse increased to £31,000 following the recent £1,400 pay award.

fact_check_explanation_title: European countries’ Test and Trace programmes cost much more than €100,000
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Covid-19 tracking apps of countries like Germany and the Netherlands alone cost millions of euros.

fact_check_explanation_title: Disney Christmas show accused of pushing ‘satanic agenda’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Thousands of people have shared claims that a moment from a new Disney+ miniseries reveals a ‘satanic agenda’.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence radiation from AirPods is causing brain tumours
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some scientists have expressed concern over the potential health effects of low-level radiation from mobile devices, but there’s no evidence wireless headphones like AirPods are causing brain tumours.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence midazolam used to kill thousands of patients in April 2020
fact_check_explanation_summary: It is not surprising that prescriptions of a palliative care drug used to make dying people more comfortable increased during one of the worst months of the pandemic.

fact_check_explanation_title: London and Manchester are not ‘minority white’ cities
fact_check_explanation_summary: A tweet from Nigel Farage making the claim has been shared thousands of times.

fact_check_explanation_title: PCR tests aren’t being used to clone humans
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no evidence that Covid-19 PCR tests are being used to clone humans. A paper cited to support this theory explores the use of the PCR technique in gene cloning, …

fact_check_explanation_title: Big spending list on Test and Trace and furlough loss needs context
fact_check_explanation_summary: £37 billion was the budget for the first two years, but less was actually spent and the furlough fraud figure is out of date and includes losses from other Covid-19 …

fact_check_explanation_title: M&S is not giving away ‘golden envelopes’ with £750 vouchers on Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post falsely claims to show a senior member of staff at Marks & Spencer holding golden tickets to win.

fact_check_explanation_title: Long Covid is not really just Covid-19 vaccination side effects
fact_check_explanation_summary: Many sufferers are unvaccinated and evidence suggests vaccination reduces the risk.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Wanted’ poster missing context on Test and Trace spending
fact_check_explanation_summary: £37 billion was the budget for Test and Trace, not the spend.

fact_check_explanation_title: Post claiming a lost puppy has been found is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The image dates back five years and shows the home of the actual owner.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake Argos offer still circulating online
fact_check_explanation_summary: An alleged deal promising an airfryer for just £2 is too good to be true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Steve Barclay’s figure for new nurses’ pay includes extra earnings
fact_check_explanation_summary: The health secretary said that a new nurse will typically earn over £31,000 a year on current pay. This is an estimate that includes extra earnings such as overtime. Basic …

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Free’ Greggs giveaway is not genuine
fact_check_explanation_summary: The company is not offering a free sausage roll and hot drink to anyone who likes a Facebook post.

fact_check_explanation_title: Covid-19 variants including Delta are real
fact_check_explanation_summary: The post claims that the Delta variant is fake.

fact_check_explanation_title: Copycat posts about ‘missing’ boy shared widely on Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: Hundreds of people have shared a fake appeal for information about an apparently missing boy.

fact_check_explanation_title: Liz Kendall’s claim that there were no NHS strikes under Labour ignores local walkouts
fact_check_explanation_summary: Staff at NHS hospitals did take part in local strikes when Labour was last in power.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much of the rise in ‘economic inactivity’ is due to long Covid?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A BBC news bulletin claimed a recent rise in the number of people who are neither working nor looking for work is “largely because of long Covid”. But there are …

fact_check_explanation_title: Boy claimed ‘missing’ on Facebook was found months ago
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture is of a boy of a different name who went missing in June but has been found.

fact_check_explanation_title: Amazon is not selling Kindle Oasis e-readers for £1.78 for Black Friday
fact_check_explanation_summary: Amazon is holding a Black Friday sale, but it has confirmed it is not offering Kindle Oasis e-readers for £1.78, as a number of Facebook posts have claimed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake Argos ‘deals’ on electric scooters and air fryers circulating online
fact_check_explanation_summary: Deals that appear too good to be true are circulating on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can you tell a drink has been spiked by its appearance?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A poster shares ways to tell if a drink has been tampered with. But spiked drinks do not necessarily exhibit any changes in appearance, taste or smell.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post misinterprets BBC report on a ‘spike’ in neonatal deaths
fact_check_explanation_summary: The BBC article said that “two spikes” in the neonatal death rate had occurred in Scotland—not that spike proteins had been found in babies’ bodies.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook posts claiming man with dementia is missing with his dog are false
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture in the posts shows a man with a different name who has never gone missing.

fact_check_explanation_title: No published data to support minister’s claim about migrants saying they’re under 18
fact_check_explanation_summary: Robert Jenrick’s claim that up to 20% of adult men arriving at an asylum processing centre say they’re under 18 has prompted new questions about the Home Office’s use of …

fact_check_explanation_title: Covid-19 is not ‘a lie’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on Instagram claims that Covid-19 is a ‘lie’. This is false, and there is ample evidence to prove it is a real, deadly disease.

fact_check_explanation_title: Wetherspoons still not offering free ‘meal for two’ Facebook deal
fact_check_explanation_summary: Another post from an account calling itself ‘JD Wetherspoon’ promising free meal offers has received thousands of shares on Facebook.

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC graph showing impact of Autumn Statement contains several errors
fact_check_explanation_summary: A graph shown on the BBC News at Six contained, among other things, an inaccurate figure and a mislabelled axis.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour MP wrongly claims £37bn spent on Test and Trace app
fact_check_explanation_summary: Karl Turner claimed that Matt Hancock and Boris Johnson “blew” £37 billion on the Track and Trace app. The app’s actual cost in the first year was about £35 million.

fact_check_explanation_title: Iran hasn’t sentenced 15,000 protesters to death
fact_check_explanation_summary: Iranian parliamentarians have called for “harsh punishments” which could include the death penalty, but we can find no evidence for viral claims that 15,000 people have already been sentenced to …

fact_check_explanation_title: Warning over alleged Christmas postal ‘scam’ is long out of date
fact_check_explanation_summary: The premium-rate number a Facebook post warns about was shut down in 2005.

fact_check_explanation_title: British Heart Foundation comments on 30,000 excess deaths lack important context
fact_check_explanation_summary: Not all of the 30,000 excess deaths involving heart disease in England since the pandemic started were necessarily caused by healthcare disruption. Many may have been caused by Covid-19.

fact_check_explanation_title: MailOnline muddles up cost of a possible rise in council tax
fact_check_explanation_summary: If council tax rises by 5%, it would cost households in an average band D property about £100 more per year—not per month.

fact_check_explanation_title: Some staff at NHS hospitals did take part in local strikes when Labour was last in power
fact_check_explanation_summary: The shadow health secretary claimed there were no strikes in the NHS during Labour’s last spell in government, but we’ve found some examples of local strikes taking place.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake alerts for missing pensioners are circulating online
fact_check_explanation_summary: The names, pictures and locations of those being sought are false.

fact_check_explanation_title: Wetherspoons ‘meal for two’ deal is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: Thousands of people have shared a Facebook post which claims that Wetherspoons boss Tim Martin is retiring.

fact_check_explanation_title: MPs' vaccine debate fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: MPs Danny Kruger, Sir Christopher Chope and Andrew Bridgen all made claims about vaccines that need context.

fact_check_explanation_title: Bill Gates’s daughter Phoebe Gates did have childhood vaccinations
fact_check_explanation_summary: Several sources of evidence suggest that she has also had the Covid-19 vaccine.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK nurses don’t usually take a pledge which might prevent them from going on strike
fact_check_explanation_summary: While the Florence Nightingale Pledge does exist, it is not usually taken by nurses in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Nadhim Zahawi didn’t mistakenly pay tribute to a living Birds of a Feather actress
fact_check_explanation_summary: An apparently fake screenshot of a tweet purportedly by Nadhim Zahawi has been shared hundreds of times on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: Discount e-scooter promotion is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: No such offer has been announced by the retailer.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘New’ UK trade deals don’t account for ‘over £800 billion worth of new global trade’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Michael Gove tweeted a graphic claiming the UK has signed new trade deals with more than 70 countries, worth over £800 billion in new global trade. But the majority of …

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence for Irish passport numbers among MPs and peers
fact_check_explanation_summary: Widely shared figures about the number of UK parliamentarians with Irish passports appear to have no source.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claims that bogus census takers are robbing houses in the UK are false
fact_check_explanation_summary: Similar posts have been appearing around the world for at least six years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Post about missing uncle in Sunderland is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The man in the picture is from California and died earlier this year.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence for Rishi Sunak’s claim about ‘record’ number of new homes built
fact_check_explanation_summary: At last week’s PMQs, the new Prime Minister claimed a record number of new homes were built in the last year—but we’ve not found any evidence to support this.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK has not suspended aid to Ukraine
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government has pledged to continue its support.

fact_check_explanation_title: Penny Mordaunt was given special permission to wear submariners badge in 2019
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claims Penny Mordaunt MP shouldn’t have worn a badge awarded to submariners. In fact, she was invited to wear the badge by the Royal Navy.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK Government doesn’t retain £50bn of Scottish taxes
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts on social media overcount and double count Scottish revenues while undercounting Scottish expenditure.

fact_check_explanation_title: News articles didn’t claim the same boy died of Covid-19 in three different countries
fact_check_explanation_summary: A widely shared tweet claims that the same child was reported to have died of Covid-19 in three different countries. This isn’t true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claims about 47,000 homeless veterans need context
fact_check_explanation_summary: The figure is the estimated number of homeless veterans in 2015 in the United States. We don’t know how many homeless veterans there are in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence that Rishi Sunak said homeless veterans could ‘easily manage’ winter
fact_check_explanation_summary: We can find no record of any such comments by him in Parliament, or elsewhere.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post linking Covid-19 vaccines with report about cancer in the under-50s is misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no evidence that the Covid-19 vaccines are causing cancer.

fact_check_explanation_title: Contrails can last for hours
fact_check_explanation_summary: A false claim that contrails, the lines of frozen water vapour which form behind planes, disappear quickly is being used to suggest that chemtrails exist.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are crime rates at a record high?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Although the number of crimes recorded by police is on the rise, the overall crime rate as measured by the crime survey is falling.

fact_check_explanation_title: Asylum seekers in hotels will not receive £57 per week
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post refers to reports that a hotel in Ipswich is set to be used to house asylum seekers, and claims that they would be paid £57 per week.

fact_check_explanation_title: President Zelenskyy magazine cover circulating on social media is a fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: An image of a magazine cover showing Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy drawing in money and weapons is circulating on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: The World Economic Forum didn’t say it’s engineering the climate
fact_check_explanation_summary: An out-of-context screenshot of an article from 2018 has led to misleading claims being shared online.

fact_check_explanation_title: Uber ‘walking buddy’ service is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The joke first appeared online in 2020.

fact_check_explanation_title: How the media misreported the '£2,500 energy bill cap'
fact_check_explanation_summary: Our analysis using Full Fact’s AI media-monitoring software has found more than 100 potentially misleading claims about the government’s Energy Price Guarantee—which is a cap on prices, not bills.

fact_check_explanation_title: Articles claiming Amazon is encouraging users to sign up to cryptocurrency platform are fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: because Amazon has not launched a cryptocurrency trading platform under either of these names.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post about injured dog in Tyneside uses old picture from Australia
fact_check_explanation_summary: Multiple posts claim the dog was found in different UK locations.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claims that Pfizer vaccine wasn’t tested on preventing transmission need context
fact_check_explanation_summary: Post-trial studies showed the Covid-19 vaccine offered some protection against transmission of early variants.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral picture is not of cameras that can detect drivers on mobile phones
fact_check_explanation_summary: National Highways confirmed that the cameras pictured were to monitor all lane running smart motorways.

fact_check_explanation_title: How might the Retained EU Law Bill affect our right to watch the Olympics for free?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In PMQs, Labour MP Stella Creasy claimed the Retained EU Law Bill would ‘abolish’ the right to watch the Olympics for free. The government told Full Fact that this wouldn’t …

fact_check_explanation_title: Deaths due to SADS aren’t covering up ‘genocide’ caused by Covid-19 vaccines
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no evidence that Covid-19 vaccines are causing people to die of SADS, or that deaths due to the Covid-19 vaccine are being misreported as SADS as part of …

fact_check_explanation_title: The facts around former PMs’ £115,000 annual ‘allowance’
fact_check_explanation_summary: They are allowed to claim back up to £115,000 each year for the costs associated with continuing public duties—but it’s not a “salary”.

fact_check_explanation_title: A letter from the Prime Minister wasn’t mistakenly signed by Kwasi Kwarteng
fact_check_explanation_summary: Liz Truss’s letter to the former chancellor followed the convention of similar letters sent by her predecessor Boris Johnson.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Injured’ man in fake post is popular YouTuber
fact_check_explanation_summary: The image is three years old and relates to a medical emergency, not a car accident.

fact_check_explanation_title: Private Eye did not say Kwasi Kwarteng was paid £20,000 a month by a hedge fund
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims circulating on social media don’t reflect what was reported by the magazine, or what’s recorded in the Register of Members’ Financial Interests.

fact_check_explanation_title: Old picture of Jacob Rees-Mogg in 2018 scuffle going viral
fact_check_explanation_summary: A photo taken in 2018 is being mistakenly shared as being from recent events in Parliament.

fact_check_explanation_title: Halloween Cadbury chocolate hamper offer is not genuine
fact_check_explanation_summary: An alleged offer posted on Facebook has no connection with Cadbury despite claiming to.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video doesn’t show American B-2 stealth bomber deployed to Poland
fact_check_explanation_summary: Footage purporting to show the aircraft landing was shot in England in 2020.

fact_check_explanation_title: President Zelenskyy’s office was not blown up in recent Kyiv strikes
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims online that the Ukrainian presidential office was bombed around 10 October 2022 are unevidenced.

fact_check_explanation_title: The mRNA vaccines don’t show Covid-19 ‘doesn’t exist’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post has wrongly claimed Pfizer and Moderna vaccines do not contain a live virus because SARS-CoV-2 doesn’t exist.

fact_check_explanation_title: Bank of England did not sell £80 billion in gilts shortly before mini-Budget
fact_check_explanation_summary: Sir Iain Duncan Smith claimed the Bank of England sold ‘some £80 billion in gilts’ around the time of the mini-budget announcement on 23 September. This didn’t happen.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is government plan to cap revenues of renewable electricity generators a windfall tax?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Jacob Rees-Mogg strenuously denied that the new government policy proposal is a windfall tax during an appearance on the Today programme.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sunday Express misinterprets suicide data
fact_check_explanation_summary: We do not yet know whether suicides in young people rose in 2021. Suicide registrations did rise, but this may have been caused by delays earlier in the pandemic.

fact_check_explanation_title: Senior SNP politicians mislead on renewable energy generation
fact_check_explanation_summary: Scotland produces about as much renewable electricity as the total amount of electricity it consumes—but it also generates electricity from nuclear power stations and fossil fuels.

fact_check_explanation_title: Volodymyr Zelenskyy does not translate to ‘evil rules the world’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Social media posts selectively group letters from the name to achieve this result.

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS pay award will increase pay for nurses by 72p per hour
fact_check_explanation_summary: At Prime Minister’s Questions Labour MP Ian Lavery said nurses had been given a '72p a week pay rise'. The pay award offered to most NHS staff actually amounts to …

fact_check_explanation_title: Evidence for claim that 60% of small boat arrivals are Albanian not yet published
fact_check_explanation_summary: The figure has been used by Priti Patel in Parliament and a number of times in the media, but it isn’t yet supported by published government statistics.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim that Scotland receives no money from England is missing context
fact_check_explanation_summary: The level of public spending is higher than its level of contribution to the UK economy.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour claims about a £500 rise in mortgage payments lack important context
fact_check_explanation_summary: Sir Keir Starmer said mortgages are going up as “a direct consequence” of the mini-Budget. But much of the rise estimated by Labour is due to rates climbing earlier.

fact_check_explanation_title: Nadhim Zahawi wrong to say Moderna booster protects against both Covid-19 and flu
fact_check_explanation_summary: The former minister for Covid vaccine deployment claimed that the Moderna booster protected against Covid-19 and flu.

fact_check_explanation_title: Image shared on social media doesn’t show BBC journalist pretending to be on the frontline of war in Ukraine
fact_check_explanation_summary: A single screenshot of a news report from March has led to claims that the BBC exaggerated the situation in Ukraine.

fact_check_explanation_title: Protestors did not close Bristol vaccination clinic ‘for the foreseeable future’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A group of protesters made a video claiming they ‘closed’ the centre. It reopened three days later.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence small boat arrivals beat NHS waiting lists
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claims people arriving in small boats can beat the NHS waiting lists.

fact_check_explanation_title: Liz Truss’s 2022 Conservative party conference speech: fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We check five key claims from Ms Truss’s speech, including on tax, GP access and whether she was the first PM to attend a comprehensive school.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Bank of England hasn’t already spent £65 billion following mini-Budget
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that the government had spent £65 billion have been shared extremely widely on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: Kwasi Kwarteng wrong on ‘record unemployment’ under Labour
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Chancellor was wrong to say that Labour left office with record unemployment. During this period unemployment peaked below the record level, set in 1984.

fact_check_explanation_title: Article on impact of voice assistants on children is not ‘new research’
fact_check_explanation_summary: An article which suggests voice assistants may hinder children's cognitive and social development is not based on original research, and has been criticised by experts.

fact_check_explanation_title: Queen’s funeral was not cover-up for planning global recession
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no evidence to support a video claiming that the Queen did not die on 8 September, and that her funeral was a cover-up for world leaders to gather to …

fact_check_explanation_title: Do Treasury claims about a 'typical' first-time buyer’s savings add up?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve looked into the figures behind a tweet from the Treasury showing how the mini-Budget could benefit a hypothetical first-time buyer.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do the mini-Budget tax cuts favour the rich?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Income tax-payers across the income scale will benefit to some extent as a result of the Chancellor’s announcement—but higher earners will benefit much more.

fact_check_explanation_title: Bayer executive wrongly said mRNA vaccines are gene therapy
fact_check_explanation_summary: A spokesperson for Bayer said Stefan Oelrich’s comments were an ‘obvious slip of the tongue’.

fact_check_explanation_title: Article saying gardening is a sign of ‘far-right extremism’ does not exist
fact_check_explanation_summary: A digitally manipulated screenshot of a Canadian news site has been shared widely online.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many Russian soldiers have died in Ukraine?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Estimates vary from as few as 6,000 to as many as 55,000.

fact_check_explanation_title: Liz Truss wrong to repeatedly say energy bills are capped at £2,500
fact_check_explanation_summary: This figure is based on the amount a “typical” household with average use will pay—but total bills aren’t capped.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video of Italian protesters removing European flag from building is from 2013
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s been claimed that the video was filmed during the recent general election in Italy.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claims about vaccine adverse events based on article since-deleted over inaccuracies
fact_check_explanation_summary: An Express headline is being shared to claim the truth about the Covid-19 vaccine is “starting to unravel”. The article in question was deleted after the Express acknowledged it was …

fact_check_explanation_title: Keir Starmer’s 2022 Labour party conference speech: fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at the Labour leader’s claims on tax cuts, burglaries and offshore wind, and whether Labour policies are fully costed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Andy Burnham did not say he was a ‘better politician’ than Keir Starmer
fact_check_explanation_summary: A headline, now changed, of an article published by The Sun misleadingly claimed Greater Manchester mayor Andy Burnham said he was a “better politician” than Keir Starmer.

fact_check_explanation_title: The deficit is lower than it was 12 years ago
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour shadow chancellor Rachel Reeves said in a speech that the Conservative government had not got the deficit down during 12 years in power. This isn’t true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Liz Truss wrong to claim ‘no household’ will pay more than £2,500 on energy bills
fact_check_explanation_summary: During an interview on CNN the Prime Minister claimed ‘nobody’ would have to pay more than £2,500 in energy bills. Per the government’s own figures, this isn’t true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Flu vaccines may contain harmless levels of formaldehyde
fact_check_explanation_summary: Formaldehyde is naturally present in our bodies, and there isn’t enough in vaccines to harm us.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ed Davey left out important context about energy bills
fact_check_explanation_summary: Yes, annual household bills will rise about £500 in October, but people will also receive a £400 discount under the Energy Bills Support Scheme.

fact_check_explanation_title: Will 16 million patients be left without a GP by 2030?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures projecting a shortfall of 8,800 GPs by 2030 don’t necessarily suggest that one in four people will be without a GP by the end of the decade.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claims exaggerate the number of Covid-19 deaths in 2022
fact_check_explanation_summary: Far fewer people are dying of Covid-19 in 2022 compared with 2021 and 2020—although some sources of data make the numbers look higher.

fact_check_explanation_title: Poll didn’t find 20% of Britons are resorting to ‘DIY dentistry’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Headlines in the Telegraph and MailOnline claimed that a fifth of people had been forced to attempt their own dental treatment.

fact_check_explanation_title: Two week waiting time for GP appointments not official requirement
fact_check_explanation_summary: Health Secretary Thérèse Coffey has described calls for a two week waiting time for GP appointments in England as an “expectation” rather than a requirement.

fact_check_explanation_title: Health secretary’s claim on health spending fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: Dr Thérèse Coffey said health and social care account for 40% of government day-to-day spending. That’s only true if you don’t count spending on things like pensions.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photo of Meghan Markle in outfit similar to Princess Diana’s was not taken at Queen’s funeral
fact_check_explanation_summary: The photo of the Duchess of Sussex was actually taken in 2019.

fact_check_explanation_title: Picture of Queen in Spitfire is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The image of her in a Spitfire’s cockpit has been edited.

fact_check_explanation_title: Picture doesn’t show Boris Johnson queueing for the Queen’s lying-in-state
fact_check_explanation_summary: The photograph seems to originate on Twitter. The person who first shared it has confirmed that it does not show Boris Johnson.

fact_check_explanation_title: Image of Nintendo console displaying mourning message was created as a joke
fact_check_explanation_summary: The widely shared image suggests UK consoles will not function until after the Queen’s funeral.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did several billion people watch the Queen’s funeral?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Various claims about worldwide TV viewing figures have been reported, but they don’t appear to have been clearly evidenced.

fact_check_explanation_title: World Economic Forum has not said private vehicle ownership should be restricted to ‘elites’
fact_check_explanation_summary: The WEF has proposed shared car ownership as a way to reduce material usage. But not for private vehicle ownership to be ended or restricted.

fact_check_explanation_title: Asylum seekers do not get £175 per week on a prepaid card
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s closer to £175 per person per month.

fact_check_explanation_title: Controversial colonial carriage belongs to Dutch not British royal family
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some online have claimed the 1898 ‘golden coach’ belonged to Queen Elizabeth II.

fact_check_explanation_title: Supposed ‘chemtrails’ in the sky are just clouds left by planes
fact_check_explanation_summary: An image on Facebook shows two contrails.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK children under 12 aren’t ‘banned’ from having the Covid-19 vaccine
fact_check_explanation_summary: Children who turned five before September 2022 are still eligible, as are some others.

fact_check_explanation_title: No truth to claims no plane parts were found at 9/11 crash sites
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claims that “zero plane parts” were found at the 9/11 crash sites. This isn’t true.

fact_check_explanation_title: The World Economic Forum didn’t say it’s racist to not want to eat bugs
fact_check_explanation_summary: A digitally-manipulated tweet claiming to be from the WEF has been shared on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: Scrabble picture is wrong to say Covid-19 doesn’t exist
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is plenty of evidence the disease and the virus that causes it are real.

fact_check_explanation_title: False Facebook post claims baby abandoned in Bristol
fact_check_explanation_summary: The image with the post shows a baby in Thailand two years ago, and police say they are not aware of a baby abandoned in Hengrove.

fact_check_explanation_title: Irish dancers video outside Buckingham Palace filmed months before Queen’s death
fact_check_explanation_summary: The clip, which was first shared on TikTok in January 2022, went viral following the announcement of the death of the Queen.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much will the Queen’s funeral cost?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no official estimate for how much the state will pay for the funeral, or its wider economic impact. Royal funerals in the past have cost up to about …

fact_check_explanation_title: The Royal Family doesn’t have £73 billion to ‘share’ around the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that the British monarchy is worth £73 billion are not an accurate reflection of the wealth of the Royal Family.

fact_check_explanation_title: The government hasn’t proposed banning unions
fact_check_explanation_summary: Digitally manipulated images designed to look like the government website have been shared hundreds of times online.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Atlantic did not publish an article titled ‘The Soft Bigotry of Bush did 9/11’
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture showing this has been edited.

fact_check_explanation_title: Real terms business investment has not fallen by 20% since Brexit
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that business investment has fallen by 20% since Brexit refer to the difference between current business investment and projections based on pre-referendum trends.

fact_check_explanation_title: Other funerals have not been banned on day of the Queen’s funeral
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government has not issued specific advice on funerals scheduled for the day of the Queen’s funeral. Funeral service providers say some services have been cancelled at the request of …

fact_check_explanation_title: Wetherspoons has not stopped selling condoms for a ‘royal period of mourning’
fact_check_explanation_summary: The pub chain confirmed that a sign suggesting its vending machines were closed is fake, and said it doesn’t have condom vending machines anyway.

fact_check_explanation_title: Russell Brand admits falsely claiming that ivermectin is a Covid-19 treatment
fact_check_explanation_summary: A page of the National Institutes of Health website says that ivermectin is not recommended, and does not work, as a treatment for Covid-19.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral video does not show the Queen throwing food at 'African' children
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video circulating on social media shows French women throwing coins at a group of children, and was filmed long before the Queen was born.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are England’s cities ‘majority non-white’?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Most of England’s cities are not “majority non-white” as an Instagram post has claimed. The latest data we have shows that none are.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim that 44% of Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine trial pregnancies ended in miscarriage is wrong
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number is based on miscalculation from a now-deleted blog post.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson’s final speech as PM: fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve checked six key claims from Boris Johnson’s final speech as Prime Minister, on the vaccine rollout, NHS, schools and more.

fact_check_explanation_title: The government hasn’t ‘removed’ Covid-19 vaccine advice in pregnancy
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims seem to be based on a document published around the time the Pfizer vaccine was first approved.

fact_check_explanation_title: Telegraph miscalculates the cost of working from home
fact_check_explanation_summary: Its estimate that on average working from home will add £2,500 a year to energy bills was flawed, and there are other questions around its calculations too.

fact_check_explanation_title: Report of abandoned newborn babies around the country are false
fact_check_explanation_summary: Images of a newborn baby supposedly abandoned in several English towns and cities were actually taken in Thailand in 2017.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson’s kettle comments taken out of context
fact_check_explanation_summary: An out-of-context clip of the Prime Minister talking about savings from buying a new kettle appears to have been an attempt at an analogy about nuclear power.

fact_check_explanation_title: Innovative bus driver strike in Japan is not ‘currently’ happening
fact_check_explanation_summary: Industrial action by drivers in Okayama ended in May 2018.

fact_check_explanation_title: No proof drinking tea cuts risk of early death
fact_check_explanation_summary: A headline published in the Daily Mail incorrectly claims a study showed tea cuts the risk of an early death.

fact_check_explanation_title: No plans for Starbucks to go cashless across the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that the coffee chain is due to go cashless in October have been shared thousands of times.

fact_check_explanation_title: This ‘injured dog’ has not been found in your area
fact_check_explanation_summary: Multiple posts with the same text using a picture of a dog from a 2021 news article are being shared on Facebook.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pregnant and breastfeeding women are still advised to get the Covid-19 vaccine
fact_check_explanation_summary: The advice has not been “quietly changed” as some online have claimed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video does not show an aircraft spraying ‘massive’ chemtrails behind it
fact_check_explanation_summary: Specific lighting and atmospheric conditions make the vapour cloud look especially dense.

fact_check_explanation_title: Nadine Dorries didn’t say people should use cats and dogs to keep warm this winter
fact_check_explanation_summary: Another fake tweet from the Culture Secretary has been shared thousands of times on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence the media is covering up vaccine deaths with stories about heart issues
fact_check_explanation_summary: Newspapers have been writing about what household items and activities might cause heart attacks since before the pandemic.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does Scotland have an ‘order’ to chop down 17 million trees?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This seems to step from a story that 14m trees had been cut down over 20 years to make way for wind farms.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence rise in deaths due to unknown causes in Canada is linked to Covid-19 vaccines
fact_check_explanation_summary: A rise in deaths recorded as due to “other ill-defined and unknown causes” in Alberta, Canada has been linked to the Covid-19 vaccines without evidence.

fact_check_explanation_title: Energy companies aren’t getting 91p for every £1 they invest in green energy
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on social media appears to misunderstand a recent change in UK law.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour’s £29 billion plan would not fully cover the cost of freezing the energy price cap
fact_check_explanation_summary: Freezing the price cap would require roughly £8 billion more funding, according to the IFS.

fact_check_explanation_title: Contrails are not evidence of plan to block out the sun
fact_check_explanation_summary: A YouTube video suggests that vapour trails in the sky are evidence of “global elites” attempting to “block out the sun”. They are actually contrails caused by frozen water vapour.

fact_check_explanation_title: Monkeypox simulation event doesn’t mean outbreak was planned
fact_check_explanation_summary: The virus was used in a fictional scenario during a theoretical planning event in March 2021.

fact_check_explanation_title: Out-of-date map showing high GB electricity prices compared to Europe re-emerges
fact_check_explanation_summary: A screenshot circulating on social media shows electricity prices in September 2021, and doesn’t reflect current prices.

fact_check_explanation_title: Image does not show parents of ‘trans baby’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A picture of a trans couple who paused their own transitions to have a baby is being falsely labelled.

fact_check_explanation_title: Snoring doesn’t mean you’re eligible for £156 benefits a week
fact_check_explanation_summary: Many different news sites have published articles claiming that snoring could mean you're entitled to Personal Independence Payments.

fact_check_explanation_title: The EU has not set lower gas price cap than the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post claiming that the EU has set a gas price cap far lower than that of the UK is not based in fact.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mariupol concert footage doesn’t prove Ukraine isn’t a warzone
fact_check_explanation_summary: Russian forces now control the city and there was a concert there in July. Footage shows destroyed buildings in the background.

fact_check_explanation_title: WHO director Dr Tedros has been vaccinated
fact_check_explanation_summary: A clip circulating on social media has been used to claim the WHO director said he hadn’t received the Covid-19 vaccine. This isn’t true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Survey on cycling proposals not representative of all drivers
fact_check_explanation_summary: A headline in the Daily Mail claims 91% of drivers support proposals for cyclists to have registration plates.

fact_check_explanation_title: Real wages fall sharply—but not by ‘record’ amount when using best measure
fact_check_explanation_summary: When you look at people’s total pay—including bonuses—the most recent fall in real wages is not a record, although it is very large.

fact_check_explanation_title: Reports of a serial killer on the loose in Dundee are false
fact_check_explanation_summary: Multiple posts claim the same individual is active in cities around the world.

fact_check_explanation_title: President Zelenskyy did not sell 17 million hectares of land to American conglomerates
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no record of Monsanto, Cargill or DuPont having bought large swathes of land from the Ukrainian government under President Zelenskyy, despite claims on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: Energy companies won’t automatically give struggling customers £49 vouchers
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that people with less than £4 on their prepayment meter can get a £49 voucher from their energy company have been shared on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video of farmers harvesting next to burning crops isn’t from Ukraine
fact_check_explanation_summary: A dramatic video of a field on fire was actually taken thousands of miles from Ukraine.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour’s energy price freeze: fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: There appear to be some errors in the calculations in Labour’s plan to freeze the energy price cap, which might mean that it isn’t “fully-funded” after all.

fact_check_explanation_title: Telegraph ‘migrant’ graph only captures fraction of arrivals in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: A graph published by the Telegraph misses hundreds of thousands of people who moved to the UK to live, study and work in 2021.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claims Boris Johnson heckled in Greece without evidence
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no available evidence that Italian TV showed the Prime Minister being heckled by British holidaymakers while in Greece.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence shingles ‘renamed’ as monkeypox is a Pfizer vaccine side effect
fact_check_explanation_summary: Shingles and monkeypox are caused by two totally different viruses.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral ‘Letter from London’ article is part of satirical series
fact_check_explanation_summary: The article is attributed to the Papua New Guinea Courier, which does not exist, and is part of a series published by The Secret Tory blog.

fact_check_explanation_title: Residents of Greater Manchester are not ‘being poisoned’ by their water company
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that a Freedom of Information request has revealed the presence of poisons in drinking water are false.

fact_check_explanation_title: Report of newborn baby abandoned in Barnsley is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: An image of a newborn baby abandoned in South Yorkshire was taken in Thailand in 2017.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are one million people in the UK using anabolic steroids?
