fact_check_explanation_summary: The widely quoted figure can be traced to an extrapolated estimate from 2015, but a review earlier this year suggests the actual number is much lower.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mark Zuckerberg is not David Rockerfeller’s grandson
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Rothschilds don’t have a 10% stake in Facebook either.

fact_check_explanation_title: YouTuber misinterprets Covid-19 vaccine evidence on children from Singapore
fact_check_explanation_summary: Dr John Campbell claims that new evidence shows more children “suffered a severe reaction to vaccine” than required oxygen therapy for Covid-19. But this is incorrect, and the comparison is …

fact_check_explanation_title: Leaked report doesn’t ‘vindicate’ view that most people crossing the Channel on small boats are 'economic migrants'
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Mail on Sunday recently published an article stating that four in 10 people crossing the Channel in small boats are from Albania.

fact_check_explanation_title: Monkeypox is not a government conspiracy to cover up ‘vaccine-induced’ diseases
fact_check_explanation_summary: Thousands of monkeypox infections have been directly confirmed in laboratories, and the Covid-19 vaccines have not caused widespread damage to people’s immune systems

fact_check_explanation_title: Pharmacists survey didn't find patients’ ‘lives’ were being put at risk
fact_check_explanation_summary: A headline in the Daily Express does not accurately reflect the findings of a survey published in The Pharmaceutical Journal.

fact_check_explanation_title: Wigan ‘diaper give away’ seems not to be genuine
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post promising details of a free nappy event leads instead to a website that asks people to share personal and financial details and claim ‘deals’ such as entering …

fact_check_explanation_title: Who can vote in the Conservative leadership contest?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve taken a look at the membership rules for the leadership contest, to see who could be eligible to vote in the upcoming vote.

fact_check_explanation_title: Post warning communities of a dangerous man in the area are fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post warning that a man is attacking people is fake. Multiple versions of the warning have been circulating on Facebook.

fact_check_explanation_title: Monkeypox isn’t just spread by sexual contact
fact_check_explanation_summary: Monkeypox is thought to be primarily spreading through sexual contact, but there are other ways to catch the disease. A small number of cases in children have been confirmed in …

fact_check_explanation_title: No solid proof cannabis oil can ‘cure’ cancer
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some cannabis-based products have been approved for medical use in the UK, but there’s no proof cannabis oil cures the disease.

fact_check_explanation_title: Rishi Sunak video fails to say some retained EU laws have already been repealed or replaced
fact_check_explanation_summary: Mr Sunak’s pledge to review or repeal ‘all 2,400’ EU laws retained following Brexit doesn’t account for the fact many have already been repealed or replaced.

fact_check_explanation_title: A Cabinet minister was not entitled to £470,000 severance pay after two days on the job
fact_check_explanation_summary: Former education secretary Michelle Donelan was due much less—and has said she won’t be taking it anyway.

fact_check_explanation_title: Warnings about 'homeless pair' attacking people are fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post warning that two people are pretending to be homeless before attacking people is fake. Several versions of the warning have been circulating on Facebook.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sky News Conservative leadership Q&A: Rishi Sunak and Liz Truss fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve taken a look at some of the claims made by the final two contenders to be the next Prime Minister during Sky News’s “The Battle For Number 10” Q&A.

fact_check_explanation_title: The government has not awarded a £70 billion net zero contract to a small Cornish company
fact_check_explanation_summary: A public body consortium has chosen the company to provide a procurement service.

fact_check_explanation_title: Not all people with hearing loss are unable to access extra cancer care help
fact_check_explanation_summary: A tweet from Macmillan Cancer Support appears to suggest that 11 million people with hearing loss in the UK can’t access extra help following a cancer diagnosis. This is unlikely …

fact_check_explanation_title: Do a disproportionate number of women end up in prison for failing to pay TV licences?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Conservative leadership candidate Liz Truss has raised concerns over the number imprisoned, but since 1995 twice as many men have been jailed.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence for a rise in sudden deaths or that Covid-19 vaccines are the cause
fact_check_explanation_summary: SADS or Sudden Adult Death Syndrome does not appear to have increased in the UK in 2021.

fact_check_explanation_title: Would Liz Truss’s plans for regional pay boards have saved £8.8 billion?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at the detail of the Conservative leadership candidate’s proposals for public sector pay, which she has now dropped after criticism.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tweet from Liz Truss’s father calling her ‘poo-poo bear’ is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: Her father did not tweet saying she couldn’t tie her shoelaces until she was 12.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post’s claim about a newborn baby being found by police in Essex is false
fact_check_explanation_summary: It uses an image of a baby recently found in Arizona.

fact_check_explanation_title: Picture does not show ‘unnatural’ cloud formations
fact_check_explanation_summary: A picture of the sky does not show “unnatural” cloud formations but rather a long-standing natural phenomenon known as “mackerel sky”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral hot dog clip was a ‘deliberate fake’ by creator
fact_check_explanation_summary: An edited version of the TikTok clip, which supposedly shows a hot dog contaminated by dirt and parasites, has been shared without proper context on Facebook.

fact_check_explanation_title: Article about monkeypox living on door handles for 120 years is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The altered screenshot also claims the virus “can infect anyone from 5 miles away”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Monkeypox is not a cover-up for the effects of the Covid-19 vaccine
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no evidence of any link between the recent monkeypox virus outbreak and the Covid-19 vaccines, which do not damage immune systems, as a video claims.

fact_check_explanation_title: No proof ‘cancer cure’ in viral TikTok actually cured cancer
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no evidence that products made by an Amish man who was jailed for breaking FDA laws actually cured disease.

fact_check_explanation_title: Vigorous coughing will not save you during a heart attack
fact_check_explanation_summary: Advice that coughing vigorously could save you in the event of a heart attack is incorrect and could make things worse.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine is causing monkeypox
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no evidence that monkeypox is linked to the widespread distribution of the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine.

fact_check_explanation_title: Study comparing side effects of Covid-19 and vaccines nothing to do with WHO
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some experts have also raised questions about the study itself, which has been shared thousands of times on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence Keir Starmer tried to block the prosecution of Muslim grooming gangs
fact_check_explanation_summary: Widely-shared posts on Facebook make an unsubstantiated claim about Mr Starmer’s work for the Crown Prosecution Service.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tumours are not ‘there to save your life’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post which claims cancer is ‘created’ by doctors performing needle biopsies on tumours and that it can be starved by natural remedies is inaccurate and potentially harmful.

fact_check_explanation_title: The World Economic Forum has not planned for a future without pets or animal charities
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claims that the WEF has said there will be no need for animal charities in the future as people won’t have pets or eat meat. It hasn’t …

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence Mel Gibson claimed Hollywood elites drink ‘baby blood’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Quotes about a conspiracy theory claiming Hollywood elites drink baby blood have been wrongly attributed to the actor.

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC Conservative leadership debate: Rishi Sunak and Liz Truss fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve taken a closer look at the claims made by the final two contenders to be the next Prime Minister.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did the heatwave see London Fire Brigade’s busiest day since WWII?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim was repeated by Sadiq Khan and subsequently reported around the world.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence Covid-19 vaccines causing heart attacks in children
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post misleadingly suggests that the vaccines are causing all sorts of previously rare health problems, including heart attacks in children.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Sky News’ screenshot linking vaccines with climate change is a fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The broadcaster never published an article claiming that people should get vaccinated to beat climate change.

fact_check_explanation_title: Zara hasn’t banned women wearing hijab from its stores
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim has been reshared on social media after first going viral in 2015.

fact_check_explanation_title: Murder of grandmother didn’t take place in UK, or in 2022
fact_check_explanation_summary: Dorothy Dow’s murder has been the subject of misinformation in the past.

fact_check_explanation_title: Liberal Democrats overstate cost of ministerial severance pay
fact_check_explanation_summary: Boris Johnson and the other ministers who resigned are not entitled to £420,000 between them. The true figure is much lower.

fact_check_explanation_title: Polling doesn't show Penny Mordaunt is the only Conservative leadership candidate who can beat Keir Starmer
fact_check_explanation_summary: Penny Mordaunt’s claim in the ITV Conservative leadership debate is not supported by the polling we’ve seen.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ice cubes will not cause healthy dogs to overheat on hot days
fact_check_explanation_summary: It is generally fine to give dogs ice cubes to cool them down on a hot day, although dogs suffering from heatstroke should not be given ice.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence Tesla has ‘invented a new electronic currency’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A number of videos claiming Tesla has invented a new electronic currency have appeared on Facebook.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral posts about a baby being snatched from a hospital are false
fact_check_explanation_summary: Several widely-shared posts wrongly claim a newborn baby has been stolen from a UK hospital by a woman dressed as a nurse.

fact_check_explanation_title: Rishi Sunak pledge to review ‘2,400’ remaining EU laws doesn’t tell the full story
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government’s own figures show that hundreds of EU laws have already been amended, repealed or replaced.

fact_check_explanation_title: Vaccinated people are not more likely to die of Covid-19
fact_check_explanation_summary: A blog post looks at how many vaccinated vs unvaccinated people have died, while ignoring mortality rates.

fact_check_explanation_title: Comparisons between Japan and US infant vaccination programs are inaccurate
fact_check_explanation_summary: It is not true that Japan has the lowest infant mortality rate in the world while the US has the highest, or that Japan does not vaccinate children under two.

fact_check_explanation_title: ITV Conservative leadership debate: fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve looked into some of the claims made by the contenders to be the next Prime Minister.

fact_check_explanation_title: Channel 4 Conservative leadership debate: fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: With those running in the Conservative leadership race clashing over tax, the cost of living and more, we take a look at some of the claims made.

fact_check_explanation_title: Martin Lewis has not endorsed a cryptocurrency platform in a BBC interview
fact_check_explanation_summary: A page appearing to mimic BBC News has claimed Martin Lewis announced he was endorsing a cryptocurrency platform.

fact_check_explanation_title: NASA has not faked images of the surface of Mars
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that NASA has released fake images of the surface of Mars are false as the images have never been released by the space agency.

fact_check_explanation_title: Post comparing chemtrails and contrails shows two examples of contrails
fact_check_explanation_summary: An image posted to Facebook of two vapour trails left by aircraft does not show how chemtrails differ from contrails. Chemtrails do not exist.

fact_check_explanation_title: Health minister claims contract yet to be awarded has been ‘procured’—then denies she said it
fact_check_explanation_summary: Maria Caulfield told Parliament that an ambulance service support contract was “procured”—not that “we are procuring” it, as she later claimed. NHS England says this contract has not yet been …

fact_check_explanation_title: Pilots wearing ‘chemtrails’ badges is a long-running joke about the conspiracy theory
fact_check_explanation_summary: The images appear alongside other pictures of water tanks used to simulate the weight of passengers during flight testing, but don’t prove anything.

fact_check_explanation_title: Report that Covid-19 vaccine was required to join Roe v Wade protests comes from satirical page
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no evidence “My body, my choice” protests actually had a “vaccination status check”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Poll saying 5% of Northern Ireland trusts UK government is about protocol specifically
fact_check_explanation_summary: A poll said 5% of people in Northern Ireland trusted the UK government to manage the interests of Northern Ireland with respect to the protocol.

fact_check_explanation_title: Average household unlikely to save £900 per year under Zahawi’s plan to cut income tax
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Chancellor had pledged to cut income tax by 1p in 2023 and 2p by 2024 if he became Prime Minister, but available data suggests this would save the average …

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim two-thirds of child asylum seekers are actually adults is false
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Sun article wrongly claimed that two-thirds of people who sought asylum in the UK as unaccompanied children were in fact over 18.

fact_check_explanation_title: Covid-19 vaccines have not killed twice as many people as the virus
fact_check_explanation_summary: This claim is based on a survey which is unlikely to be representative of the US population.

fact_check_explanation_title: Covid-19 vaccines do not harm fertility
fact_check_explanation_summary: An article from the misinformation site, the Exposé, is full of false information about fertility, based on misrepresented science.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photo of Zelensky in front of green screen doesn’t mean he was ‘never’ in Ukraine
fact_check_explanation_summary: A picture of the Ukrainian president in front of a green screen has fuelled false claims about his whereabouts.

fact_check_explanation_title: Conservative leadership contest: four early claims fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We take a look at some of the early claims, including Penny Mordaunt’s estimate of fuel VAT savings and Jeremy Hunt’s claim about corporation tax.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did Boris Johnson actually resign?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Following speculation on social media we’ve taken a look at the context behind Boris Johnson’s decision to remain in office until a new leader is elected.

fact_check_explanation_title: What payouts do ministers receive when they leave office?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Government ministers under 65 are entitled to severance pay when they leave office, as long as they don’t return within three weeks.

fact_check_explanation_title: Rape has not been legalised in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video posted on Facebook claims that rape is now legal and offenders can escape punishment if they apologise.

fact_check_explanation_title: Articles about heart attack risks do not show causality
fact_check_explanation_summary: A collection of articles reporting on possible links between certain factors and heart attacks do not show “you can’t do anything without risking a heart attack”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson repeats false claim about Keir Starmer voting 48 times to ‘take us back’ into the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister has made the same incorrect claim several times before.

fact_check_explanation_title: Social media posts about the ‘birth song’ of the Himba tribe are false
fact_check_explanation_summary: A popular Facebook post describing unique songs created for every child born to the Himba tribe in Africa has no basis in fact.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence half of UK was victim of online crime in past year
fact_check_explanation_summary: We couldn’t find any data to support a claim made by a former police watchdog on the Today programme.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the government going to build 48 new hospitals by 2030?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We looked into the government’s claim that it would build 48 new hospitals by 2030 after the National Audit Office said it would review the policy.

fact_check_explanation_title: Conspiracy theory about Boris Johnson not having Covid-19 is back
fact_check_explanation_summary: A satirical article in 2020 claimed that St Thomas’ Hospital made staff sign the Official Secrets Act when Mr Johnson was admitted, and sent home those who refused—but none of …

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake post about a missing child is spreading on Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: The post contains a link to a false article about a missing child which may be from an unsafe website.

fact_check_explanation_title: Announcement of Prince Philip’s death on BBC is edited
fact_check_explanation_summary: The announcement of the Duke of Edinburgh’s death did appear abruptly on the radio station, but not quite in the way the viral clip suggests.

fact_check_explanation_title: Argentina is not giving all its citizens a 40-day public holiday so they can watch the World Cup
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that the entire nation of Argentina will begin a 40-day public holiday in November so citizens can watch the World Cup are untrue.

fact_check_explanation_title: An image of a rock shaped like an elephant has been digitally altered
fact_check_explanation_summary: The original image shows a real UNESCO world heritage site in Greece.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake claims about McDonald’s ingredients are recirculating on Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post claiming that only 15% of McDonald’s beef was found to be beef, and that its sauces and spices contained pork grease is not correct.

fact_check_explanation_title: Football clip doesn’t show on-loan player scoring to relegate parent club
fact_check_explanation_summary: An Instagram post incorrectly claims that the clip shows a player scoring a goal that relegated his parent club.

fact_check_explanation_title: Microwaves don’t make food ‘highly toxic’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video on Instagram falsely claims that microwave ovens destroy all the nutritional value in food and turn it into a “toxin”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Social media posts claim ethanol is being added to petrol to increase sales
fact_check_explanation_summary: Although added ethanol does slightly reduce cars’ fuel economy, the government has said this is being done in order to reduce net carbon emissions.

fact_check_explanation_title: The number of people in poverty has remained relatively stable since 2010
fact_check_explanation_summary: SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford claimed last week that the Conservatives have “pushed millions of people into poverty”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Old image of Glastonbury aftermath re-emerges on social media
fact_check_explanation_summary: A photo of rubbish at the Glastonbury festival site used to criticise environmental campaigning is actually from 2015.

fact_check_explanation_title: Picture of huge shark is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture has been circulating online since at least 2016.

fact_check_explanation_title: Covid vaccines won’t stop people getting pregnant
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no evidence the vaccines affect fertility.

fact_check_explanation_title: Study on male fertility doesn’t show depopulation plan
fact_check_explanation_summary: Certain measures of male fertility in sperm donors was found to temporarily drop between 2.5 and five months after vaccination.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence deaths from Sudden Adult Death Syndrome are really caused by Covid-19 vaccines
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that cases of sudden, unexpected deaths are actually the result of Covid-19 vaccines are unevidenced. Nor is there currently any evidence that these deaths have become more common in …

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake video doesn’t show Russian strike on Ukrainian arms depot
fact_check_explanation_summary: The video is CGI.

fact_check_explanation_title: Carrie Johnson’s mother did not appear on recent episode of Question Time
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some social media users have suggested Ms Johnson’s mother was in the audience during an episode of the BBC debate show.

fact_check_explanation_title: Times graph on Boris Johnson’s leadership mixes up poll results
fact_check_explanation_summary: Voters were asked if they’d prefer Boris Johnsons to still be Prime Minister in a year’s time, or if they’d prefer someone else.

fact_check_explanation_title: Unvaccinated people are still dying from Covid-19
fact_check_explanation_summary: An Instagram post claiming that “the unvaccinated aren’t dying” is not correct. Sadly, unvaccinated people are still dying from Covid-19 and other causes.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence that parabens in cosmetics cause 99% of cancers
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claiming that 99% of cancers are caused by parabens found in cosmetics is not true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Zero evidence airport disruption planned by World Economic Forum
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claims travel disruption has been deliberately planned.

fact_check_explanation_title: Iain Duncan Smith wrong to say successful asylum seekers would return from Rwanda
fact_check_explanation_summary: The terms of the government’s agreement with Rwanda mean that people whose claims for asylum are accepted will be allowed to settle there—not return to the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Public information film about the dangers of electricity has not been banned
fact_check_explanation_summary: A segment of a 1970s short film warning about the dangers of playing near electrical substations has not been banned.

fact_check_explanation_title: Which train operating companies are run by other countries’ governments?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A list spreading on Facebook claims 17 train operators are fully or partly owned by state-run companies from abroad. But the list is out of date.

fact_check_explanation_title: Rainbow ‘Gayo’ mayonnaise for Pride is not real
fact_check_explanation_summary: The product, although realistic-looking, is not genuine.

fact_check_explanation_title: Image does not show chemicals being dispersed over the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post inaccurately compares contrails caused by a US Air Force formation over the UK to a chemical spraying operation during the Vietnam War.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photo of astronaut floating above Earth is real
fact_check_explanation_summary: The iconic photo shows astronaut Bruce McCandless II untethered from the Challenger space shuttle.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence nutrients ‘reverse’ ADHD
fact_check_explanation_summary: Possible links between some nutrients and ADHD have been studied, but there’s no evidence they reverse it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Saharan dust, not ‘chemtrails’, responsible for substance left behind by rain in Wales
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook video claiming to show chemicals deposited by planes likely shows Saharan dust.

fact_check_explanation_title: Average salary of workers involved in RMT national rail strike is not £44,000
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures for the salary of rail workers mentioned by transport secretary Grant Shapps are not representative of those involved in the national rail strike.

fact_check_explanation_title: RMT exaggerates money ‘wasted’ on PPE and NHS Test and Trace
fact_check_explanation_summary: Funding the NHS for years would cost far more than the total amount spent—let alone “wasted”—on PPE and Test and Trace during the pandemic.

fact_check_explanation_title: European Court of Human Rights not involved in 2014 deportation case
fact_check_explanation_summary: The court was not involved in the decision to overturn the deportation of a Libyan man convicted of 78 offences in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Popular tips on filling cars with petrol don’t offer big savings
fact_check_explanation_summary: A widely-circulated selection of tips on how to save money when filling your car is unlikely to provide any economic benefit.

fact_check_explanation_title: Child self-harm numbers in the Guardian, Mirror and Independent don’t reflect survey’s actual findings
fact_check_explanation_summary: About 3% of parents taking part in a survey said their children had begun to self-harm in response to the cost of living crisis.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU court didn’t prevent Rwanda flight from taking off
fact_check_explanation_summary: It was the European Court of Human Rights, which isn’t an EU institution.

fact_check_explanation_title: Article vastly exaggerates number of Covid-19 vaccine deaths
fact_check_explanation_summary: Reports of death following vaccination do not mean that the vaccine caused the death.

fact_check_explanation_title: The EU did not completely outlaw use of imperial measures in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that the EU forced the UK to adopt the metric system and made the use of imperial measures illegal are not entirely true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Health spending isn’t set to account for almost half of all taxes
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures quoted by LBC presenter Nick Ferrari didn’t take account of the total amount of public spending.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence of a ‘plan’ to cause travel disruption
fact_check_explanation_summary: We can find no evidence to support claims that travel disruption at airports is part of a deliberate attempt to stop people travelling. And there’s plenty of evidence for staff …

fact_check_explanation_title: NASA Mars mission would cost much more than two years of NHS Test and Trace
fact_check_explanation_summary: £37 billion was the original budget for Test and Trace over two years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Australian citizens aren’t being forcibly vaccinated via ‘chemtrails’
fact_check_explanation_summary: False claims have been shared about an old clinical trial for a genetically-modified cholera vaccine.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence Facebook hackers sending ‘offensive comments’ to your friends which you can’t see
fact_check_explanation_summary: A popular Facebook claim warning that hackers are posting “offensive comments” which account owners can’t see has been repeatedly debunked.

fact_check_explanation_title: Picture of Harry Styles wearing t-shirt with obscenity about ‘Tories’ has been Photoshopped
fact_check_explanation_summary: He did not wear a t-shirt that used a swear word to describe members of the Conservative party.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are petrol and diesel taxed in Gibraltar?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no VAT in Gibraltar, but there is fuel duty.

fact_check_explanation_title: Living expense calculations ignore that not all income is taxed
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post showing the average take home pay of someone earning minimum wage does not account for the fact that people do not pay tax on all of their …

fact_check_explanation_title: Crude oil is not cheaper in pounds now than in 2008
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post inaccurately claims that oil was more expensive in pounds in 2008 while fuel was cheaper. In fact, both crude oil and fuel were cheaper in pounds in …

fact_check_explanation_title: Decision to stop Rwanda flight nothing to do with EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: The European Court of Human Rights is a totally separate institution from the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence one refugee from Rwanda will come to the UK for every asylum seeker sent there
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Home Office said this is not happening, and has previously said “a small number” of refugees will be resettled in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: June’s pay figures: explained
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures published by the ONS showing a 2.2% fall in earnings do not account for bonuses, although there are a number of different figures available.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour makes misleading claim about fall in affordable housing under Conservative government
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour’s claim that affordable housing supply has fallen by 95% misinterprets the statistics.

fact_check_explanation_title: Figures on benefit and tax fraud investigators misrepresented
fact_check_explanation_summary: Data uncovered by an MP about the number of fraud investigators employed by HMRC and the DWP has been reshared on social media. But the figures are out of date …

fact_check_explanation_title: A US federal agency did not say that Covid-19 was a planned ‘scamdemic’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A retired neurosurgeon expressed this opinion in a journal article, which can be found by searching PubMed on the agency’s site.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence for link between AIDS epidemic and smallpox vaccine
fact_check_explanation_summary: An article in a 1987 edition of the Times claimed a possible link between the smallpox vaccine and AIDS. There is no evidence for such a link.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much do asylum seekers living in hotels get to live on per week?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some are eligible to receive £8 per week to cover costs for items not provided by their accommodation.

fact_check_explanation_title: Monkeypox is being detected in countries with and without wild monkeys
fact_check_explanation_summary: The bigger question is why there are outbreaks in countries where it isn’t endemic.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video of driver escaping police roadblock by driving on roof of bus is not real
fact_check_explanation_summary: Footage showing a driver escaping from a police roadblock by driving over the roof of a truck and then a double decker bus is a computer simulation.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Coalition did not build more affordable homes in a year than Labour did in 13 years of government
fact_check_explanation_summary: Boris Johnson was wrong to make this claim, according to the government’s own definition of affordable housing.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ofgem said that 12 million households—not people—might end up in fuel poverty
fact_check_explanation_summary: These estimates are uncertain for several reasons, but 12 million households would amount to many more than 12 million people.

fact_check_explanation_title: Research didn’t find contraceptive pill reduces risk of suicide
fact_check_explanation_summary: An article in The Sun misrepresents the findings of a study looking at possible links between hormonal contraceptives and suicide.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claims of ‘40 million in fuel and food poverty’ are too high
fact_check_explanation_summary: Both food insecurity and fuel poverty are serious problems that affect many people in the UK, but almost certainly not 40 million.

fact_check_explanation_title: Survey of GPs’ retirement plans is not reliable
fact_check_explanation_summary: The GPs who responded were the ones who knew about the survey and chose to participate—who are not necessarily representative of GPs as a whole.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Spanish Meteorological Agency has not ‘confessed’ to using chemtrails
fact_check_explanation_summary: Spain has not admitted to using chemtrails to change its weather or fight Covid-19.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post about BBC footage of Boris Johnson being booed is misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: The broadcaster has been criticised for the way it used audio in a clip of the Prime Minister and his wife.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence ‘chemtrails’ are responsible for new chemical found in atmosphere
fact_check_explanation_summary: The long-running ‘chemtrails’ conspiracy theory has been widely shared in recent months.

fact_check_explanation_title: War in Ukraine has contributed to global shortages of certain products
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post suggesting that war in Ukraine is not the cause of shortages of a number of products is missing context.

fact_check_explanation_title: Reports that ‘Bernie Gores’ died in both Uvalde school shooting and Afghanistan are fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: Facebook posts claiming ‘Bernie Gores’ was reported to have died in the school shooting nine months after he was first reported to have died in Afghanistan are based on fake …

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC didn’t ‘censor’ audio of crowd booing over Boris Johnson clip
fact_check_explanation_summary: The crowd sounded different in two versions of the clip because it was recorded by different crews.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU rules didn’t ‘ban’ crown symbols on pint glasses
fact_check_explanation_summary: The law is more complicated than recent headlines have made it seem.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Queen was not involved in disappearance of Indigenous children from Canadian school
fact_check_explanation_summary: A conspiracy theory linking the Queen and Prince Philip to missing Indigenous children in Canada has re-emerged on Facebook.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Platinum Jubilee will not cost each UK household £38,000
fact_check_explanation_summary: We don’t yet have reliable figures for the total cost of the event, but a Facebook post muddles the maths.

fact_check_explanation_title: Modified chimpanzee virus in AstraZeneca vaccine isn’t linked to monkeypox
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that the use of a modified chimpanzee virus in the AstraZeneca Covid vaccine are the cause of monkeypox are untrue.

fact_check_explanation_title: Australian grandmother did not shoot two rapists
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claiming an Australian grandmother shot off the testicles of two men who raped her granddaughter is not true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Monkeypox isn’t shingles in disguise
fact_check_explanation_summary: A tweet claims shingles is ‘being termed as monkeypox’.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pfizer CEO did not say he wanted to decrease population by 50%
fact_check_explanation_summary: Footage of Albert Bourla speaking at Davos has been edited.

fact_check_explanation_title: Saudi Arabia has not announced plans for an ‘International Straight Pride Month’
fact_check_explanation_summary: An image of a BBC World News tweet about the announcement is photoshopped, and Saudi Arabia has revealed no such plans.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence Keanu Reeves nature quote is real
fact_check_explanation_summary: The lack of source hasn’t stopped hundreds of people sharing it online.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence rise in monkeypox cases is linked to Covid-19 vaccine
fact_check_explanation_summary: An article claiming the monkeypox outbreak is evidence that the Covid-19 vaccine causes a form of AIDS is not based in fact.

fact_check_explanation_title: Bill Gates hasn’t launched artificial breast milk
fact_check_explanation_summary: Mr Gates has invested in a start-up producing such a product, but it's not yet available to the public.

fact_check_explanation_title: The FDA did not say Covid-19 vaccines are causing more heart attacks
fact_check_explanation_summary: A tweet also shared to Facebook claiming the FDA said 71 times more heart attacks occurred following the Covid-19 vaccine than any other vaccine is inaccurate.

fact_check_explanation_title: The World Economic Forum does not have its own paramilitary force
fact_check_explanation_summary: An Instagram post depicting a police officer wearing a WEF badge is not proof the forum has its own force.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence monkeypox is an agent of biological warfare
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video of a man opening textbooks to pages about monkeypox does not show the outbreak is a ‘war on us’.

fact_check_explanation_title: Monkeypox is not ‘vaccine acquired’ shingles
fact_check_explanation_summary: They are caused by completely different viruses.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence Covid-19 vaccines cause monkeypox
fact_check_explanation_summary: Monkeypox is a rare disease caused by a virus. There is no evidence it is a side effect of vaccination against Covid-19.

fact_check_explanation_title: The US military did not find traces of pesticides in Moderna’s Covid-19 vaccine
fact_check_explanation_summary: A claim that members of the US special forces found traces of pesticides in vials of Moderna’s Covid-19 vaccine is false.

fact_check_explanation_title: Private jet pictures aren’t from Davos ‘climate change conference’ this year
fact_check_explanation_summary: One of the pictures dates back to a 2015 boxing match in Las Vegas.

fact_check_explanation_title: Image said to show a centuries-old ship is actually a photo of a replica
fact_check_explanation_summary: False claims that the photo of the replica vessel shows a 282-year-old ship returning to London have been circulating online for years.

fact_check_explanation_title: White lines in the sky are not ‘chemtrails’
fact_check_explanation_summary: The lines are contrails, formed when water vapour from aircraft engines freezes at high altitude.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence Denzel Washington quote about being criticised is real
fact_check_explanation_summary: Many versions of the quote have been shared online, but there’s no evidence the actor ever actually said it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Not everybody is getting their passports issued in four to six weeks
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister’s claim that everybody is getting their passports within four to six weeks is not true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Dyson clearance sale on Facebook has nothing to do with Dyson
fact_check_explanation_summary: Neither the online retailer AO, nor Dyson, has any connection to a promotion on Facebook that claims to give people the chance to buy extremely cheap hairdryers.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence Sigmund Freud said viral quote about depression
fact_check_explanation_summary: A quote that has been often misattributed to Freud may actually have been first shared by a Twitter user.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did the Prime Minister mislead Parliament over ‘Partygate’?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The publication of the Sue Gray report has prompted fresh claims Boris Johnson misled Parliament when he stated all lockdown rules were followed.

fact_check_explanation_title: RNLI lifeguarded beaches don’t all provide   wristbands with contact details for children
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral Facebook post claimed that parents can get free wristbands for their children that they can put their contact details on RNLI lifeguarded beaches.

fact_check_explanation_title: Was the Attorney General right to say that a single mother will be £1,600 better off?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Suella Braverman told the Question Time audience that a single mother in certain circumstances would be £1,600 better off this year compared with last year, because of government support.

fact_check_explanation_title: Smallpox not the only infectious disease eradicated by humans
fact_check_explanation_summary: While reporting on the rise of monkeypox, the Times said that smallpox is the only disease ever eradicated by humans. But there has been another—the cattle disease, rinderpest.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many jobs has Crossrail created?
fact_check_explanation_summary: After Boris Johnson claimed at PMQs that 72,000 jobs have been delivered by Crossrail, we’ve looked at the numbers.

fact_check_explanation_title: A picture of the sky does not show ‘chemtrails’
fact_check_explanation_summary: White vapour trails often seen in the sky are thin clouds of condensation left by aircraft engines—not evidence of a conspiracy to poison the planet.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post does show real images of the sun
fact_check_explanation_summary: Despite claims that they’re just CGI artwork, detailed images of the sun being shared on Facebook seem to be real.

fact_check_explanation_title: Most Britons are not projected to be obese by 2040
fact_check_explanation_summary: While a Daily Express headline suggests otherwise, the proportion of Britons forecast to be obese or severely obese by 2040 is actually 36%.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake Washington Post screenshot says dachshund is the ‘face of online homophobia’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A story about a dog called Whitney Chewston did appear in another publication, but not in the Washington Post.

fact_check_explanation_title: Shadow cabinet member uses misleading £2,600 cost of living figure on BBC, ITV and Sky
fact_check_explanation_summary: The shadow justice secretary used an unreliable Labour estimate for the impact of the cost of living crisis. We have repeatedly asked Labour to stop using this number.

fact_check_explanation_title: Post claiming the Pfizer vaccine has only a 12% efficacy rate is inaccurate
fact_check_explanation_summary: False claims circulating on social media about the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine are not based on newly published documents.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UN doesn’t have a plan to abolish private land ownership
fact_check_explanation_summary: Both Agenda 21 and Agenda 2030 are non-binding plans intending to improve sustainable development around the world. Both include private enterprise.

fact_check_explanation_title: Green levy costs do not make up 25% of energy bills
fact_check_explanation_summary: A claim made by Robert Halfon MP, who is in favour of scrapping green levies, on BBC Radio 4’s Today programme and repeated elsewhere is inaccurate.

fact_check_explanation_title: Government minister made misleading claim about employment figures
fact_check_explanation_summary: Northern Ireland secretary Brandon Lewis is the latest cabinet minister to claim that employment is higher than before the pandemic, when it is not.

fact_check_explanation_title: BlackRock doesn’t own 75% of Ancestry
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook claim that the investment management firm BlackRock has a majority stake in the genealogy website ancestry.com is false.

fact_check_explanation_title: £37 billion was the two-year budget for NHS Test and Trace, not how much was spent
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts questioning where the £37 billion allocated to Test and Trace was spent have been shared hundreds of times on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: There’s no evidence Jean-Claude Van Damme is Muslim
fact_check_explanation_summary: A quote about him not getting job offers after converting to Islam is likely false.

fact_check_explanation_title: Amber Heard did not quote The Talented Mr Ripley during trial
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral claim that the actor quoted a film during the opening lines of her testimony during the trial of a defamation case brought against her by Johnny Depp is …

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook image promoting vaccine damage payments scheme is not an official government poster
fact_check_explanation_summary: The poster includes a link to a genuine scheme, which has existed since before the pandemic, under which people severely disabled by vaccines can apply for £120,000.

fact_check_explanation_title: Covid vaccines haven’t been mandated in the EU ‘under the radar’ under ‘Resolution 2361’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on Facebook claims that the European Council has removed its objection to mandatory Covid-19 vaccines.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence John Lennon quote about happiness is real
fact_check_explanation_summary: Despite versions being shared many times online, there’s no evidence the former Beatle ever said it.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence inspiring Facebook quote comes from Sir Anthony Hopkins
fact_check_explanation_summary: Advice that people should “say the truth that you’re carrying in your heart like hidden treasure” appears to have been written by the founder of an online lifestyle brand in …

fact_check_explanation_title: Reports that ‘most teachers’ are suffering from depression are based on a self-selecting survey
fact_check_explanation_summary: The data comes from members of the NASUWT teaching union who chose to complete its survey, so it can’t reliably tell us about the wellbeing of teachers as a whole.

fact_check_explanation_title: No hard evidence behind claim holidaymakers have 50% chance of ‘timely’ passport renewal
fact_check_explanation_summary: This figure is an estimate from an economic consultancy and doesn’t appear to be based on statistical data.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence hepatitis in children is caused by vaccinated breastfeeding mothers
fact_check_explanation_summary: An article shared on Facebook claims that most children with hepatitis were breastfed by fully vaccinated mothers.

fact_check_explanation_title: A man who arrived in Japan with a fake passport did not mysteriously vanish
fact_check_explanation_summary: It seems that the man himself was real, according to reports at the time. He was arrested, but we can find no evidence that he vanished—let alone that he came …

fact_check_explanation_title: Article 61 of the Magna Carta doesn’t mean you don’t have to pay council tax
fact_check_explanation_summary: Those liable do have to pay council tax, and nothing in the Magna Carta stops that being the case.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Lancet didn’t say Covid-19 vaccines are only 1% effective
fact_check_explanation_summary: This claim appears to be based on a misunderstanding of a 2021 article that suggested a different measure of effectiveness be published alongside the usual measure.

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS dentists are still operating in Somerset
fact_check_explanation_summary: A headline suggesting otherwise is not accurate. There is a reported shortage of appointments for new NHS patients, however.

fact_check_explanation_title: ‘Pfizer document’ doesn’t show company admitting vaccines unsafe in pregnancy
fact_check_explanation_summary: A screenshot of a supposed new document from Pfizer has been shared thousands of times but is out of date.

fact_check_explanation_title: Man wasn’t jailed only for staring at a woman on the train
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Spectator article recently claimed that a man had been sentenced to 22 weeks in prison after “continuously staring” at a woman.

fact_check_explanation_title: Harrier jets didn’t spell out expletive over Houses of Parliament
fact_check_explanation_summary: The farewell flypast for the jets didn’t even pass London.

fact_check_explanation_title: There were not 65,000 flu deaths in the winter of 2017/18
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’re not sure where this number comes from, but official estimates suggest it’s more than double the true figure.

fact_check_explanation_title: Some voting in local elections can pick more than one candidate
fact_check_explanation_summary: Until recently the Gov.uk website had given a misleading explanation of how to vote in local elections in England and Wales.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fanta Lemon is not being discontinued in Europe
fact_check_explanation_summary: This seems to stem from a now-deleted tweet from the brand in 2018.

fact_check_explanation_title: Keir Starmer’s GMB interview: fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Labour leader made claims about the UK’s economic growth and fraud during the pandemic.

fact_check_explanation_title: 1939 Cancer Act doesn’t criminalise discussion of cancer ‘cures’
fact_check_explanation_summary: The legislation prohibits advertising ‘cures’ to the general public, including orthodox treatments.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson’s GMB interview: fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister made claims about the UK’s economic growth, council tax, and his record on bus passes while Mayor of London.

fact_check_explanation_title: Angela Rayner repeats misleading claim that families are £2,620 ‘worse off’
fact_check_explanation_summary: This figure comes from an unreliable Labour estimate that doesn’t take account of wage or benefit rises.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Rothschilds don’t own Reuters or the Associated Press
fact_check_explanation_summary: AP is owned by a membership made up of other media companies. Reuters is part of Thomson Reuters, which is majority-owned by the Thomson family in Canada.

fact_check_explanation_title: GB News presenter wrong about booster vaccine deaths
fact_check_explanation_summary: Mark Steyn claimed during his programme that booster vaccines were ineffective and wrongly suggested they increased the chance of hospitalisation and death.

fact_check_explanation_title: Clip of French TV shows technical glitch, not election fraud
fact_check_explanation_summary: An error made by France 2 has led to accusations of electoral fraud in the French presidential elections.

fact_check_explanation_title: Overturned cars in Ukraine were likely flipped by Russian forces, not explosion
fact_check_explanation_summary: A photo of cars in front of an apparently undamaged building is being used to imply an attack was “staged”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post’s figures for the state pension and House of Lords allowance are broadly right
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims on social media about these payments are often inaccurate, but these numbers are correct for the financial year just finished.

fact_check_explanation_title: Was Rishi Sunak’s in-laws’ company a ‘beneficiary’ of a UK-India trade deal?
fact_check_explanation_summary: An announcement of £1 billion worth of trade and investment between the UK and India included Infosys, as well as a number of other firms.

fact_check_explanation_title: Picture of Icelandic lake has been edited
fact_check_explanation_summary: The real lake doesn’t look like an eye.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photographs of aeroplanes don’t prove existence of ‘chemtrails’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Pictures shared online have been falsely claimed to show that the ‘chemtrails’ conspiracy theory is correct.

fact_check_explanation_title: High reported Covid-19 deaths due to Easter holiday backlog
fact_check_explanation_summary: No deaths were reported over the Easter bank holiday weekend, leading to a spike in reports in the following days. The actual number of Covid-19 deaths occurring is falling.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did David Blunkett propose sending asylum seekers abroad in 2004?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look into Boris Johnson’s claims at PMQs that the former Labour Home Secretary first proposed plans similar to the government’s deal with Rwanda.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour election leaflets and ads wrongly claiming families are ‘£2,620 worse off’
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim that families are ‘£2,620 worse off’ does not account for any rises in wages or benefits, and is based on some cost estimates which are not reliable.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson makes false employment claim for ninth time in Parliament
fact_check_explanation_summary: The PM claimed there are more people in work than there were before the pandemic. This figure only counts employees and not the self-employed. In total there are 600,000 fewer …

fact_check_explanation_title: Rishi Sunak’s in-laws’ company isn’t registered in Rwanda
fact_check_explanation_summary: Infosys, the company founded by Akshata Murty’s father, is not registered in Rwanda.

fact_check_explanation_title: Number of death certificates with only Covid-19 is a bad estimate of the death toll
fact_check_explanation_summary: To the end of 2021, over 150,000 deaths in the UK had been registered with Covid-19 as the underlying cause.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral pensions post has its maths all wrong
fact_check_explanation_summary: The post misunderstands how state pensions work in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Working pensioners will have to pay the health and social care levy from 2023
fact_check_explanation_summary: National Insurance is increasing, but so is the threshold for paying it, and how it affects working pensioners changes next year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Article claiming link between referee whistles and heart problems in athletes is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no credible evidence of an expert describing a link between referee whistles and heart problems in athletes.

fact_check_explanation_title: GB News interview features misleading claims about Covid-19 and vaccines
fact_check_explanation_summary: Mark Steyn and Dr Guy Hatchard made a number of misleading claims about unreviewed studies, excess deaths and underlying risk factors.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pictures of chocolate eggs don’t show ‘salmonella and maggots’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Damaged eggs being shared on Facebook are not those potentially affected by the problem at Ferrero’s factory in Belgium.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Great Reset: What is it?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The World Economic Forum’s website is open about its desire for a ‘Great Reset’, but what that means has been the subject of false claims.

fact_check_explanation_title: There is no upper limit for how much MPs can claim to cover heating costs
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on Facebook claims MPs can claim ‘up to’ £3,400 for utility bills.

fact_check_explanation_title: Dr Anthony Fauci has not been arrested by Special Forces
fact_check_explanation_summary: This is a complete fabrication. Dr Fauci has appeared in public since the claim was made.

fact_check_explanation_title: Iceland isn’t giving away free food
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral post claims liking and sharing it is enough to get £35 of free food from the Iceland supermarket chain. The official Iceland page makes no reference to this …

fact_check_explanation_title: 10% of criminal barristers haven’t quit in the past year
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of criminal barristers has stayed steady, but the number working full-time on publicly-funded cases has fallen.

fact_check_explanation_title: Nadine Dorries didn’t say ‘food doesn’t grow on trees’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral image claims Culture Minister Nadine Dorries said ‘every family needs to live within their means’ because ‘food doesn’t grow on trees’. This is a fake tweet.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boots isn’t selling lateral flow tests ‘the taxpayer has already paid for’
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s been falsely claimed on social media that the retailer has been ‘given’ taxpayer funded Covid-19 tests to sell back to the public.

fact_check_explanation_title: Thérèse Coffey wrong to claim employment is up over the pandemic
fact_check_explanation_summary: Government ministers have repeatedly claimed employment is higher than pre-pandemic levels, when it is not.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK’s Covid ‘survival rate’ is lower than 99.972%
fact_check_explanation_summary: Roughly 99.76% of the population of the UK have not died with Covid as the underlying cause, which is another way of saying that about 0.24% have.

fact_check_explanation_title: Single occupancy council tax discount can’t be revoked if you don’t take in Ukrainian refugees
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims on Twitter and Facebook say that an elderly man in a London borough was told by his council he could be forced to take in a Ukrainian family.

fact_check_explanation_title: Historic claim on refugee and pensioner incomes is still wrong
fact_check_explanation_summary: The post also compares Germany’s maximum state pension to the UK’s. Germany’s state pensions are difficult to compare to ours as theirs are based on income whilst the UK’s isn’t.

fact_check_explanation_title: Keir Starmer wrong to say families will be £2,620 worse off this year
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour’s estimates do not include rises in wages or benefits, and contain several unreliable assumptions.

fact_check_explanation_title: Why Rishi Sunak’s wife’s tax status isn’t a direct consequence of her citizenship
fact_check_explanation_summary: Ms Murty uses her non-domiciled status to not pay UK tax on foreign income, but this is an active choice, and not a direct consequence of her Indian citizenship.

fact_check_explanation_title: Keir Starmer wrong to suggest taxes aren’t rising on stocks and shares
fact_check_explanation_summary: While income from stocks and shares isn’t subject to National Insurance, dividend income is subject to dividend tax which is increasing by the same amount.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mirror wrong to say catching Covid in warm weather cuts risk of long Covid
fact_check_explanation_summary: Surveys on the prevalence of long Covid did not measure the difference between groups of people based on when they caught Covid in the first place, nor necessarily based on …

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence ‘vast majority’ of people crossing Channel in small boats are economic migrants
fact_check_explanation_summary: Research indicates that the majority of people crossing the Channel go on to be granted asylum, but the full picture is not covered by official statistics.

fact_check_explanation_title: WEF didn’t say that property ownership would become ‘unsustainable’
fact_check_explanation_summary: A screenshot of a tweet claims Klaus Schwab said eating meat and property ownership are unsustainable.

fact_check_explanation_title: 2,612% rise in food bank use under David Cameron needs context
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Trussell Trust did provide about 27 times more food parcels at the end of David Cameron’s time in office than it had at the beginning—but this doesn’t mean food …

fact_check_explanation_title: Claims about German Test and Trace costs completely wrong
fact_check_explanation_summary: The costs of German and UK Covid-19 testing and tracing programmes cannot be easily compared.

fact_check_explanation_title: Asda’s milk is vegetarian
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that Asda’s non-organic milk is not vegetarian are false and have been circulating since at least 2016.

fact_check_explanation_title: Chris Rock did not say he ‘crossed a line’ following Will Smith Oscars slap
fact_check_explanation_summary: The comedian has not issued an official statement.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence for MP’s claims ‘tens of thousands of people’ have ‘suffered severe damage’ from vaccines
fact_check_explanation_summary: Conservative MP Sir Christopher Chope made the claim about Covid-19 vaccines during an interview with GB News.

fact_check_explanation_title: Chris Bryant wrong on 0% EU VAT for heat pumps
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour MP Chris Bryant also claimed that VAT exemption on solar panels already happens in the EU. This isn’t quite true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook video shows actors making a TV series in 2020—not staging the war in Ukraine
fact_check_explanation_summary: The clip was first shared by a producer of the series in December 2020.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pelicans don’t push their spines out of their mouths to cool down
fact_check_explanation_summary: A widely-shared meme actually shows birds yawning.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe photo makes it look like husband and daughter aren’t smiling
fact_check_explanation_summary: A picture shared by an MP of the family has been digitally altered.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ukraine is not enacting the ‘Great Reset’ with an app
fact_check_explanation_summary: An app available to Ukrainians is how those who’ve lost their job because of the war can get a one-off payment, but it doesn’t mean the introduction of a social …

fact_check_explanation_title: Video doesn’t show Russian and Ukrainian soldiers dancing together after invasion
fact_check_explanation_summary: The clip was uploaded at least six days before the Russian invasion of Ukraine even began.

fact_check_explanation_title: The House of Lords’ daily allowance is about what Universal Credit pays in a month—but peers don’t get it every day
fact_check_explanation_summary: This is the daily allowance for doing parliamentary work in the House. However, not all Lords can claim it, or do.

fact_check_explanation_title: US military deaths didn’t increase by 1,100% last year
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims of a huge spike in deaths are based on faulty data.

fact_check_explanation_title: List of MPs’ crimes isn’t true
fact_check_explanation_summary: This list was supposed to describe the crimes of members of the US Congress more than 20 years ago, and even then it wasn’t verifiable.

fact_check_explanation_title: A video of a failed grenade launcher does not show Russian army
fact_check_explanation_summary: A longer version says it shows the Kenyan army.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video of someone smoking in a body bag was taken on set of a music video
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that the video shows a ‘dead body in Ukraine’ smoking are false.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour overstates amount spent on ‘dodgy PPE’ which will be burnt
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Government did write off £8.7 billion spent on PPE—but not all of that relates to equipment which will be burnt.

fact_check_explanation_title: Waitrose is not offering anyone who shares a Facebook post free food
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook page that’s less than a month old claims those who share or comment on a post will receive a £50 box of food.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence quote about photo of child in Nagasaki is true
fact_check_explanation_summary: The post claims to recount an interaction between a US soldier and a child in the aftermath of the bombing of Nagasaki in 1945.

fact_check_explanation_title: A newly released document does not reveal ‘side effects’ of the Pfizer vaccine
fact_check_explanation_summary: It lists reported adverse events, which may not have been caused by the vaccine. It also concludes that its data raises no safety concerns.

fact_check_explanation_title: The price of fuel is quite closely connected to the price of oil
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post made it look like the fuel price is rising faster than oil, because it used fuel prices that were not adjusted for inflation.

fact_check_explanation_title: Picture of Putin popping Ukraine balloon isn’t a Banksy
fact_check_explanation_summary: The clearly-edited image has been shared tens of thousands of times on Facebook.

fact_check_explanation_title: Express publishes misleading article about safety of the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine
fact_check_explanation_summary: A recently published US document listing adverse events does not show “side effects” of the vaccine. Nor is it the first time the public have been able to see data …

fact_check_explanation_title: Video of underground tunnel isn’t a secret UK military site
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post says it’s ‘UK Area 51’, but it’s actually a decommissioned nuclear bunker that has been shown to the outside world many times.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video doesn’t show Ukrainian president and his wife covering a Lionel Richie song
fact_check_explanation_summary: Facebook posts shared thousands of times claim to show Volodymyr Zelenskyy singing a duet.

fact_check_explanation_title: Why is petrol more expensive now than it was 15 years ago?
fact_check_explanation_summary: International oil prices recently reached similar levels to 2008, but pump prices haven’t dropped to what they were back then.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour graph showing reduction in army size is misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: The graph suggests a reduction in army numbers planned to take place by 2025 had already happened in 2021.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video of person moving inside body bag isn’t from Ukraine
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s actually from a climate protest in Vienna.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did Labour invent the ‘hostile environment’?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Michael Gove recently claimed that the concept was conceived under a Labour Home Secretary.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is sharing photographs of prisoners of war banned by the Geneva Convention?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Legal opinion suggests sharing photographs of prisoners of war doesn’t necessarily breach the Convention—but it still may be better not to do so.

fact_check_explanation_title: Edited image falsely claims to show Ukrainian tractor pulling Russian rocket
fact_check_explanation_summary: An image from 2018 of a space rocket on board a train has been edited to show it being pulled by a tractor.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photograph of crowded railway station is from Ukraine in March 2022
fact_check_explanation_summary: A black-and-white version has been shared, making it look like a scene from the Second World War

fact_check_explanation_title: Social media posts overestimate how much tax is on petrol and diesel
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims are circulating that £1 per litre is now taken in taxes, but it’s more like 80-90 pence for fuel duty and VAT.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral video does not show US paratroopers landing in Ukraine
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video viewed over seven million times shows US paratroopers in North Carolina—not Ukraine, as claimed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sajid Javid wrong on government guidance for Ukraine family visas
fact_check_explanation_summary: Home Office guidance says the Ukraine Family Scheme isn’t currently open to relatives of Ukrainians on a UK work visa.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fuel duty and VAT adds about 80-90 pence per litre on petrol and diesel at the pump
fact_check_explanation_summary: Road fuel prices have reached or passed 190 pence per litre in parts of the country. At that price, just under half of that is fuel duty and VAT.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photograph of Ukrainian volunteer wearing Ghostbusters badge is genuine
fact_check_explanation_summary: A picture shared on social media was originally taken by a Reuters journalist

fact_check_explanation_title: Footage of plane under fire is from a video game, not Ukraine
fact_check_explanation_summary: The video is actually from the tactical shooter game Arma 3.

fact_check_explanation_title: Home Office claim to have launched first Ukrainian visa scheme lacks context
fact_check_explanation_summary: Many countries taking Ukrainian refugees never required visas in the first place. Others have waived visa schemes entirely.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photograph of men in military uniform doesn’t show squad members of FC Dynamo Kyiv
fact_check_explanation_summary: A photograph claiming to show the Dynamo Kyiv football team in army uniform actually shows members of a nationalist group in Ukraine.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence news channel used shot from Deep Impact to show people fleeing Kyiv
fact_check_explanation_summary: Italian fact checkers have found no evidence the shot was broadcast by TGCOM24.

fact_check_explanation_title: Government has not backed up Russian sanction claims
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office said it has sanctioned Russian bank assets worth more than those sanctioned by the US or EU—but hasn’t explained how it reached its figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: Barcodes alone can’t show a product was made in Russia
fact_check_explanation_summary: They can only show that the company that registered the code was based there.

fact_check_explanation_title: Nuclear weapons do exist
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s plenty of evidence that the bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki were not napalm, as a Facebook post claims.

fact_check_explanation_title: £24bn in extra defence spending will be spread over four years
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Institute for Fiscal Studies has previously described the practice of adding up multiple years of spending increases as “misleading”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson’s claims on UK accepting people fleeing conflict miss vital context
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK has resettled more people than other European countries through resettlement schemes, but that doesn’t include hundreds of thousands of people also seeking asylum.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sign telling Russian troops ‘go f*** yourselves’ was Photoshopped
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture, which went viral online, was designed by the Ukrainian authorities to encourage people to tear down road signs.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photo of wounded Ukrainian woman near Kharkiv is genuine
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts on Facebook claim that photographs of a Ukrainian woman injured after an airstrike near Kharkiv actually depict events from 2018. This isn’t the case, and the images are genuine.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video of explosion aftermath is from Lebanon in 2020, not Ukraine
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video shared on social media claims to show an explosion and collapsed buildings in Ukraine, but it actually shows an explosion in Lebanon in 2020.

fact_check_explanation_title: Lightning strike video doesn’t show war in Ukraine
fact_check_explanation_summary: The video appeared online almost a month before the Russian invasion.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video shows game footage, not a plane being shot at in Ukraine
fact_check_explanation_summary: The developers of Arma 3 confirmed that the footage came from a modified version of their game.

fact_check_explanation_title: Map of Russian nuclear targets in UK dates back to the Cold War
fact_check_explanation_summary: A map being shared on social media suggests potential sites of Russian nuclear strikes across the UK, but the original estimates are now 50 years old, and don't give any …

fact_check_explanation_title: Pornhub isn’t blocked in Russia following the invasion of Ukraine
fact_check_explanation_summary: This is a rumour that may have begun on Twitter. The site appears to be working normally for users in Russia.

fact_check_explanation_title: Beirut port explosion footage being mistaken as Ukraine
fact_check_explanation_summary: Video apparently taken from a street in Beirut of the 2020 explosion is being shared as though it was filmed in Ukraine.

fact_check_explanation_title: Collection of heart attack articles includes one fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: A list of things that can cause heart attacks “in 2022” includes one fake article and another from 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: CNN did not claim the same man was killed in both Ukraine and Afghanistan
fact_check_explanation_summary: The report came from fake CNN Twitter accounts which have now been suspended. The photo used appears to be of a YouTuber, who is alive.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video shows explosion at air base, not Ukraine’s main airport
fact_check_explanation_summary: The video actually shows the Melitopol air base.

fact_check_explanation_title: Images of girl confronting soldier are not from Ukraine
fact_check_explanation_summary: They come from a video that says it shows children in Palestine, which was published online in 2012.

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC Breakfast uses old footage of Russian parade rehearsal to show invasion of Ukraine
fact_check_explanation_summary: The clip of military planes is one of a number of misleading videos which have circulated online following the invasion.

fact_check_explanation_title: CGI WW2 video being used as Ukraine footage
fact_check_explanation_summary: The video first appeared on TikTok in 2021.

fact_check_explanation_title: Maajid Nawaz got Covid-19 facts wrong on the Joe Rogan podcast
fact_check_explanation_summary: The former LBC broadcaster made misleading claims about vaccines, infection rates and death tolls.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video of 2015 explosion in China being mislabelled as Ukraine
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video recorded by an American man of a warehouse exploding has been wrongly claimed to show Russian airstrikes in Ukraine.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photos claiming to show explosions in Ukraine are actually from Gaza
fact_check_explanation_summary: Pictures that have been widely shared on social media do not show the war in Ukraine.

fact_check_explanation_title: Videos claiming to show Ukraine invasion sourced to old TikTok videos
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s not clear when or where some of these clips were taken, but they predate the Russian invasion of Ukraine by some weeks.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake Ukraine video includes footage from 2015 and a computer game teaser
fact_check_explanation_summary: At least some of the clips in a video supposedly showing Russia invading Ukraine aren’t genuine.

fact_check_explanation_title: Video claiming to show planes during Russian invasion of Ukraine is actually of 2020 parade rehearsal
fact_check_explanation_summary: The military parade rehearsal took place in May 2020 near Moscow, as revealed by Spanish fact checkers.

fact_check_explanation_title: Police cars are exempt from having an MOT
fact_check_explanation_summary: Even though a police car’s registration may show as ‘overdue’, the government’s MOT checking site explains the vehicles are exempt.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral tweet on wealth tax generating £250 billion for NHS is misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: A campaign group estimated £250 billion could be raised globally by a financial transaction tax, with £20 billion being raised in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Estimating vaccine effectiveness by comparing case rates is seriously flawed
fact_check_explanation_summary: A common form of misinformation in recent months, comparing case rates does not give a reliable estimate of vaccine effectiveness.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson repeats misleading claim on number of people in employment
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of people in employment is down since the pre-pandemic peak, while the number of employees (not counting the self-employed) is up.

fact_check_explanation_title: Keir Starmer hasn’t voted 48 times to take the UK back into the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: The figure repeatedly quoted by Boris Johnson appears to include some votes which were not about whether or not the UK should be part of the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: News clip doesn’t prove Queen is being treated with ivermectin
fact_check_explanation_summary: Screenshots and clips of an Australian news segment about Queen Elizabeth II have been shared widely online.

fact_check_explanation_title: Flying bin video was not filmed during Storm Eunice
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video from TikTok of a trampoline and wheelie bin flying through the air were online long before Storm Eunice.

fact_check_explanation_title: Footage of a rolling ferry was not made during Storm Eunice
fact_check_explanation_summary: It shows a ferry in Scotland during Storm Dennis in February 2020.

fact_check_explanation_title: Irish reporter did not get hit by sign during storm
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral video from 2015 has been edited.

fact_check_explanation_title: MPs can’t claim £50 for a breakfast
fact_check_explanation_summary: This familiar claim has returned on Facebook. MPs’ food and drink allowance, when they are away on business, is £25 per day.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence Sir Anthony Hopkins penned essay about personal relationships
fact_check_explanation_summary: Similar words attributed to a different author predate attribution to Sir Anthony.

fact_check_explanation_title: Iceland’s CEO is not offering free food to people who like a Facebook page
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post promising essential goods worth £40 for free is not affiliated with Iceland.

fact_check_explanation_title: Test and Trace money wasn’t just spent on an app
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video on Facebook makes claims about government overspending on Test and Trace, PPE and the value of fraudulent loans.

fact_check_explanation_title: Driving during red weather warning won’t void your insurance
fact_check_explanation_summary: Although drivers are advised to avoid travelling during red weather warnings, the Association of British Insurers has said rumours that doing so will void your insurance are not true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Storms with female names are not ‘more deadly’ because people underestimate them
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim that more people die in storms with female names, like Eunice, is based on flawed research. Better evidence suggests that the name makes no difference.

fact_check_explanation_title: Washington Post overstates prevalence of long Covid
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Washington Post claimed at least 50% of people who survive Covid-19 have debilitating health issues in the months afterwards. Official estimates are far lower.

fact_check_explanation_title: 'Storm Eunice video' supposedly showing crane fall in Portsmouth is actually from Poland
