fact_check_explanation_title: Mirror claims NHS staff work 11 hours unpaid overtime on average but it’s probably more like two hours
fact_check_explanation_summary: NHS staff survey data suggests the average respondent in 2019 worked around two hours unpaid overtime. Even this should be taken with a pinch of salt.

fact_check_explanation_title: WhatsApp Gold scams are real, but these other threats are made up
fact_check_explanation_summary: Misinformation claiming a malicious WhatsApp video called Dance of the Pope will install software and format your phone has been going viral since at least 2015.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pressing ‘cancel’ does not prevent cash machine fraud
fact_check_explanation_summary: It is a common myth that pressing cancel before using a cash machine will prevent fraud

fact_check_explanation_title: A post incorrectly claims to show Australian warships turning away people trying to enter the country illegally
fact_check_explanation_summary: While Australia does turn back boats, this image does not show that action.

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s not true the BBC decided against showing Dame Vera Lynn’s funeral live
fact_check_explanation_summary: Widely shared posts on Facebook wrongly claim the BBC decided not to broadcast Dame Vera Lynn’s funeral live, but did broadcast live the funeral of George Floyd.

fact_check_explanation_title: Why a Facebook post about an elderly lady looking for her Scottish niece keeps going viral
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no reason to doubt the original story is genuine, but people have been reposting it for several months.

fact_check_explanation_title: Not all Tesco meat is halal
fact_check_explanation_summary: According to the retailer, it sells halal meat in some of its stores.

fact_check_explanation_title: Cohabiting grandparents cannot bubble with a couple and their grandchildren
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister suggested that grandparents could bubble with the household of their grandchildren. This isn’t always allowed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mask graphic contains a number of inaccuracies
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post has claimed that Covid-19 can’t be spread person to person. This is the main way the disease spreads.

fact_check_explanation_title: Police do have legal powers to enforce face covering laws
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some police officers and groups have suggested the new mask rules may be tricky to enforce.

fact_check_explanation_title: Independent SAGE’s estimated death rate is too high
fact_check_explanation_summary: It is wrong to suggest that the government has said it would be happy for the Covid-19 death rate to remain at this level.

fact_check_explanation_title: Spending on online slot machines didn’t go up 25% in lockdown
fact_check_explanation_summary: This was claimed in an article when the rise has actually been since last year.

fact_check_explanation_title: What are the new lockdown rules on social distancing?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Rules about who you can meet and what you can do outside have been updated by the government.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claims that Muslims caused Leicester’s Covid-19 outbreak are baseless
fact_check_explanation_summary: It is still too early to give a definitive explanation for why Leicester’s outbreak happened.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tony and Cherie Blair are not directors of a PFI consortium
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no evidence for this claim

fact_check_explanation_title: Did the government meet its Covid-19 test targets?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government has often been unclear about exactly what its testing targets were. It has hit some and missed others, and announced successes without evidence that the success was real.

fact_check_explanation_title: Government issues contradictory advice on travel quarantine
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government has given conflicting advice about who needs to quarantine after travelling home from abroad from 10 July.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mobile phone cancellations in China don’t prove that 21 million have died of Covid-19
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of mobile phone subscriptions in China fell by 21 million between December and February. This doesn’t mean 21 million have died.

fact_check_explanation_title: Increase in doctors and nurses does not include Covid-19 returners
fact_check_explanation_summary: Rises in the number of full-time doctors and nurses in the NHS do not include staff members who returned to help during the coronavirus pandemic.

fact_check_explanation_title: New data reveals PM’s testing speeds claims as wrong
fact_check_explanation_summary: The PM claimed all tests at regional sites and mobile units were processed within 24 hours. New data shows, at the time, only 19% and 5% of tests respectively were …

fact_check_explanation_title: City Of London Police are not warning people about this scam claiming to involve banks and mobile network providers
fact_check_explanation_summary: This is not a real scam.

fact_check_explanation_title: The “Irish slave” myth has been widely discredited
fact_check_explanation_summary: The myth is based on a misunderstanding of indentured servitude.

fact_check_explanation_title: Leicester going back into lockdown has nothing to do with 5G
fact_check_explanation_summary: Leicester is one of many cities which has 5G coverage.

fact_check_explanation_title: The government’s education funding figures need context
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures given by the Department for Education about the amount of weekly funding for schools do not give the full picture.

fact_check_explanation_title: Coronavirus cures: debunked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve been asked by readers to find the truth about many alleged ‘cures’ for Covid-19.

fact_check_explanation_title: Data from Barnardo’s doesn’t show the number of children needing foster care has grown 44%
fact_check_explanation_summary: Barnardo’s has seen a 44% increase in the number of children referred from councils to be placed in foster care during the pandemic.

fact_check_explanation_title: Covid-19 testing is not as fast as Matt Hancock claimed
fact_check_explanation_summary: Almost all the tests Matt Hancock described deliver results by the end of the next day—not within 24hrs

fact_check_explanation_title: We all deserve a better debate on poverty
fact_check_explanation_summary: Politicians from all sides quote seemingly contradictory poverty figures on a regular basis. This is bad for anyone who wants to understand the story of poverty in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What was the New Deal?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister recently compared the government’s policy program to Franklin Roosevelt’s New Deal. They’re not on the same scale.

fact_check_explanation_title: This is what we know about the government loan to pay slave owners compensation after slavery was abolished in 1833
fact_check_explanation_summary: This amounted to £20 million, or 40% of government spending that year.

fact_check_explanation_title: How medical staff found themselves at the centre of an information battle during the pandemic
fact_check_explanation_summary: Over the past months, as the coronavirus pandemic gripped the country, medical staff have found themselves – often unwillingly – at the centre of a parallel information crisis.

fact_check_explanation_title: We know of one successful conviction of a police officer for the killing of someone in police custody since 1971
fact_check_explanation_summary: Also two police forces and one officer have been prosecuted successfully for crimes related to the death of someone in custody since 1971.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation wasn’t kicked out of India
fact_check_explanation_summary: Also, claims that the polio vaccine paralysed thousands of children are based on shaky evidence.

fact_check_explanation_title: Covid-19 study that links deaths to low vitamin D levels is flawed
fact_check_explanation_summary: This study has been removed from the online research library it was published on.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral illustration shows one type of Covid-19 sampling method
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are different ways to take samples to test someone for Covid-19.

fact_check_explanation_title: This little girl called Alice has not been kidnapped from your area
fact_check_explanation_summary: This is a recurring fake claim.

fact_check_explanation_title: What do we know about Covid-19 inequalities among people from minority ethnic groups?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are stark inequalities in Covid-19 outcomes in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Lord’s Prayer is not banned from Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: This has never been Facebook’s policy.

fact_check_explanation_title: This was a real petition calling for the White Cliffs of Dover to be renamed
fact_check_explanation_summary: The petition on change.org called for “The Black Lives Matter Cliffs of Dover” but it doesn’t seem to be connected to the BLM UK group.

fact_check_explanation_title: This Facebook post isn’t by tennis player Serena Williams
fact_check_explanation_summary: The post was shared by someone with the same name.

fact_check_explanation_title: There is no evidence that suicides have increased 200% under lockdown
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no clear source for this figure.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK has had one of Europe’s worst Covid-19 outbreaks
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK is not the only European country with many Covid-19 deaths.

fact_check_explanation_title: Bill Gates doesn’t own the vaccine for or patent of the Covid-19 virus
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral Facebook post claims he is a partner in a Wuhan lab, which he isn’t.

fact_check_explanation_title: Why did few MPs attend a debate on health worker pay?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This was a Petitions Committee debate. These do not lead to any direct decision or vote on changes to law.

fact_check_explanation_title: South Korean police don’t use purple dye cannons on protesters
fact_check_explanation_summary: Dye in cannons is a widely used but controversial policing tactic around the world.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post about Italy, coronavirus and 5G is almost all false
fact_check_explanation_summary: The post wrongly claims Italian doctors have found Covid-19 is caused by a bacteria.

fact_check_explanation_title: Keir Starmer led the CPS when it did not charge Jimmy Savile, but he wasn’t the reviewing lawyer
fact_check_explanation_summary: Keir Starmer was Director of Public Prosecutions when it was decided there was insufficient evidence to charge Savile, but he was not the reviewing lawyer on the case.

fact_check_explanation_title: Covid-19 is the underlying cause of death for most people who die with it
fact_check_explanation_summary: ONS data suggests Covid-19 is the underlying cause of death for 94% of people who die with it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Alcohol-based hand sanitiser cannot catch fire, without a spark, just because it's in a hot car
fact_check_explanation_summary: Hand sanitiser can only ignite at temperatures found in a hot car if there is a spark.

fact_check_explanation_title: Footballers aren’t banned from wearing the poppy
fact_check_explanation_summary: The poppy has always been allowed in the Premier League. It was banned in international fixtures but this ban has been lifted.

fact_check_explanation_title: More people have probably been killed by coronavirus than were killed during the Blitz
fact_check_explanation_summary: An image being shared online is a fair reflection of what we know about the death tolls from Covid-19 and the Blitz.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does any country have 'a functioning track and trace app'?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Boris Johnson claimed no country currently has a functioning Covid-19 track and trace app.

fact_check_explanation_title: This honeycomb pattern was made by bees, but it was no accident
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture was originally attributed to bees at a National Trust property, but actually seems to come from a beekeeper who partly curated the pattern.

fact_check_explanation_title: Police have not warned the public about face masks doused in chemicals
fact_check_explanation_summary: Viral Facebook posts falsely claim criminals are handing out face masks doused in chemicals that cause unconsciousness so they can rob houses.

fact_check_explanation_title: Many French care workers will get a tax-free bonus of up to £1,340 for working during the pandemic
fact_check_explanation_summary: Those in the most heavily affected areas will get up to £1,340 and the rest will get up to £890.

fact_check_explanation_title: Black Lives Matter Scotland say they did not produce “Kill a White On Sight” stickers
fact_check_explanation_summary: The group have said they do not support the message of the stickers.

fact_check_explanation_title: Marcus Rashford did not tweet this at Katie Hopkins
fact_check_explanation_summary: The footballer did not reply when she tweeted at him.

fact_check_explanation_title: This is what has happened with student nurses who volunteered to work for the NHS early
fact_check_explanation_summary: Final year nursing students were asked to start being paid to work for the NHS early, but now that is ending.

fact_check_explanation_title: No, the government is not proposing to inject the public with tracking microchips
fact_check_explanation_summary: Boris Johnson did not write a letter asking the public for their thoughts on mandatory RFID microchips.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson overstates number of schools with returning students
fact_check_explanation_summary: Boris Johnson was wrong to say that 97% of primary schools which report data had kids coming back. The figure on the day he was speaking was 69%.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence to back up these claims about fluoride
fact_check_explanation_summary: Fluoride is added to toothpaste and water to help prevent tooth decay. The only potential negative effect of fluoride at levels recommended in the UK is teeth discolouration.

fact_check_explanation_title: Public transport use higher than transport minister claimed
fact_check_explanation_summary: Grant Shapps claimed use of public transport is at 5% of its usual levels, but government figures show it is actually much higher.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson incorrect to say Keir Starmer is “completely wrong” about past trends in child poverty
fact_check_explanation_summary: Mr Starmer said 600,000 more children are in poverty than in 2012, which is correct according to government data on children in low income households.

fact_check_explanation_title: A Norwegian-British research paper doesn’t claim the virus causing Covid-19 was man-made
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is still no evidence to suggest that the new coronavirus was man-made.

fact_check_explanation_title: Some children with no recourse to public funds are eligible for free school meals
fact_check_explanation_summary: A question at PMQs by Labour MP Stephen Timms suggested this wasn’t the case. Free school meal eligibility has been temporarily extended to some of these children.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Covid-19 track and trace app has not been automatically downloaded onto people’s phones
fact_check_explanation_summary: “COVID-19 exposure notifications” is not an app—it is an API that can work with tracing apps if they are downloaded.

fact_check_explanation_title: What did lockdown rules say when these Labour MPs are claimed to have broken them?
fact_check_explanation_summary: These Labour MPs have either apologised for or defended their actions during lockdown.

fact_check_explanation_title: Yes, patients were discharged to care homes without Covid-19 tests
fact_check_explanation_summary: Until 15 April there was no requirement to test patients being discharged from hospitals to care homes for Covid-19 in England.

fact_check_explanation_title: This video of protesters in London chanting “We’re racist and that’s the way we like it” is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The audio has been taken from a video of racist Chelsea fans in Paris in 2015.

fact_check_explanation_title: There were no stabbings reported at protests in London over the weekend
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Met police have confirmed no stabbings happened at the protests.

fact_check_explanation_title: A viral Facebook post about 52 free horses is a repost from 2011
fact_check_explanation_summary: Similar posts have been circulating online since a genuine appeal in 2011.

fact_check_explanation_title: A viral post on autopsies, Italy and the new coronavirus has many inaccuracies
fact_check_explanation_summary: Covid-19 is not caused by bacteria.

fact_check_explanation_title: Half of these images of injured police officers are not from recent Black Lives Matter protests
fact_check_explanation_summary: The images include photos from a pro-Tommy Robinson protest, a far-right protest, and one against David Cameron.

fact_check_explanation_title: This person isn’t the one from viral footage of someone trying to burn the Cenotaph’s Union Jack
fact_check_explanation_summary: They are two different people.

fact_check_explanation_title: Some of these figures comparing the cost of the government job retention scheme to other government spending are wrong.
fact_check_explanation_summary: The furlough scheme is estimated to cost £14 billion per month.

fact_check_explanation_title: The government updated total Covid-19 death data with April and May deaths confirmed by non-NHS labs
fact_check_explanation_summary: The cumulative deaths total increased by 445 more than the daily increase in coronavirus deaths.

fact_check_explanation_title: Be wary of social media posts comparing fatality rates in confirmed Covid-19 cases
fact_check_explanation_summary: These figures don’t count the large numbers of people who’ve had the disease but haven’t been tested.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim by Independent SAGE about Covid-19 infections in children is based on unclear evidence
fact_check_explanation_summary: Research literature doesn’t suggest that children are as likely as adults to become infected and carry the virus.

fact_check_explanation_title: The limits of what we can say about early lockdowns
fact_check_explanation_summary: Analysis comparing countries’ excess deaths tallies based on when they locked down needs to be put into context.

fact_check_explanation_title: What counts as essential travel during the Covid-19 lockdown?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We were asked by readers to explain what travel is permitted under the new coronavirus guidance.

fact_check_explanation_title: New antibody tests are not 100% accurate on all measures
fact_check_explanation_summary: It was reported that new antibody tests were 100% accurate, but evaluation of the tests by Public Health England shows this is not the case.

fact_check_explanation_title: What is ‘shielding’ and who needs to do it?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Readers have asked Full Fact to look into the guidance around ‘shielding’ during the Covid-19 pandemic .

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim that extending the Brexit transition period could cost £380 billion is not credible
fact_check_explanation_summary: Most studies into the economic impacts of Brexit show leaving the customs union and single market will mean the UK economy is smaller compared to remaining.

fact_check_explanation_title: Two metres is a little better than one
fact_check_explanation_summary: New research shows that keeping your distance does protect against coronavirus

fact_check_explanation_title: Chris Whitty did not personally receive millions of pounds from the Bill & Melinda Gates foundation
fact_check_explanation_summary: The money was given to the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, where Chris Whitty worked.

fact_check_explanation_title: We still don’t know if the UK does the most Covid-19 tests in Europe
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister claimed “we test more than virtually any country in Europe.” The UK appears to test more than most.

fact_check_explanation_title: This is how you can verify you are actually being contacted by the government’s Test and Trace service
fact_check_explanation_summary: Tracers will not ask for personal information such as financial details or online logins.

fact_check_explanation_title: The figure of 1 million children not returning to school is uncertain
fact_check_explanation_summary: Teachers were surveyed between 7 and 17 May on whether they thought families would send their children back to school when they reopened.

fact_check_explanation_title: SAGE did not advise against reopening schools on 1 June
fact_check_explanation_summary: This was the opinion of the Independent SAGE, who are a different group of scientists.

fact_check_explanation_title: No, the Mail didn’t use an old photo of Jeremy Corbyn to claim he wasn’t social distancing on his birthday
fact_check_explanation_summary: The photo is from 2020 as the Mail claimed and first appeared on a Facebook group for canal boat owners.

fact_check_explanation_title: Covid-19 may not be a “high consequence infectious disease”, but it is a real emergency
fact_check_explanation_summary: The new coronavirus can cause many thousands of deaths even though Covid-19 is no longer considered a “high consequence infectious disease”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can hand sanitiser catch fire in a hot car?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts suggest that an image shows the aftermath of a fire started by a bottle of alcohol antibacterial hand gel left in a hot car.

fact_check_explanation_title: Patent application 060606 does not mention inserting microchips into the body
fact_check_explanation_summary: This patent application appears to be for some sort of wearable activity tracker.

fact_check_explanation_title: What did the lockdown rules say when Dominic Cummings travelled to Durham?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some of Dominic Cummings’s choices were not specifically permitted by the guidelines, and it appears that he did not fully explore the alternatives, as was required.

fact_check_explanation_title: 50 French schools have closed due to coronavirus cases, but it is likely these infections happened before schools reopened
fact_check_explanation_summary: It is still too early to know the effect of school openings will have on coronavirus cases in France.

fact_check_explanation_title: Dominic Cummings’ sister is not director of company that runs the NHS track and trace app
fact_check_explanation_summary: An Alice Cummings is a director at Idox but she’s not his sister and the company has nothing to do with the app.

fact_check_explanation_title: It is not clear that 19 million people have already had the new coronavirus
fact_check_explanation_summary: New findings that 19 million people in the UK have already had the new coronavirus are very uncertain.

fact_check_explanation_title: A 2019 Dominic Cummings blog post was recently edited to explicitly mention a coronavirus
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Wayback Machine website shows the edit being made in mid-April 2020.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim that 7.7% of UK goods exports go to the EU is a big underestimate
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Express has misquoted figures on the UK goods trade with the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Dominic Cummings is not in this picture of the Bullingdon Club
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post shared on social media incorrectly claims Dominic Cummings is pictured as a member of the Bullingdon Club alongside David Cameron and Boris Johnson.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much have healthcare workers paid through the immigration health surcharge?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister claimed £900 million had been raised by the surcharge, but there was some confusion as to whether he was only referring to contributions from health workers.

fact_check_explanation_title: Daily Express diabetes and coronavirus deaths headline is misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: A quarter of patients who died with Covid-19 in English hospitals had diabetes. But that doesn’t mean that all these deaths were linked to diabetes.

fact_check_explanation_title: The government says 125,000 workers in care settings and 118,000 care home residents have been tested for Covid-19
fact_check_explanation_summary: In PMQs, Boris Johnson misspoke by saying 125,000 care home staff and 118,000 care home workers have been tested for coronavirus.

fact_check_explanation_title: No, Italy hasn’t recounted its coronavirus data and found that most died from other diseases
fact_check_explanation_summary: Official data shows that most people who died from Covid-19 had other conditions, not that these conditions were the real cause of their death.

fact_check_explanation_title: We don’t know exactly how many NHS workers have died from Covid-19
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures on the number of NHS workers who have died from the new coronavirus are incomplete.

fact_check_explanation_title: Animals and the origins of the new coronavirus
fact_check_explanation_summary: It is thought that the new coronavirus originated from bats and was transmitted to humans through another animal.

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s likely that over 100,000 people have entered the UK since the lockdown began
fact_check_explanation_summary: Government estimates on arrivals are opaque, but recent figures suggest 100,000 is an underestimate.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hydroxychloroquine is not used as a treatment for radiation sickness
fact_check_explanation_summary: There isn’t yet reliable evidence that this drug, or chloroquine, cures Covid-19 patients either.

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s not right that you’re more likely to drown than die of Covid-19 if you’re under 60 with no health problems
fact_check_explanation_summary: It was claimed on Question Time that you are more likely to drown than die of Covid-19 if you are under 60 with no health conditions.

fact_check_explanation_title: This viral UK Facebook post claiming 31 million job losses probably refers to the USA
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral post shared by a UK Facebook user claims 31 million people have lost jobs in the last five weeks. This isn’t correct for the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Nurse pay up over the past few years but down on 2010
fact_check_explanation_summary: Matt Hancock claimed nurse salaries had risen significantly in recent years. These increases don’t counterbalance falls in real terms pay over the past decade.

fact_check_explanation_title: German police cannot vaccinate people by force
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on Facebook wrongly claims that German police can come into homes and forcibly vaccinate people.

fact_check_explanation_title: Currently, people in independent living housing aren’t automatically eligible for coronavirus testing
fact_check_explanation_summary: Testing for asymptomatic people is currently only available for people in regulated care homes and in the NHS.

fact_check_explanation_title: Far more people have died of Covid-19 in the UK than in Japan
fact_check_explanation_summary: Far more people have died of Covid-19 in the UK than in Japan, but we don’t yet know why

fact_check_explanation_title: No, Shamima Begum is not back in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: There's no evidence to suggest this is true.

fact_check_explanation_title: We don’t know the true Covid-19 survival rate yet
fact_check_explanation_summary: We don’t have a good idea of how many people have had Covid-19 yet, so don’t know how many have survived it.

fact_check_explanation_title: These patents are not for the new coronavirus or its vaccine
fact_check_explanation_summary: The patents are for other forms of coronavirus and show no evidence Covid-19 was manufactured.

fact_check_explanation_title: The 1918 pandemic did have a deadly second wave, but not due to quarantine being lifted
fact_check_explanation_summary: The 1918 outbreak is considered one of the most deadly pandemics in history.

fact_check_explanation_title: Osama Bin Laden pictures with US politicians are fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: Pictures of the terrorist with Barack Obama, Hillary Clinton and Condoleeza Rice are not real.

fact_check_explanation_title: Police officers around the world have died from Covid-19
fact_check_explanation_summary: This post incorrectly claims that there are no reports of police officers dying from Covid-19.

fact_check_explanation_title: This photo of Brighton was taken during the coronavirus lockdown
fact_check_explanation_summary: Metadata from the photo showed it was taken when social distancing rules were in place.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can children transmit the new coronavirus to other people?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The evidence to date suggests that it is uncommon for children to transmit the new coronavirus. Widespread antibody testing is required to fully understand this issue.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can you go to work if your partner works in a ward treating Covid-19 patients?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It depends on your specific circumstances.

fact_check_explanation_title: Testing positive for Covid-19 doesn’t necessarily mean you’ll get ill
fact_check_explanation_summary: The ONS found there was no evidence that the rate of infection differed by age, but being infected doesn’t necessarily mean you become ill.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claims about who’s paid by the state aren’t very meaningful
fact_check_explanation_summary: People can be supported by the state in lots of ways, by employment, benefits or pensions.

fact_check_explanation_title: Lockdown rules mean you can’t meet someone from another household if you’ve got your child with you
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve been asked whether parents can meet people from other households with their child. This is not currently allowed.

fact_check_explanation_title: This tweet misreports an interview with Keir Starmer
fact_check_explanation_summary: The interview was about changes to how child sexual abuse is prosecuted

fact_check_explanation_title: Covid-19 deaths in care homes have started to fall
fact_check_explanation_summary: Keir Starmer was right, in one way, to say that deaths in care homes were rising. In another way, Boris Johnson was right to disagree.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can I move to a different home during lockdown?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is different guidance on this depending on the circumstances.

fact_check_explanation_title: Government guidance did say it was ‘very unlikely’ people in care homes would be infected with Covid-19
fact_check_explanation_summary: Boris Johnson was incorrect to say government guidance had not said it was ‘very unlikely’ that people in care homes would get the new coronavirus

fact_check_explanation_title: Why were there mixed messages over returning to work in lockdown?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Initial reports suggested some people would be expected to return to work on Monday rather than Wednesday.

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s true that recent changes to lockdown rules are slightly different throughout the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK government can only change lockdown rules for England.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson mistakenly said that Covid-19 could be monitored through the water supply
fact_check_explanation_summary: When talking about monitoring Covid-19, Boris Johnson referred to detecting it in the water supply when he meant to say wastewater.

fact_check_explanation_title: This little girl called Alice is not missing from your area
fact_check_explanation_summary: This is an ongoing scam. Do not click the link.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral Facebook post is wrong on deaths in first three months of 2020
fact_check_explanation_summary: The statistics in this Facebook post are wrong. Many people are dying of Covid-19 in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: New lockdown guidance doesn’t mean you can see both parents at once
fact_check_explanation_summary: Dominic Raab was wrong to say that people can see both their parents at once as long as they all social distance.

fact_check_explanation_title: Two police forces did not use the same photo to illustrate two different lockdown crimes
fact_check_explanation_summary: Cumbria Road Police said that the picture is from an incident they dealt with.

fact_check_explanation_title: This post about Covid-19 and blood clotting conditions contains inaccuracies
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some people with severe Covid-19 develop blood clotting problems, but this doesn’t mean that pneumonia is a misdiagnosis.

fact_check_explanation_title: A scientific review did not conclude that there are no cases of children transmitting the new coronavirus
fact_check_explanation_summary: Newspapers have incorrectly reported the results of a review of evidence relating to Covid-19 in children.

fact_check_explanation_title: Health Secretary uses Facebook poll to estimate coronavirus tracing app take-up
fact_check_explanation_summary: Facebook polls cannot be said to represent the wider population.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Control of Diseases Act was not changed in April to say you can be forcibly vaccinated
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no Covid-19 vaccine yet, but this law does not say you can be forced to get the injection.

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post on Ireland’s plans for exiting lockdown goes viral
fact_check_explanation_summary: The post says phases will start on 18 May, 8 June, 29 June, 20 July and 10 August.

fact_check_explanation_title: Official advice says handwashing is better at protecting against coronavirus than gloves
fact_check_explanation_summary: The best preventive measure is still regular hand washing.

fact_check_explanation_title: There’s no evidence immigrants caused a PPE shipment to be destroyed at Dover
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Home Office says these claims are totally false.

fact_check_explanation_title: It's incorrect to say flu vaccines don't work
fact_check_explanation_summary: An argument that the flu vaccine doesn’t work because the flu has not been eliminated doesn’t add up.

fact_check_explanation_title: A doctor claims his contract was terminated after talking about PPE shortages to the press
fact_check_explanation_summary: Concern that the story was incorrect led to prominent posts on social media being deleted.

fact_check_explanation_title: It seems unlikely the accounts resharing a viral post about the UK press are bots
fact_check_explanation_summary: The viral message began on Facebook in late April.

fact_check_explanation_title: What we know, and what we don’t, about the true coronavirus death toll
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s too soon to compare the UK’s coronavirus death toll with other countries

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the government really hit 100,000 tests a day, and what happens next?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Full Fact has looked into the reality behind the government’s testing target.

fact_check_explanation_title: Some PPE exported to the EU could have been used in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: At PMQs Dominic Raab was right to point out it isn’t necessarily the case that PPE exported from the UK could have been used here. But some PPE exported to …

fact_check_explanation_title: The government hasn’t provided evidence for its claim that 15,000 arrive per day into the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims from the Health Secretary that 15,000 passengers are still arriving in the UK per day during the coronavirus lockdown haven’t been backed up.

fact_check_explanation_title: A Nobel Prize-winning immunologist has not said coronavirus is manmade, as claimed
fact_check_explanation_summary: Professor Tasuku Honjo said: “I am greatly saddened that my name and that of Kyoto University have been used to spread false accusations and misinformation”.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Maytrix Group receives no money from Captain Tom’s fundraiser
fact_check_explanation_summary: The company, which Captain Tom’s daughter is a director of, helped set the fundraiser up but receives no money from it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Here’s what you should know about photos where people look like they aren’t social distancing
fact_check_explanation_summary: Here’s what to keep in mind when looking at photos of crowds.

fact_check_explanation_title: This letter about inflammation in children is real but only refers to a handful of cases
fact_check_explanation_summary: So far there have been very few cases, but doctors have been warned to look out for these symptoms in children.

fact_check_explanation_title: A picture of one boy who died has been mistakenly used to cover stories on the deaths of two other boys
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts on Facebook suggest a media conspiracy because a picture of a deceased Irish teenager has been used to illustrate the deaths of two other boys.

fact_check_explanation_title: Some context for the claims that Romanian seasonal workers are taking UK workers’ jobs
fact_check_explanation_summary: Despite optimistic reports, Britain is still in need of skilled farm labour.

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s incorrect that the money raised by Captain Tom is only going towards the NHS in England
fact_check_explanation_summary: The money will be spent on charities in each of the four UK nations.

fact_check_explanation_title: No, Jennifer Saunders did not write this statement about PPE shortages
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post about NHS PPE shortages has been falsely attributed to Jennifer Saunders.

fact_check_explanation_title: Event 201 didn’t predict the Covid-19 pandemic
fact_check_explanation_summary: Event 201 was an event organised in October 2019 to simulate what might happen if there was a “high-level” pandemic.

fact_check_explanation_title: Figure comparing arena capacity to Covid-19 deaths needs context
fact_check_explanation_summary: There have been around 21,000 deaths in UK hospitals of people who’ve tested positive for the new coronavirus.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK branches of McDonald’s did not reopen on 27 April
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post has incorrectly claimed that McDonald’s branches in the UK reopened on Monday 27 April.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake stories wrongly claim Elisa Granato, one of the UK's first Covid-19 vaccine trial participants, has died
fact_check_explanation_summary: False news reports wrongly claim that Dr Elisa Granato, one of the first participants in a UK Covid-19 vaccine trial, has died. She is not dead.

fact_check_explanation_title: Total deaths in the UK in 2020 have now risen above the deaths during the same period in 2018
fact_check_explanation_summary: Total deaths registered in England and Wales for 2020 so far are below 2018, but the weekly death figure is still well above what it has been.

fact_check_explanation_title: It is not true that worldwide terrorism has stopped while western countries fight Covid-19
fact_check_explanation_summary: A widely shared post on Facebook claims international terrorism has ‘stopped’ as a result of western countries being ‘busy’ fighting the new coronavirus.

fact_check_explanation_title: The 1918 Philadelphia parade fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 1918 Philadelphia saw 200,000 attend a parade, despite reports of influenza in the city. After the parade, cases skyrocketed.

fact_check_explanation_title: How does UK foreign aid spending compare to NHS donations
fact_check_explanation_summary: UK foreign aid spending was £15 billion in 2019. Donations to the NHS Charities Together totalled £457 million last year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Covid-19 prevention claims put down to Unicef go viral again
fact_check_explanation_summary: Gargling with salt, putting clothes out in the sun, and ‘any mask’ will not stop you getting Covid-19.

fact_check_explanation_title: Any health secretary will be the owner of this NHS supply company, not just Matt Hancock
fact_check_explanation_summary: The company was created by the Department of Health.

fact_check_explanation_title: An image of a dog vaccine for a different coronavirus has gone viral
fact_check_explanation_summary: There isn’t a vaccine for the new coronavirus yet.

fact_check_explanation_title: This video of a man wiping his hands on a public lift was not filmed in Wales
fact_check_explanation_summary: The video is from Bangkok.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral claim about France’s tax-free health care workers bonus needs context
fact_check_explanation_summary: Care workers in nursing homes will get a bonus but we don’t yet know how much.

fact_check_explanation_title: There is no evidence supporting claims about a government-run network of fake NHS Twitter accounts
fact_check_explanation_summary: Viral posts on social media claim to have uncovered a network of fake Twitter accounts created to post pro-government messages. There is no evidence for this.

fact_check_explanation_title: Not all New Zealand MPs have been ordered to take a pay cut, and UK MPs have not awarded themselves a £10,000 bonus
fact_check_explanation_summary: The New Zealand pay cut does not apply to all MPs, and UK MPs can only claim extra money for office costs.

fact_check_explanation_title: JustGiving are not keeping £2m from donations to Captain Tom
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts on social media claim the platform kept money raised by the veteran and intended for NHS Charities Together.

fact_check_explanation_title: The German government hasn’t billed China for “coronavirus damages”
fact_check_explanation_summary: An article in the Express suggested the German government had billed China for “coronavirus damages.” The bill was mocked up by a German newspaper.

fact_check_explanation_title: The nurses that treated Boris Johnson for coronavirus are real UK nurses
fact_check_explanation_summary: Both are registered nurses working at St Thomas’s hospital.

fact_check_explanation_title: No, the UK didn’t turn down 50,000 ventilators offered by the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK did not join an EU scheme to stockpile medical equipment. However, even if the UK had joined this scheme, the budget would deliver nowhere near 50,000 ventilators across …

fact_check_explanation_title: Facebook post on how to make a silent 999 call is misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: If you can’t talk on an emergency call, this is what to do.

fact_check_explanation_title: Government misses one of its Covid-19 test targets
fact_check_explanation_summary: Government committed to 25,000 tests a day by mid-April, later relaxed to “mid to late April”. Latest figures show 18,665 tests a day.

fact_check_explanation_title: The NHS is not asking people with type O negative blood to go to donate at Manchester Royal Infirmary
fact_check_explanation_summary: NHS Blood and Transplant have said that the post asking for donors in Manchester is fake.

fact_check_explanation_title: False posts that suggest Boris Johnson didn’t have Covid-19 are based on a blog post now labelled as satire
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claims first appeared in the Dorset Eye and now say they may be satire, but some people seem to have believed them.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim that Conservatives voted against a nurse pay rise needs some context
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2017 the Conservatives voted against a Labour amendment aiming to end the public sector pay rise cap, before ending it themselves anyway for the next financial year.

fact_check_explanation_title: How does the new coronavirus affect pregnancy?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is currently no evidence to suggest that pregnant women or their unborn babies are at higher risk from Covid-19.

fact_check_explanation_title: If you need the police but can’t talk, dial 999 from a mobile, then 55 when prompted and don’t hang up
fact_check_explanation_summary: If you can’t talk but need the police, you can dial 55 when prompted on a 999 call from a mobile.

fact_check_explanation_title: Here’s where those 5G and coronavirus conspiracy theories came from
fact_check_explanation_summary: Conspiracy theorists have been peddling 5G myths for a while now, we’ve only just started to listen.

fact_check_explanation_title: The 5G And Beyond Act is not a British law
fact_check_explanation_summary: The 5G And Beyond Act is not a British law. Nor is it about speeding up 5G installation.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do face masks protect against the new coronavirus?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The limited evidence suggests that wearing face masks in public, may help to reduce the spread of the new coronavirus specifically from people who have the virus but aren’t showing …

fact_check_explanation_title: This viral coronavirus breathing advice needs context
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral video on how to relieve Covid-19 symptoms won’t necessarily give appropriate advice in all cases.

fact_check_explanation_title: This viral voice message about ambulances shared on WhatsApp is inaccurate
fact_check_explanation_summary: The message, which says ambulances won’t be sent to people struggling to breathe, and the government will prevent all outside exercise from “next week”, is incorrect.

fact_check_explanation_title: Most people do not need to keep their cats indoors during the new coronavirus outbreak
fact_check_explanation_summary: British Veterinary Association advice to keep cats indoors applies only to cats from infected or self-isolating households.

fact_check_explanation_title: No, a survey didn’t find a majority of doctors saying that hydroxychloroquine is the most effective treatment for Covid-19
fact_check_explanation_summary: The poll was not representative of all doctors. 37% of doctors involved in Covid-19 treatment listed these drugs as among the most -effective treatments.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many people have been evicted as a result of coronavirus?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Housing charity Shelter says there has been a spike in evictions due to all reasons, though not as large a spike as found in a recent survey.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claims about Swansea nurses dying in intensive care were false
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim that three nurses had died in a Swansea ITU, presumably from Covid-19, was false.

fact_check_explanation_title: What do we know about cats and the new coronavirus?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A tiger has tested positive for Covid-19, but there’s currently no evidence that cats (big or small) can pass the new coronavirus to humans.

fact_check_explanation_title: A tweet claiming the Prime Minister has died is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: This was claimed by a fake BBC Breaking News Twitter account.

fact_check_explanation_title: £20 notes don’t have a secret message about 5G and coronavirus
fact_check_explanation_summary: The so-called 5G tower is actually Margate lighthouse, and there’s no evidence 5G can hurt you.

fact_check_explanation_title: This video of body bags in a hospital was not filmed in St Mary’s, London
fact_check_explanation_summary: The hospital trust confirmed to us that it wasn’t filmed at St Mary’s and fact checkers have found it was filmed in Ecuador.

fact_check_explanation_title: This video supposedly showing Covid-19 patients at St Mary’s Hospital, London was actually filmed in Madrid
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video sent by a reader was claimed to show Covid-19 patients lying on the floor of St Mary’s Hospital, London. The video was actually filmed in two different Madrid …

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS Nightingale does not want art in the post
fact_check_explanation_summary: “Rainbows for Nightingale” was an unofficial appeal for art in the post that spread widely on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: McDonald’s is not reopening on 6 April in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral post claiming this has been debunked by McDonald’s.

fact_check_explanation_title: There is no plan to combat the new coronavirus with helicopters spraying disinfectant
fact_check_explanation_summary: Fake advice that five helicopters are about spray the streets with disinfectant has spread all over the world

fact_check_explanation_title: Ignore these pranks on Facebook saying lockdown will be lifted in the next few days
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims circulating on April Fool’s Day have claimed the UK lockdown could be lifted in the next few days. That’s not correct.

fact_check_explanation_title: A mobile phone mast was relocated due to local concerns about school cancer cases
fact_check_explanation_summary: A mobile phone mast was relocated due to local concerns about school cancer cases. But there is no evidence to suggest the mobile phone mast caused the cancers.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Great Pyramid’s location isn’t as spooky as this post makes out
fact_check_explanation_summary: A line of latitude going through the Great Pyramid in Egypt does match the speed of light, but about 20,000 other lines go through the pyramid as well.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photo circulating of busy mosque was taken before lockdown
fact_check_explanation_summary: The photo was taken before the government ordered mosques, churches and other places of worship to close.

fact_check_explanation_title: 5G is not accelerating the spread of the new coronavirus
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no evidence to suggest that 5G is increasing the spread of the new coronavirus.

fact_check_explanation_title: It's very rare to catch Covid-19 twice
fact_check_explanation_summary: The new coronavirus seems to produce a normal antibody response, which makes people immune afterwards, at least for a while.

fact_check_explanation_title: These trucks aren’t carrying the bodies of Covid-19 victims, and the picture wasn’t taken in Italy
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on Facebook claimed to show military trucks carrying dead bodies in Italy. The image shows the French army on operations in Paris.

fact_check_explanation_title: Good news coronavirus list needs context
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral list containing good news stories about Covid-19 is largely accurate, but needs some context.

fact_check_explanation_title: Home Covid-19 tests will not be readily available to the public by the end of March
fact_check_explanation_summary: You probably won’t be able to buy a new coronavirus test from Boots by the end of March.

fact_check_explanation_title: We don’t know how many people in the UK have Covid-19 and the symptom tracker app doesn’t tell us
fact_check_explanation_summary: 10% of the 650,000 people who have signed up to track their Covid-19 symptoms on a new app have symptoms. That doesn’t mean 10% of the UK has Covid-19.

fact_check_explanation_title: We don’t yet know if anti-malaria drug chloroquine is a cure for Covid-19
fact_check_explanation_summary: People have been claiming that the drug, and a similar one hydroxychloroquine cures the virus. We don’t know if that’s true yet.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral list of UK lockdown rules is not right
fact_check_explanation_summary: A list of rules for the UK Covid-19 lockdown has been widely shared on Facebook, but is not accurate.

fact_check_explanation_title: Anyone can make an Extinction Rebellion sticker
fact_check_explanation_summary: There have been numerous instances of the Extinction Rebellion logo being used to mock the group or distort its message.

fact_check_explanation_title: US scientists have not created a vaccine for the new coronavirus
fact_check_explanation_summary: Many scientists are working on a vaccine to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus, but it will likely be 18 months before it is available for public use.

fact_check_explanation_title: This text message is not an official government communication
fact_check_explanation_summary: While people have received a genuine text from the government about the new coronavirus lockdown rules, one about monitoring their movement is fake.

fact_check_explanation_title: How you can fact check claims about Covid-19
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s a lot of misinformation about Covid-19, so Full Fact is sharing its top tips on how to check if a claim is true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Xbox and PlayStation servers are not being shut down during school hours
fact_check_explanation_summary: This is not a real news story.

fact_check_explanation_title: These numbers about Covid-19 deaths in the UK and Italy are broadly accurate
fact_check_explanation_summary: Not enough is known about the new coronavirus to say that the number of deaths in the UK will grow at the same rates as Italy.

fact_check_explanation_title: There’s still no evidence that you can catch the new coronavirus from your pet
fact_check_explanation_summary: Hundreds of thousands have shared claims on Facebook that pets don’t carry the virus.

fact_check_explanation_title: A government report didn’t say the countryside was “too white”
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government did publish a report about national parks, and parts of it discuss how to encourage black, Asian and minority ethnic people to visit these areas.

fact_check_explanation_title: Vladimir Putin did not say that all Russian people should stay at home or face five years in jail
fact_check_explanation_summary: Russia currently has no nationwide restrictions of this kind.

fact_check_explanation_title: Russia has not unleashed 500 lions to stop people going outdoors
fact_check_explanation_summary: This is a fake story that uses a picture of a lion in South Africa from 2016.

fact_check_explanation_title: An adoption centre did pause adoptions of rabbits for fear they’d be used as food, but there’s no evidence it’s widespread
fact_check_explanation_summary: The adoption centre said they were worried by a number of phone calls.

fact_check_explanation_title: This “quote” from the Italian Prime Minister about coronavirus is made up
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Italian Prime Minister has not said his country has exhausted all options to fight against the new coronavirus pandemic and has not pleaded with God to “rescue your people.” …

fact_check_explanation_title: This is a scam and is not from the government
fact_check_explanation_summary: This is a phishing scam.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral posts about Covid-19 symptoms contain false information
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts shared thousands of times on Facebook make false – and potentially harmful – claims about the new coronavirus.

fact_check_explanation_title: List of symptoms and how to prevent the new coronavirus contains inaccuracies
fact_check_explanation_summary: The viral post makes a number of claims about the symptoms of and ways to prevent Covid-19, but not all of them are right.

fact_check_explanation_title: Picture of 'army' in Clapham Junction is actually of students
fact_check_explanation_summary: A widely shared picture claims to be proof of the military taking to the streets in Clapham.

fact_check_explanation_title: Postal workers have been told to keep their distance when delivering parcels
fact_check_explanation_summary: Royal Mail staff will keep their distance when making deliveries. If the item needs a signature, the postman or postwoman will sign it on your behalf.

fact_check_explanation_title: There’s limited data on how many Covid-19 tests are being done globally, but the UK doesn’t rank third in the world
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no centralised data on the number of Covid-19 tests being conducted across the world.

fact_check_explanation_title: That ‘medical alert’ about severe Covid-19 cases in Cork due to anti-inflammatories is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: These claims appear to have originated from a fake message circulating in Ireland said to be from “Dr Tim”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: your new coronavirus questions answered
fact_check_explanation_summary: We asked readers to send in their questions about the new coronavirus to help sort the good information from the bad.

fact_check_explanation_title: There’s mixed evidence on whether people with Covid-19 should avoid ibuprofen
fact_check_explanation_summary: The French health minister warned people with the new coronavirus against taking ibuprofen.

fact_check_explanation_title: Drinking and gargling water will not cure the new coronavirus
fact_check_explanation_summary: The NHS advises people to drink water when they are ill with the new coronavirus, but this is not a treatment for the disease.

fact_check_explanation_title: Could the new coronavirus outbreak be stopped by warmer weather?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Not enough is known about the new coronavirus to say that it will disappear, or even have its spread reduced, in the UK as the temperature increases.

fact_check_explanation_title: The WHO has clarified that they aren't warning people against using paper money due to coronavirus
fact_check_explanation_summary: WHO advise the public to wash their hands after handling money, especially if handling or eating food.

fact_check_explanation_title: These claims about the new coronavirus and 5G are unfounded
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no evidence of a link between coronavirus and 5G.

fact_check_explanation_title: The government’s “£1.8 billion pay rise” from a US trade deal doesn’t outweigh the impacts of Brexit on wages
fact_check_explanation_summary: Analysis from the government estimates real wages after 15 years to be 6.4% less than had we stayed in the EU, but a US deal could counterbalance wages by 0.2%.

fact_check_explanation_title: Holding your breath is not an indicator of whether you have the new coronavirus, and drinking water doesn’t protect against it
fact_check_explanation_summary: Holding your breath is not an indicator of whether you have the new coronavirus, and drinking water doesn’t protect against it.

fact_check_explanation_title: What to do if you think you have the new coronavirus
fact_check_explanation_summary: If you think you may have the new coronavirus, the NHS advice for people throughout the UK is to call 111. Do not visit your GP surgery, pharmacy or hospital.

fact_check_explanation_title: What are the symptoms of the new coronavirus?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The symptoms of Covid-19, the disease caused by the new coronavirus, include a cough, high temperature and shortness of breath.

fact_check_explanation_title: Coronavirus graphics you may have been sent on WhatsApp are not actually from Unicef
fact_check_explanation_summary: Graphics containing false advice about the new coronavirus, with Unicef branding have been spreading online.

fact_check_explanation_title: A study has not claimed the new coronavirus was ‘genetically engineered for efficient spread in humans’
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Daily Express has wrongly reported the findings of new research which compared SARS-CoV-2 with other coronaviruses.

fact_check_explanation_title: How does the new coronavirus compare to influenza?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The World Health Organisation says the Covid-19 coronavirus spreads slower than the flu, but appears to have a higher mortality rate.

fact_check_explanation_title: Your pets almost certainly won’t give you Covid-19
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is a possibility that dogs and cats can test “weakly” positive for Covid-19, but there is no evidence that they can pass it on to humans.

fact_check_explanation_title: There’s no evidence that the new coronavirus can survive on packages for 28 days
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no reason to believe that the new coronavirus can survive for long periods on packages from affected areas.

fact_check_explanation_title: Here is the transcript of what Boris Johnson said on This Morning about the new coronavirus
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims the Prime Minister said the country should take the new coronavirus “on the chin” and allow it to spread through the population have been taken out of context.

fact_check_explanation_title: Experts say soap and water is preferable, but high alcohol sanitiser does work
fact_check_explanation_summary: Experts say soap and water is preferable, but high alcohol sanitiser does work.

fact_check_explanation_title: This is not a vaccine for the 2019 coronavirus
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are many different types of coronavirus, and they can affect humans or animals.

fact_check_explanation_title: There’s not enough evidence to say it’s as easy to buy drugs as pizza in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: The head of a Home Office investigation into drug use in Britain claimed it is almost easier to buy drugs than pizza.

fact_check_explanation_title: 726 homeless people are estimated to have died in England and Wales in 2018
fact_check_explanation_summary: The figure is not around 700,000 as shadow chancellor John McDonnell said on the Andrew Marr show.

fact_check_explanation_title: What can you do to avoid the new coronavirus?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The official guidance recommends washing your hands with soap and water often for at least 20 seconds, and always when you arrive at home or work, and eat or handle …

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s true these things kill more people each day than Covid-19 has so far
fact_check_explanation_summary: Cancer, diabetes, and snake bites all cause more deaths than Covid-19 has so far.

fact_check_explanation_title: A rash is now listed as a possible symptom of the new coronavirus
fact_check_explanation_summary: Symptoms include a persistent cough, and high temperature.

fact_check_explanation_title: Most of these NHS jobs are classed as “skilled” under new immigration rules
fact_check_explanation_summary: The minimum eligible salary will be £20,480, but other criteria will also apply.

fact_check_explanation_title: No, Celine Dion didn’t wind her car window up while a fan was singing to her
fact_check_explanation_summary: Celine Dion didn’t wind her car window up at a singing fan. This video is edited. Celine Dion waited patiently as the fan sang ‘I Surrender’

fact_check_explanation_title: Gambling spend down since 2008 on average
fact_check_explanation_summary: Licensed gambling has grown 40% over the last decade. However, this is largely because before 2014 non-UK online gambling firms weren’t counted.

fact_check_explanation_title: Children aren’t immune from the new coronavirus
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that children can’t get Covid-19 are incorrect.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Kama Sutra is not the UK’s most popular book
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that the UK’s favourite books of the last three years include the Modern Kama Sutra and a scratch and sniff book about cannabis are based on limited data.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
fact_check_explanation_summary: The viral post makes a number of claims about the symptoms of and ways to prevent Covid-19, but not all of them are right.

fact_check_explanation_title: Context is needed in this article about offences committed prior to prison sentences
fact_check_explanation_summary: In prison sentences of less than six months, the average number of previous offences was 60 for females and 57 for males.

fact_check_explanation_title: Takeaways and restaurants are responsible for 8% of norovirus cases
fact_check_explanation_summary: Research estimates takeaways and restaurants are responsible for around 8% of the three million yearly norovirus cases in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: We fact checked claims about avoiding social contact and how you wash clothes in the face of the new coronavirus
fact_check_explanation_summary: An ‘essential guide’ to avoiding the new coronavirus by the Daily Mail includes several pieces of advice not recommended by the government.

fact_check_explanation_title: No, the Treasury doesn’t expect the economy to shrink if we sign a Canada-style deal with the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Treasury estimates that Brexit will cause GDP to grow more slowly than if we hadn’t left the EU, but not to shrink.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour hospital and acute care PFI contracts in England cost £1.4 billion in 2017/18
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims on Facebook overestimate the scale of Labour’s hospital PFI contracts.

fact_check_explanation_title: This little girl has not vanished from your local area
fact_check_explanation_summary: A fake article about a kidnapped girl appears to be an attempt to access a user’s Facebook account.

fact_check_explanation_title: Bus fares have risen faster than wages since 2010
fact_check_explanation_summary: Lisa Nandy said that bus fares have risen 60% in 10 years, which is correct using one estimate, but doesn’t take the change in wages into account.

fact_check_explanation_title: Most of these claims about Grenfell Tower are wrong
fact_check_explanation_summary: Grenfell Tower was not built by a Labour council.

fact_check_explanation_title: The NHS hasn’t advised people to stop shaking hands to avoid the Wuhan coronavirus
fact_check_explanation_summary: No advice on handshaking has been issued by NHS England or Public Health England in response to Wuhan coronavirus.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pre-cut onions are not dangerous
fact_check_explanation_summary: It is perfectly safe to keep chopped onions in the fridge for up to a week.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU regulations on dredging did not cause recent flooding
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no specific EU law on banning dredging, but while some governance does affect it, it does not prevent it.

fact_check_explanation_title: When arriving to an EU airport, which queue do I now use at passport control?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Continue to use the EU/EEA/Switzerland queue at European airports until the end of 2020.

fact_check_explanation_title: There wasn’t more polar ice “than ever” in 2015
fact_check_explanation_summary: There was not more ice than ever in 2015—the polar ice caps have been shrinking for decades.

fact_check_explanation_title: These quotes “predicting” coronavirus are from two different books
fact_check_explanation_summary: Read separately, the quotes do not sound much like the new Wuhan coronavirus at all.

fact_check_explanation_title: Shamima Begum has not secretly returned to Britain
fact_check_explanation_summary: Shamima Begum is living in a refugee camp in Syria, not in secret in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: This arrow is pointing at Egypt
fact_check_explanation_summary: The border between Israel and Egypt is commonly accepted as the transition from Africa to the Middle East.

fact_check_explanation_title: Einstein did argue the rich control communication and this damages democracy
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claiming Einstein warned in 1949 that the rich control communication and damage democracy is true.

fact_check_explanation_title: The images in this post about the rhino horn and ivory trade have been digitally altered but the scheme is real
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is a scheme to dye the inside of rhino horns pink, but this did not affect their outside appearance.

fact_check_explanation_title: Henry Kissinger has never given a speech about exterminating people with vaccines
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post claims that Henry Kissinger gave a speech on eugenics and vaccines to the Council on Eugenics. Neither the speech nor the council is real.

fact_check_explanation_title: The European Community supported Britain during the Falklands War
fact_check_explanation_summary: During the Falklands War, the European Community banned all weapons sales to, and imports from, Argentina.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many birds are chickens?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Around 4-12% of birds are poultry, but if you looked at mass rather than the number of birds, poultry would account for 70%.

fact_check_explanation_title: Kobe Bryant’s wife Vanessa has not died by suicide
fact_check_explanation_summary: A website purporting to be BBC News has falsely claimed Kobe Bryant’s wife Vanessa died by suicide.

fact_check_explanation_title: Kobe Bryant’s daughter has not died by suicide
fact_check_explanation_summary: A website purporting to be BBC News has falsely claimed Kobe Bryant’s daughter Natalia died by suicide.

fact_check_explanation_title: This is an image of one debate about the NHS Funding Bill
fact_check_explanation_summary: Bills go through many readings and debates which can be attended by varying groups of MPs.

fact_check_explanation_title: This is not a real photo of a family murder
fact_check_explanation_summary: This image has been doctored.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim about the Kray Twins and great train robbers’ prison releases are false
fact_check_explanation_summary: One Kray twin was released on compassionate grounds, and none of the Great Train Robbery convicts served the full 30 years.

fact_check_explanation_title: No, milk doesn’t make a poison when mixed with cough syrup
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral Facebook post claiming four children died after being given a toxic mix of milk and cough syrup is false. Mixing milk and cough syrup doesn’t form a poison.

fact_check_explanation_title: Iceland has not declared that all religions are mental disorders
fact_check_explanation_summary: A satirical article falsely claims Iceland has declared all religions to be mental disorders.

fact_check_explanation_title: You should generally wear a protective face mask with the coloured side pointing outwards
fact_check_explanation_summary: Wearing a protective mask the wrong way around can reduce its effectiveness.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson did write that “blue collar” men are likely to be drunk, criminal, aimless, feckless and hopeless
fact_check_explanation_summary: In a 1995 Spectator article, Boris Johnson wrote that ”blue collar” men are likely to be drunk, criminal, aimless, feckless and hopeless.

fact_check_explanation_title: MPs cannot claim £50 for breakfast as viral post claims
fact_check_explanation_summary: They can claim £25 for food bought during the day provided they are staying overnight outside of London and their constituency.

fact_check_explanation_title: MPs salaries have grown faster than starting salaries of nurses, teachers and police officers
fact_check_explanation_summary: Starting salaries for nurses, teachers and police officers have fallen since 2010 when you factor in inflation.

fact_check_explanation_title: Some pensioners will lose £70 a week, but Boris Johnson didn’t introduce the change
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some pensioners will lose £70 a week under reforms set out in 2007 Pensions Act.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral image about patents for viruses is misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims about patents existing for AIDS, Zika, SARS, swine flu and Ebola are misleading.

fact_check_explanation_title: Here’s what the books that “predicted” the Covid-19 coronavirus actually say
fact_check_explanation_summary: One is a sci-fi novel about a disease created in a lab outside of Wuhan, and another is a book of predictions that said a “pneumonia-like” illness would spread in …

fact_check_explanation_title: You can have freedom of movement outside the EU if you’re in the single market
fact_check_explanation_summary: Norway and some other countries follow the free movement rules of the single market without being EU members.

fact_check_explanation_title: Who are “economically inactive” people, and could they join the work force?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Economically inactive people don’t have a job, and they aren’t classed as unemployed because they’re not looking for or able to start a new job.

fact_check_explanation_title: Women who have had 10 or more sexual partners do not double their risk of getting cancer
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no evidence that having 10 or more sexual partners directly increases the risk of cancer for either gender.

fact_check_explanation_title: Whether wages have passed their pre-crisis level depends on whether you include bonuses
fact_check_explanation_summary: Average wages excluding bonuses have surpassed the 2008 peak, but wages including bonuses haven’t yet.

fact_check_explanation_title: The World Health Organisation did not know about the Covid-19 virus before the current outbreak
fact_check_explanation_summary: The World Health Organisation did not know about the Covid-19 pathogen before the current outbreak.

fact_check_explanation_title: Change in LGBT+ hate crime levels not as simple as Dawn Butler suggests
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are two sources of data on this type of hate crime, one estimates a 261% increase and the other a 40% decrease since around 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: Justice spending is down 25% since 2010, not 40%
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government did announce a real terms reduction of 40% to the Ministry of Justice but ultimately reduced funding by 25% between 2010/11 and 2019/20.

fact_check_explanation_title: Two men did go to prison for throwing bacon at a mosque, while a man was fined for burning poppies
fact_check_explanation_summary: However, it is unclear if Mr Choudhury’s fine came out of his benefits.

fact_check_explanation_title: There's no evidence that the 2019 coronavirus originated in a Chinese government laboratory
fact_check_explanation_summary: A new article written by Chinese scientists does not prove that the 2019 coronavirus outbreak came from bats in a government laboratory.

fact_check_explanation_title: Dettol hasn’t tested its products against the new Wuhan coronavirus yet
fact_check_explanation_summary: Coronavirus is a category of viruses that includes the common cold.

fact_check_explanation_title: Research suggesting health benefits of golf could also suggest benefits of being rich
fact_check_explanation_summary: Golfers in a study were less likely to die prematurely than other over 65s but the research didn’t prove that golf was the reason why.

fact_check_explanation_title: It is not illegal to drive with pyjamas on in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: The article presented as evidence of the new law in this claim is an April Fool’s joke.

fact_check_explanation_title: Poverty hasn’t skyrocketed in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Joseph Rowntree Foundation said “there has been little change in overall poverty levels for more than 15 years.”

fact_check_explanation_title: Scotland’s maths and science scores are falling in international tests but rising in national tests
fact_check_explanation_summary: Boris Johnson’s claims about education in Scotland are not all quite right.

fact_check_explanation_title: There are some mistakes in these figures about lung cancer diagnoses
fact_check_explanation_summary: The figures in this article are inaccurate, leading to exaggerated claims about late lung cancer diagnoses in A&E.

fact_check_explanation_title: Daily Mirror incorrectly reports the results of statins and blood pressure drugs study.
fact_check_explanation_summary: A study found that taking statins or blood pressure pills increased the likelihood of obesity by 82%, but the findings can’t be applied to the wider population.

fact_check_explanation_title: This image on benefits for pensioners and refugees is not correct
fact_check_explanation_summary: This viral image claims that pensioners can collect just a fifth of the benefits ‘illegal immigrants’ and refugees can. But how much can each group really get?

fact_check_explanation_title: These aren’t satellite images and they don’t show evidence of mass cremations in Wuhan
fact_check_explanation_summary: Images claiming to show high levels of sulphur dioxide above Wuhan are not based on real satellite data.

fact_check_explanation_title: Prisoners don’t have to pay the TV licence whereas most pensioners will soon have to
fact_check_explanation_summary: Prisoners who have a TV in their cell are exempt from the TV licence fee, but pay a weekly rental charge.

fact_check_explanation_title: The figures in this post give an inaccurate view of Britain
fact_check_explanation_summary: The figures in this post are either out of date or inaccurate in their claims. However, it is unlikely people are taking them seriously.

fact_check_explanation_title: Unpublished Home Office target needs explaining
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures reportedly briefed by the Home Office suggest that migration law change could cut unskilled EU migration by 90,000. That’s higher than the number of unskilled EU migrants coming to …

fact_check_explanation_title: One in seven parents don’t read to their 7-9 year-old for more than 15 minutes per week
fact_check_explanation_summary: Research found one in seven parents spend less than 15 minutes a week reading to their young children, but that doesn’t mean one in seven children are read to for …

fact_check_explanation_title: Universal Credit has not got 200,000 people into work
fact_check_explanation_summary: The prime minister is wrong to claim that a government prediction about the benefits of Universal Credit has already come true.

fact_check_explanation_title: There’s not enough evidence to say the net zero emissions target will be missed by 49 years
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour’s claim that net zero emissions won’t be reached until 2099 cannot be proved.

fact_check_explanation_title: Corbyn claim about Boris Johnson’s climate change scepticism needs context
fact_check_explanation_summary: Mr Johnson did not say that climate change in general is a primitive fear without foundation, but has expressed views sceptical of the scale of the human impact on the …

fact_check_explanation_title: The government sets the licence fee, not the BBC
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Sun was wrong to suggest the BBC had increased the licence fee. The government sets the licence fee.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Royal College of Nursing hasn’t told nurses to call women by gender-neutral terms
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Royal College of Nursing’s style guide recommended using the word “women” instead of “ladies”. This is for official RCN documentation and not advice to nurses.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK death rates have stayed the same since 2011
fact_check_explanation_summary: It is important to take the size and age structure of the population into account.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sir Iain Duncan Smith is wrong to say that only 15% of people ever move above low pay
