fact_check_explanation_summary: There are different ways to measure the number of people who exceed low-pay or low-skill work, but it is more than 15% during the course of a working life.

fact_check_explanation_title: Since 2010, the UK has granted protection to around 41,000 asylum seekers and refugees under the age of 18
fact_check_explanation_summary: At least 40% were accompanied by a parent or carer.

fact_check_explanation_title: Driving with an unsecured pet isn’t an offence, but driving carelessly is
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s not against the law to drive with your pet unsecured, but if the animal distracts you or you have an accident then this could be an offence.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson gets his numbers muddled on economic growth
fact_check_explanation_summary: While comparing economic growth to carbon emissions, Mr Johnson claimed the economy has grown 73% under this government. It has grown by around 20%.

fact_check_explanation_title: There is no patent for the Wuhan coronavirus
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no patent for the Wuhan coronavirus. Claims that Jacob Rothschild owns the patent are untrue.

fact_check_explanation_title: Brexit: What will change after 31 January?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The main thing you need to know about what will change after Brexit day is that most things will stay the same—for eleven months, at least.

fact_check_explanation_title: The makers of Dettol did not know about the new Wuhan coronavirus before the rest of us
fact_check_explanation_summary: Coronavirus is a category of viruses which includes the common cold, as well as the new Wuhan coronavirus.

fact_check_explanation_title: This company is based in Shanghai, not Wuhan
fact_check_explanation_summary: Authorities have not yet traced the origin of the new coronavirus outbreak.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Wuhan coronavirus has nothing to do with 5G
fact_check_explanation_summary: Lots of cities in China have 5G coverage, not just the city at the centre of the new coronavirus outbreak.

fact_check_explanation_title: The virus in this clinical study is not the coronavirus seen in China in 2019/2020
fact_check_explanation_summary: Facebook posts incorrectly claim a vaccine to the Wuhan coronavirus was trialled earlier this month. The study trialled a vaccine to MERS, a different type of coronavirus.

fact_check_explanation_title: A mistake did mean a town with a voting population of around 6,400 did have an election where 41,000 votes were counted
fact_check_explanation_summary: The error occurred due to block votes being counted for each individual rather than split between candidates.

fact_check_explanation_title: A patent for the coronavirus spreading in Wuhan was not applied for in 2015
fact_check_explanation_summary: Coronavirus is not one single virus: it’s a family of them.

fact_check_explanation_title: The poorest in UK are living longer, but it seems they feel worse
fact_check_explanation_summary: Newspapers go too far in saying that adults in low-income households are objectively less healthy than they used to be

fact_check_explanation_title: Alex Cunningham and Boris Johnson  both used the wrong figures about health inequality
fact_check_explanation_summary: Most men in Stockton live much longer than men in Ethiopia, but one ward is far worse off, and the gap in UK life expectancy is widening.

fact_check_explanation_title: There were 25,260 excess winter deaths across all ages in Great Britain last year
fact_check_explanation_summary: The figure has also been higher in recent years.

fact_check_explanation_title: These claims about the 2019 Labour conference are incorrect
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no evidence of these claims happening at the 2019 Labour conference.

fact_check_explanation_title: HS2 isn’t expected to cost as much as this post claims
fact_check_explanation_summary: The latest estimates have put the cost of HS2 at around £106 billion, which is lower than has been claimed recently online.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the “cost of Brexit” amounted to more than the UK’s total net contributions over 47 years?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Not quite. In real terms we paid £216 billion into the EU between 1973 and 2018, while the economic cost was estimated at £130 billion by 2019.

fact_check_explanation_title: A nearly empty House of Commons may not be a sign that no one cares
fact_check_explanation_summary: The House of Commons was nearly empty at the end of January 15 because this was an adjournment debate.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK’s adverts watchdog has banned a misleading advert about 5G
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Advertising Standards Authority banned an advert which made unsubstantiated claims about the health impacts of 5G.

fact_check_explanation_title: President Obama does not plan to govern Kenya next
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims this is the case are based on a joke article about Barack Obama wanting to be president of Kenya

fact_check_explanation_title: Mixing baby oil and iodine won’t remove body hair
fact_check_explanation_summary: Iodine and baby oil isn’t an alternative to shaving.

fact_check_explanation_title: This is not an official Extinction Rebellion sticker
fact_check_explanation_summary: This has been done by another group who make materials in the style of the climate activists.

fact_check_explanation_title: Japan does accept a small number of official refugees
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that Japan doesn’t take in any refugees are false.

fact_check_explanation_title: This Boris Johnson quote has been edited and taken out of context
fact_check_explanation_summary: Two sentences from an article written by Mr Johnson in a 2013 article arguing for and against Brexit have been edited together.

fact_check_explanation_title: There’s limited evidence that lie detectors will be effective on terror offenders
fact_check_explanation_summary: Lie detectors aren’t accurate, but that’s not the only measure of their worth.

fact_check_explanation_title: Quarter of private renters experience sickness over housing worries—but we don’t know if private renting is the cause
fact_check_explanation_summary: A quarter of private renters agree that housing worries have made them ill. The Guardian claimed private renting is the cause which confuses correlation and causation.

fact_check_explanation_title: This claim that 2,000 people have died waiting for benefits since a Universal Credit review was announced needs context
fact_check_explanation_summary: The estimate is an average based on how many people died between 2013 and 2018 waiting for a decision on their Personal Independence Payment decision.

fact_check_explanation_title: Jeremy Hunt muddled the numbers on botched surgeries
fact_check_explanation_summary: Jeremy Hunt said the NHS operates on the wrong part of someone’s body four times a day. It’s actually four times a week.

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s very unlikely that fewer knife offenders are facing jail
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims from Labour about knife crime sentencing aren’t comparing like-with-like.

fact_check_explanation_title: A Bill to change referendum rules came from one Lord, not the government
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Bill proposing changes to the rules around referendums has been put forward by a Conservative Lord, but has not been endorsed by the party or government.

fact_check_explanation_title: Up to 260 UK patients per year experience vision loss because of healthcare delays
fact_check_explanation_summary: Glaucoma is the most common main diagnosis for such patients.

fact_check_explanation_title: Finland is not going to have a four-day working week.
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim came from an informal proposal made by the Prime Minister when she was Minister of Transport.

fact_check_explanation_title: Migration drives the majority of UK population growth—exactly how much is debatable
fact_check_explanation_summary: Migration to and from the UK has directly accounted for about 60% of UK population growth since the turn of the century, or higher if you try to count the …

fact_check_explanation_title: Spectator report on the effect of the sugar tax needs more context
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Spectator said the “achievement” of the sugar tax is an increase in sugar consumption. This data referred to food which isn’t covered by the tax. Sugar consumption in drink …

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson’s first interview of 2020: fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister repeated a number of claims about the NHS and policing which we’ve looked at before.

fact_check_explanation_title: State spending isn’t at a record high when you consider the size of the economy
fact_check_explanation_summary: Public spending amounts to around 40% of the size of the economy. It’s been smaller before. It’s also been bigger before.

fact_check_explanation_title: Poll shows public thinks Brexit and NHS are most important issues facing the country
fact_check_explanation_summary: A survey reported by the Mail found social care to be the most pressing issue for the new government, but only among a selective list.

fact_check_explanation_title: How long do murderers serve in prison?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Over half of murderers released from prison have served between 11 and 18 years in custody.

fact_check_explanation_title: This video does not show an official alert siren playing in London
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK’s siren system has been decommissioned since 1992.

fact_check_explanation_title: This video does not show a real nuclear attack alert
fact_check_explanation_summary: The original video was made just for fun.

fact_check_explanation_title: Not every Nando’s UK restaurant is halal
fact_check_explanation_summary: Not every Nando’s UK restaurant is halal. An ad claiming this was for its Singapore restaurants.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim that 500,000 people who haven’t paid any UK tax sign up with GPs per year is wrong
fact_check_explanation_summary: Immigrants who do sign up with GPs have almost certainly paid UK tax.

fact_check_explanation_title: The police won’t always be dispatched if you dial 55 during a 999 call
fact_check_explanation_summary: If you can’t speak during a 999 call, dialling 55 can alert the operator that you need help, but it won’t guarantee that the police will come.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pension strikes in France have been widely reported in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: Pension strikes in France have been widely reported. It’s not the case that the British media is ignoring the story.

fact_check_explanation_title: Rail fares are increasing in price faster than other goods and services
fact_check_explanation_summary: Rail fare increases have been called both above and below inflation. They’re probably getting more expensive than most other things.

fact_check_explanation_title: The facts behind Labour and Conservative Facebook ads in this election
fact_check_explanation_summary: If there’s one issue that dominated discussion of campaign techniques in the run up to the election, it was online adverts. We look at how the Conservative and Labour campaigns …

fact_check_explanation_title: Usman Khan and sentencing terror offences
fact_check_explanation_summary: After the London Bridge attack, there's been a debate over how people in the UK are sentenced for terror offences, in particular Usman Khan, the attacker.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much rail investment goes to Wales?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Wales makes up about 11% of the rail network in England and Wales.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many trade deals will we lose access to post Brexit if we leave the Customs Union?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on the 2019 general election, answering your questions about the election, from claims the main parties are making to what …

fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on the 2019 general election, answering your questions about the election, from claims the main parties are making to what …

fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on the 2019 general election, answering your questions about the election, from claims the main parties are making to what …

fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on the 2019 general election, answering your questions about the election, from claims the main parties are making to what …

fact_check_explanation_title: Election 2019: what you need to know about polling day
fact_check_explanation_summary: Polling day for the 2019 General Election is on Thursday 12th December. Here are some key things to know about how to vote.

fact_check_explanation_summary: This article summarises our fact checks of claims made by the Conservative Party. Rounding up the work we’ve done over the campaign to help you get the facts you need.

fact_check_explanation_summary: This article summarises our fact checks of claims made by Plaid Cymru, the Green Party and the brexit Party. Rounding up the work we’ve done over the campaign to help …

fact_check_explanation_summary: This article summarises our fact checks of claims made by the Labour Party. Rounding up the work we’ve done over the campaign in a series of easy-to-read guides to help …

fact_check_explanation_title: Our key fact checks of the SNP and Liberal Democrats in the 2019 general election campaign
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article summarises our fact checks of claims made by the Scottish National Party and the Liberal Democrats.

fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on the 2019 general election, answering your questions about the election, from claims the main parties are making to what …

fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on the 2019 general election, answering your questions about the election, from claims the main parties are making to what …

fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on the 2019 general election, answering your questions about the election, from claims the main parties are making to what …

fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on the 2019 general election, answering your questions about the election, from claims the main parties are making to what …

fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on the 2019 general election, answering your questions about the election, from claims the main parties are making to what …

fact_check_explanation_title: How many seats are each of the main parties contesting?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on the 2019 general election, answering your questions about the election, from claims the main parties are making to what …

fact_check_explanation_title: There is no evidence to suggest the photo of a boy sleeping on a hospital floor was staged
fact_check_explanation_summary: The hospital has confirmed that the incident happened.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did the Lib Dems quadruple renewable energy?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Renewable energy generation expanded considerably under the Coalition, but some of that was because of projects commissioned under the previous Labour government.

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC Question Time under-30s special: fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: Last night we watched a special edition of BBC Question Time, where representatives of all 7 main GB parties were questioned by an audience of 18-30 year olds. We’ve fact …

fact_check_explanation_title: Angela Rayner is wrong on tuition fees
fact_check_explanation_summary: Angela Rayner claimed tuition fees were £1,000 under Labour and that Labour didn’t triple them. Labour tripled tuition fees from £1,000 to £3,000 in 2006.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are the Conservatives planning to raise the retirement age to 75 if they stay in power?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on the 2019 general election, answering your questions about the election, from claims the main parties are making to what …

fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on the 2019 general election, answering your questions about the election, from claims the main parties are making to what …

fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on the 2019 general election, answering your questions about the election, from claims the main parties are making to what …

fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on the 2019 general election, answering your questions about the election, from claims the main parties are making to what …

fact_check_explanation_summary: Your 2019 general election questions answered, from claims the main parties are making, to what happens on polling day.

fact_check_explanation_title: What is the total number of vacancies in the NHS for medical and support staff?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on the 2019 general election, answering your questions about the election, from claims the main parties are making to what …

fact_check_explanation_title: What do leaked Treasury documents tell us about checks on goods crossing the Irish Sea?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the leaked Treasury documents Jeremy Corbyn revealed say about checks on goods between Northern Ireland and Great Britain.

fact_check_explanation_title: The BBC Prime Ministerial Debate: fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: On Friday night the final televised debate between Jeremy Corbyn and Boris Johnson, the Labour and Conservative candidates to be the next prime minister, took place on the BBC.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Barnett Formula isn’t set out in law
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Barnett Formula didn’t apply when the DUP negotiated £1 billion for Northern Ireland because public spending in England didn’t change.

fact_check_explanation_title: £30,000 would be a high graduate salary for most new teachers in England
fact_check_explanation_summary: A commitment to raise teacher salaries to £30,000 by 2022/23 would likely put new teachers in the top quarter of graduate earners in England.

fact_check_explanation_title: Got a question about the election? Ask Full Fact
fact_check_explanation_summary: Ask us any questions you have about the UK general election, and we'll try and get you the answers you deserve.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sajid Javid claims 50% fall in homelessness under Conservatives—homelessness is up since 2010
fact_check_explanation_summary: Statutory homelessness increased by 39% between 2010 and 2017 (more recent data isn’t comparable). Rough sleeping is also up by 165%.

fact_check_explanation_title: This quote about selling NHS assets does not appear in the leaked UK-US trade documents
fact_check_explanation_summary: A quote about the US having a “right to withdraw all trade, aid and communication” in negotiations about the NHS does not appear in a leaked government document.

fact_check_explanation_title: SNP manifesto claim on living wage is slight underestimate
fact_check_explanation_summary: Around 83% of employee jobs in Scotland receive the real living wage or more, this is higher than any of the UK countries, but it lower than in the South …

fact_check_explanation_title: The housing supply has increased by a million in the past five years
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims about the increasing number of homes under the Conservatives are correct, but the majority of homes are built by the private sector, not the state.

fact_check_explanation_title: There are 11 million people in the private rented sector
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2009/10 there were 3.4 million households renting from a private landlord and this has risen to 4.5 million in 2017/18.

fact_check_explanation_title: If you are earning £80,000 you are in the top 5% of income tax payers
fact_check_explanation_summary: Despite the disagreement of an audience member on question time, a salary of £80,000 a year puts you in the top 5% of income tax payers.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour claims about savings under their policies are not credible
fact_check_explanation_summary: These figures are not credible and do not represent what “average families” will save under Labour’s policies.

fact_check_explanation_title: No single figure about child poverty tells the whole story
fact_check_explanation_summary: Based on one of the most comprehensive measures, child poverty fell between 2010 and 2015, but has been rising since. The latest figures suggest it’s now back to roughly what …

fact_check_explanation_title: Corbyn incorrectly says UK has worst recycling in the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK has a fairly average recycling rate for the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK has one of the highest levels of foreign-born doctors and nurses in the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Telegraph columnist’s comments exaggerate by claiming the UK is the only EU country with a health service heavily dependent on foreign staff.

fact_check_explanation_title: The BBC and ITV seven-party debates, fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We fact check the key claims and major topics from the BBC and ITV seven-party debates, including the NHS, Brexit, poverty, immigration and criminal justice.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake Jeremy Corbyn tweet spreads after the London Bridge attack
fact_check_explanation_summary: A fake tweet falsely claims Jeremy Corbyn said the London Bridge attacker was “murdered by British Police”.

fact_check_explanation_title: The BBC did not “donate” money to the Conservative party
fact_check_explanation_summary: Appearance fees from the BBC appear in some Conservative politicians declarations, as they do for MPs from other parties. These are not donations.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson on LBC: fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: Conservative party leader Boris Johnson took part in an audience phone-in on LBC Radio. We fact checked his responses.

fact_check_explanation_title: Angela Rayner uses exaggerated figure for number of WASPI women in poverty
fact_check_explanation_summary: Ms Rayner said millions of women have fallen into poverty because of changes to the pension age. We don’t know the number for certain but it is certainly not millions.

fact_check_explanation_title: What do the trade documents Jeremy Corbyn showed actually say about drug prices?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The documents show that, as expected, drug patents are a US negotiating objective in trade talks. But they don't show us what, if anything, the UK has actually agreed.

fact_check_explanation_title: SNP manifesto 2019: fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: This page will feature all our fact checks on the SNP manifesto for the 2019 general election.

fact_check_explanation_title: Councils aren’t using pre-filled postal ballots to suppress the youth vote
fact_check_explanation_summary: Councils say postal ballots are prefilled to prevent people from entering the wrong date.

fact_check_explanation_title: It is not Labour policy to scrap the single occupant council tax discount
fact_check_explanation_summary: This seems to come from a report that made recommendations to Labour about council tax, but is not party policy.

fact_check_explanation_title: This supposed Dominic Raab tweet seems to be an old fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no evidence he ever tweeted it and it was widely reported as a fake over a year ago.

fact_check_explanation_title: Twitter polls are not accurate opinion polls
fact_check_explanation_summary: The BBC only cited the YouGov poll showing 51% of people though Boris Johnson won the ITV leaders debate, because it was the only poll conducted in a way to …

fact_check_explanation_title: How to register to vote: everything you need to know
fact_check_explanation_summary: 26 November 2019 is the last day you can register to vote for the general election on 12 December. Here are a few facts about the process of registering and …

fact_check_explanation_title: The £20.5 billion NHS England spending increase is the largest five year increase since the mid-2000s
fact_check_explanation_summary: NHS England spending is set to increase by £20.5 billion between 2018/19 and 2023/24. The last time spending increased by at least that amount was between 2004/05 and 2009/10.

fact_check_explanation_title: Latest poll puts support for Welsh independence at 24%
fact_check_explanation_summary: On the Andrew Marr show, Mr Marr said support for Welsh independence was never more than 10% while Plaid Cymru leader Adam Price said it was at up to 30%.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour corrects broadband cost figure
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour initially calculated the cost of maintaining a full fibre broadband network at £230million a year. Data suggests costs would be two to four times this amount.

fact_check_explanation_title: Conservative party manifesto 2019: fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: This page will feature all our fact checks on the Conservative party manifesto for the 2019 general election.

fact_check_explanation_title: Diane Abbott did say that Chairman Mao did more good than harm
fact_check_explanation_summary: This was said during an interview on This Week in 2008.

fact_check_explanation_title: It's not correct to say two-thirds of businesses make less than £10,000 profit
fact_check_explanation_summary: Two-thirds of limited companies have corporation tax liabilities of up to £10,000, but fewer than half of businesses make a profit of less than £10,000.

fact_check_explanation_title: Conservative party misleadingly edit video of Jess Phillips
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video from October where Ms Phillips talks about how parties can’t deliver everything in manifestos was edited by the Conservatives to make it look like she was talking about …

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the NHS up for sale?
fact_check_explanation_summary: At the moment it comes down to who you believe, but beware of extreme and unrealistic predictions.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour party manifesto 2019: fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: This page will feature all our fact checks on the Labour party manifesto for the 2019 general election.

fact_check_explanation_title: Liberal Democrat manifesto 2019: fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: This page will feature all our fact checks on the Liberal Democrat manifesto for the 2019 general election.

fact_check_explanation_title: Public spending on buses not down by half in a decade
fact_check_explanation_summary: Funding from local authorities in England (excluding London) is down 43%, and this excludes money from central government which has not seen such large falls.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Daily Mail front page did not call Boris Johnson a traitor
fact_check_explanation_summary: A fake Daily Mail front page criticising Boris Johnson is circulating online.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much public health spending goes to the private sector?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Depending on how you count it the figure could be anywhere between 7% and 26% of spending by the Department of Health and Social Care and NHS England.

fact_check_explanation_title: Most African countries can export goods to the EU tariff free
fact_check_explanation_summary: Nigel Farage talked about the EU putting up trade barriers on African countries. The majority of African countries have no tariffs on exports to the EU, although a handful do …

fact_check_explanation_title: Lib Dem claims about EU health workers and the NHS are generally true
fact_check_explanation_summary: It is true that tens of thousands of NHS staff are from other EU countries, and that other EU nursing numbers have noticeably dropped.

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s unclear whether an independent Scotland could be forced to join the euro as an EU member
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU requires most member states to commit to adopting the euro at some point, but in practice it’s unclear whether member states would or could be forced to do …

fact_check_explanation_title: The ITV Boris Johnson vs Jeremy Corbyn debate, fact checked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We fact check the key claims and major topics from the ITV debate between Jeremy Corbyn and Boris Johnson, including Brexit, the NHS and inequality.

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s true that a Conservative councillor in Croydon is a former member of the IRA
fact_check_explanation_summary: Councillor Maria Gatland was a member of the provisional IRA in the 1970s.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim that immigrants “only” pay £400 surcharge to use the NHS ignores their tax contributions
fact_check_explanation_summary: At the moment, the immigration health surcharge is £400 for non-EEA immigrants to the UK, but their tax payments also contribute to the running of things like the NHS.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour draws unsubstantiated link between dental costs and hospital admissions
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour’s claim is also partially based on data which is a decade old.

fact_check_explanation_title: This is a photo from Tony Benn’s funeral
fact_check_explanation_summary: Gerry Adams, Martin McGuinness and Jeremy Corbyn were both attendees of theLabour MP’s funeral in 2014.

fact_check_explanation_title: A&E waiting times have hit their worst levels on record
fact_check_explanation_summary: 83.6% of patients attending A&E departments in England were admitted, transferred or discharged within four hours. That’s the lowest level on record, going back to 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: Conservative claim about immigration under Labour is not credible
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s not credible to put a specific number of the effect of a policy when no one knows exactly what the policy is.

fact_check_explanation_title: Scottish government uses non-official data on youth unemployment
fact_check_explanation_summary: That data shows Scottish youth unemployment has fallen. But official data shows it has increased in Scotland over the last year.

fact_check_explanation_title: We don’t know if there’s a north/south divide in flood defence spending because the data was taken offline
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures from the Environment Agency that could have helped shed light seem to have been taken offline.

fact_check_explanation_title: The USA doesn’t “allow” maggots in orange juice—it sets levels at which enforcement is mandatory
fact_check_explanation_summary: The US sets levels of natural contaminants in food above which it takes immediate enforcement action. The EU doesn’t set such levels.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim that Brexit will cost every Scot £1,600 is not right
fact_check_explanation_summary: These claims give the impression individuals would lose money, when it’s actually a prediction of how much less the GDP would be in a decade’s time compared to remaining.

fact_check_explanation_title: How sophisticated was the “sophisticated” cyber attack against Labour?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A DDoS attack by itself is not a sophisticated or particularly novel website attack.

fact_check_explanation_title: Another flawed “cost of Corbyn” figure from the Conservatives
fact_check_explanation_summary: You can’t work out the cost of a manifesto which hasn’t been published yet. And it’s flawed to assume all income tax payers have the same tax burden.

fact_check_explanation_title: There are serious problems with the Conservatives’ claim that Labour would spend £1.2 trillion
fact_check_explanation_summary: You can’t work out the cost of a manifesto that hasn’t been published yet.

fact_check_explanation_title: The BBC did use old footage of Boris Johnson laying a Remembrance Wreath
fact_check_explanation_summary: Excerpt The footage is from the 2016 Remembrance Sunday service. The BBC says it was a production error.

fact_check_explanation_title: Cambridge University has not banned poppies
fact_check_explanation_summary: The student union confirmed that a vote last year had been misinterpreted by the press.

fact_check_explanation_title: Spending on services for young people in England has fallen since 2010
fact_check_explanation_summary: The English budget for children and young people is down 13% in real terms, while spending on youth services specifically has fallen by 73%.

fact_check_explanation_title: No indication that the European Court of Justice would be the arbiter of all disputes in a future UK-EU trade agreement
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK and EU’s mutually agreed intention is that the EU courts would only be the ultimate arbiter of disputes which relate to the interpretation of EU law.

fact_check_explanation_title: This is not an image of Jeremy Corbyn at an IRA funeral
fact_check_explanation_summary: The man in the photos has been identified by those familiar with Bobby Sands as Jim Gibney, who now serves as a political aide.

fact_check_explanation_title: Police officer numbers in England and Wales
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of police officers has dropped by 20,600 since 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: Paying £500 million more a week for drugs post-Brexit is based on a fairly extreme scenario
fact_check_explanation_summary: While it’s certainly possible the NHS could pay more for drugs after a post-Brexit US trade deal, we can’t say what this would look like until after a draft agreement …

fact_check_explanation_title: John McDonnell repeats misleading claim about Conservative pension age plans
fact_check_explanation_summary: The recommendation to raise the pension age to 75 comes from the Centre for Social Justice think tank. There’s no evidence that it’s Conservative Party policy.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ken Clarke did not say he won’t vote for the Conservatives
fact_check_explanation_summary: He did say there was a possibility that he might not, but that he didn’t expect this to be the case.

fact_check_explanation_title: This video has been edited to make Keir Starmer appear confused at the end
fact_check_explanation_summary: In the original video, Mr Starmer promptly answers Piers Morgan’s question.

fact_check_explanation_title: £50 billion “remain bonus” figure is a reasonable estimate but highly uncertain
fact_check_explanation_summary: The calculation is a fair assessment of the best available forecasts. But those forecasts themselves contain a high degree of uncertainty.

fact_check_explanation_title: Lib Dem leaflet falsely attributes pro-Lib Dem quote to the Guardian
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Lib Dem leaflet edited a Guardian headline, which paraphrased the words of Jo Swinson, to make it look like the Guardian said it directly.

fact_check_explanation_title: This footage of Keir Starmer being interviewed on Good Morning Britain was edited before being posted by the Conservative party
fact_check_explanation_summary: The interview was edited before being posted by the Conservative party to make Mr Starmer look confused.

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC Question Time did not hire the son of a producer to say pro-Brexit statements
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim was spread by a now-deleted tweet.

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC Question Time get themselves in a mess over who broke electoral law
fact_check_explanation_summary: Fiona Bruce and an audience member found themselves each talking about Leave.EU and Vote Leave.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Mail’s diabetes front page needs context
fact_check_explanation_summary: Type 2 diabetes sufferers make up one in 10 hospital admissions in England but a small fraction were admitted for type 2 diabetes as the main diagnosis.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK workers’ rights: what are the rules on sick pay, maternity and annual leave?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Most of the numbers in a viral post about UK and EU workers’ rights are correct, but could benefit from some more context.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim about social care spending and nurse numbers needs more context
fact_check_explanation_summary: Just under 97,000 nurses voluntarily resigned from the NHS in England between 2010 and 2018. Overall the number of nurses working in the NHS is higher than in 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: You need to read the small print on this Lib Dem voting intention graph
fact_check_explanation_summary: A graph showing the Lib Dems just behind the Conservatives in NE Somerset does not make clear that this is in a hypothetical scenario where voters are told the other …

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s unlikely that these are bots commenting on Boris Johnson’s post
fact_check_explanation_summary: It is most likely that these are genuine commenters posting similar messages on purpose.

fact_check_explanation_title: These claims about people of certain ages remembering parts of World War Two are generally incorrect
fact_check_explanation_summary: 65 year-olds are unlikely to remember rationing and 75 year-olds the Luftwaffe.

fact_check_explanation_title: Don’t compare Labour and Conservative costings for police recruitment
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour’s costing for more police officers appears smaller because it doesn’t take into account recruitment or training.

fact_check_explanation_title: Image on flu jab ingredients is misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: A local UKIP Facebook page has shared a misleading image about the flu vaccine.

fact_check_explanation_title: This image claiming there are four million 17 year-olds who’ll be able to vote in the election is not about the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: The image is about the US. There are only around 725,000 17 year-olds in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: You can register to vote in two places
fact_check_explanation_summary: You are allowed to register to vote in two places. In a general election you can then vote in one of them.

fact_check_explanation_title: 182 places could be happier than the “UK’s happiest place”
fact_check_explanation_summary: Because of confidence intervals in the data, it’s very hard to tell which is actually the happiest place in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson repeats his false claim that extending Brexit costs £1 billion a month
fact_check_explanation_summary: A three month extension costs the same amount in EU budget payments as Boris Johnson’s own deal.

fact_check_explanation_title: Unevidenced tweet about People’s Vote crowd size spreads to Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: German TV did not say there were 2.2 million people, and the number was most likely in the low hundreds of thousands.

fact_check_explanation_title: Poll about support for violence against MPs is flawed
fact_check_explanation_summary: The survey asked people if they would accept the risk of violence against MPs for their preferred Brexit outcome.

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s misleading to claim the Lib Dems refused to support an end to NHS privatisation
fact_check_explanation_summary: Lib Dems abstained from a motion regretting that the government hasn’t pledged to repeal the 2012 Health and Social Care Act, which extended health privatisation.

fact_check_explanation_title: You can’t really compare rates of food poisoning between the US and UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s hard to tell whether someone in the US or UK is more likely to get a foodborne disease.

fact_check_explanation_title: Blue trick or treating pumpkin buckets are not official symbols for the autistic community
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post about blue pumpkins went viral on Facebook, but it’s not clear if the autism community widely supports the campaign.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Brexit deal has not passed Parliament
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Withdrawal Agreement Bill has not passed Parliament—it passed its “second reading”, which is just an early stage in Parliament passing it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Knife crime at eight-year high
fact_check_explanation_summary: Knife crime in England and Wales is at an eight-year high. Comparable data before this time is not available.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence that People’s Vote march had over two million people
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no evidence that Sky News and German TV made such estimates, as has been claimed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Think tank did not say GDP per capita will fall by 7% under Boris Johnson’s deal
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Mirror incorrectly wrote that experts say UK GDP is expected to fall under the new Brexit deal.

fact_check_explanation_title: Southampton MP gets trade figures wrong
fact_check_explanation_summary: Royston Smith claimed 90% of trade through the Port of Southampton is with non-EU countries and so under WTO terms. They’re not the same thing.

fact_check_explanation_title: Jeremy Corbyn did not wear a poppy pin that said “lets forget”
fact_check_explanation_summary: This image from a March session of PMQs has been edited to include the poppy pin.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson's new Brexit deal: four key questions answered
fact_check_explanation_summary: Following the publication of the revised agreement between Boris Johnson's government and the European Union, we look at four key questions about the deal.

fact_check_explanation_title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some of the claims aren’t quite correct and need some context.

fact_check_explanation_title: Could we still have a “no deal” Brexit in 2020 at the end of the transition?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A "no deal" remains a possibility at the end of 2020 even if the withdrawal agreement passes, but this is a different type of “no deal” to the one that’s …

fact_check_explanation_title: Does the new withdrawal agreement create a border in the Irish Sea?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Checks would have to take place on goods crossing into Northern Ireland from Great Britain.

fact_check_explanation_title: This comparison between Brexit’s impact and the financial crisis is flawed
fact_check_explanation_summary: Government analysis estimated GDP and wages will be lower following Brexit than if the UK remained in the EU. It’s wrong to say the analysis says GDP and wages will …

fact_check_explanation_title: There are some problems with this estimate of Labour’s nationalisation plans
fact_check_explanation_summary: Analysis says nationalisation will cost £196 billion or shareholders will suffer losses. Some outlets said both would occur.

fact_check_explanation_title: SNP members voted to commission a plan for pension increases in an independent Scotland
fact_check_explanation_summary: The resolution recommending this said the OECD average of 63% of average earnings should be set as the minimum.

fact_check_explanation_title: Voter ID scheme: far more turned away than convicted of electoral fraud
fact_check_explanation_summary: 740 people did not vote due to having incorrect ID in voter ID trials in 2019. 181 people have been accused of impersonating someone else at a polling station since …

fact_check_explanation_title: Evening Standard wrong to say wages aren’t rising
fact_check_explanation_summary: Reporting on the latest jobs data, the Evening Standard seemed to confuse flat wage growth with flat wages. Wages are growing at 1.9% per year in real terms.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong
fact_check_explanation_summary: It incorrectly claims that child poverty is up 50%, crime is up 30%, and public sector pay is down 15%.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU Flags were not replaced by Union Jacks outside of parliament
fact_check_explanation_summary: EU flags are never officially flown in Westminster.

fact_check_explanation_title: This is not a diesel generator at an Extinction Rebellion protest
fact_check_explanation_summary: The photo is taken from a generator’s marketing website.

fact_check_explanation_title: How long does the average government last?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Since WWII, the mean length of a government is 3.8 years, and the median length is 4.1 years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake Boris Johnson quote spreads on Facebook
fact_check_explanation_summary: Boris Johnson did not say "we have wiped out the national debt". He did say the Conservatives had tackled the debt and deficit.

fact_check_explanation_title: A judge did say he would pay a teenage girl’s victim surcharge after she stabbed the man who had sexually assaulted her
fact_check_explanation_summary: The judge spared her prison time and gave her a two year youth rehabilitation order.

fact_check_explanation_title: You do not need to stay home for two weeks after getting the flu vaccine
fact_check_explanation_summary: Most flu injections in the UK are inactive and therefore cannot spread between people.

fact_check_explanation_title: These 130,000 deaths cannot be explicitly linked to austerity
fact_check_explanation_summary: The think-tank behind the figure says wider policy issues are also important.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim about UK wealth and poverty is flawed
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK is the sixth- or ninth-richest country in terms of GDP, and the 20th- or 27th-richest in terms of GDP per capita.

fact_check_explanation_title: More prisoners to be released two thirds of the way through sentence than halfway
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government pledged to mandate serious criminals spending two thirds of their sentence in prison. Judges already have discretion to impose this.

fact_check_explanation_title: Over 200,000 elderly people experienced domestic abuse in 2017/18
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2017/18 an estimated 210,000 people aged 60 to 74 were victims of domestic abuse, most of which was carried out by a partner.

fact_check_explanation_title: That claim you’ve seen about Supreme Court judges getting paid £175,000 by the EU is totally made up
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some work ad hoc for the European Court of Human Rights, but that is separate from the European Union.

fact_check_explanation_title: This quote attributed to Boris Johnson is not real
fact_check_explanation_summary: Boris Johnson did not say "we have wiped out the national debt". He did say the Conservatives had tackled the debt and deficit.

fact_check_explanation_title: Despite reports to the contrary, Clint Eastwood is alive
fact_check_explanation_summary: Despite reports to the contrary, Clint Eastwood is alive.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the suicide rate up?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of registered suicides in England is up, but changes to how suicide is recorded may account for some of the rise.

fact_check_explanation_title: The government has given six hospitals money to upgrade buildings
fact_check_explanation_summary: Another 21 hospital trusts were given money to plan for new buildings, but not to actually begin construction.

fact_check_explanation_title: Don’t trust claims about the change in the number of churches and mosques in London
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s hard to say exactly how many churches and mosques there are in London.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Royal British Legion will offer poppies in all UK communities
fact_check_explanation_summary: The charity has confirmed poppies will be offered “in every community in the UK.”

fact_check_explanation_title: The Royal British Legion is not stopping poppy sales in certain areas due to “upset minorities”
fact_check_explanation_summary: The charity has routinely said this claim is untrue.

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s not true to say a Brexit extension would cost £1 billion
fact_check_explanation_summary: You can say your plan is to leave with a deal, or you can say an extension will cost £1 billion a month, but you can't say both.

fact_check_explanation_title: This post incorrectly claims everyone with cancer has a pH that is too acidic
fact_check_explanation_summary: This post makes claims about the relation between the body’s pH and health that have been widely debunked.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU staff don’t lose their pensions for criticising the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral post falsely claims senior EU employees don’t criticise the EU because they’d lose their pensions.

fact_check_explanation_title: That viral photo of a cloud that looks like a skull was taken from a heavy metal album cover
fact_check_explanation_summary: A picture which shows a skull which looks like a cloud in California has been faked. The cloud is taken from an Iron Maiden album cover.

fact_check_explanation_title: An Italian politician did not expose her underwear during her swearing-in ceremony
fact_check_explanation_summary: The original photo has been edited to show this.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim Brexit is about concealing offshore accounts is baseless
fact_check_explanation_summary: New EU tax laws aim to stop tax avoidance practices by companies. They do not aim to make owners of offshore bank accounts “come clean”.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much do Lib Dem MPs claim in expenses?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post gets the expenses claims of Lib Dem MPs roughly right, but their collective claims are around average for all MPs overall.

fact_check_explanation_title: This picture shows a model of an extinct amphibian
fact_check_explanation_summary: A picture showing a ‘hammerhead salamander’ shows a model of a diplocaulus, an extinct amphibian.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence for how Supreme Court judges voted in EU referendum
fact_check_explanation_summary: Judges have to stay politically impartial, and we have no idea how they voted.

fact_check_explanation_title: This video of a crowd booing Boris Johnson is not from the 2019 Conservative party conference
fact_check_explanation_summary: The footage is from 2015.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pretty Little Thing products can contain lead, but probably not dangerous amounts
fact_check_explanation_summary: The State of California requires companies to declare if they use any chemicals from a toxicity list.

fact_check_explanation_title: This is a real photo of Margaret Thatcher and Menachem Begin
fact_check_explanation_summary: It was taken in 1979 during his visit to the UK as Israel’s prime minister.

fact_check_explanation_title: Top CEOs make average worker salary in three days
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2018 the average pay for a FTSE 100 CEO was £3.5 million – over 110 times the average full-time salary.

fact_check_explanation_title: Poverty in the UK: a guide to the facts and figures
fact_check_explanation_summary: How many people are in poverty in the UK, and how has this been changing in recent years?

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim about cost of Labour’s welfare policy is unsubstantiated
fact_check_explanation_summary: This estimate for Labour’s welfare bill is meaningless because Labour haven’t detailed their welfare policies.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour didn’t vote to scrap all immigration controls
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour passed a motion at its party conference to extend free movement. This doesn’t mean scrapping all immigration controls.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is Luxembourg the biggest beneficiary of the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post falsely claims that Luxembourg receives the most EU spending, relative to what it pays in.

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s not certain that 87 people a day are dying waiting for care
fact_check_explanation_summary: The data behind this figure has limitations and there are some reasons to suspect the true figure may be lower.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Lord Kerr who wrote Article 50 isn’t the Lord Kerr who sits on the Supreme Court
fact_check_explanation_summary: Lord Kerr of Kinlochard is a different person to Lord Kerr of Tonaghmore.

fact_check_explanation_title: Jeremy Corbyn did not attend an IRA funeral wearing an ‘I heart the IRA’ t-shirt
fact_check_explanation_summary: The photo has been edited.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Nazis were not socialists
fact_check_explanation_summary: Despite naming themselves the national socialist party, the Nazi’s policies - including the persecution of left-wing critics - did not align with socialist ideals.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK citizens can’t be conscripted into an ‘EU army’
fact_check_explanation_summary: If the UK stays in the EU, it wouldn’t be forced into participating in an EU army. The UK has a veto on security and defence policy.

fact_check_explanation_title: Express front page headline on diabetes is based on flawed research
fact_check_explanation_summary: The research by Diabetes UK makes a big assumption which is poorly evidenced.

fact_check_explanation_title: This old photo of rubbish in Hyde Park isn’t from a climate protest
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture was taken after the event promoting the legalisation of cannabis in April, not the climate protest in September.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does badger culling work?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Research suggests that badger culling has a limited impact on the spread of bovine TB. We have seen some small reductions in bovine TB cases in recent years.

fact_check_explanation_title: A photo of Greta Thunberg and Al Gore has been edited to replace him with George Soros
fact_check_explanation_summary: The photo has been edited to put George Soros’ face over Al Gore’s.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral post has flawed understanding of EU debt
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU acknowledges that Brexit will leave a “sizeable gap” in its budget, but has plans to manage it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is schools spending going to be at record levels?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Per pupil spending in England is set to increase over the next three years to roughly the level it was at in 2009/10.

fact_check_explanation_title: There’s no evidence Shamima Begum has been flown back to the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: And Cherie Blair is not her lawyer.

fact_check_explanation_title: There’s absolutely no evidence the man who confronted Boris Johnson in a hospital was wearing a microphone
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s extremely unlikely from the sound quality in all the videos taken at Whipps Cross we can find that the man was wearing a microphone.

fact_check_explanation_title: You don’t need to worry about that video claiming to show a snake in a pepper
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral video claims to show a poisonous snake in a pepper. It doesn’t.

fact_check_explanation_title: How long do child killers serve in prison?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s possible for people who murder children to be given whole-life sentences, but the law doesn’t currently require this as a starting point in all cases.

fact_check_explanation_title: Were the Lib Dems the first party to campaign for an EU referendum?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Lib Dems were not the first party ever to campaign for an EU referendum, but they were the first major party to do so—advocating that the UK remain in …

fact_check_explanation_title: Jo Swinson said the Liberal Democrats supported an EU referendum in 2008
fact_check_explanation_summary: She also said in 2019 that she couldn’t forgive David Cameron for calling a referendum.

fact_check_explanation_title: Diane Abbott did not say an Iraqi migrant was found off the coast of a landlocked country
fact_check_explanation_summary: The unedited tweet was actually about a body found off the coast of Belgium.

fact_check_explanation_title: The ‘headline’ on this BBC article linked to by a Conservative Party Facebook ad isn’t the real headline
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Conservative Party Facebook advert seems to have altered the headline of a BBC article to make the government seem more generous than it’s being.

fact_check_explanation_title: We think there's a big error in that viral article about hedge funds and Brexit
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim that the number of “short positions” spiked when Boris Johnson became leader of the Conservative party seems to be a misreading of the data.

fact_check_explanation_title: There was not a 12kg rat in London
fact_check_explanation_summary: A photo of a rat makes it look deceptively big. It almost certainly weighed less than 3kg, rather than 12kg as claimed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photo shows Jeremy Corbyn shaking hands with man previously jailed for electoral fraud
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on Facebook shows a genuine photo of Jeremy Corbyn shaking hands with Tariq Mahmood, who was convicted in 2008 for electoral fraud.

fact_check_explanation_title: John Major did prorogue parliament for three weeks in 1997
fact_check_explanation_summary: Major’s prorogation in 1997 delayed a report into Conservative MPs taking bribes, whether or not that was his intention.

fact_check_explanation_title: We can’t say how many people are ‘hooked on’ prescription drugs
fact_check_explanation_summary: Research by Public Health England into the prescribing of five specific types of drug found there wasn’t enough evidence to say how many people were addicted.

fact_check_explanation_title: The price of Freddos has risen five times faster than inflation
fact_check_explanation_summary: The price of Freddos has risen much faster than inflation, and so has the value of the minimum wage.

fact_check_explanation_title: MP’s claim about rising unemployment in the West Midlands is wrong
fact_check_explanation_summary: Unemployment in the West Midlands has fallen slightly over the past year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Why Sinn Féin MPs don’t get salaries
fact_check_explanation_summary: Sinn Féin MPs aren’t allowed to take salaries but can claim expenses.

fact_check_explanation_title: Scotland doesn’t have the highest taxes in Europe
fact_check_explanation_summary: At his first Prime Minister’s questions, Boris Johnson incorrectly claimed Scotland has the highest taxes in Europe.

fact_check_explanation_title: The ranking of most popular baby names depends on how you count them
fact_check_explanation_summary: Grouping together various spellings of the name Muhammad can push it up the rankings, but so can counting Harrys and Henrys as one group.

fact_check_explanation_title: This post oversimplifies and confuses details about Hitler’s rise to power
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve seen no evidence that Hitler referred to the dissolution of parliament as “the will of the people”.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does proroguing parliament mean?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We explain what it means to prorogue parliament, why it’s controversial, and how it could affect Brexit.

fact_check_explanation_title: This post about British Steel’s buyout by Turkish fund is mostly accurate
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Turkish military’s pension fund is the preferred buyer of British Steel, based in Scunthorpe which voted to leave the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: This picture of Boris Johnson isn’t from this week
fact_check_explanation_summary: The image is from an interview with the BBC in April 2019.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does stop and search work?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Discussion of stop and search focuses on its use as a crime deterrent. But this ignores its use as an investigatory power.

fact_check_explanation_title: Red Bull and Monster don’t contain bull semen
fact_check_explanation_summary: Taurine in Red Bull and Monster drinks doesn’t come from bull semen.

fact_check_explanation_title: Dominic Cummings did not say this phrase about genetics and poor people
fact_check_explanation_summary: Boris Johnson’s chief adviser did not write or say this phrase.

fact_check_explanation_title: GATT 24: new argument, same old problems
fact_check_explanation_summary: A new claim about GATT 24 runs into an old problem: the EU probably won’t agree to it, and it doesn’t explain that it would mean significant barriers to trade …

fact_check_explanation_title: Would an extension to Brexit cost £1 billion a month?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This only works if you’re comparing an extension to a no deal exit where the UK doesn’t pay the divorce bill.

fact_check_explanation_title: A new Brexit bill doesn’t allow the EU to unilaterally extend the Brexit date
fact_check_explanation_summary: Parliament has the power to reject an extension date suggested by the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is £14 billion being spent on education?
fact_check_explanation_summary: By 2022/23 the government aims to spend £4.3 billion more on education, once you account for inflation, than in 2019/20.

fact_check_explanation_title: This image was edited to make it appear that Remain supporters burnt a Union Flag
fact_check_explanation_summary: The photo was edited to include a burning flag.

fact_check_explanation_title: Some images of Union Flags burning have been edited
fact_check_explanation_summary: One photo from a recent protest has been edited to falsely show a Union Flag flag burning.

fact_check_explanation_title: This picture of Remain supporters burning a Union Flag is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The photo was edited to include a burning flag.

fact_check_explanation_title: Life expectancy in the UK isn’t falling
fact_check_explanation_summary: UK life expectancies have been growing for more than a century, but growth has slowed down considerably in recent years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Muslim knife attacker claim is unfounded and implausible
fact_check_explanation_summary: A claim that 11,000 of 13,000 knife attacks in London were carried out by Muslim immigrants is unfounded and implausible.

fact_check_explanation_title: Not all of these claims about what MPs can claim in expenses are correct
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claims about what Iain Duncan Smith can claim in expenses as an MP are not all true.

fact_check_explanation_title: There’s no evidence that any current vaccines cause cancer
fact_check_explanation_summary: Vaccines go through a number of trial stages to check they don’t have dangerous side effects.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim that 97% of Labour activists support remain alliance is flawed
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim that 97% of Labour activists want a “Remain alliance” comes from a survey of a pro-remain campaign group. It is not representative of all Labour activists.

fact_check_explanation_title: This post about the decision to increase the state pension age needs some context
fact_check_explanation_summary: Its figures on the pension of the former-permanent secretary to the DWP are correct, his role in the decision making process is less clear cut.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do Notting Hill Carnival and Glastonbury have similar crime rates?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures which suggest that Notting Hill Carnival has a similar crime rate to Glastonbury are unreliable.

fact_check_explanation_title: Drinking water at set times does not provide certain health benefits
fact_check_explanation_summary: While it is a good idea to stay hydrated, drinking water at regimented times has no identifiable health benefits.

fact_check_explanation_title: This viral post about the costs of Brexit gets a lot of things wrong
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral post about the “costs” of Brexit misrepresents a number of economic analyses.

fact_check_explanation_title: A brother and sister did not win the right to marry in the United States
fact_check_explanation_summary: Marriage between siblings is illegal in both the UK and US.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can refugees enter the UK illegally?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Refugees can’t be penalised for entering illegally if they are claiming asylum and coming from a place where their life or freedom are threatened.

fact_check_explanation_title: Misleading claim about pension age continues to circulate online
fact_check_explanation_summary: Facebook posts continue to falsely claim the government is planning to raise the pension age to 75. It is a policy recommendation from the Centre for Social Justice.

fact_check_explanation_title: Poland has not refused to allow the building of mosques
fact_check_explanation_summary: A similar view has been expressed by a Polish politician but it is not government policy.

fact_check_explanation_title: This picture of a man swimming with a jaguar isn’t from the 2019 Amazon fires
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture was probably taken in 2016 and shows a soldier swimming with one of the army’s jaguar mascots, called Jiquitaia.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does a no deal Brexit mean no divorce bill?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s highly uncertain whether or not the UK would have to pay the divorce bill, if it left the EU with no deal.

fact_check_explanation_title: The EU doesn’t have a 30% tariff on African cocoa imports
fact_check_explanation_summary: The vast majority of African countries can export cocoa to the EU tariff-free.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sadiq Khan was a solicitor for the Nation of Islam
fact_check_explanation_summary: He represented the group back when he was a human rights lawyer.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many emergency patients are waiting over four hours for a bed?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There was more than a 7x increase in the number of emergency admissions taking more than four hours from decision to admit to admission from 2010 to 2018.

fact_check_explanation_title: We can’t be sure how many migrants registered with GPs in the last decade
fact_check_explanation_summary: There were 6.5 million new GP registrations in England and Wales from 2007 to 2017 where the person’s previous address was abroad. But we can’t be certain about these figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU immigration to the UK has been bigger than we thought
fact_check_explanation_summary: Official estimates of migration to and from the UK have been wrong for several years, and have lost their quality mark as a result.

fact_check_explanation_title: The meme you’ve seen about Instagram privacy settings is not true
fact_check_explanation_summary: Several celebrities have reposted the incorrect image, which has no truth to it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hundreds of birds were found dead in the Netherlands but it had nothing to do with 5G
fact_check_explanation_summary: Almost 300 starlings were found dead in a park in The Hague but no 5G tests were going on at the time.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did “our boys” change the handball rule?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Ian Holloway was wrong to suggest that non-British organisations had changed the VAR and handball rules against the will of British football organisations.

fact_check_explanation_title: This picture of women ‘dressing up like 9/11’ was taken in the UK, not Israel
fact_check_explanation_summary: The students wore the outfits to a nightclub in Chester in 2013, and it had nothing to do with Purim.

fact_check_explanation_title: Being ‘measles free’ doesn’t mean there are no cases of measles
fact_check_explanation_summary: The World Health Organisation says ‘eliminating measles’ means the number of cases in a country is at a level where it can’t circulate easily.

fact_check_explanation_title: The government has not just “set in stone” the repeal of the European Communities Act
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government has put into force part of the EU Withdrawal Act, which will repeal the European Communities Act on Brexit day. But parliament still has the means to stop …

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s not government policy to raise the pension age to 75
fact_check_explanation_summary: This was recommended in a report the Centre for Social Justice.

fact_check_explanation_title: Survation didn’t say the Liberal Democrats are polling ahead of the Conservatives in Esher and Walton
fact_check_explanation_summary: Survation’s poll was a national survey of voting intention which was then used to model an estimate of what local voting could be – this might not be reliable.

fact_check_explanation_title: An article about leaked Lib Dem emails is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: Images of an apparent Guardian article reporting on “turmoil at heart of Liberal Democrats” are fake.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are assaults on police officers rising?
fact_check_explanation_summary: All recorded assaults on police officers have risen by 18% since 2017/18, but it is not possible to compare this year’s figures with the stats from before then.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many rapists reoffend?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Each year in England and Wales, roughly 40-60 people are convicted of rape who had previous rape convictions.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many refugees does the UK take in?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK “resettled” more refugees than any other EU country in 2017 and 2018, but several EU countries have granted asylum to more refugees overall in that time than the …

fact_check_explanation_title: £4 billion Brexit stockpiling claim based on flawed survey
fact_check_explanation_summary: A survey claiming that Britons have spent £4 billion on Brexit stockpiling likely over-counted the amount being stockpiled.

fact_check_explanation_title: This advice on how to fight a parking ticket is wrong
fact_check_explanation_summary: If you receive a parking charge notice from a private car park and wish to appeal it, don’t pay it immediately.

fact_check_explanation_title: It's not correct that 98% of world trade is done via the WTO
fact_check_explanation_summary: 98% of global trade is done by members of the WTO, but most of this trade is done via trade agreements, not WTO rules.

fact_check_explanation_title: How energy intensive is a Google search?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s really hard to say exactly how energy intensive a Google search is, but a recent Sunday Times article overestimated the figure.

fact_check_explanation_title: These figures on MP expenses are incorrect
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post falsely claimed that Scottish Conservative MPs spent far more on travel and accommodation expenses than SNP MPs. Average expenses per MP were lower for Scottish Conservative MPs than …

fact_check_explanation_title: We can’t say patients are waiting over two weeks to see a GP on average
fact_check_explanation_summary: Reports that the average wait to see GPs has passed the two-week mark aren’t based on reliable evidence.

fact_check_explanation_title: MP tweets inaccurate quote from quotes website
fact_check_explanation_summary: The text has been circulating online for some time attributed to Monnet, but he doesn’t seem to have said it.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Telegraph’s poll figures on suspending parliament are misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Telegraph claimed a majority of people support the suspension of parliament. The figure was in fact 44%. There are other problems with this poll.

fact_check_explanation_title: The cabbage myth returns: EU cabbage regulations don’t have 26,911 words
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are not 26,911 words in EU cabbage regulations. It’s an urban legend which dates back to 1951.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tommy Robinson was not prosecuted for causing distress to men on trial for grooming
fact_check_explanation_summary: Tommy Robinson was found guilty in July 2019 of contempt of court after live-streaming footage of defendants in a trial that had a reporting ban.

fact_check_explanation_title: What is the Irish backstop?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The “Irish backstop” is an insurance policy in UK-EU Brexit negotiations to ensure there is no hard border in Ireland.

fact_check_explanation_title: Autism prevalence is up but scientists have consistently found that vaccines don’t cause it
fact_check_explanation_summary: More diagnoses of autism disorders are being made but they are not associated with being vaccinated.

fact_check_explanation_title: Islam in London: factchecking the viral image
fact_check_explanation_summary: This viral image makes claims about sharia law, mosques, no go areas and violence in London.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour members did vote to debate Palestine over the NHS and Brexit at the 2018 party Conference
fact_check_explanation_summary: However, trade unions and affiliates voted for Brexit to be debated at the conference.

fact_check_explanation_title: Government uses bad measure of wage growth, again
fact_check_explanation_summary: Average wages for GB employees grew around 2% in the last year in real terms, which isn’t the fastest in a decade.

fact_check_explanation_title: Money for the NHS: is it new or not?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It all depends on what you mean by new. But the £1 billion was money that had already been promised to hospitals but which they were unable to spend previously.

fact_check_explanation_title: Flamingo egg yolks are not bright pink
fact_check_explanation_summary: Flamingo egg yolks are usually yellow to red in colour.

fact_check_explanation_title: Was William Wilberforce a Tory?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Abolitionist William Wilberforce was an independent MP, not a Tory MP, though he was fairly loyal to the Tory Prime Minister, Pitt the Younger.

fact_check_explanation_title: This viral image on immigration and homelessness has a fundamental flaw
fact_check_explanation_summary: An estimated 320,000 people are homeless in Great Britain, and that figure includes people who aren’t British.

fact_check_explanation_title: What’s a free port, and does the EU have them?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Free ports (areas within countries where import tariffs don’t apply) exist within the EU, but in a more limited form than elsewhere in the world.

fact_check_explanation_title: 'Unelected' Prime Ministers: common or not?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Since 1900, it’s actually been the norm for Prime Ministers to enter office outside of a general election.

fact_check_explanation_title: This footage of the Queen doing the Nazi salute is real
fact_check_explanation_summary: The video was filmed around the time Hitler became Chancellor of Germany, before the Second World War began.

fact_check_explanation_title: There’s no easy way to compare benefit and tax fraud.
fact_check_explanation_summary: This graphic comparing benefit fraud and tax fraud is wrong. It’s difficult to compare DWP and HMRC, and most of the numbers quoted are incorrect.

fact_check_explanation_title: George Soros was not a Nazi SS officer
fact_check_explanation_summary: George Soros was not a Nazi in the Second World War, and a picture claiming to show him as one is actually of the Auschwitz officer Oskar Gröning.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson did say this about Gordon Brown becoming Prime Minister without an election
fact_check_explanation_summary: The now Prime Minister said in 2007 that Gordon Brown taking over from Tony Blair was a “scandal”.

fact_check_explanation_title: These tweets are from an Anjem Choudary parody account
fact_check_explanation_summary: Other tweets from that profile indicate it doesn’t belong to the radical preacher.

fact_check_explanation_title: Lamb exports to Japan aren’t due to EU trade deal
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s incorrect to say we can only export lamb to Japan because of the EU-Japan trade deal. It’s because Japan lifted a ban on lamb imports from the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: You are at risk of serious facial injuries if your feet are on the dashboard during a car crash
fact_check_explanation_summary: There have been multiple cases of people suffering severe facial injuries from having their feet on a car dashboard during a crash.

fact_check_explanation_title: This picture of a sign about refugees has been digitally altered
fact_check_explanation_summary: The original picture was taken in Canada in 2015, but the edited version was shared by Nigel Farage last year.

fact_check_explanation_title: A picture of a woman voting was taken in Pakistan
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture isn’t from the 2016 Mayor of London election.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did Boris Johnson write this quote about Liverpudlians and Hillsborough?
fact_check_explanation_summary: He was editor of the Spectator, where the comments appeared.

fact_check_explanation_title: You almost certainly won’t get arrested for flying a British flag
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral post claims flying terrorist flags is legal but flying the British flag isn’t. This is incorrect.

fact_check_explanation_title: Police numbers under Boris Johnson’s time as Mayor
fact_check_explanation_summary: Police officer numbers fluctuated during Boris Johnson’s time as Mayor of London.

fact_check_explanation_title: Driving in flip flops isn’t an offence, but driving carelessly is
fact_check_explanation_summary: Driving carelessly could lead to a maximum fine of £5,000, 3-9 points on your licence and possibly a driving ban in the most serious cases.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson's first speech as Prime Minister: factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: On 25 July Boris Johnson made his first speech as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom. We factchecked claims on no deal Brexit, the number of EU nationals living in …

fact_check_explanation_title: There’s no solid evidence to support this Brexit Party MEP’s claim about fishermen’s nets
fact_check_explanation_summary: Ann Widdecombe made a claim about fishing regulation during her maiden speech at the EU parliament saying they’d reduced income by 40%.

fact_check_explanation_title: These claims about radical Muslim preachers and Tommy Robinson are mostly incorrect
fact_check_explanation_summary: Anjem Choudary, Abu Qatada and Abu Hamza all received judicial action for their crimes.

fact_check_explanation_title: This Guardian quiz on Boris Johnson is meaningless
fact_check_explanation_summary: A recent Guardian quiz on Boris Johnson attracted over 70,000 responses. The respondents were not representative of Guardian readers or the public.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mobile phone base stations like this do not pose a radiation risk
fact_check_explanation_summary: The most powerful antennas have exclusion zones around them, but the mast in this viral post isn’t one of them.

fact_check_explanation_title: The EU "divorce bill"
fact_check_explanation_summary: The latest estimate for the size of the UK’s ‘divorce bill’ with the EU is £33 billion.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many people with dementia have to sell their homes to pay for care?
