fact_check_explanation_summary: A poll found that 16% of respondents who said they had friends or family with dementia also said that person had to sell their home to pay for care.

fact_check_explanation_title: Was a record amount spent on private providers by the Department of Health?
fact_check_explanation_summary: £9.2 billion was spent on purchasing health care from private providers in 2018/19—a record amount in cash terms, but not in real terms or as a proportion of the department’s …

fact_check_explanation_title: It is generally fine to give your dog small amounts of ice
fact_check_explanation_summary: In most situations, it is fine to give your dogs ice or frozen treats.

fact_check_explanation_title: This advert on the tube was not made by the Conservatives
fact_check_explanation_summary: Political adverts aren’t allowed on the London Underground, and the advert is fake.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson’s kipper claim is a red herring
fact_check_explanation_summary: Boris Johnson claimed that EU regulation required kipper sellers to pack kippers in ice. This is not an EU regulation – it is UK regulation.

fact_check_explanation_title: Old claim about Brexit economic boost resurfaces
fact_check_explanation_summary: A claim that a new analysis shows the UK will be £135 billion richer after Brexit is based on an old report from Economists for Free Trade. Most other economists …

fact_check_explanation_title: How much more difficult is it to buy a home?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Jeremy Hunt said since the mid-90s house prices have gone up threefold while incomes of people in their twenties has gone up 20%. That underestimates income growth.

fact_check_explanation_title: This is not a video of Palestinians protesting
fact_check_explanation_summary: The video was taken in Israel during protests by Ethiopian-Israelis.

fact_check_explanation_title: What can MPs claim on expenses?
fact_check_explanation_summary: MPs can claim housing, travel, food, computing and telephone calls on expenses in certain circumstances, as well as other things.

fact_check_explanation_title: It is unlikely this person got struck by lightning twice in quick succession
fact_check_explanation_summary: Inconsistencies in the video and lack of news coverage cast doubt on this event.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does the UK have the best education system in the world?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This claim is based on a survey of public perceptions of different educational systems. It is not good data to objectively rank education systems.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the gig economy doubled in size in three years?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A TUC report found that the gig economy has doubled since 2016, but its claim that this means more UK workers are patching a living together is unproven.

fact_check_explanation_title: Metropolitan police taking part in London Pride were on duty
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Metropolitan police in the parade were in full uniform with personal protection equipment and radios and so could have dealt with any incidents on the day.

fact_check_explanation_title: The GATT with nine lives: revisiting Article 24 again
fact_check_explanation_summary: There was a heated discussion during the Conservative leadership debate between Boris Johnson and Jeremy Hunt about GATT 24. No matter how many times the claim is repeated, the facts …

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the NHS introducing price lists for treatments?
fact_check_explanation_summary: NHS trusts can offer patients the option to “self-fund” a select range of treatments, if they don’t meet the criteria to have it paid for by the NHS.

fact_check_explanation_title: Would a corporation tax cut more than pay for itself, as Jeremy Hunt suggests?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Cutting corporation tax could lead to economic growth over the long-term, but is still expected to cost more than it raises.

fact_check_explanation_title: The withdrawal agreement is not a trade deal with the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: The withdrawal agreement only sets the immediate terms of the UK’s exit from the EU. The future trading relationship would need to be negotiated once the UK has left.

fact_check_explanation_title: The ITV Conservative Leadership Debate, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: On Tuesday night, the latest televised leadership debate between Jeremy Hunt and Boris Johnson took place on ITV. This article looks at the facts behind their claims.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are three million more patients using good or outstanding hospitals?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There were 2.7m more admissions in 2017/18 to hospital trusts that had improved their rating to good or outstanding than admissions to trusts that had dropped their rating to a …

fact_check_explanation_title: Spending on the NHS in England
fact_check_explanation_summary: How much will the government spend on health in England over the next few years?

fact_check_explanation_title: This video of a robbery at knife point did not take place in London
fact_check_explanation_summary: The video is from CCTV footage of a robbery in Bloemfontein, South Africa.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sadiq Khan did not pose for photos with a Sharia zone leaflet
fact_check_explanation_summary: An image of West Midlands police posing with synthetic cannabinoids has been edited.

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s correct that Labour’s support is at a record low in polling history
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Labour Party polled 18% this week. It has only polled this low once before, in May 2009.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK's EU membership fee
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2018 the UK government paid £13 billion to the EU budget, and EU spending on the UK was forecast to be £4 billion. So the UK’s ‘net contribution’ was …

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s unclear where these facts about veganism are from
fact_check_explanation_summary: These widely circulated figures about veganism are poorly sourced, but a vegan diet does reduce your consumption of animals and CO2

fact_check_explanation_title: Do MEPs get to vote for the new President of the European Commission?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The President of the European Commission is nominated by the European Council, but must be approved by a majority of MEPs too.

fact_check_explanation_title: Was the new President of the European Commission democratically elected?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Ursula von der Leyen is the nominee for President of the European Commission. Her nomination will be confirmed if approved by the European Parliament.

fact_check_explanation_title: A turtle was deformed by a plastic ring in the water
fact_check_explanation_summary: The turtle apparently became trapped in the ring when it was younger and grew around it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Most of these claims about glyphosate, vaccines and cancer are misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: Evidence on whether glyphosate causes cancer seems contradictory and Cancer Research UK says there is some evidence people exposed to very high levels of it could have a slightly increased …

fact_check_explanation_title: £1 trillion was not spent on bailing out banks during the financial crisis
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government spent £137 billion on bailing out banks during the financial crisis. Around £1 trillion worth of guarantees were provided to investors, but this does not amount to actual …

fact_check_explanation_title: An image on social media does show Nazi party members turning their backs during a speech
fact_check_explanation_summary: They did so during a speech by a communist politician in the Reichstag. Joseph Goebbels can be seen in the picture.

fact_check_explanation_title: These are photos of rubbish left after various Glastonbury festivals
fact_check_explanation_summary: Glastonbury festival, like many major events, has a robust cleanup strategy and rubbish policy.

fact_check_explanation_title: This comparison of pensions in different countries is misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: Pension systems differ a lot internationally, so it’s difficult to compare them fairly.

fact_check_explanation_title: YouGov did not predict that Jeremy Corbyn will lose his seat to the Lib Dems
fact_check_explanation_summary: A YouGov poll did not forecast Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn losing his Islington North seat to the Lib Dems after 36 years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sadiq Khan’s former law firm did consult on the defence of someone convicted in relation to 9/11
fact_check_explanation_summary: Back when he was a human rights lawyer, Sadiq Khan’s then-law firm consulted on the defence man who was later convicted of conspiring with the 9/11 attackers.

fact_check_explanation_title: There aren’t human foetal cells in lots of popular snacks and drinks
fact_check_explanation_summary: The cells (which are cloned from an aborted foetus) are not used as flavourings, but used in flavouring development. All but one company named said they didn’t work with the …

fact_check_explanation_title: More context is needed for these “facts about immigration”
fact_check_explanation_summary: The image makes claims about the number of foreign-born NHS doctors, Brits living abroad and whether immigrants are more likely to claim benefits.

fact_check_explanation_title: Brexit plans: five key arguments factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We round up five of the most commonly repeated points about how to get a Brexit deal over the line that we’ve covered before.

fact_check_explanation_title: These plants won’t stop you getting pregnant, and some could cause you harm
fact_check_explanation_summary: Plants are not a substitute for contraception.

fact_check_explanation_title: Not all these claims about fluoride are accurate
fact_check_explanation_summary: We factchecked a series of claims about fluoride, from whether it was used by the Nazis to sedate prisoners to whether it calcifies your pineal gland.

fact_check_explanation_title: There is no D-notice blocking reporting on Yellow Vest protests
fact_check_explanation_summary: DSMA notice, or d-notices, are not legally binding and cover a range of general topics related to national security rather than specific events.

fact_check_explanation_title: The ride shown in this video has been edited to make it appear more complex
fact_check_explanation_summary: A swing capability and an extending top have been added to the drop ride.

fact_check_explanation_title: Was Harry and Meghan’s home renovated with taxpayer money?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Renovations to Prince Harry and Meghan Markle’s home were paid for out of public money.

fact_check_explanation_title: You shouldn’t rely on a pregnancy test to tell you whether you have testicular cancer
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some people with testicular cancer can get a positive result on a pregnancy test. But it is not a conclusive way of diagnosing yourself.

fact_check_explanation_title: These Mark Field tweets are fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: Tweets claiming Mr Field threatened a girl on the tube and is in favour of beating women and children are fake.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson didn’t say this quote about Scotland – it’s a parody
fact_check_explanation_summary: Scandalous quotes about Scotland attributed to Boris Johnson were actually from a parody article.

fact_check_explanation_title: Stop and search in England and Wales
fact_check_explanation_summary: Use of stop and search has decreased in England and Wales since 2009 and the arrest rate has gone up. In 2017/18 17% of stop and searches led to arrest. …

fact_check_explanation_title: UK greenhouse gas emissions: fast progress but not yet enough to meet future targets
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK has made fast progress on tackling climate change by cutting carbon emissions, but is set to miss long-term targets.

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s time to stop saying there are “1.9million more children in good or outstanding schools”
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim there are 1.9 million more children in good and outstanding schools since 2010 is technically accurate, but it doesn’t factor in increasing pupil numbers or changing inspection practices.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour makes misleading claim on solar energy
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour used misleading figures, but there is evidence to show that the solar industry in the UK is stagnating.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are a quarter of 11 year-olds in England unable to read?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A quarter of year 6 students (10 to 11 year-olds) in England do not achieve the expected reading level in their SATs. This doesn’t mean they can’t read.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did four in ten dads not see their children this Father’s Day?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A survey does not show that four in ten dads would not see their children on Father’s Day, as newspapers and Fathers4Justice have claimed.

fact_check_explanation_title: There is no evidence to say why this veteran is crying
fact_check_explanation_summary: The identity of the man and reason for his tears have been debated, and remain unclear.

fact_check_explanation_title: Boris Johnson repeats an old line about “GATT Article 24”
fact_check_explanation_summary: Boris Johnson’s claim during the Conservative leadership debate about Article 24 of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade needs some context.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did only 11 MPs turn up to a debate on adolescent mental health?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The screenshot claiming to show this is from an adjournment debate, an end of day session which does not require a decision to be made by parliament.

fact_check_explanation_title: This sign saying the tube in summer smells like 16-year-old ham is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: Like many other viral tube signs, this one is a fake.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did crime fall while Boris Johnson was Mayor of London?
fact_check_explanation_summary: While Boris Johnson was London’s mayor, the homicide rate fell from 21 to 13 per million people. The overall police recorded crime rate fell 23%.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour's record on inequality and social mobility: 1997 to 2010
fact_check_explanation_summary: In a video on Labour's inequality record Tony Blair lists statistics on topics from the NHS to poverty. The figures are all broadly correct, but also don't include overall income …

fact_check_explanation_title: Counting Esther McVey’s record on employment
fact_check_explanation_summary: Since 2010, when the Conservatives entered government, employment levels have increased by 3.7 million. That can’t necessarily be attributed to any specific government policies.

fact_check_explanation_title: We can’t explicitly link 130,000 preventable deaths to austerity
fact_check_explanation_summary: A think tank estimated that 130,000 deaths due to preventable risk factors wouldn’t have occurred if pre-2012 trends had continued between 2012 and 2017.

fact_check_explanation_title: This supposed Chuka Umunna tweet doesn’t seem to be real
fact_check_explanation_summary: A tweet supposedly from the MP saying he wouldn’t be caught dead in a yellow rosette seems to have been faked.

fact_check_explanation_title: These food facts are mostly incorrect or misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: The video suggests that a number of things about foods are harmful but the claims it makes are mostly incorrect or misleading.

fact_check_explanation_title: Adidas, Nike and Puma use kangaroo leather in some products
fact_check_explanation_summary: All three companies use kangaroo, or k-leather in some of their football boots.

fact_check_explanation_title: You’ve less than a one in three chance of reaching 100
fact_check_explanation_summary: The chance of reaching 100 for a 30 year old in the UK is estimated to be 17.2% for women and 12.5% for men. Not “one in three” as claimed …

fact_check_explanation_title: Does it cost more to watch TV in hospital than in prison?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some hospitals provide TV for free, others for £8 per day. Prisoners are charged £1 per week to rent an in-cell TV.

fact_check_explanation_title: Was foreign aid money spent on an airport that doesn’t run flights?
fact_check_explanation_summary: St Helena airport didn’t run commercial flights between its opening in May 2016 and October 2017, but now runs flights to Ascension Island and South Africa.

fact_check_explanation_title: Would the Brexit party win a majority of 240 seats at a general election?
fact_check_explanation_summary: EU parliamentary election results aren't a perfect indicator of what would happen in a general election. It’s highly unlikely that the Brexit party would win the same vote share in …

fact_check_explanation_title: The EU hasn’t said Brexit will collapse the EU budget
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU didn’t admit its budget will collapse without the UK’s contribution post-Brexit. The EU are in the process of agreeing a budget, without the UK, for 2021-27.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK can’t be forced into an “EU Army”
fact_check_explanation_summary: If the UK stays in the EU, it wouldn’t be forced into participating in an EU army. The UK has a veto on military policy.

fact_check_explanation_title: This is not a photo of women of the Red Cross landing at Normandy
fact_check_explanation_summary: The viral photo is actually of women working for the Red Cross arriving in Southern France in 1945.

fact_check_explanation_title: Factbombing: methodology
fact_check_explanation_summary: The methodology that we used for our factbombing article.

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s still misleading to say 1.9 million more children are in good or outstanding schools
fact_check_explanation_summary: This doesn’t factor in the fact that pupil numbers have risen and inspection practices have changed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Employment: What’s happened to wages since 2010
fact_check_explanation_summary: In our fifth and final piece we look at what's happened to wages since 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: Employment: Is employment up only because of zero hours contracts?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In our fourth piece of this series we look at the claim that employment is only up since 2010 because of zero hours jobs.

fact_check_explanation_title: Employment: Is work being spread more thinly?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In our third piece of this series, we look at whether the employment rate is high because people working one hour a week are included as employed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Employment: How is it defined and why does that matter?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In our second piece of this series, we look at the definition of employment. Lots of people think that the government changes the definition of unemployment, so you can’t compare …

fact_check_explanation_title: Employment: Can you trust employment statistics?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The debate around employment and earnings can be confusing and combative. Our new series explains the facts.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK-US trading and investment: a special relationship
fact_check_explanation_summary: We factchecked claims made by Theresa May and Donald Trump during the latter’s recent state visit and found they were correct.

fact_check_explanation_title: This video does not show Muslims in Birmingham attacking cars during Ramadan
fact_check_explanation_summary: The video is actually of football fans in Switzerland.

fact_check_explanation_title: This tweet on public sector pay doesn’t factor in inflation
fact_check_explanation_summary: The figures on how much nurses, teachers, police and MPs got paid in 2010 and 2018 are pretty much correct in cash terms, but without including inflation they don’t tell …

fact_check_explanation_title: These videos of pro- and anti-Trump protests in the UK are from last year
fact_check_explanation_summary: A number of viral videos showing large crowds supporting and opposing President Trump are old.

fact_check_explanation_title: This post greatly exaggerates the risks of infection from people who have just been vaccinated
fact_check_explanation_summary: This post advising people on live vaccine exposure greatly exaggerates the risks of infection.

fact_check_explanation_title: The ‘Imperial March’ was not played to Donald Trump during his UK state visit
fact_check_explanation_summary: The ‘Imperial March’ was not played for Donald Trump during his UK state visit.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour MP’s Brexit poll is meaningless
fact_check_explanation_summary: Tom Watson MP found in a poll that 84% of Labour members back a vote by members to decide the party’s future Brexit policy. But there are a number of …

fact_check_explanation_title: What do the EU election results tell us about public support for leave and remain?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We should be wary of directly translating the EU election results into a poll on public support for leave or remain.

fact_check_explanation_title: Which NHS treatments are free for EU citizens?
fact_check_explanation_summary: EU visitors receive free NHS treatment for unplanned illness if they have an EHIC card. Similarly UK citizens receive free (or discounted) state healthcare when visiting other EU countries.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did one third of voters support a no deal Brexit at the EU elections?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A third of votes at the 2019 EU parliamentary elections were cast for parties that support a no deal Brexit. But turnout was relatively low compared to other types of …

fact_check_explanation_title: These trees weren’t cut down because of 5G
fact_check_explanation_summary: The trees in a Serbian town were being felled as part of a redevelopment project, and were due to be replaced.

fact_check_explanation_title: This picture doesn’t show someone wearing a hazmat suit to install 5G
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s more likely that they’re cleaning the mobile phone tower in a suit to protect their skin and clothes.

fact_check_explanation_title: There is no EU police force being rolled out in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU is not rolling out its own police force in the UK as part of its PESCO strategy.

fact_check_explanation_title: This FOI about vaccines is real
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK Vaccine Damage Payment provides payments to people who are severely disabled by vaccines.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many plastic straws do we use?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In recent years estimates for the number of plastic straws used in the UK or in England alone have ranged from around 4 billion to 40 billion. All of these …

fact_check_explanation_title: Theresa May's resignation speech: factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We factchecked the claims made by Theresa May during her speech announcing she will resign as leader of the Conservative Party on 7 June 2019.

fact_check_explanation_title: This image does not show Nigel Farage wearing a gollywog badge
fact_check_explanation_summary: This picture has been edited to show Nigel Farage wearing a gollywog badge.

fact_check_explanation_title: There is no evidence to suggest Nigel Farage was a member of the National Front.
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no evidence to suggest Nigel Farage was a member of the National Front.

fact_check_explanation_title: What happened to council funding, welfare spending and police numbers under the Coalition?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Andrew Marr correctly quoted a number of figures on reductions in welfare spending, council funding and police numbers under the Coalition, during an interview on his show.

fact_check_explanation_title: There’s no evidence that this man was attacked because he’s in the armed forces
fact_check_explanation_summary: A member of the British armed forces was hit by a car in West Yorkshire. There’s no evidence that he was attacked for being in the armed forces.

fact_check_explanation_title: Measles is not the “number one side effect” of the MMR vaccine
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s incorrect to claim that measles and death are side effects of the MMR.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has cocaine use really doubled in five years?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There isn’t enough available evidence to say that cocaine use in Britain has doubled, and certainly not that one in 50 Londoners are snorting it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mental health spending in the English NHS
fact_check_explanation_summary: Around one in every ten pounds spent by the Department of Health in England goes on mental health in the NHS.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claims that a no deal Brexit “will cost us nothing” are incorrect
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government has already spent money preparing for it, and it may reduce economic performance in the long term.

fact_check_explanation_title: Was the vote to leave the “largest democratic vote” in British history?
fact_check_explanation_summary: More people voted to leave the EU in 2016 than have voted for any other single electoral option in British political history. But that’s not the only way to define …

fact_check_explanation_title: Polish pensions are not directly subsidised by the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: As of 2018, the most common retirement age for men and women in the EU was 65. In some countries, women can retire as early as 60.

fact_check_explanation_title: This post about EU budget contributions is misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: The next EU budget is being planned to exclude the UK, and we also don’t know for sure what would happen to the UK’s rebate if it stayed in the …

fact_check_explanation_title: The heart disease death rate isn’t increasing
fact_check_explanation_summary: The death rate in the UK from heart disease is falling, but at a much slower rate than in previous years.

fact_check_explanation_title: GP numbers: up or down?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Theresa May and Jeremy Corbyn clashed over the trend in GP numbers at PMQs, but they were talking about different things.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does 61% of the country now back Remain?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Polls suggesting 61% of people would back remain in a second referendum are probably overstating the lead.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK can’t be forced to leave the EU or to join the euro
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK cannot be forced to join the euro if it remains a member of the EU. The EU could apply political pressure on the UK to do so, but …

fact_check_explanation_title: There is no evidence to suggest Theresa May said this about lesbianism
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no evidence to suggest Theresa May said this about curbing the promotion of lesbianism in schools.

fact_check_explanation_title: This is not a video of “migrant hordes” attacking Danish police
fact_check_explanation_summary: This is not footage of migrants rioting in Denmark, it is from a protest in Algeria.

fact_check_explanation_title: This is not a picture of a mum snorting drugs in front of a child
fact_check_explanation_summary: This picture of a mum snorting drugs in front of a child is not real and was in fact a joke.

fact_check_explanation_title: The mercury-based chemical found in some UK vaccines is not dangerous
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no evidence that thiomersal, found in some UK vaccines, can do any harm.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK won’t have to adopt the Euro by 2020
fact_check_explanation_summary: Even if the UK is still in the EU next year, the Lisbon treaty does not force it to adopt the Euro. The UK has an opt-out from this.

fact_check_explanation_title: Front-page error from the Times about how much private schools save taxpayers
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Times claimed independent schools save taxpayers £20 billion per year. The report they referred to put the figure at £3.5 billion per year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Government resurfaces misleading claim about good or outstanding schools
fact_check_explanation_summary: You can’t properly compare the level of good or outstanding schools in 2018 with 2010, because of changes to school inspection practices.

fact_check_explanation_title: Figures about EU health costs need more context
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post circulating on Facebook makes claims about how much the UK pays out to other EU countries for health costs incurred by UK citizens abroad.

fact_check_explanation_title: This video doesn’t show an actual wind turbine exploding
fact_check_explanation_summary: This video doesn’t show an actual wind turbine exploding.

fact_check_explanation_title: This map doesn’t just show churches “destroyed” in France
fact_check_explanation_summary: These aren’t just churches that were destroyed, the map also includes incidents of vandalism, violence and theft in churches, and attacks on priests.

fact_check_explanation_title: How did different constituencies vote in the 2016 EU referendum?
fact_check_explanation_summary: These figures about how constituencies voted in the referendum show the right general pattern according to best estimates.

fact_check_explanation_title: This photo does not show a French police officer pepper spraying a protester
fact_check_explanation_summary: The photo was actually taken at an anti-war protest in the USA in 2007.

fact_check_explanation_title: This image does not show a woman about to be stoned to death under Sharia law
fact_check_explanation_summary: The image does not show a stoning in Iran but a protest in Colombia.

fact_check_explanation_title: This is not a picture of Jeremy Corbyn with the IRA
fact_check_explanation_summary: The photo does not show Mr Corbyn with the IRA, but an unnamed man at Bobby Sands’ funeral.

fact_check_explanation_title: What will happen to your vote in the upcoming EU parliament elections?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Smaller parties are disadvantaged by the voting system in Great Britain, so it’s harder to win as many seats as larger, unified voting blocs.

fact_check_explanation_title: Germany doesn’t “owe” the UK £3.7 trillion of war debt
fact_check_explanation_summary: Property damage after the Second World War was valued at around £1.5 billion at the time.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did Margaret Thatcher say bus users over the age of 25 were failures?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The quote appears to have been coined by a poet. It has since been attributed to Mrs Thatcher, but we don’t know whether she ever quoted it.

fact_check_explanation_title: This picture doesn’t show a woman making an offensive gesture at Jeremy Corbyn
fact_check_explanation_summary: The image of Jeremy Corbyn and a woman has been digitally edited.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pepsi doesn’t use a flavouring made from aborted foetal cells
fact_check_explanation_summary: Pepsi had a contract with a company which develops flavourings using a cell line originally derived from an aborted foetus. But Pepsi says its own flavourings are not developed this …

fact_check_explanation_title: What is the UK’s public debt?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In May 2010, when the Conservative-led coalition came to power, the national debt was £1.03 trillion. As of March 2019 it had risen to £1.80 trillion.

fact_check_explanation_title: This image about vaccine ingredients is extremely misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: The ingredients it lists are either not present in vaccines, or not in high enough concentrations to do harm.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do Conservative councils charge £100 less tax than Labour or Liberal Democrat councils?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Conservatives’ claim they charge less council tax than Labour is pretty meaningless. It’s based on a flawed method.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does the UK have the world’s third most powerful military?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A think tank ranked the UK third in the world for “military might” but this isn’t the only way to measure military strength.

fact_check_explanation_title: Have the most deprived councils seen the biggest reductions in funding?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Nine of the ten most deprived council areas in this country have seen cuts that are almost three times the average of any other council.

fact_check_explanation_title: This picture does not show the aftermath of the Extinction Rebellion protests
fact_check_explanation_summary: The litter was left after an event promoting cannabis use on 20 April.

fact_check_explanation_title: The EU referendum wasn’t quite the largest democratic exercise in UK history
fact_check_explanation_summary: More people voted in the 1992 general election than the 2016 EU referendum, but no single option has received more votes than the vote to leave.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do Conservative councils recycle more than Labour ones?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The best available data shows that Conservative councils recycle more of their waste than Labour.

fact_check_explanation_title: Lemon juice, coconut oil and stopping all sugar intake won’t cure cancer
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve seen no scientific evidence to show these alternative therapies can cure cancer.

fact_check_explanation_title: Evidence shows there is no link between the MMR vaccine and diabetes
fact_check_explanation_summary: A brand of MMR vaccine used in the USA (not in the UK) lists diabetes as an ‘adverse reaction’. But that’s not the same as a side effect caused by …

fact_check_explanation_title: There isn’t good data on how much the NHS spends on translators
fact_check_explanation_summary: A claim saying NHS translators cost £100 million over five years is based on incomplete data from almost ten years ago.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do Labour councils cost you £350 less in council tax?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We haven’t found a fair and accurate way to compare whether Labour or Conservative councils cost you more in council tax.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does the public want no deal?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some polls indicate no deal is the most preferred Brexit outcome but others don’t. The results are heavily influenced by methodology.

fact_check_explanation_title: Prime Minister’s pension claims don’t adjust for inflation
fact_check_explanation_summary: Theresa May said under the Conservatives the basic state pension increased by over £1,450. That’s correct in cash terms but once you account for inflation it’s around £550 more.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the government prepared for a no deal Brexit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A number of government ministers have said they are ready for no deal. The government is not completely prepared in a number of areas, and in other areas there is …

fact_check_explanation_title: This post about MPs is untrue and around 20 years old
fact_check_explanation_summary: The original post made unverified claims about members of the US Congress.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does Poland’s migration policy explain its lack of terror attacks?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Poland doesn’t have a “no-migrants” policy, but does have very few migrants. Its lack of terror attacks can’t be explained by this alone.

fact_check_explanation_title: Former Labour minister didn’t call for Sharia law
fact_check_explanation_summary: Quotes claiming a former Labour minister supported Sharia law are falsified.

fact_check_explanation_title: Have 200,000 nurses quit the NHS?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Around 200,000 nurses and health visitors who have left the NHS in England in the last eight years, including those who have retired or died in service.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does most of the EU have no steel industry?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Seven EU countries produce more steel than the UK, including Germany, Italy and France. The UK is responsible for 4% of the EU’s steel production.

fact_check_explanation_title: Brexit department makes misleading claim on Brexit options
fact_check_explanation_summary: DExEU incorrectly claimed that the single market doesn’t cover services.

fact_check_explanation_title: This photo of an elephant carrying a lion cub is an April Fools' joke
fact_check_explanation_summary: The image was a digitally edited April Fools' Joke made by a South African game reserve.

fact_check_explanation_title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK wouldn’t be losing its currency, the Queen or ownership of its oil, gas and minerals if it stayed in the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does a “WTO rules” Brexit look like?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This viral post about a no deal Brexit exaggerates our EU payments and the “free trade” opportunities of no deal, but makes other correct claims.

fact_check_explanation_title: No, water cannon will not be deployed at the pro-Brexit march
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Met Police does not own any water cannon and their use is not currently authorised in England and Wales.

fact_check_explanation_title: This image on the costs of Brexit is very misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government modelled the impact of different post-Brexit trade deals on the economy. They expect slower growth under each model, but the exact details remain unclear.

fact_check_explanation_title: This isn’t a real sign at a protest
fact_check_explanation_summary: This protest sign isn’t from the People’s Vote march, it’s from 2011, and has been edited.

fact_check_explanation_title: This video doesn’t show the final moments of the Ethiopian Airlines flight that crashed in March
fact_check_explanation_summary: We can tell from the plane’s interior that it’s not the same flight.

fact_check_explanation_title: This boy in Sweden was killed but the motive is unclear
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral image does show Arminas Pileckas, a 15 year-old Lithuanian student in Sweden who was stabbed at school by a 14 year-old boy from Syria in January 2016.

fact_check_explanation_title: You can’t have an “implementation period” after Brexit without a deal
fact_check_explanation_summary: If Theresa May were to drop her deal and leave the EU now, we wouldn’t get an implementation period.

fact_check_explanation_title: Reports on the benefits of 10 minutes of exercise need a health warning
fact_check_explanation_summary: The study looked at the impact of doing 10-59 minutes of moderate activity a week, compared to inactivity.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is it possible to repeatedly sign a parliamentary petition using the same email address?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s possible to use the same email address to sign the Revoke Article 50 petition up to two times.

fact_check_explanation_title: There almost certainly weren’t a million people on the People’s Vote march
fact_check_explanation_summary: Experts in crowd estimation put the number at between 312,000 and 400,000.

fact_check_explanation_title: The boots Neil Armstrong wore on the moon do match the footprints he left there
fact_check_explanation_summary: This picture of Neil Armstrong’s spacesuit doesn’t include the ‘lunar overshoes’ he actually wore on the moon.

fact_check_explanation_title: This video does not show the final moments of the Ethiopian Airlines flight
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s a video from 2016 of an Etihad flight that experienced severe turbulence but went on to land safely.

fact_check_explanation_title: This isn’t a picture of Angela Merkel and Adolf Hitler
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post doesn’t show a picture of a young Angela Merkel and Adolf Hitler. Hitler died nine years before Merkel was born.

fact_check_explanation_title: This picture doesn’t show a child's heart infected with a dog parasite
fact_check_explanation_summary: This parasitic dog heart worm spreads via mosquito.

fact_check_explanation_title: This picture does not show Fidel Castro holding Justin Trudeau as a baby
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture is of the Cuban leader with Trudeau’s late brother, Michel.

fact_check_explanation_title: This video doesn't show a church in Pakistan being burned in retaliation for the New Zealand attacks
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video circulating online falsely claims to show a mosque being attacked in Pakistan in March 2019. It shows an attack on a church in Egypt in 2013.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU member countries don’t all have to join the Euro by 2020
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK and Denmark both have opt-outs to joining the Euro and seven other countries only have to join once they’ve fulfilled certain requirements.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU immigration to the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: How many EU immigrants come to the UK, how many leave, and what effect has Brexit had?

fact_check_explanation_title: Setting the record straight on climate change in the school curriculum
fact_check_explanation_summary: Climate change is a compulsory part of the school curriculum in England, but some students say they’re not being taught enough about it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does WTO Article 24 allow us to have tariff-free trade with the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Article 24 of the WTO’s GATT allows countries negotiating a free-trade area or customs union to have an "interim" agreement in place if they have a “plan and schedule” agreed …

fact_check_explanation_title: You shouldn’t put a tampon in a stab wound
fact_check_explanation_summary: The most important thing is to apply pressure to the wound and dial 999.

fact_check_explanation_title: We don’t know who attacked this Swedish woman
fact_check_explanation_summary: Posts online have suggested the attacker was a Muslim migrant, despite there being no evidence to prove this.

fact_check_explanation_title: If we leave without a deal, what happens to the Irish border?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: There’s a lot wrong with this viral list about the Lisbon Treaty
fact_check_explanation_summary: A large number of our readers have asked us to factcheck a list of claims about the Lisbon Treaty, or “what will actually happen if we stay in the EU”, …

fact_check_explanation_title: Period poverty: how widespread is it?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 27% of women responding to a survey in Great Britain said they couldn’t afford sanitary products. But it wasn’t designed to be representative and more representative surveys found it's about …

fact_check_explanation_title: Clary sage in Radox isn’t dangerous for pregnant women
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Office for Product Safety and Standards told us there’s no evidence that clary sage would be dangerous at these levels.

fact_check_explanation_title: This Diane Abbott poster is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: The mocked up poster was superimposed onto a photo taken in 2005 of a billboard in Hackney.

fact_check_explanation_title: Don’t attempt ‘cough CPR’ if you think you’re having a heart attack
fact_check_explanation_summary: If you think you’re having a heart attack you should dial 999.

fact_check_explanation_title: Donald Tusk’s grandfather was not in the SS
fact_check_explanation_summary: Donald Tusk’s grandfather was not in the SS, but was conscripted into the German armed forces after time spent imprisoned in concentration camps.

fact_check_explanation_title: What’s happening to knife crime?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Knife crime has almost certainly been rising in recent years, and knife-related homicides are at a record high.

fact_check_explanation_title: The “Momo challenge” is an online hoax fuelled by media coverage
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at the extreme level of media coverage devoted to Momo, in comparison to the dearth of evidence that it actually exists.

fact_check_explanation_title: What happens to the money from National Insurance Contributions?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Surplus funds from National Insurance Contributions in the UK are currently invested to reduce the national debt.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK taxpayers aren’t subsidising France’s 35-hour working week
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU budget is not spent on subsidising the French or German working week, or transport and utilities systems.

fact_check_explanation_title: This claim about cameras and speed limits on the M60 and M62 isn’t quite true
fact_check_explanation_summary: This claim about speed cameras on the M60 and M62 have gone viral, but the national speed limit still stands on these roads.

fact_check_explanation_title: Red Cross documents do not undermine official Holocaust death toll
fact_check_explanation_summary: Anti-Semitic claims that Red Cross documents show the Holocaust death toll was well below the widely accepted six million estimate are false.

fact_check_explanation_title: Theresa May didn’t say paedophiles should be allowed to adopt children
fact_check_explanation_summary: An academic wrote a report proposing the change in 2010, but that wasn’t backed by the government.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does the government subsidise grouse shooting?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Grouse moorland is eligible for agricultural subsidy, provided it is kept in a fit state for grazing. We don’t know how much subsidy grouse moors receive in total.

fact_check_explanation_title: Overblown: Wind turbines don’t take more energy to build than they will ever produce
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post claiming wind turbines can never produce as much energy as was taken to build them is based on a selective quotation and is incorrect.

fact_check_explanation_title: The estimated number of homeless people in Britain is broadly comparable to the population of Iceland
fact_check_explanation_summary: The calculation includes the number of people living in temporary accommodation, hostels and those sleeping rough.

fact_check_explanation_title: No, we are not experiencing “global cooling”
fact_check_explanation_summary: 18 of the 19 warmest years on record have occurred since 2001, and the average global temperature has increased by about 0.8°C to 1.0°C since the period 1951-1980.

fact_check_explanation_title: Emmanuel Macron hasn’t said the UK must join the Euro if it wants to remain in the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post has fabricated a quote from Emmanuel Macron about the conditions for the UK if it wants to remain in the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Middle-EastEnders?  No, the BBC isn’t adding Arabic subtitles to its flagship soap
fact_check_explanation_summary: A claim that the BBC will add permanent Arabic subtitles to EastEnders, to help refugees and other migrants settle in, is from a satirical news website and not true.

fact_check_explanation_title: This video does not show Shamima Begum beheading someone in Syria
fact_check_explanation_summary: The video, from 2015, shows a child, not Shamima Begum, beheading a man in Syria.

fact_check_explanation_title: You can’t be exempt from council tax if your home is used as a place of worship
fact_check_explanation_summary: Muslims who use rooms in their homes as a ‘place of worship’ aren’t exempt from council tax.

fact_check_explanation_title: Brexit: What’s a “Germany plus” deal?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral post stating the “benefits” of remaining in the EU is largely accurate—but most “benefits” would also be achieved by leaving the EU

fact_check_explanation_title: The Cancer Act doesn’t ban the researching of cancer cures
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Cancer Act 1939 makes advertising cancer cures or treatments illegal unless it’s to certain groups, mainly those involved in the medical profession.

fact_check_explanation_title: Here’s why Migration Watch got their study on post-Brexit immigration wrong
fact_check_explanation_summary: Migration Watch has withdrawn a study into post-Brexit immigration levels due to accuracy concerns.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mark Carney didn’t say Brexit could usher in “a golden age of trade”
fact_check_explanation_summary: Bank of England governor Mark Carney said Brexit is the first test of the new global order, not that it could usher in a golden age of trade.

fact_check_explanation_title: If we leave with no deal, how much of the divorce bill will we be legally obligated to pay?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's uncertain if the UK would legally have to pay the "divorce bill" if it left with no deal. The EU would be within its rights to take the case …

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s unclear exactly how NHS England plans to save 500,000 lives
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s unclear how NHS England plans to save 500,000 lives through its Long Term Plan. It hasn’t published much detail on how it calculated the figure.

fact_check_explanation_title: Booze telling the truth? Is Britain sobering up or not?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Alcohol consumption in Britain has been falling over time. But alcohol-related hospital admissions and deaths have remained at roughly the same level.

fact_check_explanation_title: This MP is very wrong about the Marshall Plan
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK received more funding from the Marshall Plan than any other country.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many migrants have registered with GPs in the last decade?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 6.5 million migrants have joined GP surgeries in the decade from 2007, but not all of them are here long-term and some were double counted.

fact_check_explanation_title: Violent crime is not at record levels
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s not correct that violent crime is at a record high. Several reliable sources indicate that violent crime is far lower now than it was in the 1990s.

fact_check_explanation_title: This image on benefits for pensioners and refugees is not correct
fact_check_explanation_summary: This viral image claims that pensioners can collect just a fifth of the benefits ‘illegal immigrants’ and refugees can. But how much can each group really get?

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral image about pensioners and refugees is wrong on every single number
fact_check_explanation_summary: People living in Britain as refugees are entitled to the same benefit and pension payments as UK citizens.

fact_check_explanation_title: This picture doesn’t show a horse found living in a flat in Preston
fact_check_explanation_summary: The picture has been shared over 25,000 times, but was actually taken in Illinois in the USA. It’s not a real horse.

fact_check_explanation_title: What are the possible side effects of the contraceptive pill Rigevidon?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook post on people’s experiences with this combined pill has gone viral. But what are the risks in taking it?

fact_check_explanation_title: Are dogs dying from eating jerky treats?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is some association between dogs eating jerky treats and developing a kidney disorder called Fanconi Syndrome, but it is not linked to any brand or shop.

fact_check_explanation_title: These claims about speed cameras on the M1 and M25 aren’t true
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims about speed cameras on the M1 and M25 have gone viral, but the rules on speeding on these motorways haven’t changed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Viral video of police officer taking drugs doesn’t feature a real officer
fact_check_explanation_summary: A prank video showing someone in a police uniform taking drugs didn’t feature a real police officer.

fact_check_explanation_title: What’s the cost of preparing for Brexit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government hasn’t said how much money departments are spending preparing for a ‘no deal’ Brexit outcome.

fact_check_explanation_title: Greenwich Council have removed a Lee Rigby memorial
fact_check_explanation_summary: Greenwich council have removed a memorial stone to Lee Rigby and replaced it with an official memorial.

fact_check_explanation_title: No, this image doesn’t show Merkel, May and the Lithuanian president hanging out as teenagers
fact_check_explanation_summary: An image of Angela Merkel as a teenager with friends does not also show Theresa May and the Lithuanian President,

fact_check_explanation_title: The London Underground isn’t as dangerous as New York’s in the 1990s
fact_check_explanation_summary: Crime levels on the London Underground have risen recently, but are still below New York City’s at its worst in 1990.

fact_check_explanation_title: It’s not true that dialling 55 in a silent 999 call lets the police track your location
fact_check_explanation_summary: Dialling 55 when you make an emergency call should put you through to the police, but doesn’t mean your location will be tracked.

fact_check_explanation_title: Could there be an “implementation period” after a no deal Brexit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There could in theory be a short “standstill” transition period after a no deal Brexit, but this isn’t the same as the two year “implementation period” set out in the …

fact_check_explanation_title: No postal votes from the EU referendum are recorded as “missing”
fact_check_explanation_summary: Over one million postal votes weren’t returned or were rejected during the EU referendum. A higher proportion of postal votes were counted than at the two previous elections.

fact_check_explanation_title: Will local NHS services in England have £570 billion to spend over the next five years?
fact_check_explanation_summary: English CCGs budgets are set to increase by around £3 billion each year in real terms over the next five years.

fact_check_explanation_title: How does a vote of no confidence in the government work?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A vote of no confidence is one of two ways that parliament can trigger an early general election. Although MPs first have 14 days to try and form a new …

fact_check_explanation_title: Do refugees have to stay in the first safe country they reach?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Refugees are not required to seek asylum in the first safe country they reach. But under EU law they can sometimes be returned to the first safe EU country they …

fact_check_explanation_title: No, Kenya doesn’t export flowers to the EU on WTO terms
fact_check_explanation_summary: Trade between the EU and Kenya is governed by a trade agreement. That’s different to trading under WTO terms.

fact_check_explanation_title: We factchecked a viral video on asylum seekers
fact_check_explanation_summary: Asylum seekers have to be destitute to get support and, if eligible, can’t choose what type of housing they get.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK’s poverty rate is around average for the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: UK poverty by one measure is around the EU average. A viral tweet misleadingly suggests the UK poverty rate is much higher by using a different measure for the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Who trades with the EU under WTO rules?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Most WTO members outside the EU have either a free trade agreement or preferential access to EU markets.

fact_check_explanation_title: This viral flyer on prescriptions after Brexit isn’t from an official source
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Department of Health and Social Care told us it didn’t make this poster.

fact_check_explanation_title: Deaths of homeless people in England and Wales up 24% since 2013
fact_check_explanation_summary: An estimated 597 homeless people died in England and Wales in 2017, up 24% since 2013.

fact_check_explanation_title: Full Fact Quiz of the Year
fact_check_explanation_summary: So we finally had a year without a major public vote. Regardless, 2018 saw a stack of claims for the Full Fact team to check—some accurate, some not. Here’s a …

fact_check_explanation_title: Has there been a ‘Brexodus’ of EU citizens since the referendum?
fact_check_explanation_summary: What's happened to immigration, EU workers and the population since the Brexit referendum?

fact_check_explanation_title: During the transition period will the European Court of Justice be able to veto or change any UK laws?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: What’s happening to rented social housing in England?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Social housing is low cost rented housing and low cost home ownership for people who may not be able to access the private market.

fact_check_explanation_title: Inaccuracies spreading about UN migration pact
fact_check_explanation_summary: Much criticism has been directed towards the UN’s new migration agreement. A lot of the criticism is inaccurate.

fact_check_explanation_title: Government proposes new zero hour contract legislation
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government plans to introduce draft legislation on workers’ rights, but it has not yet come into force.

fact_check_explanation_title: Why is avoiding a hard border in Ireland a priority?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: How accurate have Brexit forecasts been since the referendum?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Revisions to economic forecasts after the Brexit vote proved to be fairly accurate in the medium term, though less so in the short term.

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC Question Time: Recap and Factcheck
fact_check_explanation_summary: David Dimbleby's final Question Time came from the London borough of Southwark. Topics covered included Theresa May, Brexit, and whether comedians should be offensive.

fact_check_explanation_title: How does a leadership contest in the Conservative Party work?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 15% of Conservative MPs need to call for a vote of no confidence in the party leader: in which all Conservative MPs then vote for or against the leader.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is income tax being cut for 32 million people?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Treasury estimates 32 million will benefit from tax changes between 2015/16 and 2019/20.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Brexit timeline
fact_check_explanation_summary: We sum up the key issues and events you might want to know about, and how they all fit together.

fact_check_explanation_title: How does the UK feel about women leading the country?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 58% of UK adults would be “very comfortable” with a female head of government, and a further 30% would be “fairly comfortable”

fact_check_explanation_title: Wage growth is only the fastest in a decade if you ignore inflation
fact_check_explanation_summary: Weekly wages in cash terms are rising at their fastest rate in a decade. But accounting for inflation it’s only the fastest for two years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the divorce bill that we’re paying less than half of what the EU originally asked for?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Would a trade deal with the USA mean lower food standards?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does Labour's Brexit policy mean no Irish backstop?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour’s proposals may avoid a hard border in Ireland, but it seems extremely unlikely that the EU would accept those proposals alongside everything else Labour wants from Brexit.

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC Question Time: Recap and Factcheck
fact_check_explanation_summary: This week's Question Time was in Bishop's Stortford. The panel discussed the government’s Brexit withdrawal agreement, climate change and the police tactic of knocking suspected criminals off mopeds d

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the backstop permanent or temporary?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Both the EU and UK intend for the Irish backstop to be temporary but if an alternative isn’t agreed it may remain indefinitely.

fact_check_explanation_title: What exactly is the divorce bill paying for? And why are we paying it?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: What will be the repercussions of Brexit on our membership of Interpol?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can we avoid going into the Irish backstop?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are a third of domestic abuse victims men?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim is based on the ONS’ crime survey of England and Wales and includes partner and family, partner and non-physical forms of abuse.

fact_check_explanation_title: What do the government’s Brexit vote defeats mean?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government was defeated on three key votes. But what do contempt of parliament and Dominic Grieve's amendment actually mean for Brexit?

fact_check_explanation_title: If there is no deal will any restrictions apply to flights to and from EU airports?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Will the UK remain part of the "Everything but Arms" initiative after Brexit?

fact_check_explanation_title: Will we be able to implement trade deals with other countries if the Irish border situation is unresolved?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: If we go into the backstop, will the UK be making any financial contributions to the EU for that period?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: What would happen to medical supplies and drinking water if we left with no deal?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does it really mean to take back control of our waters and fishing, are there controls outside the EU which we will have to adhere to after Brexit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Where does Brexit leave us with regards to the Galileo project?

fact_check_explanation_title: What will happen to the European Health Insurance Card and emergency medical treatment after Brexit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can we unilaterally quit the withdrawal agreement or backstop in future?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can Article 50 be extended or stopped, and how would this happen?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_summary: Question Time was in Penzance this week and the panel discussed the Brexit withdrawal agreement, the TV debate and young people's mental health.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: your Brexit questions answered
fact_check_explanation_summary: Your questions about Brexit answered, including the withdrawal agreement, the "divorce bill", Article 50, and the prospect of "no deal".

fact_check_explanation_title: How long will we be paying the divorce bill?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Will the UK be able to do separate trade deals during the transition period?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Will there still be a transition period if we leave with no deal?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can Spain really veto the withdrawal bill?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article is part of our Ask Full Fact series on Brexit, answering your questions about Brexit and the latest negotiations between the UK and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK economic growth within the G7
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK had the fastest growing economy in the G7 in 2015, middling growth in 2016 and became the slowest grower in 2017.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does the latest Brexit deal mean for immigration?
fact_check_explanation_summary: If parliament approves the withdrawal agreement negotiated by the UK and EU, the plan is for free movement of people between the UK and EU to end in 2021.

fact_check_explanation_title: This claim about children with diabetes is completely wrong
fact_check_explanation_summary: A report in the Express said that ten years ago no child had type 2 diabetes – that’s wrong

fact_check_explanation_title: Supermarket pay image—where do the figures come from?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral image saying the government subsidises low paid workers at four big supermarkets has gone viral. But where does the data come from?

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS England: £394 million more a week?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Spending on NHS England will have increased by £20.5 billion by 2023/24 compared to 2018/19. That doesn’t cover all health spending though, and of the money won’t come from a …

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC Question Time: Recap and Factcheck
fact_check_explanation_summary: Question Time was set in the Staffordshire town of Cannock this week and discussed Brexit, gambling and homelessness.

fact_check_explanation_title: Real wages aren’t growing at their fastest rate in a decade
fact_check_explanation_summary: Real-terms total pay in Great Britain grew by 0.8% in the year to September 2018.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are a majority of youth knife offenders minority ethnic?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Across England and Wales in 2017, 38% of knife possession convictions among under 25s were convictions of non-white youths.

fact_check_explanation_title: Brexit withdrawal deal and future trade deal—what’s the difference?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Brexit withdrawal agreement outlines how we’ll leave the EU. The future trade agreement will outline how we trade with the EU after that.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU staff in the NHS: what has happened since the referendum?
fact_check_explanation_summary: EU nationals make up a similar percentage of the NHS workforce in England now as they did in 2016.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do diabetes prescriptions cost £1 billion a year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The net ingredient cost in 2017/18 of prescription items for diabetes in England was around £1 billion. But that doesn’t factor in things like discounts the NHS might receive or …

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC Question Time: Recap and Factcheck
fact_check_explanation_summary: Question Time on 16 November came from the Welsh harbour town of Milford Haven, and was entirely dominated by Brexit and the draft withdrawal agreement.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does the Brexit withdrawal agreement mean Northern Irish separation?
fact_check_explanation_summary: If the EU and UK don’t agree to extend the transition period or strike a new trade deal the backstop kicks in, under which Northern Ireland is treated differently to …

fact_check_explanation_title: Parliamentary expenses: is this meme about Theresa May correct?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The figures quoted in the meme are mostly correct, though they date from the late 2000s when Mrs May was an opposition MP.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are the UK’s armed forces recruiting enough people?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The full-time trained size of the armed forces is around 136,000. That’s 9,000 below the target.

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC Question Time: Recap and Factcheck
fact_check_explanation_summary: Question Time on 8 November came from Dulwich, London. Topics covered included whether stop and search and knife crime, Brexit deals, and if burning a model of Grenfell Tower should …

fact_check_explanation_title: Is a young person diagnosed with an STI in England every four minutes?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There were 144,000 diagnoses of the STIs chlamydia and gonorrhoea in young people in England last year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are there 3.5 million vegans in the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are almost certainly not 3.5 million vegans in the UK. Half a million is a better estimate, although that’s from 2016 research.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much does the government subsidise the railways by?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The average rail ticket is 20% more expensive than it was in 1995, and government subsidies for the railways have also increased.

fact_check_explanation_title: Would extending the Brexit transition period cost £15 billion?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We can’t know for sure, but £15 billion a year seems a reasonable estimate for now.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are we saving £1,205 a year in income tax?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A basic rate taxpayer will pay around £940 less in 2019/20 compared to 2010/11, once you factor in how prices have changed over that time.

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC Question Time: Recap and Factcheck
fact_check_explanation_summary: Question Time on 1 November came from Clacton-on-Sea. Topics covered included income tax changes, austerity, early elections, policing priorities, and the impact of the investigation into Arron Banks.

fact_check_explanation_title: Would Labour borrow a trillion pounds?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim that Labour's manifesto promises would cost a trillion pounds is not a fully costed estimate, and we don't know if it refers to spending increases or total spending.

fact_check_explanation_title: Water rip-off? Are water bills up 40% since privatisation?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Water bills rose sharply after privatisation in 1989 but have been falling slightly in recent years, due to regulatory oversight.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is fracking causing earthquakes?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Fracking is causing lots of micro-earthquakes, most of which are at a level that can’t be felt. In the UK there are thousands of such earthquakes each year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are 100 companies causing 71% of carbon emissions?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s more to the claim that 100 companies cause 71% of emissions.

fact_check_explanation_title: How have wages changed over the past decade?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK average weekly wage has fallen from around £540 to £520 in real terms over the past 10 years. Wages have levelled off since 2016.

fact_check_explanation_title: Budget 2018: three things we learned
fact_check_explanation_summary: What does the 2018 budget mean for austerity, income tax, and taxes on digital companies?

fact_check_explanation_title: A guide to what economic terms mean
fact_check_explanation_summary: A simple guide to what some key economic terms - like GDP, inflation, debt and deficit - mean.

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC Question Time: Recap and Factcheck
fact_check_explanation_summary: Question Time on 25 October 2018 came from Barrow-in-Furness. Topics covered included Brexit, austerity, Trident and non-disclosure agreements.

fact_check_explanation_title: What is Labour’s policy on the customs union and single market?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour wants to be outside the customs union and single market after Brexit, but with similar levels of access as to now. The EU would almost certainly reject this without …

fact_check_explanation_title: What was promised about the customs union before the referendum?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Campaigners weren’t explicit about what Brexit would mean for the customs union before the referendum.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has 86% of austerity fallen on women?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Since 2010, coalition and Conservative governments have aimed to reduce public spending through tax and benefit changes. 86% of those changes come from spending on women.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did 670,000 march for a People’s Vote on Brexit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 670,000 is an estimate from the organisers. We can’t say for sure if it’s accurate or not, but it may be on the high side.

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS and private hospitals: who pays business rates?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Private hospitals can register as charities and save 80% on their business rates payments, while some NHS hospitals have faced a business rates increase.

fact_check_explanation_title: Universal Credit isn’t the reason there are 1,000 more people a day in work
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are over 3 million more people in employment since 2010, but employment tends to rise over time. There is no clear evidence on how many people Universal Credit has …

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC Question Time: Recap and Factcheck
fact_check_explanation_summary: On the panel this week were deputy chairman of the James Cleverly, shadow Keir Starmer, Nish Kumar, Michael Dobbs, and Zanny Minton Beddoes.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is £84 billion being spent on the NHS?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The increase is £20.5 billion in real-terms for the NHS in England between 2018/19 and 2023/24.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Rates: National Minimum Wage, National Living Wage and Living Wage
fact_check_explanation_summary: What is the National Minimum Wage? What is a living wage? How different are they and what does the law say about them?

fact_check_explanation_title: 35% of girls wearing school uniform have been sexually harassed in public
fact_check_explanation_summary: 35% of 14-21 year-olds said they had experienced unwanted sexual attention or unwanted sexual or physical contact while wearing school uniform in public.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hate crime in England and Wales
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of recorded hate crimes in England and Wales spiked after the 2016 EU referendum and after terror attacks in the UK in 2017.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK foreign aid budget: what did the government spend in 2017?
fact_check_explanation_summary: An image saying foreign aid funding should be diverted to the NHS has gone viral. But is it right about the size of the UK government’s foreign aid budget?

fact_check_explanation_title: Are drug related deaths in the UK the highest in the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Estonia had the highest rate of drug-related deaths per million people, based on research using data from 2015 and 2016. The UK placed joint-third alongside Ireland.

fact_check_explanation_title: 200,000 more people in work under Universal Credit? The government can’t know the answer
fact_check_explanation_summary: The National Audit Office says the government will never be able to measure whether Universal Credit leads to 200,000 more people in work.

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC Question Time: Recap and Factcheck
fact_check_explanation_summary: Question Time on 11 October 2018 came from Edinburgh. Topics covered included Universal Credit, Brexit and education in Scotland and the line-up included Kezia Dugdale, Mike Russell and Fraser Nelson.

fact_check_explanation_title: The government should stop saying there are 1.9 million more children in good or outstanding schools
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government’s claim about more children in good or outstanding schools doesn’t acknowledge the impact of rising pupil numbers, and that many schools haven’t been inspected since 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much of this meme on government spending is true?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A widely shared tweet makes several claims about government spending on defence, the royals, HS2, Trident, Donald Trump’s visit and more. But what did these things actually cost?

fact_check_explanation_title: Government school spending figures: correct but misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: Spending per pupil in England fell by 8% in real terms from 2009/10 to 2017/18, and will be held constant from 2017/18 to 2019/20. UK education spending was about average …

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC Question Time: Recap and Factcheck
fact_check_explanation_summary: Question Time on October 5, 2018 came from Canary Wharf in London. Topics covered were austerity, immigration, knife crime and clapping being replaced with hand waving.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has austerity hit the most vulnerable the hardest?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Austerity policies have impacted the poorest households most. Despite this, since 2010 the poorest households have seen their post-tax incomes rise the most.

fact_check_explanation_title: Jeremy Corbyn’s shadow cabinets have been the most diverse ever
fact_check_explanation_summary: 45% of Labour’s shadow cabinet are women and 13% are of non-white ethnicities

fact_check_explanation_title: Cannabis kids: are more under-18s being prosecuted for supplying the drug?
