fact_check_explanation_summary: Fewer 10 to 17 year-olds have been prosecuted for the cultivation and possession of cannabis over the last 10 years, but increasing numbers for the possession with intent to supply, …

fact_check_explanation_title: Doing a sterling job? How the UK’s employment record compares to the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: Over the past eight years the UK’s employment growth has ranked 12th out of 28 EU countries. Our employment rate was fourth highest in the EU in the first three …

fact_check_explanation_title: Do new Universal Credit requirements affect women more?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Under Universal Credit, parents have to look for work when their child turns three. Some research suggests this could be more difficult for single parents—the majority of whom are women.

fact_check_explanation_title: Police funding in England and Wales
fact_check_explanation_summary: Police funding fell from 2010/11 to 2015/16. An extra £460 million for 2018 largely comes from allowing PCCs to increase council tax.

fact_check_explanation_title: There are lots of things wrong with this MP’s Brexit poll
fact_check_explanation_summary: Charlie Elphicke MP used a poll from his own Facebook page to show the “astonishing” popularity of a free trade deal. But polling like this is deeply flawed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Have 100,000 retail jobs been lost over three years?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of retail jobs changes with the season, but the annual average has dropped slightly in the last three years.

fact_check_explanation_title: One measure of inequality makes the UK look far less equal than other countries—it’s not
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK is about average among similar high-income countries when it comes to income inequality.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are the majority of British Jews Zionists?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A 2015 survey found around 60% of British Jews are Zionists and 90% support Israel’s right to exist as a Jewish state.

fact_check_explanation_title: Real wage growth is just above 0%
fact_check_explanation_summary: This claim doesn’t factor in inflation, nor peoples’ total pay. Total pay in Great Britain is growing in real-terms by 0.2% in the three months to July 2018.

fact_check_explanation_title: The no deal papers: why no deal could mean lots of little deals on travel
fact_check_explanation_summary: What could no deal mean for UK-EU airline and bus routes, and airport security checks?

fact_check_explanation_title: What do we know about which ethnic groups get arrested for terrorism charges?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In the year to June 2018, slightly more white people were arrested for terrorism-related activity than any other group, although their ethnicity was recorded by police.

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC Question Time: Recap and Factcheck
fact_check_explanation_summary: Question Time on 20 September 2018 came from the West Yorkshire town of Dewsbury. Topics covered included the Chequers deal, rail nationalisation, Islamophobia, and party conferences.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has public opinion swung in favour of a second EU referendum?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is some evidence that public opinion has swung towards a referendum on the final Brexit deal, but the evidence is not consistent.

fact_check_explanation_title: Shifting boundaries: what would reducing the number of MPs mean?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are proposals to reduce the number of MPs from 650 to 600 at the next election. We explain what impact this could have.

fact_check_explanation_title: Out of Africa: the facts about EU tariffs on African exports
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU has schemes in place with the majority of African countries that mean that they can import almost all of their goods into the EU tariff-free.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU immigrant workers in the UK: five things we learned
fact_check_explanation_summary: The independent Migration Advisory Committee (MAC) today released a report about the impacts of EU immigrant workers on the UK economy, and recommendations for how immigration policy should change.

fact_check_explanation_title: BBC Question Time: Recap and Factcheck
fact_check_explanation_summary: Question Time on September 13, 2018 came from the Oxfordshire town of Banbury. Topics covered included the Salisbury poisoning, Brexit, zero hours contracts, and prisons.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many people on zero hours contracts want more hours?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Around 780,000 people were estimated to be on zero hours contracts in mid-2018.

fact_check_explanation_title: Three things you might want to know about the government’s preparations for a No Deal Brexit
fact_check_explanation_summary: A number of new guidance documents came out today, and we’ve picked out just three things that could directly affect you.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is 82% of population growth driven by migration?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Including children born to immigrants, this seems broadly correct for the period 2001-2016.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK has posted record export figures, but that’s not very remarkable
fact_check_explanation_summary: In August the UK government launched its new export strategy and made a number of claims about the UK’s recent export performance.

fact_check_explanation_title: Irish border: how much trade?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at the volume of trade across the Irish border.

fact_check_explanation_title: What is unemployment?
fact_check_explanation_summary: How many people are unemployed in the UK? What is unemployment and how is it measured? And what's the difference between structural and cyclical unemployment?

fact_check_explanation_title: This claim about maternity units closing is misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: Half of the NHS trusts in England that responded to an FOI were forced to close at least one of their maternity units temporarily in 2017.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK has licensed at least £4.7bn of arms exports to Saudi Arabia since the start of the Yemen War
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK has licensed at least £5.5bn of arms to Saudi Arabia and its coalition partners during the Yemen War. But not all licences are ultimately exported.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pay rises: how much do nurses, the police, teachers and MPs get paid?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Several claims have been made about pay changes for police, teachers, nurses and MPs. We took a look at them.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the Chequers deal on Brexit more unpopular than the Poll Tax?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Opinion polling suggests that the Chequers deal has marginally less support than the Poll Tax did at its least popular – but less outright opposition.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much does the UK recover in health costs from the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post circulating on Facebook makes claims about how much the UK pays out to other EU countries for health costs incurred by UK citizens abroad.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is childhood type 2 diabetes up 40%?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Type 2 diabetes among children in England and Wales has increased by around 40% over the past 4 years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Beer mat Brexit: do the facts stack up?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The pub chain JD Wetherspoon has recently distributed beer mats in its pubs making a number of claims about the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: This claim about the UK's EU contribution is correct, but meaningless
fact_check_explanation_summary: Since 2000 the UK has made a net contribution to the EU of £122 billion in today’s money.

fact_check_explanation_title: The state of social renting in Scotland
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of social homes started in Scotland each year has been slightly higher under the SNP than the Labour-Lib Dem coalition.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Natural Cycles app: does it work?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A contraception and fertility app claims to have a quarter of a million UK users, but what’s the proof that it effectively protects against pregnancy?

fact_check_explanation_title: Everything you might want to know about the UK's trade with the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: Does the EU need us more than we need them? Ultimately, future trade between the EU and us depends on what kind of agreement, if any, we reach with them …

fact_check_explanation_title: The Princess and the PCs: What will policing Princess Eugenie’s wedding cost?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Local police will provide security for Princess Eugenie’s wedding. The cost is unconfirmed but reported estimates of £2 million seem in the right ballpark.

fact_check_explanation_title: GCSE results: boys drive slightly improved performance
fact_check_explanation_summary: Overall, there has been a slight pick-up in performance levels, after a couple of years of decline in pupils achieving higher grades. Performance among boys has increased in particular.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do pensioners in the rest of the EU get more cash than the elderly in the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Pensions are difficult to compare internationally, and there are several different ways to do it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Could ‘opt-out’ organ donation save 700 lives a year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Organ transplants could soon be an ‘opt out’ system in England, but there’s limited evidence for how effective the change will be.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are there plans to build on the Green Belt?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Local authorities plan to build around 460,000 homes on the Green Belt over 15 years. That could cover 0.9% of the current Green Belt area.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is UK economic growth higher than in Europe?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Last quarter the UK economy grew at the same rate as the Eurozone. Over the long term the Eurozone economy has and is projected to grow faster than the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What’s happening to HMP Birmingham?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Birmingham prison has been taken over from G4S by the government.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many cyclists are killed each year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Cyclists made up 6% of deaths and 14% of serious injuries on British roads in 2016. Around 1% of pedestrian deaths were caused by cyclists.

fact_check_explanation_title: A-Level results: beware of the headlines
fact_check_explanation_summary: Despite inevitable headlines focusing on shifts in results, A-level performance in England, Wales and Northern Ireland remains very stable.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many people die in fires?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of people dying in fires in 2017/18 was up a quarter on the year before.

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS pay deal: why are some staff not getting their promised rises?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some NHS staff were told they would all get a 3% pay rise from April this year, but many won’t get the full rise until later this financial year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fair fares? How much are season tickets increasing by?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Train season tickets for commuters are rising by 3.2% next year – higher than wages are rising.

fact_check_explanation_title: Child poverty is increasing and decreasing at the same time—here’s why
fact_check_explanation_summary: Over the long term, UK absolute child poverty is down while relative child poverty is stable. Each measure has its own strengths and weaknesses.

fact_check_explanation_title: What are the rules on burkas and niqabs in the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Women wearing veils for religious reasons do have to show their faces in passport photos, when entering the country and if police ask them to.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the number of teenage girls self-harming doubled?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of hospital admissions for girls under 18 because of self-harm increased by around 84% between 1997/98 and 2016/17.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the government’s pay rise for public sector workers a real-terms pay cut?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The recently announced pay rises are either above or slightly below inflation forecasts. These don’t cover all public sector workers.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many deaths from this summer’s heatwave?
fact_check_explanation_summary: High temperatures have been linked to increased mortality rates in the past, but we don’t know the full picture for this summer yet.

fact_check_explanation_title: What age do mental health conditions develop at?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A New Zealand study of those born in the early 1970s, throughout their lives found that around 50% of those with mental health conditions by age 26 had developed them …

fact_check_explanation_title: Violence and drugs in prison
fact_check_explanation_summary: In England and Wales’ prisons, drugs finds, assaults, and self-harm incidents are at a decade-high.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are grammar schools facing a crisis of funding?
fact_check_explanation_summary: English grammar schools received around £700 less state funding per pupil than other state schools in 2016/17.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many armed police are there?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of police firearms incidents are at a ten year high.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has NHS funding been blocked for glucose sensors?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The FreeStyle Libre glucose sensor has been available on the NHS across the UK since November 2017, at the moment it is up to local NHS boards whether or not …

fact_check_explanation_title: Are more young people taking cocaine?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Cocaine use among 16-24 year olds is at a nine year high. 6% said they had taken cocaine in the last year, higher than other European countries.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the government’s voter ID scheme been a success?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A small-scale pilot a voter ID scheme saw more voters turned away in one day than there have been cases of voters impersonating other voters at polling stations in the …

fact_check_explanation_title: Mental health: there are fewer beds, nurses and psychiatry trainees than in 2010
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of mental health beds and nurses have decreased since 2010, and there are fewer psychiatrists in training.

fact_check_explanation_title: How the jobs market for young people has changed since 2010
fact_check_explanation_summary: Youth unemployment has fallen in the last eight years, and young people stay on in full time education more than they used to.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did the Conservatives refuse to support 6500 British shipbuilding jobs?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Estimates for the economic and jobs impact of keeping a shipbuilding contract in the UK make assumptions that are unevidenced.

fact_check_explanation_title: This viral image showing the cost of different Brexit deals is wrong in a lot of ways
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government modelled the impact of different post-Brexit trade deals on the economy. They expect slower growth under each model, but the exact details remain unclear.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are MPs allowed second jobs?
fact_check_explanation_summary: MPs are allowed to do work outside of parliament, but they have to declare what that is, how many hours they work and what they’re paid.

fact_check_explanation_title: These poll figures are for leave voters - not "most of the nation"
fact_check_explanation_summary: More adults in Great Britain, but not a majority, are dissatisfied than satisfied with the Chequers deal according to one survey.

fact_check_explanation_title: This claim about the £2,000 cost of a hard Brexit comes from a typo
fact_check_explanation_summary: A consultancy estimated a “hard Brexit” scenario could increase average household cost by £961, not £1,961 as claimed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do a majority of Britons say the police have lost control of the streets?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 43% of British adults polled said their police force was excellent or good and a majority said they felt safe on their streets.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much of the NHS budget is spent on people over 85?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Research suggests that by 2021/22 around 10% of health spending across the UK will go on those aged 85 plus.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the UK going to become the EU’s tax collector?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK government has put forward proposals for a “facilitated customs arrangement” to replace the relationship we have with the EU through the customs union. We took a look at …

fact_check_explanation_title: Does most UK trade happen outside of the EU and trade agreements?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Most of the UK’s trade is with countries we have EU trade agreements with, not under WTO rules.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK is one of the biggest contributors to the EU budget
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK has been the third or fourth largest contributing country to the EU budget in recent years, and of the 28 member states is one of 10 to contribute …

fact_check_explanation_title: Did a majority of Conservative and Labour constituencies vote to leave in the EU referendum?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Official counts for how each parliamentary constituency voted in the EU referendum don’t exist, but the best estimates suggest that a majority of both Conservative and Labour constituencies did vote …

fact_check_explanation_title: Is wolf whistling about to become illegal?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Wolf whistling is unlikely to result in a prison sentence, even if misogyny is upgraded to a hate crime.

fact_check_explanation_title: Trump’s visit: what’s the cost?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government has given £5 million to the Scottish Police to help with the costs of policing President Trump’s visit. Other police forces can also apply for special funding to …

fact_check_explanation_title: The government hasn’t u-turned on energy price caps
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government did introduce legislation to allow for temporary energy tariff caps, as promised in the 2017 Conservative manifesto.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do EU rules prevent safer lorries?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Lorry design specifications are set by the EU, but the UK initially opposed its plans to allow safer lorries on the road.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pet theft: what’s the law?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A petition signed by over 100,000 people has asked parliament to make stealing pets a crime “in its own right”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do benefit fraud investigators outnumber super-rich tax inspectors 8:1?
fact_check_explanation_summary: HMRC employs around 1,000 staff to work with and investigate the tax affairs of the affluent and super-rich. DWP employs around 4,000 staff in its benefit fraud team.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are more people unable to get full-time work?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of UK part-time workers unable to find full-time work is relatively high, but the number of people overall who want more work is low.

fact_check_explanation_title: Councils aren’t getting enough funding to meet demand for social care
fact_check_explanation_summary: Increases in council tax aren’t enough to meet the demand for social care. Experts point to a lack of council funding from central government.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is Universal Credit driving people to food banks?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Trussell Trust research shows increases in food bank use in areas where Universal Credit has been rolled out. It’s difficult to measure the extent that one is causing the other.

fact_check_explanation_title: How is the NHS funded?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Most NHS funding is from general taxation, some from National Insurance contributions and a few percent come from patient charges.

fact_check_explanation_title: Satisfaction with the NHS peaked in 2010
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour increased health spending from 1997-2010 by almost record levels. Satisfaction with the NHS peaked at 70% in 2010. It has since fallen to 57%.

fact_check_explanation_title: The number of homicides in London has fallen over the last decade
fact_check_explanation_summary: Over the long term, homicides (including murders) in London are down, even including victims of terrorist incidents.

fact_check_explanation_title: Post-Brexit trade deals: the Norway and Canada options explained
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at possible models for a UK-EU free trade deal after Brexit, based on Norway and Canada’s deals. It covers tariffs, customs checks, trade with the rest of the …

fact_check_explanation_title: How has life changed in the UK since the NHS was founded?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The NHS is celebrating its 70th birthday. Here are eight charts that show just some of the ways, large and small, that the UK has changed since the 1940s.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many retail jobs have been lost this year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Over the long term the number of UK retail jobs is stable, but jobs in other sectors are growing.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much money does the UK spend on aid compared to the rest of the G7?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2017, the UK spent a larger proportion of its income on aid than the other G7 countries.

fact_check_explanation_title: Who can stay in the UK after Brexit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government plans to allow citizens of other EU countries and family members to apply for settled status after Brexit. This gives them the same rights to live and work …

fact_check_explanation_title: What is a trade deficit and do we have one with the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK had a £70 billion ‘trade deficit’ with the rest of the EU in 2017.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did Labour leave a £38 billion black hole in defence spending?
fact_check_explanation_summary: An eight year-old claim about defence funding still hasn’t been fully substantiated.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is Heathrow just for high flyers?
fact_check_explanation_summary: More people flying from Heathrow are on connecting flights or business trips than most other London airports. The majority are still leisure travellers and on non-connecting flights.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK is not on track to meet its carbon emissions targets for the next 15 years
fact_check_explanation_summary: A report by the Committee on Climate Change says the UK is not currently on track to meet its carbon emissions targets in the 2020s and 2030s.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many children are in gangs? The data’s not good enough to know
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2014, 0.9% of 10-15 year olds in England and Wales reported being in a street gang. In 2016/17, 0.7% did.

fact_check_explanation_title: World Cup: are you allowed to fly the England flag?
fact_check_explanation_summary: You are allowed to display the cross of St George, as long as it is safe and you have permission from whoever owns the site.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is moped crime rising in London?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Met Police figures show crimes on mopeds, scooters and motorcycles have risen since last year but are currently falling each month.

fact_check_explanation_title: Upskirting: what’s the legal situation?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve looked at how the current law applies to “upskirting” and how proposed legislation would change this.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did some MPs have to leave their sickbeds to vote on Brexit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Sick and pregnant MPs had to physically vote on the Brexit bill in person last week, we’ve looked at what the rules on this are.

fact_check_explanation_title: Economy introductions: the size of government debt
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government owes £1.7 trillion. That’s the size of public sector net debt, or the national debt. It’s different to the government deficit.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sexual harassment in the workplace
fact_check_explanation_summary: Estimates for workplace sexual harassment vary depending on whether surveys define acts of sexual harassment. One survey estimated 20% of UK female workers experienced sexual harassment.

fact_check_explanation_title: Healthcheck: cancer, diabetes and mental health conditions on the rise?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of diagnoses of cancer (in England) and diabetes (in the UK) is rising.

fact_check_explanation_title: Social care: what’s the situation?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of people receiving adult social care from their local council fell by around 425,000 between 2009/10 and 2013/14.

fact_check_explanation_title: The latest plans for NHS England spending outstrip both main parties’ manifesto pledges
fact_check_explanation_summary: Neither Labour nor the Conservatives’ NHS funding pledges at the last election were as big as the government's latest announcement. The NHS is still set to get less per year …

fact_check_explanation_title: Drug poisoning deaths are the highest they’ve been in 25 years
fact_check_explanation_summary: Drug deaths are at their highest since comparable records began.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much are young people taxed?
fact_check_explanation_summary: After taxes and cash benefits the net contribution of households where the main earner is under 25 was about 19% of household income in 2016/17—that’s lower than other working age …

fact_check_explanation_title: Millennial malaise: unhealthier than their parents?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Generational health improvements are being undermined by instability and loneliness among millennials, a report says.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did more people in London vote to leave the EU than for Sadiq Khan?
fact_check_explanation_summary: More people in London voted to leave the EU than for Sadiq Khan as mayor.

fact_check_explanation_title: Brexit bill: What amendments have been passed?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This week the Commons voted on 15 amendments that have been passed in the House of Lords over the past few months. We looked at what happened.

fact_check_explanation_title: World Cup: does domestic abuse spike when England lose?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We take a look at a widely shared figure that there were 38% more reported incidents of domestic abuse when England lost World Cup games.

fact_check_explanation_title: Who’s paying £20 billion for the NHS?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister has announced that the NHS in England will receive £20.5 million more in funding in real terms by 2023/24. We’ve looked at where this might come from.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does the ‘Brexit dividend’ exist?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no guaranteed extra money – or ‘Brexit dividend’ – as a result of the UK ceasing its contributions to the EU budget after leaving.

fact_check_explanation_title: England v Wales: how bad are the roads?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In Wales, 11% of A, B and C roads are in poor condition.

fact_check_explanation_title: China didn’t build a new railway station in nine hours
fact_check_explanation_summary: A viral video shows a new section of track being laid on China’s railways, not a whole new station.

fact_check_explanation_title: Infrastructure spending: does North Wales get its fair share?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We don’t know exactly who in the UK gets what out of infrastructure spending.

fact_check_explanation_title: Electric railways and tidal lagoons: has Wales lost out?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Has the government withdrawn promises of investment in Wales for electrification and a tidal lagoon?

fact_check_explanation_title: Do the public want the railways renationalised?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A poll of 1,500 adults in Great Britain found that 64% would support bringing the railways back into public ownership.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many households have been rehoused since the Grenfell Tower fire?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 184 households from Grenfell Tower and Grenfell Walk have accepted an offer of permanent housing. Not all have moved in yet.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is home ownership on the up?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Home ownership in England rose slightly last year following year-on-year falls since 2004.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are families £900 worse off since Brexit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Mark Carney said real household incomes are about £900 lower than they were forecast to be just before the referendum, partly down to Brexit. The exact figures behind this calculation …

fact_check_explanation_title: Does the UK have the poorest regions in northern Europe?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK has six of the poorest 10 regions comparing GDP per person against nearby countries, but this doesn’t mean the people who live there are poorer.

fact_check_explanation_title: Trading places: Who are the UK and Germany’s biggest trade partners?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK’s biggest export market is the USA. We exported 18% of our goods and services there in 2016, followed by Germany which took 9% of our exports. Our biggest …

fact_check_explanation_title: Are rail fares out of control?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The average rail fare in Britain has increased by 20% in real terms since 1995, though it dropped by 1% between 2017 and 2018.

fact_check_explanation_title: 825,000 more English school places since 2010
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of state-funded school places has increased by about 825,000 in England since 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much shopping gets done online?
fact_check_explanation_summary: How much shopping is done online, and where do people get their news?

fact_check_explanation_title: Prison or Eton: which costs more?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Sending a child to a prison facility, like a young offender institution, for a year costs more than the fees for Eton.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is UK foreign aid funding filming in Beijing?
fact_check_explanation_summary: At least £440,000 aid was spent on Chinese film, TV and museum projects in 2016/17. The total foreign aid budget was £14 billion.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ofsted hasn’t inspected 300 schools for a decade or more
fact_check_explanation_summary: 300 schools haven’t been inspected by Ofsted for a decade or more as they were last rated as outstanding, so don’t have to be inspected every five years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Robbery: Is the UK a “world leader”?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The recorded robbery rate in England and Wales increased more in 2016 than 13 countries examined by the Home Office, but the rate itself wasn’t top.

fact_check_explanation_title: One born every minute? How many migrants arrive in the UK and how many children do they have?
fact_check_explanation_summary: About 775,000 children were born in the UK in 2016, 210,000 to non-UK born mothers. Net migration was at around 245,000 in the year to September 2017.

fact_check_explanation_title: Would an independent Scotland have to keep the pound and cut public spending?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A report commissioned by the Scottish National Party recommends that an independent Scotland should not immediately change its currency from the pound.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the UK’s economy growing slower than any other country in the developed world?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK’s economy is growing more slowly than most countries analysed by the OECD in a recent report, but isn’t the slowest. The OECD’s analysis also doesn’t include all developed …

fact_check_explanation_title: Abortion, human rights, and devolution
fact_check_explanation_summary: What can the Northern Ireland Assembly do?

fact_check_explanation_title: Accident and emergency: attendances and performance
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2017 there were 23.6m A&E attendances in England. Recent years have seen more targets missed and longer waiting times than previous years.

fact_check_explanation_title: HMRC: how many unanswered calls?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Around 13% of calls to HMRC have gone unanswered in the eleven months from April 2017, compared to 8% in the same months the year before.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are pay packets growing?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Wages are lower than they were ten years ago, but on some measures have risen since last year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Black and ethnic minority students at the University of Oxford
fact_check_explanation_summary: White applicants to Oxford University from the UK are twice as likely to be accepted as black applicants. Overall, 18% of undergraduates from the UK who took up their place …

fact_check_explanation_title: Higher education: a white, middle-class affair?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 4% of UK students who began their first UK university degree in 2016/17 were white, but white students are the least likely ethnic group to enter higher education.

fact_check_explanation_title: Where do UK applicants to Oxford University come from?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Oxford University students are most likely to be from Greater London.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does immigration do to wages?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It depends who you are.

fact_check_explanation_title: Health and social care: What do we spend?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We spent almost £150 billion on healthcare across the UK in 2016/17 and a further £31 billion on social care for adults and children.

fact_check_explanation_title: How does the royal family make money?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Queen gets 25% of the profit from the Crown Estate. It’s impossible to be sure how much the monarchy contribute to the economy.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are more people being prosecuted for carrying knives?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Are more people being caught with knives, prosecuted for it and spending longer in prison because of it?

fact_check_explanation_title: Winter 2017/18: the worst ever for the NHS?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In collaboration with the Nuffield Trust we looked at whether or not this winter was the worst ever for the NHS in England.

fact_check_explanation_title: What’s happened to employment since the vote to leave the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Employment is up, unemployment is down and there are more people from outside the UK in work than before the Brexit vote.

fact_check_explanation_title: Trade across the Irish Sea
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2016, the majority of Northern Irish goods trade sent outside its borders went to Great Britain.

fact_check_explanation_title: Two thirds of former Grenfell households are not in permanent homes
fact_check_explanation_summary: How many households made homeless by the Grenfell Tower fire have accepted permanent or temporary accommodation, and how many are in permanent homes?

fact_check_explanation_title: Police budgets, numbers and community policing
fact_check_explanation_summary: Police budgets, police officer numbers and community policing, we factcheck the claims.

fact_check_explanation_title: What has the leader of the fire safety review said about a cladding ban?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The leader of the government’s independent review into building regulations and fire safety said she didn’t think it was her role to go into the detail of individual regulations.

fact_check_explanation_title: Have more people died in stabbings and shootings this year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Across the whole of England and Wales homicides attributed to stabbings or shootings have increased in recent years.

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS viral image factcheck
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve factchecked a viral graphic on NHS funding, A&E waiting times, ambulance targets, hospital beds and GPs.

fact_check_explanation_title: Post-Brexit customs: Max fac and the customs partnership explained
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government outlined two post-Brexit customs options. “Max fac” aims to create a “frictionless” customs border. A customs partnership would create a system where the UK collects EU tariffs.

fact_check_explanation_title: Royal flush? How much are taxpayers paying for the Royal wedding?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Royal Family will pay for the wedding, but the security will be paid for by the state. Security for Prince William’s wedding cost over £6 million.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sure Start, school building and tuition fees: the Conservative and Coalition record
fact_check_explanation_summary: Explaining the Coalition and Conservative governments’ record on tuition fees, Education Maintenance Allowance, Sure Start, and school building.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is youth unemployment down 40%?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of unemployed 16-24 year olds has fallen by 43% between 2010 and 2018.

fact_check_explanation_title: America: seen as the number one threat to world peace, says one survey
fact_check_explanation_summary: A 2013 poll by the WIN/Gallup International network found 24% of respondents from around the world chose the USA as the country they thought posed the greatest threat to world …

fact_check_explanation_title: The Pro-sesh-ional classes: Do wealthy people drink more regularly?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Professionals and higher earners in Great Britain say they drink more regularly, if you count that as drinking weekly.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are there 100,000 vacancies in the NHS?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There were reportedly 100,000 vacancies in NHS trusts in England between October-December 2017. Home Office caps on visa numbers mean some international doctors cannot enter the UK to work.

fact_check_explanation_title: Affordable homes: comparing Labour and Conservative records
fact_check_explanation_summary: 346,000 affordable homes were added in the seven years of coalition and Conservative government to 2016/17. That’s slightly more than the last seven years of Labour.

fact_check_explanation_title: Student ‘debts’ aren’t really debts
fact_check_explanation_summary: Politicians were accused of misrepresenting students’ finance options - so how does it work?

fact_check_explanation_title: Estimates of lower GDP growth post-Brexit don’t mean a recession
fact_check_explanation_summary: Government analysis of a number of Brexit scenarios estimated that over the next 15 years economic growth could be reduced by around 2%, 5% and 8% depending on the outcome.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did Labour make 1.4 million “non-decent” homes fit to live in?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The last Labour government launched a programme to make “non-decent” homes fit for living in. An estimated 1.4 million social sector homes underwent work.

fact_check_explanation_title: What’s driving our increasing population and household numbers?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Immigration has been the largest driver of the increasing population, according to the Office for National Statistics. Life expectancy has also been steadily increasing over the last few decades.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much money do members of the House of Lords get?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A few members of the House of Lords are paid a salary, but most are not. Instead they can choose to claim an allowance of up to £300 for attending …

fact_check_explanation_title: Will four extra bank holidays cost us £10 billion?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s difficult to say exactly how much bank holidays affect the economy, but most research suggests that they do reduce GDP.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many people have a disability?
fact_check_explanation_summary: An estimated 19% of working-age adults, and 22% of all people in the UK have a disability, as defined by the Equality Act.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can people with terminal illnesses be declared fit to work?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There have been cases of people with terminal illnesses being declared fit to work reported by the media and charities. We don’t know how widespread this is.

fact_check_explanation_title: How are Theresa May and Jeremy Corbyn doing in the polls?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Theresa May is viewed as a better PM than Jeremy Corbyn, and the Conservatives are slightly ahead of Labour in the polls.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour and Conservative council tax: who costs you more?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Council tax bills often include precepts and payments to more than one authority. This means your bill could be set by bodies run by different political parties.

fact_check_explanation_title: Will one third of millennials rent for their entire lives?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Resolution Foundation estimates that between 66% and 73% of millennials will own their own homes by 2060 (around pension age). 77% of pensioners owned their homes in 2016.

fact_check_explanation_title: Comparing economic growth across the world
fact_check_explanation_summary: The economies of East Asia, Southeast Asia, and South Asia grew by 5.6%, 5.3%, and 6.5% respectively in 2017. That’s significantly faster than the UK, USA, and EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: You usually need to earn £18,600 a year to bring a non-EU partner to the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: Since 2012, £18,600 is the minimum income required to bring a non-EU partner to the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: How immigration law changed for Commonwealth citizens
fact_check_explanation_summary: Theresa May, Diane Abbott and the Immigration Act 2014

fact_check_explanation_title: What was known about Windrush in 2014?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2014, a report included stories from members of the Windrush generation facing difficulties proving their immigration status. We don’t know whether Theresa May saw it, but the Home Office …

fact_check_explanation_title: What happened to violent crime in London since 2008?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Under Boris Johnson’s time as mayor the murder rate halved, though we can’t say for sure whether the rise in stop and searches was effective.

fact_check_explanation_title: How the EU works: what is the customs union?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU’s customs union was first established in 1968 by the six founding member states of the current EU (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands).

fact_check_explanation_title: Health visitor numbers in England down by a fifth since 2015
fact_check_explanation_summary: There were the equivalent of 10,000 NHS health visitors working full-time in England in December 2015. That fell by 19% by December 2017 to just over 8,200 now.

fact_check_explanation_title: Would free bus travel save young people £1,000 a year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour made several claims about young people and bus travel in a video to launch their new free travel policy.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many child asylum seekers are found to be adults?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Two thirds of assessed child asylum seekers, but a small proportion of all child asylum seekers, are found to be over 18.

fact_check_explanation_title: 28% of 2-15 year olds in England estimated to be overweight or obese
fact_check_explanation_summary: An estimated 16% of children aged 2-15 in England were obese in 2016, and a further 12% were overweight.

fact_check_explanation_title: Stop and search: higher arrest rate?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of stop and searches fell by 78% between 2009/10 and 2016/17, with the proportion leading to arrests rising from 8% to 17% in the same period.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are children being used to carry drugs?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Reports from police in England and Wales to the National Crime Agency suggest in 42% of forces children as young as 12 are being used to carry drugs from urban …

fact_check_explanation_title: The net migration target was never likely to have been met
fact_check_explanation_summary: Governments since 2010 have set a target to reduce net migration to the tens of thousands, and this target has never been met.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many stop and searches are knife crime related?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 9% of successful stop and searches in London relate to possession of an offensive weapon, which includes knives, as well as other sharp weapons and acid.

fact_check_explanation_title: Who gets more, pensioners or refugees?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This viral image claims that pensioners can collect just a fifth of what ‘illegal immigrants’ and refugees can. But how much can each group really get?

fact_check_explanation_title: 4,000 EU prisoners in England and Wales
fact_check_explanation_summary: There were 4,000 EU nationals in prison in England and Wales at the end of 2017, and over 9,000 foreign prisoners overall. It’s not easy to determine the cost of …

fact_check_explanation_title: Knife Crime in England and Wales
fact_check_explanation_summary: In the year to September 2017, there were just under 37,500 recorded offences involving the use of a knife or sharp instrument in England and Wales.

fact_check_explanation_title: Windrush generation: what's the situation?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Around 60,000 people from the Windrush generation living in the UK in 2017 report not being a UK citizen. This doesn’t tell us how many may have faced recent immigration …

fact_check_explanation_title: What did Labour Party members say about antisemitism?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A poll found 77% of Labour members think media coverage of antisemitism in the party is exaggerated to undermine the party. But 66% also agree antisemitism is a problem for …

fact_check_explanation_title: Does parliament get a vote on military intervention?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister has the power—through the Crown—to take military action. But in recent years governments have argued that military action be put to a parliamentary vote in non-emergency cases.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK citizens getting citizenship of another EU country
fact_check_explanation_summary: Between 2015 and 2016, the number of UK citizens being granted citizenship of another EU country more than doubled.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Irish border and Brexit
fact_check_explanation_summary: Nobody can say for sure what will happen to the border between Ireland and Northern Ireland when Brexit happens.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are taxpayers paying less income tax than in 2010?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The typical taxpayer will pay £850 less tax in income tax 2018/19 compared to 2010/11, once inflation is included, due to increases in the personal allowance.

fact_check_explanation_title: Drugs and homicide
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of homicides involving a victim or suspect who was a drug user or dealer rose from 41% in 2014/15 to 42% 2016/17 in England and Wales.

fact_check_explanation_title: Have house prices risen because of immigrants?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s impossible to say for definite how much immigration has pushed up house prices.

fact_check_explanation_title: Gender pay gap: what do the new figures tell us?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 78% of 10,000 UK employers, most with over 250 staff, have a gender pay gap. The median hourly wage gap for these employers is around 10%.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are more people going into hospital for obesity related illnesses?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of obesity related hospital admissions has increased in the last four years, and obesity levels have remained roughly the same since 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the number of murders in London overtaken New York?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s correct that in February, more people were murdered in London than in New York, but New York’s overall homicide rate is higher, though falling.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tax giveaways and takeaways since 2010
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at the tax policies announced over the last eight years, and the impacts they've had.

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS pay: what’s the deal?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A proposed deal will see pay rise for some NHS staff by between 4.5% and 29% over three years, including both salary rises and staff pay progression. The rise will …

fact_check_explanation_title: Are more children being taken from their families?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are more children being “looked after” by their local authorities, which can mean they have been placed for adoption, fostered, and in some cases, placed with their parents.

fact_check_explanation_title: Free school meals and Universal Credit
fact_check_explanation_summary: The criteria for receiving free school meals is changing

fact_check_explanation_title: Lorries at Dover
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Port of Dover has previously said that between 1% and 3% of lorries arriving at Dover are not from the EU, but we haven’t been able to confirm the …

fact_check_explanation_title: Living long and prospering?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Over the last 50 years, people in the UK have become richer in general. Life expectancy isn’t falling overall, but its rate of increase has slowed down in recent years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Young trans people in Britain
fact_check_explanation_summary: A survey raised concerns about high numbers of young trans people attempting to take their own lives. We don’t know how representative the findings are of young trans people in …

fact_check_explanation_title: How did young people vote in the Brexit referendum?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A poll estimated that 73% of under-25 voters voted Remain in the EU referendum. Other polls have reached a similar figure, but it’s impossible to say exactly what the true …

fact_check_explanation_title: What rights do you get at 18?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In England and Wales, you can’t buy a house yourself until you’re 18.

fact_check_explanation_title: House building in England
fact_check_explanation_summary: Our overview of the supply and demand for homes in England.

fact_check_explanation_title: Homelessness in England
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've put together some of the key facts on homelessness and rough sleeping in England.

fact_check_explanation_title: A&E performance: England v Wales
fact_check_explanation_summary: A higher percentage of A&E patients spend 12 hours in A&E in Wales than in England. Asking who is responsible for that is a complex question.

fact_check_explanation_title: Most non-UK citizens can’t donate to UK political parties
fact_check_explanation_summary: UK political parties can only accept donations from “permissible donors”. Individuals must be on the electoral register to donate.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK is one of the three largest economies in the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK is the EU’s second largest economy after Germany, or third after Germany and France, depending on the measure of GDP you look at.

fact_check_explanation_title: Our Brexit divorce bill will probably be paid off by 2064
fact_check_explanation_summary: The OBR has estimated that the Brexit “divorce” bill will come to £37 billion and will be paid off by 2064.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fewer votes in parliament: Aye or no?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There have been fewer votes in Parliament since the 2017 election than the same period after each election since 1997.

fact_check_explanation_title: Economy introductions: the size of the government deficit
fact_check_explanation_summary: Everything you need to know about the UK's budget deficit.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mobile roaming fees could be back after Brexit
fact_check_explanation_summary: After Brexit, the UK will no longer be subject to EU laws which prohibit mobile roaming fees within the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: 11% of UK engineers are women
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are an estimated 48,000 women working in engineering professions compared to 400,000 men.

fact_check_explanation_title: 32,000 people work in the British steel industry
fact_check_explanation_summary: 32,000 people worked in steel in 2016. More than half of these jobs are in Wales, and Yorkshire and Humber.

fact_check_explanation_title: There are 1.1 million more homes in England since 2010
fact_check_explanation_summary: 217,000 homes were added to the overall housing stock in England in 2016/17, the second highest amount in the last 26 years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Social housing stock has fallen over the last 30 years
fact_check_explanation_summary: The proportion of people living in social housing halved between the early 1980s and early 2010s, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies.

fact_check_explanation_title: Factchecking campaigning leaflets on abortion
fact_check_explanation_summary: Abortion became legal in certain circumstances in Britain in 1968. There have been 8.7 million recorded abortions since then.

fact_check_explanation_title: Domestic abuse in England and Wales
fact_check_explanation_summary: 26% of women aged 16-59 report having experienced some kind of domestic abuse as adults. 15% of men report the same.

fact_check_explanation_title: Small businesses and Brexit
fact_check_explanation_summary: Theresa May and Jeremy Corbyn clashed on small businesses and Brexit negotiations. We factchecked their claims.

fact_check_explanation_title: Over half of UK exports were via EU trade agreements in 2016
fact_check_explanation_summary: Just over half of UK exports were done via EU trade agreements in 2016. 43% of exports went to EU member states.

fact_check_explanation_title: Deja-EU referendum?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In January Nigel Farage said that he feared we may have to have a second EU referendum.

fact_check_explanation_title: About 15% of the UK’s electricity comes from wind
fact_check_explanation_summary: Over a quarter of the UK’s electricity is coming from wind at the height of the winter snow, but usually it accounts for 15% across the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tuition fees and access to higher education
fact_check_explanation_summary: How have rising tuition fees affected the number of people going to university, and has it put off those from disadvantaged backgrounds?

fact_check_explanation_title: No-one knows the exact cost or benefit of the NHS internal market in England
fact_check_explanation_summary: A widely-quoted estimate of £10 billion as the cost of the NHS internal market can’t be backed up by the evidence.

fact_check_explanation_title: Trade across the Irish border
fact_check_explanation_summary: Trade across the Irish border was worth at least £5 billion in 2016.

fact_check_explanation_title: Two UK schemes have resettled 11,000 Syrian refugees
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government has a target to take in 23,000 refugees by 2020 from the Middle East and North Africa.

fact_check_explanation_title: 6% of young first-time students drop out of university after their first year
fact_check_explanation_summary: Overall, mature students are more likely to drop out of full-time degrees than younger students, and disadvantaged students are more likely than their peers to drop out.

fact_check_explanation_title: About 17% of students are forecast to fully pay back their loans
fact_check_explanation_summary: Most students won’t back their loans in full. The Institute for Fiscal Studies estimates that around 83% of graduates will see at least part of their debt written off.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much meat do we eat?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A range of surveys suggest 2-3% of the UK is vegetarian, and household consumption of meat has fallen in recent years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Could 18 million GP appointments be seen by pharmacists?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A survey of around 60 GPs found that 6% of appointments could have been dealt with at home or at a pharmacy, but we can’t say if it’s an accurate …

fact_check_explanation_title: Spending for adult skills fell by 40% between 2010 and 2015
fact_check_explanation_summary: This funding pays for “further education” such as classroom and workplace learning for people aged 19 and over.

fact_check_explanation_title: Exam stress for school children
fact_check_explanation_summary: Exam stress clearly affects children in the UK, and there’s some evidence from counselling services and school leaders that it’s a growing problem.

fact_check_explanation_title: Government defence spending is 2% of GDP
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2015, the Conservative government pledged to spend 2% of GDP on the armed forces budget in every year that decade. It has never been below this level on record.

fact_check_explanation_title: Nearly 2 million more children are in good or outstanding schools since 2010
fact_check_explanation_summary: An increasing proportion of children are in ‘good’ schools, while a decreasing proportion are in ‘requires improvement’ schools.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK spending on foreign aid
fact_check_explanation_summary: For every hundred pounds that’s made in the UK, seventy pence goes overseas as foreign aid. Here's some basic facts and figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: Falsely claiming to live alone accounts for around 9% of benefit fraud
fact_check_explanation_summary: Benefit claimants saying they were single, when in fact they lived as a couple with another person, was probably the fourth most common type of benefit fraud in 2016/17.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mental health during pregnancy
fact_check_explanation_summary: Around one in four pregnant mothers studied by King’s College London had a mental health disorder, but the study wasn’t designed to be representative of all pregnant women in the …

fact_check_explanation_title: People who look after people tend to be women on low pay
fact_check_explanation_summary: More women work in occupations that tend to offer lower salaries such as administration and caring.

fact_check_explanation_title: The gender pay gap has been falling over time
fact_check_explanation_summary: The gender pay gap, measured by comparing median hourly earnings, is close to a record low level in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: More people are in work since the Brexit vote
fact_check_explanation_summary: Employment has increased since the Brexit vote, and the unemployment rate is 4.3%.

fact_check_explanation_title: The pound has fallen in value since the Brexit vote
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK had the third-slowest GDP growth in the EU in the last year, and the value of the pound has fallen by 12% against the Euro since May 2016.

fact_check_explanation_title: Government funding for the rail industry
fact_check_explanation_summary: How does taxpayer support for privatised rail compare with funding for the old British Rail?

fact_check_explanation_title: Spending on schools in England
fact_check_explanation_summary: Real-terms per pupil funding for schools stayed at roughly the same level from 2010/11 to 2015/16, and fell after that. Since 2017/18 it has flattened out.

fact_check_explanation_title: Women in the Commons
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are a record number of women in the House of Commons. Labour has the most female MPs. The Conservatives have had the only women Prime Ministers.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are junior doctors paid enough to get a UK visa?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In December 2017, a non-EEA junior doctor needed to be earning £55,000 in order to get a visa for the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Allegations of rape
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s impossible to know how many false allegations of rape are made, but the evidence suggests that proven cases are rare. 3-4% of allegations is a reasonable estimate.

fact_check_explanation_title: Reported rapes that reach trial
fact_check_explanation_summary: Around one in ten rapes or attempted rapes reported to police in England and Wales are brought to trial.

fact_check_explanation_title: Women killed by men
fact_check_explanation_summary: Just under half of all women killed were killed by their partners or ex-partners, according to the latest official statistics for England and Wales in 2015/16.

fact_check_explanation_title: How sweet is sixteen? Legal age limits in England and Wales
fact_check_explanation_summary: You’re legally a child until the age of 18, but the minimum legal age is 16 for some things.

fact_check_explanation_title: Brits abroad: how many people from the UK live in other EU countries?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Around 1.3 million British-born people live in other EU countries, according to United Nations figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are computers getting better than humans at reading?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Computers aren't getting better than humans at reading. “Even elementary school reading comprehensions are harder” than the test computers passed, says the test’s creator.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are parents paying for free nursery places?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 28% of childcare providers responding to a survey said parents receiving 30 hours free childcare (under a government scheme) may be paying for additional hours or services.

fact_check_explanation_title: Who owns Britain’s trains, energy and postal service?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some providers of UK utilities like energy, post and rail have links with foreign governments

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS Scotland: how much is being spent?
fact_check_explanation_summary: NHS Scotland spending is planned to increase by £2 billion, accounting for projected inflation, between 2006/07 and 2018/19.

fact_check_explanation_title: Scotland spends 20% more per head on public services than England
fact_check_explanation_summary: An increasing proportion of the Scottish government’s budget comes from taxes raised in Scotland, rather than the block grant.

fact_check_explanation_title: Crime in England and Wales
fact_check_explanation_summary: Crime as experienced and recounted by adults is falling in general and has been since the mid-1990s.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fiddled A&E statistics?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Unpublished guidance to NHS Trusts has raised questions about whether A&E statistics can be trusted.

fact_check_explanation_title: The number of nurses and midwives in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: How many nurses work in the UK and what kind of work do they do? We took a look.

fact_check_explanation_title: Why was PFI so popular in the 2000s?
fact_check_explanation_summary: PFIs were widely seen as the only viable option for funding construction projects among some public bodies in the 2000s, and used across government departments.

fact_check_explanation_title: Where have all the (EU) nurses gone?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In the year to September 2017 the number of nurses from the EU leaving the NHS in England outweighed those joining it for the first time in at least five …

fact_check_explanation_title: How much is the UK spending on security at Calais?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK and France have cooperated on border controls around French ports for years. How much do we spend on doing so?

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK and France are the biggest defence spenders in Europe
fact_check_explanation_summary: Which countries in Europe spend the most on defence?

fact_check_explanation_title: Did a Labour-run council sign a PFI contract with Carillion in December?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Carillion was signed off by Leeds City Council as the preferred bidder for a project in December 2017, but no contract was signed.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many PFI contracts did the last Labour government sign with Carillion?
fact_check_explanation_summary: What proportion of Carillion PFI deals were awarded during the Labour government?

fact_check_explanation_title: How diverse is the government?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Women, ethnic minorities and people who attended a comprehensive school are all underrepresented within the Cabinet.

fact_check_explanation_title: Emergency admissions to hospitals from care homes are up 62%
fact_check_explanation_summary: Emergency admissions from care homes rose by 62% between 2010/11 and 2016/17. Overall emergency admissions rose by 11% in that time.

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS: More beds, more doctors, and more flu vaccines?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of NHS hospital beds has halved in the last thirty years, but the number of doctors has risen consistently.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much money does the NHS need and how much is it actually getting?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Experts said NHS England needed £4 billion in 2018/19. The government announced in November it will receive £1.6 billion, or £1.9 billion including capital spending.

fact_check_explanation_title: More ambulances are being delayed outside A&Es
fact_check_explanation_summary: One in six ambulances were delayed for over half an hour after arriving at A&Es in England in the first week of 2018.

fact_check_explanation_title: More people, more (NHS) problems?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Both the UK’s population and average life expectancy has increased since the founding of the NHS.

fact_check_explanation_title: The ever-changing past – constructing and revising GDP data
fact_check_explanation_summary: An explanation of how GDP is constructed and why it is revised.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do the top 1% of earners pay 28% of the tax burden?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There aren’t any readily available figures for what proportion of all taxes the top 1% pays. This claim is just referring to income taxes.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the NHS recruiting enough new GPs?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of GPs is falling, but we can’t be certain by how much. The number in training is rising, although we don’t know if this will be enough for …

fact_check_explanation_title: Has 92% of the country not been built on?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Estimates range between 88% and 99.9%. It also depends on if we include gardens and “green urban” areas.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mental health staff in the NHS
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of mental health doctors and nurses in the NHS has been falling.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mental health crisis care
fact_check_explanation_summary: Liaison psychiatry is available in nearly all A&Es in England. More than half of these are 24/7, but the extent of care provision still varies across them.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mental Health in England: Jeremy Hunt vs Ralf Little
fact_check_explanation_summary: The actor and the Health Secretary got into a dispute on Twitter over mental health services in England. We factchecked their claims.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mental health: staff working in talking therapies
fact_check_explanation_summary: Staff numbers working in the talking therapies programme for people with anxiety and depression have risen by at least 2,850 since 2012.

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS spending on mental health
fact_check_explanation_summary: NHS England spent £11.6 billion on mental health in 2016/17.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are 40% of nurses leaving full-time work in their first year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 15% of new full-time NHS England nurses left full-time work in the year May 2016 to May 2017. Overall, 41% of new nurses weren’t in full-time employment by May 2017.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can MPs breastfeed in the House of Commons?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It was ruled that breastfeeding was not allowed in the House of Commons Chamber and select committees in 2000, but a 2016 review has recommended changes.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much is spent on health and social care in the NHS?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Around 83% of English acute hospital trusts are in deficit so far this year. Social care spending has also fallen by £1.3 billion since 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: What help is available for homeless people sleeping outside in cold weather?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Councils in England can take emergency measures to help rough sleepers during extreme weather.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many children are homeless in England, Scotland and Wales?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 128,000 children are living in temporary accommodation in Britain.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is house building at record levels?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 184,000 new homes were built in England in 2016/17, and there were 217,000 more homes added to the overall stock.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are 400,000 more children in absolute poverty since 2010?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s not correct that absolute child poverty has risen by this much since 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: Brexit impact assessments: did the government bluff about their existence?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We take on the hunt for 57 disappearing impact assessments.

fact_check_explanation_title: Social mobility and universities
fact_check_explanation_summary: We looked at the proportion of private school pupils going to Oxford and getting top jobs and the proportion of students from disadvantaged backgrounds going to university.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is social mobility in England still all about the North/South divide?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A report by the Social Mobility Commission says there isn’t a simple north/south divide on social mobility.

fact_check_explanation_title: What skills are we short of in the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no simple definition for a shortage profession, but nurses and chefs are currently listed by experts as needing workers from overseas.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the number of people starting apprenticeships fallen?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Yes. Apprenticeship starts in May to July this year were 59% lower than in the same period last year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Trade with America: are we getting a good deal?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK runs a trade surplus with the USA and a deficit with the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: About one in five people live in absolute or relative poverty if their housing costs are included
fact_check_explanation_summary: An estimated one in five people in the UK lives in absolute or relative poverty, after housing costs are taken into account.

fact_check_explanation_title: Have more council houses been built in the last seven years than under Labour?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Technically more council houses have been built since 2010 than during the 13 years of Labour but most new social houses aren’t council houses.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are we spending more than half our income on rent?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are 12 local authorities where the person on the average salary would have to spend 60% or more of their income to pay the average private rent.

fact_check_explanation_title: Productivity: are we keeping up with Germany?
fact_check_explanation_summary: No. On average German workers took four hours to produce what UK workers produced in five hours in 2016.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the UK economy in the relegation zone?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Our economy was the fastest growing in the G7 in 2014 but is now one of the worst performers, according to various experts.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did badly-regulated bankers cause the recession?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Lots of things went wrong, but experts agree that regulation was one of them.

fact_check_explanation_title: What’s happened to fire services since 2010?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Firefighter numbers have decreased by 22% since 2010 and fire-related deaths have increased by 20% since last year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Childcare costs in England
fact_check_explanation_summary: A breakdown of the cost of childcare in England.

fact_check_explanation_title: Budget forecasts: take them with a pinch of salt
fact_check_explanation_summary: Predicting the future is hard—but forecasts are useful for policy makers.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the government banned the term 'pregnant woman'?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The term 'pregnant woman' is not being banned by the government. It’s not even being discouraged.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are nurses taking a second job to survive?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Nearly a quarter of respondents to a Royal College of Nursing survey said they had taken an additional job. We don’t know how representative this is of all nurses.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is austerity linked to 120,000 unnecessary deaths?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A report estimates 120,000 more people have died since 2010 than would have if the mortality rate from 2001-10 had stayed the same.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is unemployment the lowest it has been since 1975?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This is correct, as a percentage of all adults either working or looking for a job across the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the EU becoming less important to the world economy?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Although the EU’s GDP is growing, it is at a slower rate than the rest of the world’s.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did 500,000 children need emergency food supplies last year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The figure is about the number of three day emergency food supplies given out to children by the Trussell Trust last year—about 437,000—not the number of children who received them.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do women earn less than men in the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2017, the median hourly wage for women working full time was about 9.1% less than the median hourly wage for men (excluding overtime). That’s £1.32 less per hour.

fact_check_explanation_title: A&E waiting times: are they getting longer?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of A&E attendances has generally been increasing, with a smaller proportion being seen inside four hours.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do most people own one house?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In England the share of households with a second home is small. The majority of households in England, Northern Ireland and Scotland own their home.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is London losing 3,000 police officers?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Yes, according to the Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, who says she expects this to happen by 2020.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is wage growth at the same level as during the Napoleonic wars?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This isn’t quite right, but wage growth is at its lowest level in peacetime since the Napoleonic Wars.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does the UK have lower unemployment than the Eurozone?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK unemployment rate was 4.3% earlier this year, compared to 9% average across the Eurozone.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tax dodging: how big is the problem?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government says the tax gap is £34 billion. Other estimates go as high as £122 billion.

fact_check_explanation_title: Have childcare costs risen up to seven times faster than wages?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Parents of under-twos are particularly affected by rising nursery costs.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many countries allow parents to smack children?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A small group of countries in Europe, including the UK, do not have an outright ban on parents smacking children.

fact_check_explanation_title: Sexual violence and domestic abuse
fact_check_explanation_summary: Official surveys show how widespread sexual violence and domestic abuse are.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are fewer parents smacking their children?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Research suggests fewer parents are smacking their children in the UK and many other countries.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can Scotland recognise Catalonia as an independent state?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Foreign affairs are a reserved matter so the Scottish government has no legal power to recognise Catalan independence.

fact_check_explanation_title: How big is Scotland’s deficit compared to the UK as a whole?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Scottish deficit is more than three times that of the UK as a whole, as a proportion of GDP.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the EU’s budget ‘signed off’ by auditors?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s often argued both that the EU’s budget hasn’t been signed off by the auditors for years, and that it’s consistently given a clean bill of health.

fact_check_explanation_title: Shared parental leave: self-employed people
fact_check_explanation_summary: Self-employed mothers can exchange maternity allowance for shared parental leave and pay for their partner, if he is employed—but they have to give up the allowance.

fact_check_explanation_title: Economy introductions: the idea behind interest rate changes
fact_check_explanation_summary: An introduction to why the Bank of England changes its interest rates.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much has the government recouped from tax evasion and avoidance?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Last year HMRC estimates it made £29 billion extra as a result of its compliance activities.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are the super-rich paying less income tax?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The amount of income tax collected from the wealthiest in 2009 was unusual as people sought to avoid a tax rise in 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does the government spend £50 billion on debt interest payments?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Interest payments on government debt are higher than spending on defence or primary education, but slightly lower than secondary education and the NHS pay bill.

fact_check_explanation_title: Were no psychiatric beds available anywhere in England at the weekend?
fact_check_explanation_summary: NHS England say it’s incorrect there were no psychiatric beds available overnight across England on 28 October 2017. Previously services providers have said no beds of particular types were free.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is Oxbridge still a rich white student's world?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Check the figures on Oxford and Cambridge entry.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has there been a recession since the EU referendum?
