fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK economy has continued to grow since the UK voted to leave the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Will getting rid of EU tariffs help the worst off?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Higher tariffs make what we buy from other countries more expensive.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is it legal to kill people fighting for Islamic State in Syria?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no single authoritative statement of what’s allowed in international law.

fact_check_explanation_title: The number of detentions under the Mental Health Act is rising
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of people detained under the Mental Health Act has increased by 47% in ten years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do you pay a higher tax rate than a millionaire?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Marginal tax rates can be very high for both high and low earners.

fact_check_explanation_title: 30 hours free childcare: only a quarter of places delivered?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 54% of the places currently planned have been delivered so far.

fact_check_explanation_title: An ageing population and A&E
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK’s population is ageing and more people are going to A&E every year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are people in work using food banks?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The most recent data shows that 15% of households that use Trussell Trust foodbanks include at least one person with some work or employment income.

fact_check_explanation_title: What’s Labour policy on a ‘no deal’ for Brexit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour has not said how much money it thinks the UK should pay to the EU when we leave. It has said that ‘no deal’ is not an option.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did the government ignore a vote in parliament on Universal Credit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Conservative MPs were told not to take part in the vote. Over 40 Conservative MPs spoke in the debate.

fact_check_explanation_title: What proportion of benefit claimants has Universal Credit been applied to?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Between 8% of expected claimants by 2022 are claiming Universal Credit.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK economy; what was the OECD's verdict?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK economy grew at 0.3% in the last quarter, this is the slowest growth rate in the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the UK economy in the slow lane?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK economy grew at 0.3% in the last quarter, this is the slowest growth rate in the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is there a long list of people urging a pause on Universal Credit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Citizens Advice and Trussell Trust have called for a pause, and John Major has recommended a review. The number of Conservative MPs calling for a pause is based on reports …

fact_check_explanation_title: Are more people being paid an advance on their Universal Credit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The share of people getting an advance payment on their first Universal Credit payment is increasing.

fact_check_explanation_title: Young people in record levels of debt?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s not clear this is the case looking at the levels of debt of all young people, including those not at university.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much does the Universal Credit helpline cost?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Universal Credit helpline cost up to 9p a minute from a landline and between 3p and 55p per minute from a mobile. The helpline is now being made freephone.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are doctors going to be forced to ask about your sexual orientation?
fact_check_explanation_summary: NHS England told us that new guidelines on collecting information on the sexual orientation of patients aren’t compulsory.

fact_check_explanation_title: How valuable is Bombardier to the economy of Northern Ireland?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Bombardier is a significant part of the Northern Irish economy but we’ve seen no evidence that it’s worth a full 10% of GDP.

fact_check_explanation_title: Unemployment in the UK since 1975
fact_check_explanation_summary: Unemployment in the UK was at 4.3% between May and July 2017.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many women leave Northern Ireland to have an abortion in Britain?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Around 4,000 women living in Ireland and Northern Ireland came to England and Wales for an abortion in 2016.

fact_check_explanation_title: Abortions in court in Northern Ireland
fact_check_explanation_summary: Abortion is banned in Northern Ireland except to protect the health of the mother. Campaigners have been trying to change the law.

fact_check_explanation_title: 60% of Northern Ireland’s exports go to the rest of the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: Correct that 60% of all sales from Northern Ireland went to Great Britain in 2015.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is Universal Credit leading to rent arrears?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Half of council tenants in 105 councils are one month behind in rent, according to research by the Observer.

fact_check_explanation_title: Were 1.4 million stuck on out-of-work benefits under Labour?
fact_check_explanation_summary: According to 2010 research by the Department for Work and Pensions, 1.4 million people were on out of work benefits in nine of the last ten years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is Universal Credit being paid on time?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The percentage of people receiving their first universal credit payment within five or six weeks has increased since January.

fact_check_explanation_title: What is a junior doctor?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Junior doctors make up almost half of all doctors in hospitals in England, and can have up to ten years of practical medical experience.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are British businesses struggling with recruitment?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 52% of businesses surveyed by Lloyd’s Bank in June were struggling to recruit skilled labour.

fact_check_explanation_title: How old is the average Conservative Party member?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s almost impossible to know exactly what the Conservative membership's average age is, but 57 is probably the best guess for now.

fact_check_explanation_title: Who's right on disadvantaged young people at university?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Most recent data suggests disadvantaged students may be beginning to lose ground in higher education - but it's too soon to read too much into it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Housing: supply and demand
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of houses being built has increased over the last decade, but it’s not keeping up with demand.

fact_check_explanation_title: Comparisons between disadvantaged English and Scottish students are tricky
fact_check_explanation_summary: Students from a disadvantaged background in Scotland are roughly half as likely to go to university as those from England. That said, comparing the figures for Scotland and England is …

fact_check_explanation_title: Young people and race in the criminal justice system
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of young offenders has fallen to a record low, but the proportion of BAME young offenders in custody has risen over the last ten years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the term 'NHS winter crisis' becoming more common?
fact_check_explanation_summary: What does a crude search for articles containing both NHS and “winter crisis” in a newspaper database tell us about use of the term?

fact_check_explanation_title: Does Labour expect a run on the pound?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour is not expecting a run on the pound, but both Corbyn and McDonnell support “scenario-plans” which consider what to do if it should happen under their government.

fact_check_explanation_title: Will £500 million make any difference to the NHS at winter?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Government after government has considered £500 million plenty of money to boast about giving the NHS to help deal with the extra pressures of winter.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the NHS got the money it asked for?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The NHS “got less than we asked for”, the chief of NHS England Simon Stevens told MPs in the Public Accounts Committee in January.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the government getting the deficit down?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The deficit has been coming down, but not as rapidly as the Coalition and the Conservatives had said in 2010 and 2015.

fact_check_explanation_title: Heartache in Hertsmere: the unhappiest place in the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: “Overall, how happy did you feel yesterday”, the Office for National Statistics asks people every year.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many people earn less than the living wage?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Around 6 million employee jobs earned less than the living wage in 2016. We can’t say exactly how many people this applies to as some may be doing more than …

fact_check_explanation_title: 10,000 finance jobs lost since Brexit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no evidence we’ve seen showing that 10,000 jobs have already been lost in financial services following the EU referendum.

fact_check_explanation_title: Student debt: what did Labour say?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Jeremy Corbyn didn’t commit to abolishing student debt before the last election, although he did say he would “deal with” the high debts of graduates and was looking at ways …

fact_check_explanation_title: What’s been the impact of higher tuition fees on disadvantaged students going to university?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Higher tuition fees don’t seem to have affected the longer-term trend of more disadvantaged students going to university.

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS staff from the EU: one year on from the referendum
fact_check_explanation_summary: 9,800 staff reporting they were from the EU left NHS England between June 2016 and June 2017.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Foreign Secretary and the UK Statistics Authority: £350 million explained
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Foreign Secretary and the UK's statistics watchdog have clashed over an inaccurate claim that the UK is set to take back control of £350 million a week.

fact_check_explanation_title: £350 million EU claim "a clear misuse of official statistics"
fact_check_explanation_summary: After we leave the EU, we cannot take back control of £350 million a week.

fact_check_explanation_title: The food and drinks industry after the EU referendum
fact_check_explanation_summary: Has the food and drinks industry said they face significant disruption and economic damage in EU nationals continue to leave the UK?

fact_check_explanation_title: Was the private sector hit hardest by the recession?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Private sector wages dropped much more rapidly than public sector wages during the recession. They began recovering as public sector wages slowed. In recent years the gap between the two …

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the National Living Wage reduced inequality?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The National Living Wage has increased earnings, but there’s more to inequality trends than just changes to wages.

fact_check_explanation_title: The cost of lifting the public sector pay cap
fact_check_explanation_summary: Matching public sector pay to inflation over the next few years is estimated to cost £4 billion a year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Have some police officers had a 32% pay rise?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims about police pay at PMQs aren’t likely to represent the experience of most officers.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are household savings at their lowest in 50 years?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The household saving ratio has hit an all-time low, but the figures don’t quite tell the full story

fact_check_explanation_title: Disabled people in work
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of disabled people in work has increased over the last four years.

fact_check_explanation_title: The European Union (Withdrawal) Bill
fact_check_explanation_summary: The European Union (Withdrawal) Bill will repeal the European Communities Act 1972. It means EU institutions can’t make laws affecting the UK any more. It used to be known as …

fact_check_explanation_title: The Tower Hamlets fostering case: should we trust the news or trust a judge?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Media reports suggested a white Christian girl was taken from her family and made to live with a family who didn't speak English. How do we find out if this …

fact_check_explanation_title: Are we short of 40,000 nurses?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There were 40,000 vacant nursing positions in England in December 2016, according to the Royal College of Nursing.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many Nobel Prizes has the UK won?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK is second only to the United States on number of prizes won, but the position falls when you take other factors into account.

fact_check_explanation_title: Executive pay: power to the shareholders?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Executive pay policy is being strengthened, but not to the extent that was previously pledged.

fact_check_explanation_title: Energy companies profits at their highest level ever?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Average profit margins for the big six energy companies are at their highest level.

fact_check_explanation_title: What do we know about the ethnicity of people involved in sexual offences against children?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The information we have about the ethnicity of those involved in sexual grooming and sexual offences against children more widely is patchy and has a lot of problems.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are there more doctors in the NHS than in 2010?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are 11,700 more doctors working in NHS hospitals and community health services in England in May 2017 compared to May 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many non-EU students are staying in the UK illegally?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The vast majority of students here on a visa seem to be returning home, according to new data from the Home Office.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do pension changes mean 37 million people working longer?
fact_check_explanation_summary: How many people will be affected by government proposals to bring forward the rise in the state pension age by seven years?

fact_check_explanation_title: More young people are going to university
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number and proportion of young people, including disadvantaged students, attending university is now increasing.

fact_check_explanation_title: Could there be a new temporary customs union after Brexit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Department for Exiting the EU has today set out the government’s hopes for the UK’s future customs arrangements.

fact_check_explanation_title: One in four? How many people suffer from a mental health problem
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's widely claimed that one in four people suffer from a mental health problem. But it's often misunderstood where the figure comes from and what it means.

fact_check_explanation_title: Stops and searches are becoming less common
fact_check_explanation_summary: The use of stop and search powers across England and Wales has fallen significantly over the past few years.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many international students leave after studying in the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There aren’t official figures to prove how many international students return home after their studies, and the available evidence which might give an indication is contradictory.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are more working class students dropping out of university?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The proportion of first time UK students from disadvantaged areas leaving higher education during or after the first year of their degree in England is at its highest level for …

fact_check_explanation_title: What is the Prevent strategy?
fact_check_explanation_summary: BBC Question Time on 25 May featured a lot of discussion about the government’s Prevent strategy. But what is Prevent?

fact_check_explanation_title: European airport delays—is Brexit to blame?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The controls affect all passengers entering and leaving the European border-free Schengen area, not just UK citizens.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does the government spend £50 billion a year on disabled people?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government spends around £50 billion on benefits which either go wholly or in part to disabled people, people with health conditions and their carers, including housing benefit and income …

fact_check_explanation_title: The state of prisons in England and Wales
fact_check_explanation_summary: Prisoner numbers, prison staff numbers and levels of violence in English and Welsh jails.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are mental health nurse numbers down?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are 5,000 fewer mental health nurses since 2010, using a broader definition of mental health nurses used by NHS Digital, there are 7,000 fewer.

fact_check_explanation_title: Muslims in the UK: the viral poster, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post is circulating on social media making several claims about Muslims in the UK. Much of it is wrong.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does the EU say it's safe to eat chicken rinsed in chlorine?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU's food standards arm says there are "no safety concerns" with the process of washing chicken with chlorine, but has raised other concerns about hygiene.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can you be in the single market without being an EU member?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s technically possible for a non-EU member to be in the single market. But this arrangement means accepting rules set by the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Adult social care in England
fact_check_explanation_summary: Adult social care is the support provided to adults with physical or learning disabilities, or physical or mental illnesses.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the NHS been judged the best healthcare system in the world?
fact_check_explanation_summary: International comparisons of healthcare are about the UK, not just the NHS. How we do depends on the measures chosen.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are most working age people in poverty also in work?
fact_check_explanation_summary: People in poverty have been increasingly likely to be in a family where someone has a job.

fact_check_explanation_title: Income tax cuts for basic rate payers
fact_check_explanation_summary: Increases to the income tax personal allowance have taken millions out of income tax, although those on low incomes have been hit elsewhere.

fact_check_explanation_title: Could leaving the European nuclear club put cancer patients at risk?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We don't fully know how leaving Euratom - the European common market in nuclear materials - will affect our access to them.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can't get no NHS satisfaction?
fact_check_explanation_summary: One survey says most people are satisfied with the NHS, another says more of us are dissatisfied. Why the different results?

fact_check_explanation_title: Have university applicant numbers fallen in 2017?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The total number of people applying to higher education in the UK this year (as of the final June 2017 deadline) is down 4% compared to last year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Women at the despatch box for Prime Minister’s Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: Both the Conservatives and Labour have had three women in total representing their respective parties at Prime Minister’s Questions since 1997 (either as leaders, or as representatives of the leader).

fact_check_explanation_title: Is youth unemployment at a historic low?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Youth unemployment in the UK is currently 12.5%, among the lowest it’s been since 2005.

fact_check_explanation_title: £100 billion: the cost of writing off student debt?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The true ‘additional’ cost of a policy to write off current student loans, compared to the amount the government already ‘writes off’ from unpaid loans, would be lower than this.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: the 'Great Repeal Bill'
fact_check_explanation_summary: A brief explanation of the Great Repeal Bill announced by the government in October 2016, as part of the process of leaving the European Union.

fact_check_explanation_title: Who's working in the 'gig economy'?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some of the key figures on the gig economy, to put the claims into context.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are people with mental health conditions now receiving higher disability benefit payments?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A greater share of people claiming disability benefits because of mental health conditions are receiving the higher rate, but that doesn’t mean that those claiming these benefits are all better …

fact_check_explanation_title: What’s happening to nursing numbers?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We looked at the change in the number of nurses working for the NHS since May 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many journalists went to public school?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 51% of the UK’s ‘top 100’ journalists educated and working in the UK in 2015 attended a private school, according to the Sutton Trust.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many jobs are dependent on the single market?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures on this subject don't tell us how many jobs would actually be lost if we left the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Midwives leaving the profession
fact_check_explanation_summary: According to the Royal College of Midwives 80% of the midwives who were intending to leave midwifery in the next two years said that increased pay would encourage them to …

fact_check_explanation_title: Local authorities' budgets are roughly 26% lower since 2010
fact_check_explanation_summary: Have local authority budgets have been cut by 40% since 2010?

fact_check_explanation_title: Have concerns been raised in the past about key fire safety laws?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Legislation from 2005 changed the way that businesses have their fire risks assessed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Were fire safety audits and fire authority budgets cut by a quarter?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Since 2010/11 the number of fire safety audits have gone down by about 25%.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did MPs vote against forcing homes to be made fit to live in?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Currently, there aren’t any specific rules in effect requiring private landlords in England to provide properties that are ‘fit for human habitation’.

fact_check_explanation_title: How do minority governments and hung parliaments work?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A hung parliament is when no one party has a majority of MPs in the House of Commons following an election.

fact_check_explanation_title: Northern Ireland and the Barnett formula
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Barnett formula isn’t set out in law, so its future depends on political negotiations.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK public debt is rising
fact_check_explanation_summary: The deficit is falling and debt is still rising.

fact_check_explanation_title: Corporation tax: rates down, receipts up
fact_check_explanation_summary: Official forecasts say that receipts could well have been higher if the rates hadn’t been cut.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fire safety regulations: no change in 20 years?
fact_check_explanation_summary: All newly constructed or refurbished buildings must comply with the 2010 building regulations.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fire safety regulations: has the government delayed reviewing them?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Following the tragic fire at Grenfell Tower in London on the 14th June we looked at whether or not the government has delayed reviewing fire safety regulations.

fact_check_explanation_title: Election 2017: did turnout for young people surge?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures that have been circulating on social media aren't all reliable.

fact_check_explanation_title: Election 2017: what the parties haven’t told voters
fact_check_explanation_summary: Full Fact factchecks what the parties do say. Often what they haven't said matters even more.

fact_check_explanation_title: Big meaningless numbers: the viral economy infographic
fact_check_explanation_summary: We don’t care how you vote but we do care that you get the facts. Please don’t take scorecards like this at face value.

fact_check_explanation_title: The powers of the intelligence services
fact_check_explanation_summary: MI5 distinguishes between seven different types of “intelligence gathering activities”. We explain what they’re allowed to do in each area.

fact_check_explanation_title: Energy bills under the Conservatives
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Committee on Climate Change has said that household bills in 2016 were lower than they were in 2008, due to reductions in energy use.

fact_check_explanation_title: Why do immigrants come to the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This briefing looks at levels of migration to the UK, how the UK compares to other EU countries, and evidence on what factors drive immigration to the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Employment rights
fact_check_explanation_summary: Full Fact takes a look at the big changes to employment law since 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: What is the “dementia tax”?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We answer questions on the Conservatives’ proposals.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are the Conservatives right about Labour’s tax plans?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Conservatives have said that Labour plans to increase the basic rate of income tax to 25%, but that’s not the case. Labour said it won’t raise income tax for …

fact_check_explanation_title: Counter-terrorism powers
fact_check_explanation_summary: TPIMs, internment and Control Orders: how the government has tried to control terror suspects.

fact_check_explanation_title: How immigrants affect public finances
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no single "correct" answer to the question of how much migrants contribute to public finances.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: have the Conservatives redefined child poverty?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Conservative government hasn’t redefined child poverty, in terms of changing what’s counted or how it’s counted. But it did change the target.

fact_check_explanation_title: Naylor Review: will the Conservatives sell NHS property to developers?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Readers have asked us to look into claims about the Naylor Review and its recommendations on selling NHS land.

fact_check_explanation_title: Have armed police numbers been cut?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of armed police officers has fallen by about 700 since 2010, but numbers are currently on the rise.

fact_check_explanation_title: Teacher retention: are England's teachers leaving?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of teachers that are leaving is growing slowly, especially in particular regions. But the numbers aren’t as high as recent surveys of teacher intentions would suggest.

fact_check_explanation_title: Liberal Democrat Manifesto: Brexit
fact_check_explanation_summary: The value of the pound has fallen considerably since the Brexit vote, most sharply on the day of the result

fact_check_explanation_title: Corporation tax: could we have raised more?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Revenues are up in cash terms, but that isn't unarguably linked to lower rates. Corporation tax rates have gone down since 2010, and they're a lot lower than they were …

fact_check_explanation_title: Brexit: is the UK economy growing or slowing?
fact_check_explanation_summary: GDP growth was higher than expected in the second half of 2016. It slowed in the first three months of this year.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK's stake in the European Investment Bank
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK has 16% shares in the European Investment Bank, that was around £9 billion in 2016.

fact_check_explanation_title: Theresa May's EU negotiating experience
fact_check_explanation_summary: What was Theresa May’s involvement in negotiating the UK out of EU justice and home affairs laws?

fact_check_explanation_title: Trade with the Commonwealth
fact_check_explanation_summary: UK exports to the other 50 or so Commonwealth nations were 9% of the total in 2015.

fact_check_explanation_title: Green Party Manifesto: Reasons behind the Brexit vote
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look what people say they considered when voting to leave the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Green Party Manifesto: Young people's views on Brexit
fact_check_explanation_summary: More young people seem to have voted to Remain than to Leave, but putting an exact figure on how many is more complicated.

fact_check_explanation_title: Green Party Manifesto: Air pollution
fact_check_explanation_summary: Air pollution contributes to 40,000 premature deaths a year, but that doesn't necessarily mean it causes them.

fact_check_explanation_title: Green Party Manifesto: Social care
fact_check_explanation_summary: The most recent estimates suggest the spending gap for adult social care in England is around £600 million this year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Green party Manifesto: Renewable energy
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've looked at the comparative costs of wind and solar projects compared to fossil fuels.

fact_check_explanation_title: What is hard Brexit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Hard Brexit is at one end of the spectrum, it’s about moving further away from the EU and cutting the main formal ties with the EU. But there are many …

fact_check_explanation_title: How many NHS employees are there?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are roughly 1.5 million people employed by the NHS but this is a headcount. There are other ways of counting such as Full-Time Equivalents.

fact_check_explanation_title: What is the NHS budget?
fact_check_explanation_summary: NHS funding works differently across the country, but most of the budget comes from the Government.

fact_check_explanation_title: What is the NHS?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The NHS stands for the National Health Service: Government-funded health care and medical services that everyone in the UK can use without being asked to pay the full cost.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour’s Land Value Tax: will you have to sell your garden?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour isn't committing to a 'Garden Tax'. Its manifesto only promises to review the council tax and business rate systems and consider new options such as a land value tax.

fact_check_explanation_title: What’s happened to migration since 2010?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Conservative manifesto restated the government's commitment to get net migration down to the tens of thousands. But what's been happening to net migration in recent years?

fact_check_explanation_title: SNP Manifesto: Future child poverty
fact_check_explanation_summary: Child poverty is projected to rise on a number of measures by 2021.

fact_check_explanation_title: SNP Manifesto: Productivity and unemployment
fact_check_explanation_summary: Scotland's productivity has been growing faster than the UK's as a whole, but its still catching up.

fact_check_explanation_title: SNP Manifesto: Nurses' pay
fact_check_explanation_summary: Nurses in Scotland get paid more than nurses in England, Wales, and Northern Ireland. This is across all pay bands.

fact_check_explanation_title: SNP Manifesto: Accident and emergency
fact_check_explanation_summary: On average A&E departments in Scotland do perform better against the main waiting time target than those in the rest of the UK, although they’re still missing targets.

fact_check_explanation_title: SNP Manifesto: Working poverty
fact_check_explanation_summary: 67% of children in poverty live in a household where at least one person is working, according to official figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the NHS in crisis?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are so many ways of measuring success in the NHS, but the results from the Nuffield Trust show that the NHS does face significant problems in many different areas.

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS video, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked a viral video featuring NHS employees that makes claims about the NHS.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are university applications falling in the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: University applications by disadvantaged students haven’t fallen in the last few years.

fact_check_explanation_summary: The advantage for pupils who attend modern grammar schools is outweighed by the disadvantage for those who don’t

fact_check_explanation_title: Liberal Democrat Manifesto: NHS finances
fact_check_explanation_summary: Nearly two-thirds of NHS trusts and foundation trusts ended the 2015/16 year in deficit.

fact_check_explanation_summary: Air pollution contributes to 40,000 premature deaths a year and costs the NHS £15 billion

fact_check_explanation_title: Is housing getting less affordable?
fact_check_explanation_summary: But what does ‘affordable housing’ mean? The word is used to mean different things in different contexts, and there’s no single measure of the ‘right amount’ to spend on housing.

fact_check_explanation_title: Why are more people using food banks?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2005/06, fewer than 3,000 food supplies were provided by the Trussell Trust. In 2016/17 the number of parcels handed out was almost 1.2 million.

fact_check_explanation_summary: About £285 million was indeed spent on a project to design, build and operate an airport on the island of St Helena for ten years.

fact_check_explanation_summary: Germany and the UK both grew at the same rate in 2016, according to the latest data available. It may yet be revised.

fact_check_explanation_summary: Individual landlords can get allowances for the cost of running properties.

fact_check_explanation_title: Young people's participation in higher education
fact_check_explanation_summary: On all UCAS measures, young students from disadvantaged groups in England are more likely to go to university now than any other year on record.

fact_check_explanation_title: Scotland: Tax and spending
fact_check_explanation_summary: In recent years more money has been spent in Scotland than has been collected, whether or not you count money collected from the North Sea oil and gas industries.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fifty years of income inequality
fact_check_explanation_summary: We're richer than we were 55 years ago and fewer people live on very low incomes. But the gap between rich and poor has widened, and income inequality is generally …

fact_check_explanation_title: Has employment growth been driven by a rise in insecure, precarious work?
fact_check_explanation_summary: From the statistics, it doesn’t seem like unwanted part-time work or unsatisfactory temporary work has been the major driver behind the growth in employment.

fact_check_explanation_title: How immigrants affect jobs and wages
fact_check_explanation_summary: Immigration has a small impact on average wages of existing workers but more significant effects for certain groups.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is 40% of Glasgow living in poverty?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Living in a deprived area doesn’t necessarily mean a person is deprived. Around 48% of areas in Glasgow were among the 20% most deprived in Scotland.

fact_check_explanation_title: Interest payments on the national debt
fact_check_explanation_summary: About 5% of government spending goes on interest payments, although this is below the historic average.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many nurses are using foodbanks?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Media reports show that at least some individual nurses and trainees have visited food banks. We've not found any evidence on how widespread this is.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are four million children living in poverty?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Around four million children in the UK were living in relative poverty in the UK, once housing costs are accounted for, although that’s just one way to measure poverty.

fact_check_explanation_title: What is the gap in university applications for the most and least advantaged in Scotland?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are two ways to look at this. Whether the claim is correct depends on whether you look at university entry rates or university application rates.

fact_check_explanation_title: Primary class sizes in England and Wales
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of infants in classes of 31 or more in Wales has increased by 18% since 2013. In England it has increased by 32% over the same time.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can £300 million pay for 10,000 police officers?
fact_check_explanation_summary: £300 million would cover those officers’ salaries for one year, but it wouldn’t cover the costs of training, equipment, and overheads at the same time.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the SNP ever been fined for election spending mistakes?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Electoral Commission told us it has never issued the Scottish National Party with any kind of fine or sanction.

fact_check_explanation_title: When was the four-hour A&E target last hit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The four hour A&E target hasn’t been met in England since July 2015, and the last time it was met over a full year was in 2013/14. The target hasn't …

fact_check_explanation_title: If politicians talk about the rich, always ask who they mean
fact_check_explanation_summary: What does "rich" actually mean? And how rich is "rich"? There are wealthy individuals with low incomes, and there are high-income people who have accumulated little wealth.

fact_check_explanation_title: Democratic deficit? The rules on election spending
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Conservative Party has been under investigation by the Electoral Commission, the police and the Crown Prosecution Service over election spending. Why?

fact_check_explanation_summary: In June 2016 three quarters of Labour MPs in the House of Commons supported a vote of no confidence in Mr Corbyn. He was re-elected as Labour leader by the …

fact_check_explanation_title: How much more is the NHS spending on private providers?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The proportion of NHS spending going to private providers is growing year on year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are there one million older people unable to look after themselves?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There were 1.2 million over 65s who experienced difficulty with basic tasks such as eating and washing, according to Age UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What is the "rape clause"?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Conservatives have introduced a two-child cap on Child Tax Credit, which includes an exception for conception during non-consensual sex or sex in an abusive relationship.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are there one million people in hospital with nowhere else to go?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In January there were 7,100 people in hospital at the end of the month who were medically fit to leave but weren't discharged. Across the whole month there were 197,000 …

fact_check_explanation_title: Why local elections are not useful indicators of national votes
fact_check_explanation_summary: Polling expert Anthony Wells cautions against reading too much into the local election results, ahead of the general election in June.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is crime up under the Conservatives?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Not according to the best figures we have, although there are other indications that there might have been a recent uptick.

fact_check_explanation_title: The net migration target and the 2017 election
fact_check_explanation_summary: Since 2010, the centrepiece of UK migration policy has been the net migration target, which aims to reduce net migration to the tens of thousands.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many people use food banks?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We don’t know how many people use food banks in total. The Trussell Trust, which is estimated to run around half of all food banks in the UK, says it …

fact_check_explanation_title: Pensioners in poverty
fact_check_explanation_summary: Latest figures suggest two million pensioners are in relative poverty, but the rate is much lower than it was decades ago.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are pensioners better off than people of working age?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Research by a number of think tanks has found that the average pensioner income, after housing costs have been included, is now above that of the average person of working …

fact_check_explanation_title: Public support for a "hard Brexit"
fact_check_explanation_summary: For the most part Remain and Leave voters do not have diametrically opposed views of what Brexit should entail, according to polling experts at NatCen.

fact_check_explanation_title: An introduction to the World Trade Organisation
fact_check_explanation_summary: The World Trade Organisation, or WTO, comes up again and again in the Brexit debate. Here’s our quick, expert guide to what it does.

fact_check_explanation_title: Inflation catches up with wage growth
fact_check_explanation_summary: Wages have been rising faster than prices for the last few years, but inflation has now caught up.

fact_check_explanation_title: Labour's affordable housing record
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of affordable homes fell by 420,000 under Labour.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are NHS workers getting a 4% pay rise?
fact_check_explanation_summary: If they move up pay bands, possibly.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pensions under Labour and the Conservatives
fact_check_explanation_summary: The basic state pension went up by slightly more under Labour up to 2010 than under Conservative Chancellors since then, once inflation is factored in.

fact_check_explanation_title: A&E waiting times
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of people waiting four hours in all types of A&E in England in 2015/16 is higher than in 2010/11. More people are going to A&E but the percentage …

fact_check_explanation_title: Little evidence the Conservatives’ poll lead is narrowing
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that the Conservatives' poll lead has plummeted are based on patchy evidence.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is child and pensioner poverty rising?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are lots of ways to measure poverty. Some show that child and pensioner poverty have increased slightly in recent years, but others show it has been stable or fallen.

fact_check_explanation_title: £1,250 more a year for pensioners
fact_check_explanation_summary: Pensioners who receive the full basic state pension in 2017/18 are getting £1,250 more in cash per year than in 2010/11. However, in real terms the increase is only about …

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the deficit down by two thirds?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Between 2009/10 and 2015/16 public sector net borrowing decreased from 9.9% of GDP to 3.8%, or by around two thirds.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are six million people earning less than the living wage?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Close but not quite. Around six million jobs pay less than the voluntary living wage calculated by the Living Wage Foundation.

fact_check_explanation_title: 4 million people taken out of income tax
fact_check_explanation_summary: Increases to the personal allowance have meant about 4 million fewer people had to pay income tax in 2015/16 than did in 2010/11.

fact_check_explanation_title: Have wages fallen in the past ten years?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Adjusted for inflation, the official headline measure of median wages has.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are one in nine UK workers migrants?
fact_check_explanation_summary: About one in nine were foreign nationals in 2016. About one in six were born outside the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Where does councils' money come from to pay for adult social care?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Public spending on social care in England isn’t allocated in the same way that spending on something like health is.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are 40% of welfare claimants pensioners?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There aren't readily-available estimates for the proportion of all welfare claimants who are pensioners or of working age.

fact_check_explanation_title: Unemployment under Labour
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of people unemployed in the UK was higher at the end of the last Labour government than at the start

fact_check_explanation_title: Will a hard Brexit cost £100 billion?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The most recent figures can’t tell us how much of an impact Brexit has had on the Office for Budget Responsibility's forecast for public sector debt.

fact_check_explanation_title: Free school meals and educational performance
fact_check_explanation_summary: A pilot programme rolling out free school meals for all primary school pupils in certain areas had promising results, although researchers say it’s not conclusive.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is it a crime to be poor?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Court orders used to tackle rough sleeping can lead to criminal penalties.

fact_check_explanation_title: When are domestic violence victims not “vulnerable”?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The judge in a domestic violence case in Manchester has been criticised for supposedly finding that the victim wasn't vulnerable. Here's what happened.

fact_check_explanation_title: Union membership among young people
fact_check_explanation_summary: 4% of the UK population aged 16 to 24 were employees and union members in 2015 and 13% of those aged 25 to 34.

fact_check_explanation_title: Royal Marine manslaughter conviction - the evidence
fact_check_explanation_summary: The main factual evidence in the case of Alexander Blackman, the Royal Marine convicted of a battlefield manslaughter, is in the public domain.

fact_check_explanation_title: What is the NHS paying for Private Finance Initiatives?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Department of Health paid £2 billion last year in charges for PFIs on the NHS.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does the Treasury lose £40 billion each year to the super-rich?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s much uncertainty here, but that claim isn’t supported by HMRC’s own estimates. The emphasis should be on the word ‘estimates’.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Conservative manifesto on the single market
fact_check_explanation_summary: The 2015 Conservative manifesto did commit the party to the single market. The government’s EU referendum leaflet didn’t say explicitly that leaving the EU would mean leaving the single market.

fact_check_explanation_title: Experts agree school funding is falling per-pupil
fact_check_explanation_summary: The IFS, National Audit Office, Education Policy Institute and Public Accounts Committee all agree that real per-pupil spending in schools will be reduced in the next few years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Police funding: up or down?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Are police budgets being cut? It depends which source of funding you count.

fact_check_explanation_title: 1.8m more pupils in good or outstanding schools
fact_check_explanation_summary: Schools’ Ofsted performance is improving and more pupils are in schools rated good or outstanding by its inspectors.

fact_check_explanation_title: Removing extremist online material
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s the job of one particular police unit to “instigate” the removal of extremist material from the Internet where it breaches internet companies’ terms of service, or the law.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many countries are in the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Maps to guide you through a sea of acronyms.

fact_check_explanation_title: Council tax and social care: explaining your bill
fact_check_explanation_summary: We looked at the changes in how councils can collect money for social care and how this affects your tax bill.

fact_check_explanation_title: What changes are being made to pre-recorded evidence from alleged rape victims?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Plans for alleged rape victims to pre-record their evidence will be piloted in three courts from September, not rolled out nationwide.

fact_check_explanation_title: Welsh views on independence
fact_check_explanation_summary: Polls conducted over the last five years clearly show that supporters of Welsh independence are in a minority, but the exact proportion varies depending on how the question is phrased.

fact_check_explanation_title: Public sector pay
fact_check_explanation_summary: How does council chief executive pay compare to that of MPs—and is it a fair comparison to begin with?

fact_check_explanation_title: What's happened to police budgets?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Police funding in England and Wales has fallen over the last five years, and is expected to stay flat over the next five.

fact_check_explanation_title: Poverty in Wales
fact_check_explanation_summary: 23% of people in Wales lived in a household where the income is below 60% of the UK median between 2013/14 and 2015/16. That’s including housing costs, and is roughly …

fact_check_explanation_title: Wales’s fiscal deficit: the gap between tax and spend
fact_check_explanation_summary: There isn’t an official government estimate for the size of the deficit between government income and spending in Wales and it’s not simple to work out.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tax cuts: corporation tax, inheritance, capital gains and the bank levy
fact_check_explanation_summary: All four have had some cuts... but only two have been cut overall.

fact_check_explanation_title: Teachers with first class degrees

fact_check_explanation_summary: Can Scotland legally hold another referendum?

fact_check_explanation_title: What would changing the law on abortion mean?
fact_check_explanation_summary: MPs have voted to change the law on abortion, as technically criminal prosecutions are possible unless doctors approve a termination.

fact_check_explanation_title: Have the Conservatives brought in £70 billion worth of tax cuts?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour has assessed the cost of changes to corporation tax, inheritance tax, capital gains tax and the bank levy since 2010. They've suggested a £120 billion cost. Is that correct?

fact_check_explanation_title: How many men have a sexual interest in children?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It seems unlikely we’ll ever have a complete picture of how many adults experience sexual feelings towards children, partly because this is something which many people will be uncomfortable discussing

fact_check_explanation_title: Royal Marine murder appeal: what did the courts say?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Alexander Blackman – “Marine A” – had his murder conviction reduced to manslaughter this week by an appeal court. Here’s why.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the government assessed the economic impact of no Brexit deal?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A comprehensive forecast hasn’t been produced. The Brexit Secretary says the government has to decide its plan for mitigation before such a forecast can be produced.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK’s trade deficit with the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: What’s the UK trade deficit with the rest of the EU - and what might that mean for our negotiating position?

fact_check_explanation_title: Post-Brexit trade tariffs
fact_check_explanation_summary: We have a voluntary choice about import tariffs, but not the tariffs on our exports.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU membership: Spain vs Scotland
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s often assumed that Spain, with one eye on the independence movement in Catalonia, would stop an independent Scotland from joining the EU. Would it?

fact_check_explanation_summary: In last week’s BBC Question Time Fraser Nelson claimed that there was a huge gap between the rich and the poor in Scottish education. We looked into it.

fact_check_explanation_summary: Councils were given an extra £2 billion in the Spring Budget 2017. But they might use it to free up funding for other services.

fact_check_explanation_summary: We've seen claims about Labour's plans for investment spending.

fact_check_explanation_summary: This week’s Budget won’t make “average working families” £1,400 worse off, although that’s roughly the right ballpark for the long-term impact of tax and benefit changes.

fact_check_explanation_title: Could Scotland stay in the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Although technically an independent Scotland could be written into the EU treaties, in practice it would most likely need to re-apply.

fact_check_explanation_title: A second independence referendum: what does Scotland think?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Polls suggest that the gap between those who are for and against independence has narrowed since the referendum in 2014. But the picture is more mixed on whether there should …

fact_check_explanation_title: Comparing Scottish and UK growth rates
fact_check_explanation_summary: Is the Scottish economy as strong as the UK’s generally? Not according to the most recent growth figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many suspects are wanted by police?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We looked at how many people are wanted in relation to particular crimes in England and Wales.

fact_check_explanation_summary: What happens if MPs reject amendments to the law triggering Article 50 inserted by the House of Lords?

fact_check_explanation_title: Is educational attainment in Scotland at record levels?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures on attainment in Scotland depend on which measure you prefer to look at.

fact_check_explanation_summary: The NHS is getting more money every year, but the rate of increase in the 2010s is smaller than in any previous decade, experts warn.

fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve checked claims on who wins and loses from the Spring Budget 2017.

fact_check_explanation_summary: The 2015 Conservative manifesto promised not to raise national insurance rates before 2020. The 2017 budget raised the rate of national insurance contributions paid by some self-employed people.

fact_check_explanation_title: Class sizes under the Conservatives
fact_check_explanation_summary: Average class sizes in English primary schools are up since 2010, although secondary school classes are very slightly smaller.

fact_check_explanation_summary: Men and women are still some way off equal in the UK labour market, although we have the highest female employment rate on record, the overall gender pay gap is …

fact_check_explanation_summary: A High Court judge will decide whether Charlie Gard, a baby being kept alive on artificial ventilation, will continue to be kept alive or have his life support switched off. …

fact_check_explanation_summary: This is no ordinary cake.

fact_check_explanation_title: Refugees in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: How many refugees and asylum seekers are there in the United Kingdom?

fact_check_explanation_title: Sexual offences in court
fact_check_explanation_summary: Criminal barristers have estimated that 50% of Crown Court trials now involve sex crime. The official numbers we’ve seen don’t say.

fact_check_explanation_title: Police officer numbers have fallen
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of police officers has dropped by 19,000 since 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many police forces are rated good or outstanding?
fact_check_explanation_summary: While it's true that two thirds of police forces across England and Wales were rated good or outstanding in 2016, only one was outstanding. The other 28 were rated good.

fact_check_explanation_title: How difficult is it for EU nationals to apply for residence rights in the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Growing numbers of EU nationals have been applying for permanent residence status in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_summary: The percentage of new QCs that are female or from a black and ethnic minority background is going up, but that isn't changing the overall picture.

fact_check_explanation_title: What is parity of esteem?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government wants to achieve equality between the physical and mental health services provided to people, but it’s not there yet.

fact_check_explanation_title: What did the courts rule on PIP?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The recent tribunal ruling on the disability benefit PIP was about the interpretation and application of the language of existing regulations.

fact_check_explanation_title: Government borrowing
fact_check_explanation_summary: Borrowing peaked at about 10% of the size of the economy (GDP) in 2009/10, and it’s now down to about 3.5%. That’s a relatively large deficit, but not off the …

fact_check_explanation_title: Amendments to PIP legislation
fact_check_explanation_summary: People who were assessed for Personal Independence Payments before the tribunal decisions on 29 November won’t see their payments fall because the legislation has been amended.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do companies bidding for government contracts have to back Brexit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Two government jobs include a commitment to the “best possible outcome” for the UK after Brexit as a small part of the selection criteria.

fact_check_explanation_title: The legal system, explained: the Family Court
fact_check_explanation_summary: The venue for legal disputes over marriage and children in England and Wales.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are there more nurses on our wards?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We don’t have figures specifically for the total number of nurses on hospital wards.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK's international education ranking
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s important not to read too much into the UK’s rank alone, or draw conclusions from changes in our rankings about whether our education system is getting better or worse.

fact_check_explanation_title: Spending on schools up to 2020
fact_check_explanation_summary: You can look at the schools budget in terms of the actual cash that’s being spent, the value of that cash after prices have risen, and how it divides per …

fact_check_explanation_title: Do poor grammar schools pupils make twice as much progress?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Poor children in particular seem to do particularly well at grammar schools (if they attend in the first place).

fact_check_explanation_title: Most, but not all, free schools help meet demand for school places
fact_check_explanation_summary: To set up a free school in England you need to show that there’s parental demand, and either a basic shortage of places or a lack of good school places …

fact_check_explanation_title: The number of NHS hospital beds has fallen
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s hard to say exactly how far NHS bed numbers have fallen in the past ten years, since the count before 2010 included different things.

fact_check_explanation_title: Too soon to say if EU referendum has led to genuine falls in immigration
fact_check_explanation_summary: You need to tread carefully when drawing conclusions about today's headlines.

fact_check_explanation_title: Nursing training places
fact_check_explanation_summary: We don’t know yet how changes to NHS bursaries will affect the number of places universities offer.

fact_check_explanation_title: Who's cutting hospital bed numbers?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s been falling almost constantly since the 1980s, but there's more to these figures than meets the eye.

fact_check_explanation_title: A shortage of midwives?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are more midwives in England than there were in 2010, but the trade union representing them estimates that there’s a shortage, as has the National Audit Office.

fact_check_explanation_title: Business rates: how many council areas will face rate rises?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Whatever the impact it won’t happen straight away. The impact of the revaluation on 1 April will be phased in over the next few years.

fact_check_explanation_summary: 20 councils accounted for 50% of the discharges delayed due to social care in November 2016. 24 councils accounted for around 50% of delays due to any reason.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the Scottish Government budget increased or decreased since 2010?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Panelists on this week's Question Time clashed over the Scottish Government budget.

fact_check_explanation_title: How likely is a second Scottish independence referendum?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Opinion polls show more people are against a second referendum on independence than are for it.

fact_check_explanation_title: The attainment gap in Scotland’s schools
fact_check_explanation_summary: High-achieving well-off pupils in Scotland perform better at science, reading and maths than high-achieving poor pupils, according to research.

fact_check_explanation_title: Reports on employment figures are accurate, but not the whole picture
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s a lot of uncertainty, and you can tell different stories about ‘foreign’ workers depending on how you define them.

fact_check_explanation_title: Don’t trust this Stoke by-election poll until we know more about it
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've seen a poll on the Stoke by-election. As far as we're aware, the campaign group who carried it out still haven’t published the information you’d need to say whether …

fact_check_explanation_title: Fewer prison officers in England and Wales
fact_check_explanation_summary: Prison officer numbers have fallen in England and Wales since 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: The EU has shrunk as a percentage of the world economy
fact_check_explanation_summary: Daniel Hannan says that Europe has shrunk as a percentage of world GDP. We take a look at the EU's share of world GDP over time.

fact_check_explanation_title: The end of holiday fines?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A legal case may mean that councils have to stop fining parents who take their children out of school during term time.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much would a hard Brexit cost?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's not unorthodox to say that trading with the EU under terms set by the WTO would be bad from an economic perspective, but putting an exact cost on it …

fact_check_explanation_summary: In the past, UKIP’s leader has been critical of the NHS model of healthcare.

fact_check_explanation_title: A&E in England has never been busier
fact_check_explanation_summary: There were 2.5 million more attendances at English A&Es in 2016 compared with 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Dubs Amendment: 3,000 refugee children?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government never officially said that 3,000 child refugees would be accepted under the Dubs Amendment, although some campaigners say they expected that many to arrive.

fact_check_explanation_summary: What are the Dubs 'amendment' and 'Dublin regulation', and why are they relevant to closing the migrant camp at Calais?

fact_check_explanation_title: Increasing the state pension age
fact_check_explanation_summary: Changes to the state pension age mean women born in the 1950s will retire later than they expected.

fact_check_explanation_title: Staffing in A&E
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are roughly 600 more A&E consultants, 1,500 more A&E doctors, and 2,000 more paramedics since 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: Filibustering in parliament
fact_check_explanation_summary: MPs can take as much debate time as they like so long as they stay on topic.

fact_check_explanation_summary: Research has shown one in six A&Es could be closed or downgraded based on their current plans, but it's speculative. We only know for definite that about a quarter of …

fact_check_explanation_title: The half-a-trillion NHS
fact_check_explanation_summary: Adding up five years’ worth of spending on the NHS to get a really big number doesn’t tell us very much.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much can we charge people from overseas to use the NHS?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government has an “ambition” to recover £500 million a year by 2017/18 from overseas patients not eligible for free NHS treatment.

fact_check_explanation_title: Business rates: up or down?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Rates are going up for some on 1 April, but in the past few years government policies have brought them down overall.

fact_check_explanation_title: Income inequality
fact_check_explanation_summary: By several headline measures, it’s fallen gradually across the bulk of UK households in the past ten years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Brexit and economic apocalypse
fact_check_explanation_summary: There hasn’t been an immediate hit to economic growth following the EU referendum.

fact_check_explanation_title: Health tourism savings won't plug the hole in NHS funding
fact_check_explanation_summary: Estimates show health tourism costs up to £300 million a year, but savings from this alone won't fill the gap in funding for the NHS.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are we all getting 14 weeks holiday?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A graph in the Brexit white paper got the number of weeks UK law gives workers in annual holiday and EU law gives workers in paid maternity leave round the …

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: what happens if parliament rejects a new EU deal?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are several different scenarios, but the UK can leave the EU without a deal if parliament rejects the one on offer in a couple of years' time.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK, the USA, and Syrian refugees
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve looked into Jeremy Corbyn’s and Theresa May’s claims on the government response to the recent US order on refugees, and to the wider Syrian crisis.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are patients going to A&E instead of GPs?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It was estimated in 2010 that between 10% and 30% of cases attending A&E were of a type that could be seen by a GP.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many people overstay their visas?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We can't find a record of the Brexit Secretary saying this, as has been claimed - but whether he made this claim or not, it's true.

fact_check_explanation_title: Record self-inflicted deaths in prisons
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's correct that the latest figures show a record level of self-inflicted deaths in English and Welsh prisons in 2016.

fact_check_explanation_title: The total number of missed GP appointments
fact_check_explanation_summary: Perhaps surprisingly, no-one routinely collects this information.

fact_check_explanation_title: About 3.2 million citizens of other EU countries live in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s likely that around half arrived between 2006 and 2014.

fact_check_explanation_title: The NHS: low cost healthcare?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Recent OECD figures show that the UK spends more than the average for the 35-member club, but less than many individual members.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Article 50 bill
fact_check_explanation_summary: What does the law on triggering Brexit have in common with the law enabling women to sit in parliament?

fact_check_explanation_title: What’s the link between membership of the single market and lower wages?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Whatever the answer is, it won’t be simple.

fact_check_explanation_title: Why is there a Brexit court case in Ireland?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Campaigners are taking a case to the Irish High Court in order to find out whether a notification under Article 50 can be reversed.

fact_check_explanation_title: The disability employment gap
fact_check_explanation_summary: We looked at whether the government’s pledge to halve the disability employment gap won’t be met for 50 years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Assaults on NHS staff
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no separate criminal offence of assaulting an NHS worker, but they do have additional legal protections.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many earn below the living wage?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve looked at how many people are estimated to earn below the National Living Wage set by the government and the living wage that campaigners recommend.

fact_check_explanation_title: Councils in London spend more per head
fact_check_explanation_summary: From 2012/13 to 2014/15, English councils outside London spent about 35% less per head than those in the capital.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Article 50 Supreme Court judgment, explained
fact_check_explanation_summary: Our potted summary of the Supreme Court's decision that parliament has to pass a law before Brexit can get underway.

fact_check_explanation_title: Global health spending: how does the UK compare?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Compared to countries in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, health spending in the UK as a proportion of GDP was above average in 2014.

fact_check_explanation_title: Trade with the English-speaking world
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s correct that the UK trades much more with the rest of the EU than with English-speaking countries further afield - at the moment.

fact_check_explanation_title: How dangerous is burnt toast?
fact_check_explanation_summary: David Spiegelhalter explains the facts behind today's burnt toast story.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much will the UK have to pay the EU once Brexit is negotiated?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Experts and a number of media reports have suggested that the final bill to the EU once Brexit is negotiated could be anywhere between €20 and €60 billion or around …

fact_check_explanation_title: The cost of cutting corporation tax
fact_check_explanation_summary: It could reduce the government’s income, but we haven’t seen estimates for the overall effect.

fact_check_explanation_title: What do the wealthiest pay in tax?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Define wealthiest and we’ll get back to you.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much can councils raise to pay for social care?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Councils are being allowed to increase council tax by 3% next year to pay for social care, but how does that impact different councils?

fact_check_explanation_title: The pound isn’t at its highest level in two years
fact_check_explanation_summary: The pound saw a big one-day rise yesterday, but its value against the US dollar remains low compared to recent years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Half a million fewer men accepted to university than women
fact_check_explanation_summary: Between 2007 and 2016 half a million fewer men than women living in the UK have been accepted to UK universities.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do two thirds of Welsh exports go to the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The headline figure is correct for goods exports. The way Wales’ trade is calculated has changed significantly in recent months.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are there 13 deaths by suicide every day?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It is correct that in 2015 there were around 13 deaths by suicide a day in England.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much does the Prime Minister get paid?
fact_check_explanation_summary: How much the Prime Minister makes is a hot search topic at the moment. Theresa May's job comes with a salary of £150,402.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many hospital black alerts were there this week?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Media reports say that 23 hospital trusts in England have reached the highest level on the NHS’s system for saying whether they are under pressure, or are otherwise under serious …

fact_check_explanation_title: Four million on hospital waiting lists
fact_check_explanation_summary: At least 3.7 million patient referrals in England were waiting to receive non-emergency treatment as of November 2016. It may be as high as 3.9 million.

fact_check_explanation_title: The number of doctors and nurses in NHS England
fact_check_explanation_summary: In September 2016 there were the equivalent of 9,000 more doctors working full-time for NHS hospitals and community health services in England than there were in September 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS spending is going up, but other health spending isn’t
fact_check_explanation_summary: Government plans will see £5 billion rise in overall health spending in England by 2020, once you adjust for inflation.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK wealth: how much is owned by the 1%?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Even though it’s tricky to estimate what people own, especially the very rich, the claim that 1% of the UK population own 50% of its wealth isn’t supported by the …

fact_check_explanation_title: Hate incidents aren’t the same as hate crimes
fact_check_explanation_summary: A recent speech by Home Secretary Amber Rudd has been logged as a ‘hate incident’, but not as a ‘hate crime’. There’s a difference.

fact_check_explanation_title: The government has misquoted the head of NHS England on spending plans
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government has misquoted a statement from Simon Stevens in 2015.

fact_check_explanation_title: Rail dispute: are driver-only trains safe?
fact_check_explanation_summary: As unions take strike action on Southern Railway over driver-only trains, we look at what regulators have said about the safety question.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fewer doctors and nurses working in mental health
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are fewer nurses and doctors specialising in mental health now than in 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the number of people using mental health services increased?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Changes to the way these figures are gathered means we don’t know for sure how the number of people accessing mental health services has changed between 2010/11 and 2014/15.

fact_check_explanation_title: 21% of UK electricity comes from nuclear
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2015, the nuclear industry supplied about 21% of the UK’s energy overall.

fact_check_explanation_title: Elections on the horizon in Northern Ireland
fact_check_explanation_summary: The deputy First Minister of Northern Ireland, Martin McGuinness, resigned on Monday 9 January. If the Sinn Féin party don’t nominate a replacement, that does mean an election.

fact_check_explanation_title: A&E waiting times: better or worse?
fact_check_explanation_summary: More patients are being seen within four hours at A&E departments, but the percentage of visits processed within that time has been falling.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many patients die from thirst or starvation?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Roughly one patient every three or four days died as a direct result of malnutrition or dehydration in NHS and non-NHS hospitals in England and Wales across 2015.

fact_check_explanation_title: Public satisfaction with the NHS
fact_check_explanation_summary: Data from 2017 doesn’t necessarily tell us much about public perceptions of the NHS this winter, still less its actual performance.

fact_check_explanation_title: Not all of Britain’s lawyers are “raking it in”
fact_check_explanation_summary: The legal sector turned over £32 billion in 2015, up on previous years, but that’s not connected with government legal aid.

fact_check_explanation_title: Age, motherhood and the gender pay gap
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve seen evidence that the pay gap gets bigger when women become mothers, but they don’t seem to have a clear advantage before then.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many children have mental health disorders?
fact_check_explanation_summary: According to a 2004 survey for the Department of Health one in 10 children have a mental disorder. More up-to-date research is to be published in 2018.

fact_check_explanation_title: Health tourism: what's the cost?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government has previously estimated that "health tourism" costs the NHS around 0.3% of NHS spending allocated to specific services.

fact_check_explanation_title: Council house replacements
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve looked into claims made by Jeremy Corbyn in his speech at the Labour party conference.

fact_check_explanation_title: Intercepted evidence can’t be used in court
fact_check_explanation_summary: Concern that a new surveillance law permits prosecutors to lie in court about evidence from intercepted communications is misplaced.

fact_check_explanation_title: Best laid plans... for reducing the deficit
fact_check_explanation_summary: The deficit did fall while the Coalition was in power, but not by as much as originally planned.

fact_check_explanation_title: Delayed transfers of care: does geography matter?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There seems to be a 20 fold difference in delayed discharges from hospital between the best and worst performing councils. We’ve asked the Department of Health for more information.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mobile phone coverage
fact_check_explanation_summary: Is the UK really worse than Romania for mobile phone signal? A recently published report says yes.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK development aid spending
fact_check_explanation_summary: The aid budget is going up by a lot, but it isn’t set to have "more than doubled" from 2010-2020.

fact_check_explanation_title: A £2.5 billion shortfall in social care funding?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Local Government Association, and several other expert groups, predict a significant gap in funding for adult social care by 2020.

fact_check_explanation_title: Social care funding
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister and Leader of the Opposition clashed over social care spending at PMQs today. We’ve investigated.

fact_check_explanation_title: Immigrants learning English
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s true that older immigrants make up a disproportionate number of those who have poor English, although they’re still in a small minority.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does obesity cost the economy?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve looked into the claim that it costs £27 billion.

fact_check_explanation_title: Mixed evidence on the link between term time holidays and attainment
fact_check_explanation_summary: Department for Education research shows a link between missing school and lower pupil attainment, but this isn’t the case for all types of absence.
