fact_check_explanation_title: Historically high levels of tax?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In recent years the UK's tax take has varied between 30% and 35% of GDP.

fact_check_explanation_title: Robots and the future of your job
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Bank of England has estimated that 15 million jobs in the UK could be automated over the next few decades, equivalent to just under half the jobs in the …

fact_check_explanation_title: Deaths following childbirth
fact_check_explanation_summary: Suicide overtakes other causes of death between six weeks and one year after delivery, when it accounts for 15% of deaths - more than any other pregnancy-related cause.

fact_check_explanation_title: Corporation tax: UK vs USA
fact_check_explanation_summary: US corporation tax rates are about 39%, on average according to the OECD, so about twice that paid in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Article 50 and EU budget payments
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK is still a member of the European Union pending exit negotiations, so budget contributions will continue.

fact_check_explanation_title: About 1 in 7 German cars are sold in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: Germany sells about 14% of all the passenger cars it makes domestically to the UK, a little over one in seven. (That makes up about 18% of the passenger cars …

fact_check_explanation_title: How many NHS trusts are in deficit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In the third quarter of 2015/16 around 95% of acute NHS trusts were in deficit. But by the end of 2015/16 it was 65% of all NHS trusts, of which …

fact_check_explanation_title: No longer partying all night
fact_check_explanation_summary: According to an industry database, half the nightclubs in Great Britain have closed down in the past decade.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is half of the NHS not clinically qualified?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 51% of people working for the NHS are clinically qualified. Looking at it another way, that’s 53% of full-time equivalents.

fact_check_explanation_title: Jobcentre closures
fact_check_explanation_summary: Half the Jobcentre Plus sites in Glasgow are set to close under DWP plans. The Department plans to reduce its office space nationwide by 20%.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU customs union and the Irish border
fact_check_explanation_summary: Neither the British or Irish governments want customs checks on the Northern Irish border. But that’s not sufficient to guarantee it won’t happen.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ethnic diversity on company boards
fact_check_explanation_summary: People from black and minority ethnic backgrounds are underrepresented on FTSE 150 company boards.

fact_check_explanation_title: Rail delay compensation: what’s new?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A scheme providing compensation of 25% on single train fares for delays between 15 and 29 minutes will be introduced from 11 December on some services.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many excess deaths are there in winter?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There were 24,300 excess winter deaths in 2015/16. These deaths were largely attributed to respiratory or circulatory conditions or dementia.

fact_check_explanation_title: Immigration and unemployment in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s correct that there were about 1.7 million unemployed people in the UK at the last count, in July-September 2016.

fact_check_explanation_title: How Supreme Court judges are chosen
fact_check_explanation_summary: Is the system for choosing UK Supreme Court justices “secretive and opaque”?

fact_check_explanation_title: HS2: is it faster?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We looked at whether HS2 will be faster for travellers than current trains.

fact_check_explanation_title: False claims, forecasts, and the EU Referendum
fact_check_explanation_summary: Campaigners on both sides of the EU referendum made false claims, or predicted things that turned out to be wrong. Sometimes they made false claims about the false claims made …

fact_check_explanation_title: Leaving the EU without Article 50
fact_check_explanation_summary: Pulling out of the European Union without triggering Article 50 would be illegal.

fact_check_explanation_title: Article 50: a two-year limit
fact_check_explanation_summary: A two-year clock starts ticking as soon as the UK gives notice under Article 50 that it’s leaving the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Immigration to the UK has been rising
fact_check_explanation_summary: Immigration to the UK rose considerably in 2004, and is now estimated at roughly record levels.

fact_check_explanation_title: A third of babies have at least one parent born outside the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s true that about a third of children born in England and Wales have one or more parents who were born outside country, although you probably wouldn’t call all those …

fact_check_explanation_title: Why homicide is now 2,700 times more serious than cannabis
fact_check_explanation_summary: New estimates have rated crimes by their severity, but they can’t tell us about crime trends over time.

fact_check_explanation_title: Brexit in the Supreme Court: the arguments
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Supreme Court will decide whether the government has the power to trigger Brexit without an Act of Parliament. These are the competing legal arguments the justices will hear.

fact_check_explanation_title: At least 120,000 children in Great Britain are homeless
fact_check_explanation_summary: Calculations by a housing charity for the number of under-18s and expecting mothers living in temporary accommodation stack up.

fact_check_explanation_title: The economic outlook: IMF or IFS?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK is set to be the 18th fastest-growing of the ‘advanced economies’ in 2016, according to the IMF.

fact_check_explanation_title: Poverty: up or down?
fact_check_explanation_summary: About 2.7 million fewer children were living in absolute poverty by the end of the last Labour government, or 2.1 million fewer if you take housing costs into account.

fact_check_explanation_title: House building: counting the government's record
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've looked at the Labour and Conservative records on house building, the impact of the financial crisis and how house building measures affect the picture.

fact_check_explanation_title: The cost of children's funerals
fact_check_explanation_summary: The average funeral costs between £3,700 and £3,900 according to insurers, although some fees may be waived in the case of a deceased child.

fact_check_explanation_title: Heathrow airport emissions targets
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Committee on Climate Change has said that the government can meet its emissions targets and build a third runway at Heathrow, but only if strict criteria are followed. The …

fact_check_explanation_title: Will you have to prove you need to see your GP?
fact_check_explanation_summary: About 180 GP surgeries are using initial telephone consultations (telephone triage) systematically to manage high demand for their services (out of about 7,700 practices in England).

fact_check_explanation_title: Brexit in the Supreme Court: a preview
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Supreme Court will decide whether the government has the power to trigger Brexit without an Act of Parliament. Here's what you need to know about the case.

fact_check_explanation_title: Young offenders from ethnic minorities
fact_check_explanation_summary: HM Inspectorate of Prisons found that 47% of people in young offender institutions said they were black, Asian or minority ethnic in 2015/16.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do 15% of people take 70% of flights?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Crunching the best available data suggests that, yes, they do.

fact_check_explanation_title: Brexit means... borrowing?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Office for Budget Responsibility expect the government to have a £21 billion deficit in 2020/21. In March they had predicted an £11 billion surplus.

fact_check_explanation_title: Brexit and household incomes
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) expects national income in 2020/21 to be about £50 billion lower than it would have been, had the UK voted to remain in the …

fact_check_explanation_title: EU research funding
fact_check_explanation_summary: The loss of EU research funding is a worry for many academics.

fact_check_explanation_title: Far right extremism: a growing problem?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Home Office says far right referrals under the Prevent strategy are higher than other types, but the data isn't routinely published so we don't know the exact figures. Across …

fact_check_explanation_title: Paying for Buckingham Palace
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government plans to increase the Queen’s official income to cover the cost of repairs to the iconic London palace.

fact_check_explanation_title: Germans are more productive than us, work less, and earn more
fact_check_explanation_summary: Yep, it’s true.

fact_check_explanation_title: £10 billion or £4.5 billion: what's going on with NHS spending?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We looked at how much money the NHS is getting from the government this parliament and whether or not it's more than it asked for.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are one million people without social care?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Age UK say more than one million people are not receiving the social care they need, but the research hasn't been published yet. They've produced similar estimates before.

fact_check_explanation_title: Saving up for stamp duty
fact_check_explanation_summary: 69% of potential first-time homebuyers who responded to an online poll said that raising the money for costs like stamp duty would be ‘difficult’

fact_check_explanation_title: Social care and delayed transfers from hospital
fact_check_explanation_summary: Between 2011/12 and 2015/16 the number of patients whose transfer from hospital was delayed due to social care increased by one third.

fact_check_explanation_title: Disability benefits: spending on the rise?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Overall spending on disability benefits is forecast to increase in the coming years, even after inflation is taken into account.

fact_check_explanation_title: Passports for the NHS?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A London hospital has announced it will be asking women who receive maternity services to provide ID before treatment to determine whether they should be charged.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does the UK have the highest rate of property tax in the world?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s true that the UK government takes a higher proportion of GDP and a higher proportion of tax revenue in property taxes than any other developed country. It's not clear …

fact_check_explanation_title: The IMF on Brexit
fact_check_explanation_summary: Did the International Monetary Fund get its Brexit predictions wrong?

fact_check_explanation_title: Scotland's public finances
fact_check_explanation_summary: The gap between what the Scottish government spends and what it collects in taxes is higher than the rest of the UK. So at the moment, Scotland’s public finances benefit …

fact_check_explanation_title: Disposable incomes have broadly stagnated over the last decade
fact_check_explanation_summary: Over the last 15 years, disposable incomes have risen across all income groups. Over the last decade, there’s been stagnation.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many seats could UKIP have under a different voting system?
fact_check_explanation_summary: UKIP got 12.4% of the vote in 2015 but had just one MP elected.

fact_check_explanation_title: Foreigners working in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: We don’t know how many have been hired, fired or quit—however you define a “foreigner”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Unemployment is at a 10-year low
fact_check_explanation_summary: The overall employment rate is at its highest on record (since 1970). Unemployment is at a ten year low.

fact_check_explanation_title: Free trade outside the EU customs union
fact_check_explanation_summary: Can the UK be partly in and partly out of the EU customs union?

fact_check_explanation_title: What's happening to social mobility?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Social Mobility Commission says the attainment gap is narrowing, meaning that poorer pupils’ results are getting closer to those of their wealthier classmates. But there’s more to the story.

fact_check_explanation_title: Deliveroo, unions and the ‘gig economy’
fact_check_explanation_summary: On 7 November, the Independent Workers’ Union of Great Britain (IWGB) asked Deliveroo, an online food delivery company, to voluntarily recognise it as the trade union for Deliveroo drivers and …

fact_check_explanation_title: Productivity in the UK workplace: London vs. the rest
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s true that there’s a significant gap between London and other UK cities, but so far we haven’t seen an analysis wide-ranging enough to support the claim that it’s greater …

fact_check_explanation_title: Was a refugee acquitted of rape because he didn't speak German?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A case in Austria, picked up by Russia's media and president, did see a rape conviction set aside for legal reasons. But there's a lot more to it.

fact_check_explanation_title: How does the new benefit cap affect single mothers?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The new benefit cap is introduced on 7 November 2016. We look whether it affects single mothers, large families and those with higher rents more than others.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Daily Mail, “enemies of the people”, and a Nazi newspaper
fact_check_explanation_summary: A recent meme compared a Daily Mail headline in 2016 with a Nazi newspaper published in 1933.

fact_check_explanation_title: Was the EU referendum “advisory”?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A referendum can be legally non-binding but, arguably, politically binding.

fact_check_explanation_title: Appealing a ‘Fit for Work’ decision
fact_check_explanation_summary: If you appeal a Work Capability Assessment decision, you are more likely to win than lose. The most recent data suggests that about three-fifths of appeals are successful.

fact_check_explanation_title: The IFS and the benefit cap
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Institute for Fiscal Studies said that the benefit cap used to almost exclusively affect families with a lot of children or high rents, but not any more.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU staff at Great Ormond Street hospital
fact_check_explanation_summary: 23% of doctors and 17% of all doctors and nurses at Great Ormond Street hospital reported they were from the EU in 2015.

fact_check_explanation_title: The cost of public inquiries
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures cited on BBC Question Time for the cost of the Chilcot and Leveson Inquiries are correct.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK’s trade with the USA
fact_check_explanation_summary: The US is the UK’s second largest trading partner after the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does the High Court’s Article 50 ruling mean for Brexit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The judgment on 3 November means that the government can’t leave the EU without parliament passing a law allowing Article 50 to be used.

fact_check_explanation_title: Welfare sanctions and homelessness
fact_check_explanation_summary: A survey found that 39% of homeless people had been sanctioned. 21% became homeless because of it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Limits on immigration detention
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's true that the UK is the only country in the EU without a specific time limit on how long someone can be held for immigration offences.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many disabled people are in work?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Since 2013 the number of disabled people in work has increased by just under half a million. Under the current government the number of disabled people in the UK in …

fact_check_explanation_title: Food banks: hard to say whether rising use reflects rising demand
fact_check_explanation_summary: More people have access to a food bank now than in 2010, so figures for food bank use alone can’t tell us about demand.

fact_check_explanation_title: Spending on Housing Benefit
fact_check_explanation_summary: We examine the exchange between the Prime Minister and Leader of the Opposition over the Housing Benefit bill.

fact_check_explanation_title: Judges to rule on Brexit tomorrow
fact_check_explanation_summary: Joshua Rozenberg's analysis of the prospects for the Article 50 legal challenge that will be decided by the High Court tomorrow.

fact_check_explanation_title: FIFA has restrictions on England footballers wearing poppies
fact_check_explanation_summary: FIFA does have strict rules on political or religious symbols on football kit, which hit the headlines every few years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Why do migrants and asylum seekers want to come to the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the experts say on how, if at all, asylum seekers choose between potential countries of refuge.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do we have enough maternity consultants?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Around three quarters of maternity units reported not having any consultants present overnight on weekdays, according to a survey by the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists.

fact_check_explanation_title: Investment in renewables
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK has dropped down a ranking of countries by attractiveness for renewable energy investment.

fact_check_explanation_title: War and Peace and benefits regulations
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government publishes extensive guidance for its staff on handling benefit claims.

fact_check_explanation_title: Over a million food parcels given by Trussell Trust last year
fact_check_explanation_summary: Over a million food parcels were given last year by the Trussell Trust, but that isn't the same as a million people.

fact_check_explanation_title: A third of teachers leave after five years - that's nothing new
fact_check_explanation_summary: New figures have been reported showing almost a third of teachers leave state funded schools within five years of qualifying. The figures are correct, but they follow the historical trend.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK is now the second or third largest donor of aid to Syria
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK is the third largest donor of aid to Syria, behind the USA and Germany according to the United Nations.

fact_check_explanation_title: Will leaving the EU customs union mean border checks?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It seems reasonable to describe leaving a customs union as setting up a border.

fact_check_explanation_title: Spending on mental health services
fact_check_explanation_summary: 57% of Clinical Commissioning Groups plan to reduce funding for mental health services, out of those who responded to an FOI request.

fact_check_explanation_title: Asylum seekers, the UK and Europe
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2015, the UK had the ninth highest number of asylum seekers in the EU, and the fifth highest number of people accepted as refugees.

fact_check_explanation_title: We aren't spending £36m just to close the Calais 'jungle'
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK has committed £36 million to “maintain security” in Calais. Some of this money will be used to close the ‘Jungle’ camp, but some is also being spent on …

fact_check_explanation_title: Age assessments for Calais asylum seekers
fact_check_explanation_summary: Linking general statistics on age disputes to the situation of young people arriving from Calais isn't necessarily fair.

fact_check_explanation_title: Brexit: which EU citizens will have the right to stay in the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A high proportion of EU citizens in the UK are likely to be entitled to a special status under EU law by the time of Brexit, but it depends on …

fact_check_explanation_title: Do 74 people try to enter the UK illegally every day?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There were 164,000 attempts to cross into the UK made between 2010 and 2015, although these figures don’t correspond to individual people.

fact_check_explanation_title: The cost of training a doctor
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government estimates that it costs £230,000 overall to get the average student through medical school. “The taxpayer” doesn’t pay for all of this because some comes in student loans.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU accounts ‘signed off’ but subject to errors
fact_check_explanation_summary: The issue of the EU's accounts rears its head again.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does UKIP want to privatise the NHS?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Although interim leader Nigel Farage has said he wants to move to an insurance-based NHS in the past he has now said he wants it to be free for all …

fact_check_explanation_title: Are our prisons "filling up with foreigners"?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Citizens of other countries make up a declining share of the prison population.

fact_check_explanation_title: The EU's other trade agreements
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU has 48 trade agreements with other countries, which go beyond World Trade Organisation rules.

fact_check_explanation_title: Asylum seekers and dental age tests
fact_check_explanation_summary: Can you tell someone's age from tooth X-rays?

fact_check_explanation_title: Adjective inflation: are prices “soaring”?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Inflation is at a two year high, but saying that it’s “soaring” is a bit of a stretch.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hate crime and the EU referendum
fact_check_explanation_summary: After the referendum, there was a sharp increase in the number of hate crimes that were recorded by the police.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the “seven-day NHS” a fuss over nothing?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government says going to hospital at the weekend is seriously bad for your health. A group of doctors disputes the evidence on this. What’s going on?

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS trusts in deficit
fact_check_explanation_summary: The latest figures show that 75% of acute trusts (hospitals) are in deficit.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fewer police cells are being used to hold people with mental health problems
fact_check_explanation_summary: Police cells are being used less often as a ‘place of safety’ under the Mental Health Act.

fact_check_explanation_title: Few pupils are both at grammar schools and on free school meals
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s correct that grammar school pupils entitled to free school meals are one in a thousand.

fact_check_explanation_title: Total spending on mental health
fact_check_explanation_summary: Perhaps £11.7 billion was spent on mental health in 2014/15, or perhaps not.

fact_check_explanation_title: 40% of mental health trusts have seen their incomes fall
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s correct that 40% of mental health trusts had lower income in 2015/16 compared to the previous year, according to analysis by the King’s Fund think tank.

fact_check_explanation_title: Economy introductions: income tax and who pays it
fact_check_explanation_summary: An introduction to income tax - and who pays it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Poorer children are less likely to go to grammar schools
fact_check_explanation_summary: Poorer children are less likely to go to grammar schools even if they are high achievers.

fact_check_explanation_title: Was the pound overvalued before the EU referendum?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s correct that the IMF has said that in 2015 the pound was overvalued by between 5 and 20%. But it’s open to debate whether it’s undervalued right now.

fact_check_explanation_title: The biggest cause of death depends on how you count them
fact_check_explanation_summary: Dementia and Alzheimer’s disease were the single most common cause of deaths in 2015, but cancers in total caused more deaths.

fact_check_explanation_title: Scottish jobs after Brexit
fact_check_explanation_summary: A ‘Hard Brexit’ would see 80,000 fewer jobs in Scotland than EU membership, according to one set of figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: Scottish schools
fact_check_explanation_summary: The standard of schools in Scotland, as measured by recent pupil tests and exam results, seems to be slightly in decline.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK’s views on immigration
fact_check_explanation_summary: Immigration has repeatedly been highlighted as the top issue facing the UK in recent years.

fact_check_explanation_title: The oil price and Scotland’s independence
fact_check_explanation_summary: The falling price of oil hasn’t had much impact on the proportion of people saying they would vote for independence.

fact_check_explanation_title: Employment or immigration: which matters more?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Voters have expressed mixed opinions to pollsters on whether they’d prefer a more economically risky ‘hard Brexit’.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: Brexit in court
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've heard a lot about legal challenges after the vote to leave the European Union. What are they about and what do they hope to achieve?

fact_check_explanation_title: "Leaked" analysis: would a Hard Brexit cost £66 billion?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Recent "leaks" about the £38 to £66 billion potential costs of a "Hard Brexit" are based on Treasury analysis that was published in April.

fact_check_explanation_title: Brexit and price rises
fact_check_explanation_summary: Brexit has been blamed for a series of price rises, from holidays abroad to military equipment. All are down to a fall in the value of the pound.

fact_check_explanation_title: Cancer survival rates at record levels
fact_check_explanation_summary: Cancer survival rates in England are at a record high across cancer types as a whole.

fact_check_explanation_title: Japanese-owned companies in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: 140,000 people are employed by Japanese-owned companies in the UK, according to estimates from the Japanese government.

fact_check_explanation_title: "Naming and shaming" companies with foreign workers
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Conservatives did seem to suggest publishing the percentage of foreign workers at different companies, although they’ve now ruled that out.

fact_check_explanation_title: Leaving the single market
fact_check_explanation_summary: Don’t confuse the estimated cost of Brexit to GDP with the cost to tax revenues.

fact_check_explanation_title: Foreign Direct Investment in the North
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's correct that the number of FDI deals in the North has increased at double the rate of the rest of the country. But that doesn't tell us how much …

fact_check_explanation_title: Post-referendum predictions: have forecasts for the economy changed?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The average forecast for UK GDP growth this year was the same September as in June, despite the UK voting to leave the EU. But that’s not the whole story.

fact_check_explanation_title: Companies have to consider workers in the UK for some jobs
fact_check_explanation_summary: A requirement for companies to advertise in the UK before recruiting from abroad is nothing new.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tax: evasion and avoidance in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2013-14, HMRC estimate that they lost about £2.7 billion through tax avoidance and £4.4 billion through tax evasion—so about £7.1 billion overall.

fact_check_explanation_title: Human rights law means police warnings for people at risk of being killed
fact_check_explanation_summary: Recent reports on the role of the European Court of Human Rights in police ‘threat to life’ warnings are only partially correct.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK jobs and EU-owned businesses
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2014, about 1.6 million people in the UK were employed by EU-owned businesses.

fact_check_explanation_title: More refugees in the EU are Syrian than any other nationality
fact_check_explanation_summary: A majority of recently accepted refugees in the EU are Syrian, although they’re not the majority of those applying for refugee status or entering the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Net migration equals a city the size of Cardiff
fact_check_explanation_summary: Net migration in the UK was 327,000 in the year to March, roughly a city the size of Cardiff or Wakefield. It’s not at this level every year, but has …

fact_check_explanation_title: Fees for employment tribunals
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Coalition government introduced fees for employment tribunals. These can be repaid if cases are successful, but seem to have led to a big fall in number of people using …

fact_check_explanation_title: Unemployment in Wales is the lowest in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: The unemployment rate in Wales is 4.1%, lower than England, Scotland and Northern Ireland. Across the whole of the UK it’s 4.9%.

fact_check_explanation_title: Clamping down on human rights lawyers
fact_check_explanation_summary: Why is the government so upset about "activist, left-wing human rights lawyers"? Joshua Rozenberg explains.

fact_check_explanation_title: Secondary schools in the South perform better than other parts of England
fact_check_explanation_summary: There are fewer secondary schools rated good or outstanding in the North of England and the Midlands compared to the South.

fact_check_explanation_title: Rural properties are much less likely to have good broadband connections
fact_check_explanation_summary: Just under half of rural properties can't access a good broadband connection, according to Ofcom.

fact_check_explanation_title: Black Caribbean pupils three times more likely to be excluded
fact_check_explanation_summary: Black Caribbean students are three times more likely to be permanently excluded from school than all children. They are also twice as likely to be excluded as all black students.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the government’s £10bn NHS funding commitment more than NHS leaders asked for?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim that the government is investing an extra £10 billion in the NHS, more than its leaders asked for, shouldn’t be taken at face value.

fact_check_explanation_title: How do selective school ratings compare?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A greater proportion of grammar schools are rated “outstanding” or “good” by Ofsted than the proportion of all UK state schools rated in these top two categories.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can a "seven-day NHS" be paid for?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government maintains it can pay for expanded "seven-day NHS" services with the money it has already planned to spend, but experts doubt this is possible.

fact_check_explanation_title: Child poverty is up, depending on how you look at it
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of children in a low-income family increased by 2% between 2013 and 2014, according to HMRC. That's back to roughly the same level as 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: Have 12,000 asylum seekers vanished in the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Home Office data makes it unclear exactly what it means to have an asylum application “on hold”.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Conservatives’ migration record
fact_check_explanation_summary: Net migration is the highest it has ever been. The greatest annual increase in the last 20 years was in 1998.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does the Football Association get £30 million a year in public money?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve looked into claims about how much public money goes to the FA.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are judges deciding whether the UK will leave the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Judges are being asked to decide whether the government can trigger Article 50 without seeking the consent of Parliament.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does "uncontrolled mass migration" push down wages?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Immigration has a small impact on average wages, but affects particular types of workers such as low-wage workers, more significantly.

fact_check_explanation_title: How is the EU doing on refugee relocation?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU programme for relocating asylum seekers within Europe has seen 6,000 people move country in the past year.

fact_check_explanation_title: The most miserable borough in London?
fact_check_explanation_summary: How happy did you feel yesterday? There's less to this data than meets the headline.

fact_check_explanation_title: House building: at its lowest level since the 1920s?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve looked into claims made by Jeremy Corbyn in his speech at the Labour party conference.

fact_check_explanation_title: Junior doctors' contracts: an introduction to the dispute
fact_check_explanation_summary: Members of the British Medical Association voted against the junior doctors contract agreed in May. The government will introduce the contract from October.

fact_check_explanation_title: An explosion of temporary, insecure jobs?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve looked into claims made by Jeremy Corbyn in his speech at the Labour party conference.

fact_check_explanation_title: Six million jobs pay less than the living wage
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve looked into claims made by Jeremy Corbyn in his speech at the Labour party conference.

fact_check_explanation_title: What’s happening to inequality?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve looked into claims made by Jeremy Corbyn in his speech at the Labour party conference.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is EU immigration to blame for missing the net migration target?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Net migration from other EU countries isn't the only reason the government hasn't met its net migration target.

fact_check_explanation_title: Poor children at grammar schools seem to do well
fact_check_explanation_summary: Is the attainment gap in grammar schools "virtually zero"?

fact_check_explanation_title: Not so sure of Sure Start figures
fact_check_explanation_summary: While many Sure Start children's centres have closed since 2010, just how many depends on what exactly you count.

fact_check_explanation_title: What is a "seven-day NHS"?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Our introduction to a "seven-day NHS" and what the government’s plans are.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK is a major customer for the rest of the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s correct that we import between £80 billion and £100 billion more than we export to the EU each year, according to data from the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK health spending compared to France and Germany
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK spends a smaller percentage of GDP on health than France or Germany. The percentage of GDP the UK spends on health is also set to decrease.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can we be part of the single market and control immigration?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We don't know what the future arrangements for the UK will be as this will depend on the deal that is reached between the government and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: The new junior doctors’ contract and their reaction
fact_check_explanation_summary: We’ve looked into some of the elements included in the new junior doctors’ contract, including pay and working hours, and the junior doctors’ response.

fact_check_explanation_title: Wealth in the UK: The richest 1% and the poorest 20%
fact_check_explanation_summary: Oxfam claims that the richest 1% of UK wealth-holders own at least twenty-times more than the poorest 20%. That’s reasonable, but finding out what the wealthiest own is harder than …

fact_check_explanation_title: Right to Buy on target, but one in six sold off is replaced
fact_check_explanation_summary: Prime Minister's Questions 7 September 2016: Right to Buy on target, but one in six sold off is replaced

fact_check_explanation_title: Unaccompanied refugee children in Europe
fact_check_explanation_summary: How many unaccompanied children are in Europe and how many are claiming asylum here?

fact_check_explanation_title: Polls didn't show a consistent Labour lead
fact_check_explanation_summary: “We've been working, over the last year, to unite the party, and we were winning electorally and in the polls.” John McDonnell, 15 September 2016 “85 out of 89 polls …

fact_check_explanation_title: Who can veto a Brexit deal?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Individual countries won’t be able to veto an EU-UK deal on how it leaves the bloc, but could block a deal on future trade if they don’t like it.

fact_check_explanation_title: London schools outperform the rest of England
fact_check_explanation_summary: “Now we’ve got the best schools in the country [in London]. This isn’t as well about rich and poor areas, some of the best schools in London now, as a …

fact_check_explanation_title: Grammar schools benefit some pupils but the majority do worse
fact_check_explanation_summary: Evidence suggests pupils who get into grammar schools perform better than they would under comprehensive education, and pupils who don’t perform worse.

fact_check_explanation_title: Finland, Canada and South Korea rank highly for education
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've checked claims from this week's BBC Question Time on education systems across the world.

fact_check_explanation_title: A tale of two courts
fact_check_explanation_summary: Why would a judge's finding that someone killed their child be kept secret from the jury trying his case?

fact_check_explanation_title: Apprenticeship funding: going up or down?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 16-18 year olds could see a funding rate cut of between 30% and 50%, based on case studies of three of the most popular types of apprenticeships.

fact_check_explanation_title: The number of teachers in English schools
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's correct that there are more teachers in English schools now than in 2010 - but there are also more pupils.

fact_check_explanation_title: The government’s proposals could change what we know about selection
fact_check_explanation_summary: At this week's Prime Minister's Questions, Theresa May faces questions on how the government's new grammar schools plan will work.

fact_check_explanation_title: Poor children do worse in areas that have grammar schools
fact_check_explanation_summary: How many grammar school pupils are on free school meals?

fact_check_explanation_title: Social mobility in the selective education era
fact_check_explanation_summary: The evidence suggests that grammar schools weren't any better for overall social mobility in their 1950s/60s heyday than they are at the moment.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are 125,000 operations predicted to be cancelled?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Although reports have varied, the government and health bosses are now agreed that around 125,000 operations are expected to be cancelled over junior doctors’ strikes between September and December.

fact_check_explanation_title: Economy introductions: the size of government spending
fact_check_explanation_summary: Last year, the government spent about £753 billion in total. That’s roughly 40% of all the money spent in the UK. 18% is spent on health, about a fifth.

fact_check_explanation_title: Courts decide who triggers Article 50
fact_check_explanation_summary: “Will she [the Prime Minister] confirm that there is really no basis in law to require the government to seek the permission of Parliament before invoking Article 50?” Bernard Jenkin …

fact_check_explanation_title: Charity says 67% of refuges might close
fact_check_explanation_summary: Women’s Aid, a charity focusing on women suffering domestic abuse, has said that “67% of specialist domestic abuse refuges in England will be forced to close” unless they are exempted …

fact_check_explanation_title: £9 billion in housing benefit to private landlords
fact_check_explanation_summary: “Devastating figures released over this summer show that £9.3 billion of public money is paid through housing benefit directly into the pockets of private landlords.” Jeremy Corbyn, 7 September 2016 …

fact_check_explanation_title: House building: higher or lower depending on the date
fact_check_explanation_summary: Prime Minister's Questions 7 September 2016: There are a lot of different ways of looking at house building figures over time.

fact_check_explanation_title: Diversity among judges: a mixed picture
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures show that an increasing percentage of judges are female. The same goes for ethnic minorities, although the statistics don't make this clear.

fact_check_explanation_title: Two big questions about leaving the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: Two of the major issues that the government must decide after the EU referendum result are the timing of Brexit, and single market membership.

fact_check_explanation_title: The £150 million BBC licence fee loophole?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The BBC has said it will make £150 million less in 2016/17 from licence fees than it had expected in 2011, which it attributes to an 'iPlayer loophole'.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did a judge say public money is being 'squandered' on lawyers?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Several outlets report that the most senior family court judge in England and Wales says that public money is being "squandered" on lawyers. Did he?

fact_check_explanation_title: The number of frontline prison officers is falling
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of frontline prison officers is falling and has been since 2010, although there were increases in recruitment last year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Counting the number of migrants in the Calais ‘jungle’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Officials and charities disagree over an extra 2,000 migrants in the Calais camp. We look at how both got their figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: The changing face of welfare
fact_check_explanation_summary: Since 2010 the government has introduced a number of changes to the welfare system. We looked at how things have changed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Help to Buy ISAs: do they work and were they mis-sold?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Treasury hasn’t backtracked on Help to Buy ISAs, and they don’t just help people who already have the money to buy a house, contrary to some reports.

fact_check_explanation_title: What have bacon butties got to do with Brexit?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Contrary to one report, the vote to leave the EU hasn't pushed up retail prices for bacon.

fact_check_explanation_title: Net migration: still at record high and trend flat
fact_check_explanation_summary: Net migration estimates show a continuation of recent trends, with the change over last year almost five times smaller than the margin for error.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Olympic Games, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We looked into whether this was Team GB's best Olympics ever, how much funding it gets, and which sports UK athletes have won the most medals in.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is there a shortage of maternal mental health services?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures show that 39% of CCGs have no community mental health provision for pregnant or new mothers.

fact_check_explanation_title: Regional investment in transport: we don’t know exactly who gets what
fact_check_explanation_summary: There aren't figures that show exactly how much more transport investment is planned for London than the rest of the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Reporting sexual offences in schools: an incomplete picture
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures suggest sexual offences in schools have more than doubled over four years, but they are incomplete and don’t show the full picture across the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: No source yet for £6bn cost of 'bed blocking' claim
fact_check_explanation_summary: There were over 170,000 delayed bed days in June because patients weren't discharged once they were fit. This could cost the NHS up to £900 million a year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Supreme Court too costly for Labour members?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Supreme Court said it would have cost £1,000 for an appeal in the Labour membership case to be heard. Normally, it would be more expensive.

fact_check_explanation_title: Murray wins a second gold, but he’s not the first
fact_check_explanation_summary: Andy Murray is the first to win two Olympic gold medals in singles tennis, but other men and women have won multiple gold medals.

fact_check_explanation_title: Brexit and the great British pub
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's been suggested that the UK's pubs have been doing a roaring trade on the back of the vote to leave the EU. The figures don't support that theory.

fact_check_explanation_title: When judges swear in court
fact_check_explanation_summary: A judge is reportedly under investigation for using bad language in court, in response to a foul-mouthed defendant. What are the possible consequences?

fact_check_explanation_title: It's harder for young people to own their own home
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister says that young people are finding it harder to buy homes. All the evidence we've seen bears that out.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are Muslim women more likely to be unemployed?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The unemployment rate for Muslim women was 16% in 2015, compared to around 5% for women in general.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do farmers make more from subsidies than agriculture?
fact_check_explanation_summary: On average most farms in the UK make more from subsidies than they do from agriculture, but this varies depending on the size and type of the farm.

fact_check_explanation_title: The scale of abuse during childhood: how much do we know?
fact_check_explanation_summary: An estimated six million adults in England and Wales report having been abused as children, and two million report having been sexually abused.

fact_check_explanation_title: Black people and justice: the viral poster, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: A poster about the differences between white and black people's experiences of work and criminal justice in the UK has been circulating on social media.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can the UK change its mind about leaving the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's not clear whether or not the UK can halt the process of leaving the EU midway through. This has implications for suggestions of a second vote.

fact_check_explanation_title: A sporting legacy? How participation has changed since the 2012 Olympics
fact_check_explanation_summary: Participation in sports has increased overall since 2005, but is down on the Olympic peak in 2012.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does delaying airport expansion cost us £6 million a day?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There's three shortlisted projects for airport expansion. MPs suggested that delaying the decision costs the UK between £2 million and £7 million a day.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tariffs and barriers: trade between Britain and the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: What would trade between Britain and the EU look like if we left?

fact_check_explanation_title: Black people and criminal justice
fact_check_explanation_summary: Black people are over-represented at several different stages in the criminal justice process, and there’s some evidence to suggest racial bias.

fact_check_explanation_title: Deaths of BAME people in police custody
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Independent Police Complaints Commission published new statistics on deaths in police custody today.

fact_check_explanation_title: Norway's EU payments
fact_check_explanation_summary: The cost of EU membership was a major issue during the referendum. Now that we've voted to leave, joining Norway in the EEA is one option. That costs, too.

fact_check_explanation_title: Where are the UK's refugees?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Reports that over 80% of councils have taken in no Syrian refugees under the main government resettlement programme are correct - up to a point.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK's Sharia 'courts'
fact_check_explanation_summary: While there are undoubtedly lots of different religious councils and tribunals in the UK dealing with Sharia principles, they aren't courts of law.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are state school pupils less likely to reach top jobs?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Pupils who go to state schools are less represented in the 'top jobs' than they are among the general population.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much do the regions of the UK receive in EU funding?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no specific amount that each region of the UK gets from the EU, this changes from year to year depending on the number of funding applications.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are there record numbers of young people going to university?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We take a look at the different ways of measuring university participation by young people and disadvantaged young people.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Prime Minister's resignation list: is it business as usual?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Details of David Cameron's resignation honours list have been leaked. Is it standard practice for such a list to be made by outgoing leaders?

fact_check_explanation_title: How many terrorism suspects are under curfew?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It’s correct that, earlier this year, only one person in Great Britain had restrictions on his or her daily life because that person was suspected of terrorism-related activity. But that’s …

fact_check_explanation_title: Are white, working class boys the least likely to go to university?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Less well-off white boys in England are, on average, less likely to attend university than minority ethnic groups, according to research.

fact_check_explanation_title: Zero hours contracts: is the UK "the odd one out"?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Zero hours contracts, or similar forms of employment, are often unknown, banned or heavily regulated in other European countries.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did Tesco waste 119 million meals last year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Tesco estimates it produced 59,400 tonnes of food waste last year across all its UK retail operations.

fact_check_explanation_title: Refugees in Lebanon and the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: Exact figures are hard to come by, but it seems correct to say that there are 10 times as many refugees in Lebanon as in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did crime rates just double overnight?
fact_check_explanation_summary: New figures this week show almost six million incidents of fraud and cybercrime in England and Wales, which previously weren't measured by the Crime Survey.

fact_check_explanation_title: Young voters and the EU referendum
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've seen conflicting figures on turnout among young people in the EU referendum. No polls are definitive, but the young do seem less likely to have voted.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: British steel and EU rules
fact_check_explanation_summary: EU regulations do prevent some government actions to support the steel industry, but there are other actions the government can take.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the UK calling for EU duties for Chinese steel?
fact_check_explanation_summary: China is accused of 'dumping' steel on EU markets. We've looked at what this means and at the UK's position.

fact_check_explanation_title: Deaths during military training: worse than Iraq?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's correct that there have been almost as many armed forces deaths on training as in Iraq, although not all could necessarily have been prevented.

fact_check_explanation_title: Home ownership, honour-based crime and MPs' social backgrounds: Prime Minister's Questions, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've looked into claims from Prime Minister's Questions on young people owning homes, employment, honour-based crime and the social background of MPs.

fact_check_explanation_title: How the EU works: leaving the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: Professor Steve Peers explains the legal dimension of leaving the EU. The UK would notify the European Council after a leave vote, triggering negotiations.

fact_check_explanation_title: Life expectancy and poverty
fact_check_explanation_summary: Boys born in some of the UK's poorest areas are expected to live nine years fewer than those in the richest areas. For girls the figure is seven years.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for Wales?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at the possible impact of leaving the EU for Wales.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for Scotland?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU might be for Scotland in particular.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much does Trident cost?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In advance of the debate about whether to go ahead with the replacement of the Trident nuclear deterrent, we've looked at how much it would cost.

fact_check_explanation_title: Housing, zero hours contracts, and NHS funding: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on homelessness, first-time buyers, zero hours contracts, and NHS funding.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are Southern trains running on time?
fact_check_explanation_summary: When is a train 'on time' and when is it late? There's more than one definition.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for energy and climate change?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Leaving the EU will have implications for the UK's emissions, renewable energy and air pollution targets, as well as its relationship with the single market for energy.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for Northern Ireland?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on Northern Ireland.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for the environment?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on the environment in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for transport?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on transport in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for health?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on health in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU immigration and pressure on the NHS
fact_check_explanation_summary: EU immigration contributes to financial pressure on the NHS, but its annual impact is small compared to other factors.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU immigration and NHS staff
fact_check_explanation_summary: What proportion of NHS staff come from the EU, and what could leaving the EU mean for the future workforce?

fact_check_explanation_title: 7 July's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've checked the panel's claims on the UK economy, immigration and wages, voting in the EU referendum and Labour party membership figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for pensions?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on pensions in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on major policy areas in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for foreign policy?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on foreign policy in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for social security?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on social security in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for fishing?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on fishing policies in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for defence?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on defence in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for international development?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on international development policies in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Regional pay, investment and going to war: Prime Minister's Questions, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on regional pay and investment, NHS spending and conventions on going to war.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for consumers?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on consumer policy in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: School spending: up or down?
fact_check_explanation_summary: As teachers walk out, we investigate whether the schools budget is being cut or not.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for culture, media and sport?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on culture, media and sport in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for Higher Education?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on Higher Education in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for agriculture?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on agriculture in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU debate: does Brussels employ fewer bureaucrats than Derbyshire?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's roughly correct that the European Union employs the same number of people as Derbyshire County Council, although it depends on who you count.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: Would restricting free movement actually be possible?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Ask Full Fact: If the UK votes to leave the EU, how plausible is it that we will be able to restrict the free movement of EU citizens?

fact_check_explanation_title: 30 June's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've checked the panel's claims on the EU single market, why people voted to leave, money to the NHS and how many young people voted in the referendum.

fact_check_explanation_title: What would an Australian-style immigration points system mean for the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The level of immigration under a points-based system depends, in part, on how the system is designed.

fact_check_explanation_title: What's the difference between a single market and a free trade agreement? Watch this video.
fact_check_explanation_summary: A video by the National Institute for Economic and Social Research explains the difference between a single market and a free trade agreement.

fact_check_explanation_title: Poverty, insecure jobs, and incomes: Prime Minister's Questions, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on poverty, insecure jobs, and inequality.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for employment law?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on employment law in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for human rights?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on human rights in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for asylum policy?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on asylum policy in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for EU citizens in the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be for EU citizens living in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for border controls?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on border controls in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for immigration?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on immigration in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for businesses?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on businesses in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for how immigration affects the economy?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be for how immigration affects the economy.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for foreign investment?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on foreign investment in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for public finances?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on public finances.

fact_check_explanation_title: What does leaving the EU mean for trade?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at what the impact of leaving the EU will be on trade by the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: EU law
fact_check_explanation_summary: Factchecking the Vote Leave "facts" leaflet.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is it safe to vote with a pencil?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Voters can bring a pen to the polling station, but there are also laws ensuring that ballot papers aren't tampered with before the count is complete.

fact_check_explanation_title: EU Referendum debate: some useful sources
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some sources we found useful while factchecking the EU referendum.

fact_check_explanation_title: What do businesses think about the EU referendum?
fact_check_explanation_summary: As far as we’re aware, there aren’t any surveys that offer a representative picture of UK business opinion on the UK’s membership of the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: quick answers to your questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've provided sources and answers to some more of your EU questions.

fact_check_explanation_title: Will the UK pay for future Eurozone bailouts?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK can be asked for financial support for Eurozone countries but is guaranteed its money back.

fact_check_explanation_title: The government's immigration target: does EU immigration matter?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister claims that EU and British net migration was in balance as recently as 2008, but the figures themselves can't prove this.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many businesses export to the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It sounds like a simple question, but it’s not so easy to answer. We don’t have any official figures for how many UK businesses in total export to the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK wages if we leave the EU: what Stuart Rose actually said
fact_check_explanation_summary: Stuart Rose’s statement has been taken out of context

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the EU ‘pinching our fish’?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We looked into how the EU divides up the fish in its waters, the UK's position within the EU fishing industry and if leaving the EU would change things.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does a 10% rise in immigration lead to a 2% reduction in wages?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Conclusions from a Bank of England report have been repeatedly misquoted.

fact_check_explanation_title: The economic consequences of leaving the EU - statement from IFS, NIESR, and CEP
fact_check_explanation_summary: Economic institutes have made a joint statement on leaving the EU. Here's what they said.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: How long would leaving the EU take?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Ask Full Fact: How long will it take to leave the EU and how many new treaties is it likely to take?

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: In or out for the NHS or TTIP?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Ask Full Fact: Is an in or out vote best if I want to protect the NHS from further privatisation, fully fund it and remove the NHS from the TTIP …

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: Would jobs be lost as a result of leaving the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Ask Full Fact: So many claims and counter claims - will jobs be lost as a result of leaving EU?

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: Why is TTIP not being discussed before the referendum?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Ask Full Fact: With regard to TTIP, why is it not being openly discussed during the lead up to the referendum. Why is it such a secret?

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: did we vote for the EU in the 1975 referendum?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The 1975 referendum on the UK's membership of the European Community wasn't presented as just a trade agreement.

fact_check_explanation_title: False claims about false claims about the EU referendum
fact_check_explanation_summary: Accusations of "completely untrue" claims on the membership fee, Turkey joining the EU, and an EU army aren't completely true.

fact_check_explanation_title: The hunt for an EU army
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU doesn't have an army, and doesn't look like getting one. It encourages military co-operation, and at least a few politicians support EU armed forces.

fact_check_explanation_title: What happens to British citizens abroad and EU citizens here, if we leave the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: If the UK votes to leave the European Union, what happens to its citizens in EU countries, and EU citizens in the UK, will be a matter for negotiation.

fact_check_explanation_title: £136 million a week is not what the UK sends to the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK Statistics Authority has not said that the UK sends £136 million a week to the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: The EU referendum, the economy and you
fact_check_explanation_summary: There's lots of economic forecasts. What might they mean for you?

fact_check_explanation_title: Briefing: Immigration and the EU Referendum
fact_check_explanation_summary: Lots of claims have been made about immigration in the lead up to the EU Referendum. We've gathered together a briefing with everything we know about them here.

fact_check_explanation_title: Immigration, the economy, and trade: Prime Minister's Questions, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on the economic impact of leaving the EU, fishing quotas, immigration and trade.

fact_check_explanation_title: Would leaving the EU cost the NHS?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Trades Union Congress, Alistair Darling and George Osborne have all made claims about the cost to the NHS if we vote to leave the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS, EU funding and VAT: possible effects of leaving the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: Vote Leave have claimed that leaving the EU would free up 'billions' to spend on public services and reduce taxation, even after EU funding has been replaced.

fact_check_explanation_title: The government's EU leaflet: employment rights
fact_check_explanation_summary: Factchecking the government's EU referendum leaflet on free movement and employment rights.

fact_check_explanation_title: 9 June's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've checked the panel's claims on EU immigration, the economic impacts, and the UK's EU membership fee.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do we need a new house every four minutes because of immigration?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This is plausible, although we can’t be certain about immigrants’ housing needs and there’s not enough clear research that would give us better figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the UK created more jobs than the rest of the EU combined?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's true that Britain has seen a larger net increase in employment than the rest of the EU combined, and that Yorkshire has seen a larger net increase in employment …

fact_check_explanation_title: Have 5,000 jihadis come into the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that there are 5,000 terrorists loose in Europe have been attributed to the director of Europol, the EU law enforcement agency. He says otherwise.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much does the EU spend on promoting itself?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Business for Britain says that up to €3.9 billion of the 2014 EU budget could have been spent on self-promotion and propaganda. Is this accurate?

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: TTIP in or out?
fact_check_explanation_summary: If the UK votes to remain in the EU then we will be covered by TTIP, unless it is blocked. If we leave then we won't be part of the …

fact_check_explanation_title: Minimum wage, workers' rights and the EU: Prime Minister's Questions, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on the minimum wage, workers' rights and the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK law: What proportion is influenced by the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We often see conflicting figures on the percentage of UK laws that come from the EU. There's no one definitive answer, and many ways of calculating this.

fact_check_explanation_title: What would Brexit mean for criminal justice?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Criminal law expert J.R. Spencer explains how the EU affects criminal justice in the UK, and how leaving the EU might change things.

fact_check_explanation_title: Leaving the EU: why do the economic forecasts differ?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU referendum debate has seen a range of claims about the future. Why do the different forecasts make different predictions?

fact_check_explanation_title: Ten things to know about economic models
fact_check_explanation_summary: Ten things you should know about economic forecasts and economic predictions.

fact_check_explanation_title: Who can vote in the EU referendum?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This series of articles answers the most popular Google searches about the EU referendum on 23 June.

fact_check_explanation_title: Renegotiating "ever closer union"
fact_check_explanation_summary: Dropping our EU treaty commitment to "ever closer union" - as David Cameron says he wants to do - may have a political impact, but no direct legal effect.

fact_check_explanation_title: What the IFS actually said about the UK's EU membership fee
fact_check_explanation_summary: The IFS does not believe that savings on the UK's membership fee would leave more to spend on the NHS.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is there a "£20bn black hole" in the EU's finances?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's been claimed that there's a £20bn 'black hole' in EU finances.

fact_check_explanation_title: The government's immigration target: only achievable outside the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government can't guarantee meeting its net migration target if the UK remains in the EU, it depends on EU citizens choosing not to come to the UK.

fact_check_explanation_summary: We've checked the panel's claims on immigration, the EU accounts, economists’ views on leaving the EU, and the government’s house building record.

fact_check_explanation_summary: Remain campaigners often cite the reduced cost of using a mobile phone in other European countries as an EU success story. That seems fair.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much of your paid holiday is down to the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU does give workers the right to a minimum 20 days of paid leave, but it was a decision of the British government to increase that to 28 days.

fact_check_explanation_title: What could happen to VAT and energy prices if we leave the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Would energy bills be lower if we left the EU? We could cut VAT but beyond that it’s uncertain.

fact_check_explanation_title: New jobs for foreign workers
fact_check_explanation_summary: We don't know how many new jobs go to British or foreign workers, but we've looked at figures for the change in employment and the nationalities and country of birth …

fact_check_explanation_title: Is Turkey likely to join the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The dispute over Cyprus, human rights concerns and political opposition mean that candidate country Turkey isn't likely to join the EU any time soon.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did 1.8 million migrants enter the EU illegally last year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 1.8 million illegal border crossings into the EU were detected by member states in 2015. This isn’t the same as 1.8 million migrants.

fact_check_explanation_summary: There has been privatisation of services according to the WHO’s definition, but that doesn’t mean it thinks the NHS has been abolished.

fact_check_explanation_summary: We issue many more NI numbers to nationals from the rest of the EU than the number of EU nationals estimated to be immigrating here. We don't yet know why.
