fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures released this week on tax receipts aren't as simple as they might seem.

fact_check_explanation_title: 3 March's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: Last night's Question Time came from Liverpool. We've checked the panel's claims on the EU's influence, migrants into Europe, and tax.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Court of Protection
fact_check_explanation_summary: An overview of the Court of Protection, which deals with cases where people lack capacity to make their own decisions.

fact_check_explanation_title: Norway, Switzerland and EU laws
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government claims that Norway and Switzerland have to accept EU laws despite not being members in order to access the single market. That's about right.

fact_check_explanation_title: Teacher shortages, school places and childcare: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on teacher shortages, school places, childcare and joint enterprise.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do most secondary schools use non-specialist teachers?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Association of School and College Leaders has warned today that teacher shortages are having a detrimental impact on pupils' education.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the UK making progress towards its 2020 renewables target?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Without further action from the government the UK will miss its target to get 15% of energy from renewable sources by 2020.

fact_check_explanation_title: What's happening to secondary school places?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Concerns have been raised about the ability of local authorities to cope with a predicted 20% rise in secondary pupil numbers over the next decade.

fact_check_explanation_title: 25 February's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: Last night's Question Time came from Poole. We've checked the panel's claims about our EU membership, Syrian aid, and weekend deaths in hospitals.

fact_check_explanation_title: Junior doctors, the NHS, and European unemployment: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on junior doctors, NHS weekend deaths, NHS funding, and unemployment in Europe.

fact_check_explanation_title: Explaining the EU deal: is it legally binding?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There's been heated argument about whether the Prime Minister's EU deal is legally binding. We asked EU law expert Professor Steve Peers to take a look.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do EU immigrants contribute £1.34 for every £1 received from the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Research has previously found this for recently-arrived immigrants from the rest of the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: How to interpret today's reports about air pollution
fact_check_explanation_summary: A new report published today says that around 40,000 deaths are attributable to exposure to outdoor air pollution in the UK every year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Unanswered questions on “extra £1 billion” for mental health
fact_check_explanation_summary: Despite the announcement we still don’t know how spending on mental health services will fare over the next five years.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK carbon emissions are falling
fact_check_explanation_summary: The drop in UK carbon dioxide emissions was the largest since comparable records began.

fact_check_explanation_title: Explaining the EU deal: an introduction
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister's EU renegotiation deal has been announced. Here's what impartial EU experts think of it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Explaining the EU deal: the ‘emergency brake’
fact_check_explanation_summary: Professor Eleanor Spaventa explains the 'emergency brake' idea. It would allow any member country to limit access to in-work benefits for new EU immigrants.

fact_check_explanation_title: Explaining the EU deal: the 'red card'
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU deal contains a 'red card' for parliaments to challenge draft EU laws if they don't comply with 'subsidiarity'. Professor Derrick Wyatt QC explains.

fact_check_explanation_title: Explaining the EU deal: deporting EU immigrants
fact_check_explanation_summary: European Union member countries will find it easier to deport EU immigrants under the renegotiation deal, says Professor Catherine Barnard.

fact_check_explanation_title: Explaining the EU deal: child benefit
fact_check_explanation_summary: Dr Charlotte O'Brien examines the potential legal problems with the EU deal on child benefit payments.

fact_check_explanation_title: Explaining the EU deal: an "ever closer union"
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU deal says that the UK should no longer have to commit to an "ever closer union". Professor Sionaidh Douglas-Scott shows why this has no legal effect.

fact_check_explanation_title: Explaining the EU deal: the UK and the eurozone
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU deal tries to reassure non-euro countries like the UK that they won’t be ganged up on by eurozone countries. Professor Paul Craig asks why.

fact_check_explanation_title: Explaining the EU deal: limiting residence rights for family members
fact_check_explanation_summary: Professor Niamh Nic Shuibhne explains the limits on residence rights for non-EU family members of EU immigrants in the EU renegotiation deal.

fact_check_explanation_title: Could killers convicted under 'joint enterprise' walk free from jail?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Could killers walk free as a result of changes to the law? Not necessarily.

fact_check_explanation_title: 18 February's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: Last night's Question Time was in Stratford-Upon-Avon. We've checked the panel's claims about the EU, schools and whether there's a teacher shortage.

fact_check_explanation_title: Jobs figures can't show record EU migration
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures released today only show the number of EU nationals in work, not the numbers coming to the UK

fact_check_explanation_title: Domestic violence: 1.9 million say they were victims last year
fact_check_explanation_summary: And two women a week are killed by partners, ex-partners, ‘emotional rivals’, and family members.

fact_check_explanation_title: What’s behind the rise in deaths?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Reports this morning have said that a rise in the number of deaths prompted warnings of a crisis in care for the elderly.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does mental ill health cost £105 billion a year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The estimate that mental ill health costs around £105 billion comes from research by health charity Centre for Mental Health back in 2010.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many cyclists are hurt and killed on poor roads?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Last year 53 cyclists were killed or seriously injured in accidents which were contributed to by poor road surfaces, according to attending police officers.

fact_check_explanation_title: 11 February's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: Question Time last night was in Llanelli, Wales. We've checked the panel's claims on the Welsh NHS, junior doctors and the effect of immigration on wages.

fact_check_explanation_title: The level of dissatisfaction with the NHS is not the highest on record
fact_check_explanation_summary: There's been some confusion in media reports of health charity The King's Fund's analysis of survey data about public satisfaction with the NHS.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can killers now avoid life in prison with a guilty plea?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Suggested new guidelines for judges, published today, wouldn’t significantly change the rules on when someone stays in prison for life.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: Are British youngsters the most illiterate in the developed world?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A report has said that the proportion of 16 to 19 year olds in England who have “low literacy” is the highest of 23 OECD countries.

fact_check_explanation_title: Poll does not prove Brits want to quit the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: Taken together, polls have so far suggested a slight lead for the ‘remain’ camp so far.

fact_check_explanation_title: Housing, oil revenues, and teachers: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on benefits, housing, oil prices and teachers.

fact_check_explanation_title: Why is the government accusing the BMA of lying?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government has accused doctors' union the BMA of lying to its members over the pay offered in a new junior doctors' contract. Here's why.

fact_check_explanation_title: The state of private rented homes
fact_check_explanation_summary: While 30% of private rented homes aren't rated 'decent' according to a government standard, the proportion failing it because of health and safety is 17%.

fact_check_explanation_title: Would restricting in-work benefits to EU migrants reduce immigration?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Sir Stephen Nickell has said that restricting access to benefits wouldn't have much impact on EU immigration, Iain Duncan Smith says it would.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are junior doctors getting a pay cut?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Weekend pay is a major sticking point in negotiations between junior doctors and the government. What do we know about what the proposals will mean for pay?

fact_check_explanation_title: Onshore wind: how much investment would be affected by early closure of the subsidy?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look into some of the available evidence on money that's been invested in onshore wind projects.

fact_check_explanation_title: Prisons: re-offending, costs and conditions
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister will today announce reforms to the prison system in England and Wales. We've factchecked the key claims we've heard this morning.

fact_check_explanation_title: The rising prison population
fact_check_explanation_summary: The prison population was about 45,000 in England and Wales in 1990 and 1991 and is now about 86,000.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does re-offending cost £13 billion a year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: That's the upper range of an estimate for 2007/08.

fact_check_explanation_title: Self-harm and suicides in jail
fact_check_explanation_summary: We check the Prime Minister's figures on self-inflicted deaths and injuries in prison.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many prisoners re-offend within a year of release?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Close to half of all prisoners in England and Wales will commit another criminal offence within a year of being released.

fact_check_explanation_title: 4 February's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We checked the Question Time panel's claims about migrants' benefits, Norway and the EU, English speakers, and the Northern Powerhouse.

fact_check_explanation_title: Humanitarian aid to Syria in 2015
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2015 the UN got half the money it said it needed to deal with the crisis in Syria. Of that money, half was from the US, UK, and Germany.

fact_check_explanation_title: Net migration is at a record high, but it's not 380,000
fact_check_explanation_summary: Former Labour Home Secretary Alan Johnson was on Radio 4 Today discussing immigration.

fact_check_explanation_title: Cancer, waiting lists and refugee children: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on cancer patients, NHS performance and refugee children.

fact_check_explanation_title: Universal Credit: will it "make work pay"?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There have been conflicting claims over whether Universal Credit will "make work pay".

fact_check_explanation_title: Do black workers face a widening pay gap the more qualifications they earn?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s evidence of an overall pay gap, but the relationship between qualifications and pay is complicated.

fact_check_explanation_title: Just under half of migrants and asylum seekers who've crossed into Europe are Syrian
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Foreign Secretary has been reported as saying that less than half of migrants are fleeing Syria.

fact_check_explanation_title: Lord Neuberger on veils in court
fact_check_explanation_summary: Newspaper reports of what Lord Neuberger, President of the Supreme Court, thinks about women wearing veils in court are right—unlike the last time around.

fact_check_explanation_title: "The judge who dared to tell the truth"?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Immigrants, benefits, and what the judge actually said about Calais.

fact_check_explanation_title: 28 January's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We factchecked the Question Time panel's claims on Google, taxes, refugees, the railways, and what the polls tell us about the EU referendum.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is Google paying 3% tax?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The debate is over what counts as Google's "economic activity" in the UK.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much of our energy comes from wind? MPs disagree
fact_check_explanation_summary: While debating the Energy Bill, MPs disputed each other’s statistics on how much of the UK’s electricity comes from wind turbines.

fact_check_explanation_title: Would net migration fall by 100,000 if the UK left the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There’s no way to know whether net migration would fall by 100,000 if the UK leaves the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Corporation Tax, the deficit, and the 'bedroom tax': factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on Corporation Tax, today's court ruling on the 'bedroom tax', and the deficit.

fact_check_explanation_title: The ruling on the 'bedroom tax'
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Court of Appeal says that the so-called 'bedroom tax' discriminates against two particular groups of people. This doesn't spell the end of the policy.

fact_check_explanation_title: Where does the EU export to?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK is the EU’s largest single export market in goods, if you treat the UK as if it were outside the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: the UK’s trade with the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: Pro-EU campaigners say that 50% of the UK's exports go to the EU, versus 8% to up-and-coming BRICS economies. It's 44% to the EU and 8% to BRICS.

fact_check_explanation_title: The criminal courts
fact_check_explanation_summary: An expert overview of the courts that hold criminal trials in England and Wales.

fact_check_explanation_title: 21 January's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We factchecked the Question Time panel's claims about same-sex marriage in Northern Ireland, and the UK's membership of the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: Do addicts and alcoholics cost the taxpayer £10 billion a year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: £10 billion is an uncertain estimate of the public cost of people who are homeless, offenders or drug misusers or any combination of the three.

fact_check_explanation_title: Unemployment, nurses, and knife crime: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on unemployment, nurse training, apprenticeships, and knife crime.

fact_check_explanation_title: Miranda’s rights: will the Terrorism Act be changed?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The David Miranda case has been hailed as a "huge win" for journalism, but doesn't automatically mean that the Terrorism Act will be changed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are changes to maintenance grants being made through an arcane loophole?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There's a debate over the way in which proposals to replace student maintenance grants with beefed-up loans have been introduced. We've taken a look.

fact_check_explanation_title: When criminal trials are "cracked"
fact_check_explanation_summary: Criminal trials can finish unexpectedly due to witness problems. But contrary to what's been reported, witnesses aren't the only cause of "cracked" trials.

fact_check_explanation_title: 22% of Muslim women say they don’t speak English or don’t speak it well
fact_check_explanation_summary: A government claim about the number of Muslim women with little or no English is backed up by Office for National Statistics analysis of the 2011 census.

fact_check_explanation_title: 14 January's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We factchecked the panel's claims on junior doctors, deaths in hospitals at weekends, what the UK pays into the EU, and housing.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: stroke patients and weekend deaths
fact_check_explanation_summary: Jeremy Hunt has said that people who have a stroke at the weekend are 20% more likely to die. Some of our readers asked us to investigate.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can the boss now read your messages at work?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A European human rights case is said to make a big change to employees' right to privacy at work. But employees generally may not be affected.

fact_check_explanation_title: Housing, pollution, and winter deaths: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on housing, pollution, winter deaths, school performance, energy competition, and employment.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence that junior doctors' strike will put 200 lives at risk
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's been suggested that junior doctors' strike action could put 200 lives at risk, but that number isn't backed up by any published evidence.

fact_check_explanation_title: British students and the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: Campaigners to stay in the EU have invoked the number of UK students going abroad on the Erasmus programme. Their figures are broadly correct.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are homes sold under Right to Buy being replaced?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In an interview with David Cameron on the weekend, Andrew Marr claimed that many more social homes have been sold under Right to Buy than replaced.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much money does legal aid save the country?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim that the state saves £6 for every £1 spent on legal aid should be treated with caution. It's evolved out of several different pieces of research.

fact_check_explanation_title: Understanding alcohol health risks
fact_check_explanation_summary: Proposed new guidance says people should drink no more than 14 units of alcohol per week to keep health risks low. Just how risky is it?

fact_check_explanation_title: The government defence on flood defences
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour's attack on David Cameron over flood defence spending doesn't prove that total spending has fallen on his watch, but cuts have been made in some areas.

fact_check_explanation_title: Floods, housing and income inequality: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on flood defences, housing, solar panels, income inequality and chief executive pay.

fact_check_explanation_title: British influence in the EU Council of Ministers
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK's formal voting weight in the important EU Council of Ministers has declined since we joined, but recent changes push it back up to 13%.

fact_check_explanation_title: Four million people have diabetes—probably
fact_check_explanation_summary: New figures claiming that four million people have diabetes seem right, although the estimate for the half a million who are undiagnosed is hard to verify.

fact_check_explanation_title: Rail fares: up 25% in six years?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Have rail fares gone up by a quarter since 2010, as the Labour Party claims?

fact_check_explanation_title: Home ownership: the lowest in a generation?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour claims that home ownership is at its lowest level in a generation. The proportion of English households owning their home is the lowest since 1984.

fact_check_explanation_title: We don't know that 100,000 illegal migrants have been stopped at the border
fact_check_explanation_summary: The claim that 100,000 illegal migrants have been stopped at the border is an unofficial projection and is uncertain.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: is poverty being redefined to remove any reference to income?
fact_check_explanation_summary: New targets replace existing income indicators of child poverty with ones that focus on worklessness and educational attainment.

fact_check_explanation_title: Have A&E admissions for alcohol poisoning doubled?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Headlines refer to A&E admissions when the statistics they're using measure people visiting A&E, regardless of what kind of treatment they get.

fact_check_explanation_title: Social care funding: how did the sector react to the latest plans?
fact_check_explanation_summary: David Cameron and Jeremy Corbyn swapped quotes from health and social care leaders during Prime Minister's Questions.

fact_check_explanation_title: 17 December's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We factchecked the panel's claims about migrants benefits, Norway's relationship with the EU and trade.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the EU referendum outcome "on a knife edge"?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Online polls conducted this week show preferences for the EU referendum vote are neck and neck while telephone polls have found a strong lead for 'remain'.

fact_check_explanation_title: A new EU border agency, or an EU army?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Newspaper reports describe a proposed new European Border and Coast Agency as an EU "army" or "navy". We've taken a look.

fact_check_explanation_title: Employment, hospital beds, and A&E: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on employment, hospitals, A&E, and refugees.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are more teachers quitting the profession than entering it?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Labour claims that record numbers of teachers are quitting the profession, and that more are leaving it than are entering it.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much are charities spending on good works?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A new report criticises charities based on their spending on charitable activities as a proportion of their income. But this metric can be confusing.

fact_check_explanation_title: "Hoverboards" and the law
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's been claimed that the prosecution service recently made "hoverboards" illegal. But it has no such power; newspapers have just picked up on an existing law.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is immigration affecting the performance of native English speakers in schools?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's been claimed that increasing numbers of pupils with English as an additional language is affecting the performance of their peers.

fact_check_explanation_title: 10 December's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We factchecked the panel's claims from BBC Question Time on Donald Trump, the European Arrest Warrant, Norway, shoot-to-kill, and mental health.

fact_check_explanation_title: Claim that Islamic State hack brought down university internet services appears unfounded
fact_check_explanation_summary: A headline in the Express claimed that an Islamic State hack disrupted university internet services, but the evidence it gave for this is not convincing.

fact_check_explanation_title: Trade with the EU, nurses, and tuition fees: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on trade with the EU, nurses and tuition fees.

fact_check_explanation_title: Flood defences: what's happening to funding?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Capital spending is set to be £1.9 billion this parliament, up from previous parliaments. But capital spending isn't the whole story.

fact_check_explanation_title: Would early closure of the Renewables Obligation to onshore wind cost £100 million?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government says closing the Renewables Obligation to onshore wind early will bring benefits of £160 million.

fact_check_explanation_title: Air strikes: how many teachers and nurses could we pay for instead?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Would air strikes in Syria cost £508,000 each, enough to pay for about 20 teachers or 19 nurses?

fact_check_explanation_title: What effect on the public purse would closing the Renewables Obligation early have?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The impact of the early closure of the Renewables Obligation to onshore wind on public finances.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is a relentless workload forcing teachers to leave for lower paid jobs?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Research has found that people leaving teaching roles in state schools are leaving for on average lower paid jobs. It didn't look at why this was.

fact_check_explanation_title: Lord Janner's prosecution explained
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Lord Janner prosecution is big news, but what do terms like 'fitness to plead' and 'trial of the facts' actually mean? We explain, with expert help.

fact_check_explanation_title: 3 December's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We factchecked the panel's claims on junior doctors' pay, air strikes, the Syrian civil war, and excess deaths in hospitals at the weekend.

fact_check_explanation_title: Overseas aid after the Autumn Statement
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's been reported that the government will soon spend more on overseas aid than the Home Office. This is probably right, but hard to verify at this point.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much will closing the Renewables Obligation early save on your bills?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government's best estimate is that the early closure will cut the average household's electricity bill by 30p, but there's some uncertainty about this.

fact_check_explanation_title: Air strikes in Syria: what MPs are voting on
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've found some useful sources on the debate over air strikes on Syria, particularly the legal issues.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are disadvantaged children twice as likely to be obese?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Childhood obesity affects 25% of year 6 pupils attending schools in the most deprived tenth of areas, and 13% at the least deprived tenth.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Times has corrected its headline that one in five Muslims has sympathy for ISIS, but the Sun hasn't
fact_check_explanation_summary: Don't be fooled by a Facebook post doing the rounds - it suggests that the Sun has printed a "retraction" of a front page story, which hasn't happened.

fact_check_explanation_title: High Court decides on Northern Ireland abortion law
fact_check_explanation_summary: The High Court has ruled that Northern Ireland's law on abortion is a breach of human rights, but has no power to directly overrule it.

fact_check_explanation_title: The public seems to support military action in Syria
fact_check_explanation_summary: An ITV poll has been cited on social media as evidence that the public opposes air strikes against Islamic State in Syria. Professional polls say otherwise.

fact_check_explanation_title: 26 November's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked the panel's claims on Syria, the big government's big economic announcement, manufacturing, and how the NHS is doing.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did George Osborne promise to eliminate the deficit by this year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Chancellor aimed to bring the UK back into surplus by 2015, not technically the same as a promise. Deficit reduction didn't go to plan.

fact_check_explanation_title: Renewable energy, domestic violence and Libya: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on renewable energy, domestic violence, Libya, and neighbourhood policing.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did 98% of junior doctors vote to strike?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's correct that 98% of junior doctors who voted on the issue backed a strike, but not that 98% of all junior doctors voted to strike.

fact_check_explanation_title: Phonics: are more six year olds on track to become confident readers?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Education Secretary has claimed that 120,000 more six year olds are on track to become confident readers as a result of the focus on phonics.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do one in five UK Muslims sympathise with Britons fighting for IS?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Sun states that nearly one in five British Muslims sympathise with people who leave the UK to fight for IS in Syria. This isn't correct.

fact_check_explanation_title: 19 November's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked a few of the claims on this week's BBC Question Time: on intervention in Syria, homeless veterans and police budget cuts.

fact_check_explanation_title: The proposed Renewables Obligation cut off: how much onshore wind capacity loses out?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government wants to close the Renewables Obligation to onshore wind a year early. How much capacity would miss out on its proposed grace period?

fact_check_explanation_title: Airstrikes, police cuts and doctors: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on police numbers, public opinion on airstrikes in Syria, doctors contracts and the budget deficit.

fact_check_explanation_title: The EU budget has its limits
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that EU budget commitments are rising, blowing the Prime Minister's budget cut promise off course, are inaccurate.

fact_check_explanation_title: MPs don't have to approve military action in Syria
fact_check_explanation_summary: The legal position on the use of military force in Syria is clear: the government doesn't need sign-off from MPs. The political aspect is more complex.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK aid to Syria
fact_check_explanation_summary: David Cameron claims that the UK is the second largest contributor of humanitarian aid in the Syrian crisis. This is right, according to the United Nations.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many apprenticeships are successfully completed?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Business Secretary has claimed there's no evidence of a big drop-off rate in apprenticeships.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many jobs could be lost in onshore wind?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's been suggested that closing the Renewables Obligation to onshore wind could threaten 19,000 jobs.

fact_check_explanation_title: 12 November's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from this week's BBC Question Time on the EU, NHS and Trident.

fact_check_explanation_title: £200 an hour legal aid lawyers: an update
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've been looking into the evidence that the Ministry of Justice provided to prove that legal aid lawyers earn £200 an hour. It's not convincing.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did MPs vote against removing the "tampon tax"?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There's been some confusion over what MPs voted against last month regarding the so-called "tampon tax".

fact_check_explanation_title: How many major businesses have experienced a cyber-attack?
fact_check_explanation_summary: TalkTalk Group's CEO claimed on Radio 4 Today that 9 in 10 major businesses experienced a cyber-attack in the last year. That's an uncertain figure.

fact_check_explanation_title: Limiting EU human rights law
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister's speech on the EU today mentioned the possibility of stopping EU human rights law from applying in this country. Can that be done?

fact_check_explanation_title: Population, immigration, and EU renegotiation
fact_check_explanation_summary: David Cameron's speech at Chatham House contained a number of claims on population growth and immigration. We've checked them here.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do half the UK's exports go to Europe?
fact_check_explanation_summary: In 2014, the EU accounted for around 44% of the UK's exports of goods and services.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many free trade deals has the EU done?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU has concluded trade agreements with around 50 countries outside the Union—some "classic" free trade agreements, and others more wide-ranging.

fact_check_explanation_title: 5 November's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked the claims from last night's BBC Question Time on junior doctors, crime, and housebuilding.

fact_check_explanation_title: Not everything European is the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: A recent headline described the Council of Europe as an "EU body", but this is a separate organisation to the European Union.

fact_check_explanation_title: The NHS, the military covenant and adoptions: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on all things NHS, as well as the armed forces covenant, housing benefit and adoption figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: Why worry about "ever closer union"?
fact_check_explanation_summary: EU heads of government formally said last year that the treaty language "ever closer union" shouldn't force reluctant countries into further EU integration.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK's renewable energy target
fact_check_explanation_summary: There's some confusion over the UK's renewable energy target. Here's our guide to what it is, where it comes from, and what might happen if it's missed.

fact_check_explanation_title: Women on the bench
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Lord Chief Justice spoke recently about the importance of diversity among the judges of England and Wales. We've looked into the statistics he cited.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are we unusual in permitting non-consensual adoption?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Senior judges say that England and Wales is unusual in permitting non-consensual, or "forced", adoption. Academic research tells a subtly different story.

fact_check_explanation_title: "Holiday fines" case heads to High Court
fact_check_explanation_summary: A legal case on parental fines for taking children out of school for holidays wasn't the landmark it was reported to be last month—but might turn out to be.

fact_check_explanation_title: 29 October's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: Is the Lords more in tune with public opinion than the Commons? Is Scotland more left wing than the rest of the UK? We check the Question Time claims.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are we missing our targets on renewable energy?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK met its interim renewable energy target for 2013 and 2014. The European Commission has suggested that the UK might be off track for its 2020 target.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are white applicants more likely to receive offers to top universities than black applicants?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Research is mixed on whether there's underlying racial bias in admissions to Russell Group universities.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tampons, Jaffa Cakes, and razors: we pay no VAT on some of these items
fact_check_explanation_summary: MPs have called for an end to the "tampon tax", arguing they're essential items and so VAT shouldn't be paid on them. Are razors and Jaffa Cakes exempt too?

fact_check_explanation_title: Businesses, tax credit promises, and Syria: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on setting up a business, tax credits, government borrowing, and foreign aid going to Syria.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did UK steel production halve under Labour?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Yes, if you compare 1997 to 2010, when the economy was in a slump. Production has been, broadly, in decline for decades.

fact_check_explanation_title: What do Brits think about wind farms?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 70% of respondents to a survey said they'd be happy to have a wind farm built in their local area. Some other forms of renewable energy are more popular.

fact_check_explanation_title: Processed meat isn't as big a cause of cancer as smoking
fact_check_explanation_summary: Did an international health watchdog find that processed meat is as likely to cause cancer as smoking? No.

fact_check_explanation_title: Job applicants with ethnic minority sounding names are less likely to be called for interview
fact_check_explanation_summary: The ethnic group your name is associated with does have an impact on the likelihood of your success in job applications, according to research from 2009.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tax credit changes: does the House of Lords have the right to challenge them?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's claimed that it would be unconstitutional for the House of Lords to block planned tax credit changes.

fact_check_explanation_title: 22 October's BBC Question Time, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: "That's the data, that's the facts". We've taken a look at some of the claims on last night's BBC Question Time.

fact_check_explanation_title: Statistics Authority calls for research on fit to work deaths
fact_check_explanation_summary: In August the Department for Work and Pensions released statistics about people who died while on benefits, or in the year they came off benefits. But the figures were confusing.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tax credits, steel and school places: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: Factchecking some of the claims we noticed in this week's Prime Minister's Questions.

fact_check_explanation_title: The law on "holiday fines" hasn't changed
fact_check_explanation_summary: A recent case won by a parent being prosecuted for taking his child out of school to go on holiday doesn't set a legal precedent or change the law.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Energy Bill and the Salisbury Convention
fact_check_explanation_summary: The House of Lords has been discussing whether, under the 'Salisbury Convention', it's obliged to pass the Energy Bill because it emerged from the Conservative manifesto.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence 11,000 NHS weekend deaths are caused by understaffing
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Health Secretary has claimed that 11,000 weekend deaths are caused by understaffed hospitals, but the research he cites doesn't show this.

fact_check_explanation_title: Six million jobs pay below the living wage
fact_check_explanation_summary: Six million jobs were paid at below the living wage in 2014, according to ONS figures. But that doesn't mean six million individual workers were.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is new nuclear energy cheaper and more reliable than new wind power?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Based on guaranteed fixed prices, new nuclear power is expected to be cheaper than offshore wind but more expensive than onshore wind.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are three-quarters of hospitals in England 'unsafe'?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This is the sum of hospitals rated inadequate or requiring improvements in safety by the Care Quality Commission. The CQC doesn't define all these as unsafe

fact_check_explanation_title: The Conservative manifesto's onshore wind pledge
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Conservative election manifesto was ambiguous on what it meant by ending "any new public subsidy" for onshore wind farms.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tax credits, poverty and council housing: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: Factchecking some of the claims we noticed in this week's Prime Minister's Questions.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is crime now starting to rise?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Crime is at a record low level, according to the Crime Survey for England and Wales. The police are recording more violent and sexual offences, but these rises may not …

fact_check_explanation_title: Does dropping human rights laws require leaving the EU too?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's claimed that laws protecting human rights will continue to bind the UK for as long as we are members of the EU.

fact_check_explanation_title: Will changes to tax credits cost families £1,300 a year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Jeremy Corbyn has said upcoming changes to tax credits will cost working families £1,300 next year. We've taken a look at how that figure was arrived at.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does smoking cost as much as it makes for the Treasury?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Do taxes on cigarettes bring in enough revenue to cover what smoking costs the government? It's complicated.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many jobs are supported by the UK's oil and gas industry?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The industry body Oil & Gas UK's latest estimate is 375,000 jobs. These figures are uncertain and don't just include direct employment in the industry.

fact_check_explanation_title: Can working immigrants claim over £10,000 in benefits?
fact_check_explanation_summary: At the moment it's possible for some types of working households to get over £10,000 in in-work benefits, including people from the European Economic Area.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: how many refugees are in the UK population?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A Facebook graphic is broadly right that refugees are a small proportion of the UK population.

fact_check_explanation_title: "Deradicalisation" referrals: young and increasing?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's been reported that referrals to the government's "deradicalisation" programme, Channel, are on the up. That's broadly correct.

fact_check_explanation_title: A million more pupils in good or outstanding schools? Not just a simple story of school improvement
fact_check_explanation_summary: There's no doubt that schools' Ofsted performance is improving. This progress is partly due to Ofsted's changing inspection practice.

fact_check_explanation_title: David Cameron's conference speech, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: David Cameron has given his first speech to the Conservative party conference as PM of a Conservative majority. We've taken a look at some of his claims.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many truanting fines go unpaid by parents?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It was claimed today that 40% of fines for pupil absence go unpaid. It's more like 20%, according to the latest data (for 2012/13).

fact_check_explanation_title: Is immigration good or bad for the economy?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The impact of immigration on the public finances is relatively small according to most studies, costing or contributing less than 1% of UK GDP.

fact_check_explanation_title: How much money do British universities get from the EU?
fact_check_explanation_summary: British universities don't get a straightforward 15% 'top-up' from the EU on central government funding.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fall in the number of children being placed for adoption
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Department for Education puts the decrease down to the misinterpretation of two high profile court judgments.

fact_check_explanation_title: Far fewer social welfare cases get legal aid
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures given to the Labour conference are right: in 2009/10, the legal aid scheme funded advice in 460,000 social welfare cases. In 2013/14 it was 53,000.

fact_check_explanation_title: 16-19 education saw the largest fall in education spending over the last Parliament
fact_check_explanation_summary: An analysis of the claim by the Shadow Education Secretary Lucy Powell that the Conservatives have overseen the deepest cuts to post-16 education ever.

fact_check_explanation_title: Human rights and the age of consent
fact_check_explanation_summary: As a Liberal Democrat MP claims, a case at the European Court of Human Rights was responsible for a change to the age of consent for gay people.

fact_check_explanation_title: Counting the cost of human rights law
fact_check_explanation_summary: Be wary of any attempt to tell you what human rights laws and court rulings 'cost' the government or the economy in the UK. The question has no easy answer.

fact_check_explanation_title: Small businesses and EU membership
fact_check_explanation_summary: European Movement UK has claimed that small businesses support EU membership. We've taken a look at what some recent surveys tell us.

fact_check_explanation_title: Jeremy Corbyn's conference speech, factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: Jeremy Corbyn has given his first speech to the Labour party conference as leader. We've taken a look at some of his claims.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are more people self-employed?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Jeremy Corbyn has claimed at Labour's annual conference that self-employed people make up one in seven of the labour force. We investigate.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does the UK pay a fifth of the VAT going into the EU budget?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Business for Britain says the UK pays a fifth of all VAT going into the EU budget. We look at the figures behind the claim.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did the government keep its promise on the Cancer Drugs Fund?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Rising costs have caused NHS England to remove some drugs from the Cancer Drugs Fund, which could soon be replaced by a new system.

fact_check_explanation_title: How large is the housing gap?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Housing was first up in Jeremy Corbyn's debut Prime Minister's Questions, where he claimed there was a housing gap of around 100,000.

fact_check_explanation_title: Partner visas and the EU
fact_check_explanation_summary: Difficulties getting a visa for a spouse aren't directly caused by the EU; they reflect government policy on immigration, which EU migration affects.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many migrants are coming to Europe and the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: How many migrants have arrived in Europe in 2015? How many are expected to come? How many people arrived in the UK in 2014? We look at the facts.

fact_check_explanation_title: The Sun, the OECD and asylum seekers
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Sun quotes the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development as saying that many migrants aren't fleeing war zones. Here's what else the OECD said.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are only one in five asylum seekers Syrian?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Mail claims that 1 in 5 asylum seekers have been Syrian. The Guardian says there is evidence that's changing as the situation develops. Both are right.

fact_check_explanation_title: The pay gap, record employment and an extra £23 billion to GDP: women and the workplace
fact_check_explanation_summary: BBC Question time saw claims on the pay gap, women's employment and a £23 billion boost to GDP from women reaching their potential. We look at the figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: Have NHS waiting times got better or worse? Pick your measure
fact_check_explanation_summary: Have NHS waiting times got better or worse in the last few years? It depends which measure you're looking at.

fact_check_explanation_title: Food banks, zero hours contracts and falling wages: are we worse off?
fact_check_explanation_summary: John McDonnell argued on last night's Question Time that some of the government's economic boasts are hollow. We've taken a look at his claims.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: does 80% of the public support the monarchy?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A reader told us that they keep hearing that 80% of the public support the monarchy. We take a look at the figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: are asylum seekers mostly men?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Readers have asked us whether it's true that most refugees are male. Of those applying for asylum in the EU recently, more than half have been men aged over 18.

fact_check_explanation_title: Looking for impartial information about the EU? Look no further
fact_check_explanation_summary: The public and businesses say they don't have enough information about the EU. Full Fact will provide impartial information in the run up to the referendum.

fact_check_explanation_title: There's only so much £8 billion will buy you in the NHS
fact_check_explanation_summary: The £8 billion figure is totemic for the future of the NHS, but as the Nuffield Trust has explained, it is not extra money to pay for extra services.

fact_check_explanation_title: Child poverty—it's up but it's also down
fact_check_explanation_summary: Jeremy Corbyn claims child poverty went up by half a million under the last government. It's up by one measure, but down by another.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are childcare costs soaring?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We know that at the very least, costs for part-time nursery for the under 2s has been increasing—particularly in certain regions.

fact_check_explanation_title: Nobody knows how many lives could be saved by a seven-day NHS
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's claimed that better NHS care at weekends—the "7-day NHS"—could save 3,000 lives, or 6,000, or somewhere in between. In reality, nobody really knows.

fact_check_explanation_title: The human rights victories won by criminals
fact_check_explanation_summary: Just under half the cases won against the UK at the European Court of Human Rights have involved someone convicted or suspected of a criminal offence.

fact_check_explanation_title: The UK can't be forced to accept more refugees
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU can't force Britain to take a "quota" of refugees from other EU countries. The UK can choose to opt in to any such EU plan.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: Germany hasn't accepted 800,000 Syrian refugees
fact_check_explanation_summary: Germany will end up accepting hundreds of thousands of refugees, both from Syria and the wider world, but 800,000 Syrians accepted to date is way off.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do asset sales save the government money?
fact_check_explanation_summary: George Osborne found £4.5 billion in savings to be made by the government, including asset sales. Do asset sales count as savings?

fact_check_explanation_title: International law and the death of Reyaad Khan
fact_check_explanation_summary: The death of a British citizen, Reyaad Khan, in an RAF drone strike has led to debate about whether or not the killing was allowed under international law.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the performance of disadvantaged pupils improving?
fact_check_explanation_summary: School performance of disadvantaged pupils has, for the most part, been improving. The trend is less clear for the gap between these pupils and their peers.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are graduates settling for non-graduate jobs?
fact_check_explanation_summary: CIPD says 58.8% of graduates are in non-graduate roles, but this is based on an old survey.

fact_check_explanation_title: TTIP's "secret courts"
fact_check_explanation_summary: Investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) is at the heart of the debate over a proposed treaty, TTIP, between the EU and US. Here's who wins ISDS cases.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: does the NHS spend £30 million pulling kids' teeth because of sugar?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Jamie Oliver's "Sugar Rush" campaign has claimed that extracting kids' teeth due to sugar is costing £30 million a year. It's not quite that simple.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the UK only taken in 216 Syrian refugees?
fact_check_explanation_summary: A number of outlets are claiming that the UK has taken in so few Syrian refugees that you could fit them all on a tube train. This is wrong.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many free schools are in deprived communities?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Based on the available data, just under 45% of open mainstream free schools are in areas ranked as in the 30% most deprived.

fact_check_explanation_title: Police numbers: back to the 1970s?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's claimed spending cuts could mean 22,000 fewer police officers in England and Wales. Would that put police numbers at their lowest since the 1970s?

fact_check_explanation_title: Reporting on "fit for work" deaths isn't fit for purpose
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's been widely claimed that thousands of people died within weeks of being found "fit for work". This is wrong.

fact_check_explanation_title: DWP figures on benefit claimant deaths: what they do and don't tell us
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Department for Work and Pensions have published data on the benefit claimant deaths. Read our guide to interpreting the figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: Those "eight million foreigners" living in the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: The number of foreign-born people in the UK has probably passed eight million, but that's not the same as the number of non-UK nationals. Just ask Boris.

fact_check_explanation_title: Hospitals in the red: the size of the NHS provider deficit
fact_check_explanation_summary: NHS trusts faced an overall deficit of £830 million in 2014/15 and this is expected to rise to around £2 billion this year.

fact_check_explanation_title: Please do not board this train: rail fare claims held at red signal
fact_check_explanation_summary: The TUC says rail fares have risen by 25% since 2010. This is correct but refers to regulated fares only rather than all fares, as widely quoted.

fact_check_explanation_title: "Some immigration facts" ... factchecked
fact_check_explanation_summary: A blackboard showing 'some immigration facts' has some basis in fact but either misunderstands the facts available, or gives a selective viewpoint on them.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: Europol and diplomatic immunity
fact_check_explanation_summary: Officers of Europol, the European Union's law enforcement agency, are not entitled to 'diplomatic immunity' from criminal prosecution.

fact_check_explanation_title: What's happening to high-skilled jobs?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Shadow Chancellor says that the share of jobs classed as high-skilled fell in 2014. What's happening over the longer term?

fact_check_explanation_title: UK public spending down to US levels by 2018/19
fact_check_explanation_summary: The summer 2015 Budget could see UK public spending drop to US levels within four years.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pay for carers: will the 'national living wage' increase spending by £1 billion a year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some of the £1bn cost could be incurred anyway without the policy, and the figure rests on a lot of uncertainty. Other estimates even suggest higher costs.

fact_check_explanation_title: UK asylum support doesn't go as far as France
fact_check_explanation_summary: Comparisons are tricky, but it seems that the UK gives asylum seekers less cash support than many other European countries, adjusted for living costs.

fact_check_explanation_title: England not named world's second worst nation for child happiness
fact_check_explanation_summary: Compared to 14 other countries in a survey, England's children were some of the least happy on specific aspects such as their relationship with teachers and self-confidence.

fact_check_explanation_title: E-cigarettes on the NHS? Not so fast
fact_check_explanation_summary: Today's review of the evidence on e-cigarettes puts NHS prescription on the agenda, but there's more to it than this one recommendation.

fact_check_explanation_title: Evidence for 6,000 weekend deaths published
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Department of Health has published evidence behind its claim that 6,000 deaths could be prevented by a 7 day NHS.

fact_check_explanation_title: Seven in ten free schools are in areas needing more school places
fact_check_explanation_summary: By the start of the 2014/15 academic year (September 2014), 75% of open or approved free schools were in areas with an expected need, according to analysis by the Department …

fact_check_explanation_title: Diagnosis unknown: how many diabetes cases go undetected?
fact_check_explanation_summary: GP practice registers show 3.3 million diagnosed diabetes cases in 2013/14, but the methodology and reliability of the undiagnosed figure is more uncertain.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: have 100 EU 'powers' been returned to the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Have 100 EU 'powers' been returned to UK control? Yes, if by 'powers' you mean specific laws.

fact_check_explanation_title: Cash for asylum seekers: hard to say whether we give more
fact_check_explanation_summary: Media explanations about the rate of cash support for asylum seekers in France and the UK are comparing the wrong things - understandably, as it's complex.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ashes to ashes, grants to loans: how scrapping maintenance grants will affect students
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government is scrapping maintenance grants, replacing them with larger loans. What effect will this have?

fact_check_explanation_title: Britain's privatised rail: 40% too expensive?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Research carried out for the government a few years ago is the source for Andy Burnham's claim that our railways cost 40% more to run than others in Europe.

fact_check_explanation_title: What proportion of benefits claimants are sanctioned?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Department for Work and Pensions says that less than 6% of JSA claimants are sanctioned. An FOI request found a figure of 18%. Which is right?

fact_check_explanation_title: Cash cows? Milk prices and the BBC
fact_check_explanation_summary: A BBC infographic suggests that farmers make a loss of 14p per litre on the milk they supply. This isn't correct; on its own figures, it's more like 6p-8p.

fact_check_explanation_title: Pay gap: do women earn 80p for every £1 earned by men?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister has said that on average, a woman earns about 80p for every £1 earned by a man. Is he right?

fact_check_explanation_title: Kids Company: doubts over how many it helped
fact_check_explanation_summary: The now-defunct Kids Company claimed to be helping 36,000 people in 2015—the same number it claimed to help in 2011. Does this add up?

fact_check_explanation_title: How many asylum seekers has Britain had?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Figures given by Channel 4 News on asylum seekers are correct: in the first three months of 2015, six EU countries received more applications than Britain.

fact_check_explanation_title: A new Hong Kong in Northern Ireland?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It was a plan "too preposterous for words" according to the Belfast Telegraph, but that didn't stop a number of outlets reporting seriously on it.

fact_check_explanation_title: UN wrong on asylum seekers in Britain
fact_check_explanation_summary: Peter Sutherland of the UN is right that the UK receives fewer asylum seekers than other EU countries, but not as few as BBC listeners were led to believe.

fact_check_explanation_title: No evidence that seven in ten Calais migrants are entering the UK
fact_check_explanation_summary: "7 in 10 Calais migrants get into UK", says the front page of the Daily Mail. The article itself is far less certain about it.

fact_check_explanation_title: Cracking up: efficiency in the criminal courts
fact_check_explanation_summary: Michael Gove is right that less than half of criminal trials went as planned last year. Concerns about the efficiency of the criminal courts are growing.

fact_check_explanation_title: About 27% of Europeans are likely to experience a mental health problem in a year
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's claimed 27% of Europeans suffer from a mental health problem. The research backs this up.

fact_check_explanation_title: Why are there so many migrants at Calais?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Migrants at Calais are unlikely to be drawn to the UK by benefits, as they're not available to illegal entrants, although asylum seekers get some state support.

fact_check_explanation_title: Coasting schools: three strikes and you're out
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's too early to say exactly how many schools will count as 'coasting' under the government's new definition, but that hasn't stopped people from trying.

fact_check_explanation_title: Human rights court: "pseudo-judges" or super judges?
fact_check_explanation_summary: None of the current judges at the European Court of Human Rights are obviously unqualified, although they are in a sense political appointees.

fact_check_explanation_title: ESA: "extra money" for some
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister is right that support group claimants of Employment and Support Allowance (ESA) stay on a higher rate, but it'll be reduced by inflation.

fact_check_explanation_title: Factchecking the criminal legal aid dispute
fact_check_explanation_summary: Lawyers are taking industrial action over changes to criminal legal aid, including a reduction in fees. We've factchecked some of the claims in this debate.

fact_check_explanation_title: Do 40% of new teachers in England leave within a year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The answer depends on which data you look at and even then it's limited. Without better data, it's impossible to know for sure.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many deaths occur in police custody?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Home Secretary Theresa May has announced an independent review of deaths in police custody. We take a look at the latest figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: The "too old to adopt their granddaughter" myth
fact_check_explanation_summary: A widely reported story about a judge refusing to allow a child to live with her grandparents, because they were too old, is proved wrong by the judgment.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tax credits: how much has spending increased in 16 years?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Chancellor of the Exchequer claims tax credit spending has increased thirty-fold in 16 years. But not all the figures are comparable over time.

fact_check_explanation_title: Have the government's tuition fee reforms worked?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look at how the Higher Education reforms have worked out for students, graduates, universities and the public.

fact_check_explanation_title: Paying off the debt, one law at a time
fact_check_explanation_summary: Rules like the "budget surplus law" can always be repealed by a future government, and broken without any particular legal consequences in any event.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is the UK's deficit one of the highest in the developed world?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Latest figures forecast the UK to have a budget deficit of 3.7% of its GDP by 2015/16, down from 4.9% in 2014/15, one of the higher deficits in the developed …

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: Employment, unemployment and jobseekers
fact_check_explanation_summary: This article has been updated. Over on our Facebook page, some readers had questions about our roundup of employment figures. Where does the unemployment figure of 1.85 million come from, …

fact_check_explanation_title: Early help for children—uncertain definition leads to uncertain estimates
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government says it's increased funding for early help for vulnerable children, but charities say funding is down. It depends on what services you count.

fact_check_explanation_title: Prisoners absconding: an open and shut case?
fact_check_explanation_summary: This week's Prime Minister's Questions heard many claims about prisoners on the run. We establish the facts.

fact_check_explanation_title: PMQs follow up: unemployment and benefits
fact_check_explanation_summary: Prime Minister's Questions went in heavy on unemployment and out of work benefits. We've rounded up and checked the claims.

fact_check_explanation_title: 7-day NHS: no source yet for claims that 6,000 deaths a year could be avoided
fact_check_explanation_summary: Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt has said 6,000 people a year die because hospitals don't offer a 7-day service, but the evidence for this hasn't been published

fact_check_explanation_title: The hunt for 8.4 million Welsh-speaking telly addicts (yng Nghymraeg!)
fact_check_explanation_summary: Now in Welsh: Minister says twice as many people watch Welsh language TV as live in Wales.

fact_check_explanation_title: Tax credits, asylum seekers, and the underreporting of rape: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've checked the claims from PMQs on last week's budget, housing for asylum seekers, and on how many rape victims report the crime to the police

fact_check_explanation_title: The hunt for 8.4 million Welsh-speaking telly addicts
fact_check_explanation_summary: Minister says twice as many people watch Welsh language TV as live in Wales.

fact_check_explanation_title: Who's responsible for scrutinizing our official statistics?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government has announced a review of the production Britain's economic statistics. The Treasury could assume responsibility for the quality of official figures, and it's argued that this would make …

fact_check_explanation_title: Are high-earners paying a greater share of tax than in 2010?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Chancellor has claimed that the richest are paying a greater share of tax, something that's supported by Treasury analysis.

fact_check_explanation_title: Wanted: evidence that a bad diet causes 70,000 premature deaths every year
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's widely claimed that a bad diet leads to 70,000 premature deaths a year in the UK. But it's difficult to find a reliable source for this figure.

fact_check_explanation_title: Has the Prime Minister broken a promise on tax credits?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Prime Minister has been accused of breaking a pledge on child tax credits. So what exactly was promised?

fact_check_explanation_title: The welfare budget
fact_check_explanation_summary: A look at the welfare budget with context, key facts and sources of information.

fact_check_explanation_title: How is the welfare budget split?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Take a guess at how the welfare budget breaks down and see how close you are with a handy new tool from the ONS.

fact_check_explanation_title: Factchecking the Summer Budget 2015
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've picked out and checked nine claims from Osborne and Harman's speeches on the Summer Budget.

fact_check_explanation_title: The government's "modest proposal"
fact_check_explanation_summary: David Cameron describes his government's English votes scheme as a "modest proposal". Experts said recently that it lies between "moderate and radical".

fact_check_explanation_title: Are people in poverty increasingly in work?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's claimed that people in poverty are increasingly in work. We've taken a look at the figures.

fact_check_explanation_title: Legal aid lawyers aren't on £200 an hour
fact_check_explanation_summary: A remark in Parliament that legal aid lawyers can earn £200 an hour for social welfare cases gives the wrong impression. Hourly rates are around £50-£70.

fact_check_explanation_title: The benefit cap didn't cause 30,000 to get back into work
fact_check_explanation_summary: George Osborne has said that 30,000 people went into work after being subject to the benefit cap. But the reality is more complex.

fact_check_explanation_title: GP waiting times: survey doesn't show 14 million "forced" to wait a week or more
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Daily Mail says 14 million patients were forced to wait a week or more last year, according to new figures. But the figures don't say that.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: does urinating in public put you on the sex offenders register?
fact_check_explanation_summary: It's very unlikely that being caught urinating in public will get you charged with a sexual offence, like exposure, that puts you on the police register.

fact_check_explanation_title: Poverty, inequality and airport expansion: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on poverty, inequality, airport expansion and defence spending.

fact_check_explanation_title: Is Grexit legal?
fact_check_explanation_summary: EU members can leave the Union voluntarily, but there's no legal mechanism for a country to drop or be ejected from the euro. Grexit may well happen anyway.

fact_check_explanation_title: Bad graphs: Gatwick needs a short-haul overhaul
fact_check_explanation_summary: Today's Airport Commission report accidentally suggested Gatwick had more short-haul flights than Heathrow. We're on the case.

fact_check_explanation_title: Benefits: It's not true that half get more than they pay
fact_check_explanation_summary: Much of the press says that half of households get more in 'benefits' than they pay in tax. But 'benefits' here includes things like visiting your GP.

fact_check_explanation_title: The EU, the Gherkin and 'freedom of panorama'
fact_check_explanation_summary: Restrictions on 'freedom of panorama' - reproducing images of public buildings and art - have been proposed in an EU committee, but are a long way from law.

fact_check_explanation_title: GP opening hours—five years of pledges
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government has been criticised by shadow health minister Liz Kendall for not meeting a promise on GP opening hours.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ask Full Fact: What's happened to the minimum wage?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We asked our Facebook followers for suggestions for a factcheck, and this was the lucky winner. What's happened to the minimum wage since it was introduced?

fact_check_explanation_title: How many Syrian refugees are there in the UK?
fact_check_explanation_summary: 187 Syrian refugees entered the UK through a government programme. 4-5,000 Syrian refugees arrived in the UK since the crisis started. Which is correct?

fact_check_explanation_title: Income tax: Who contributes what
fact_check_explanation_summary: Former chancellor has urged the government to cut the top income tax rate to 45p. We've had a look at how high-earners fared last time it was cut.

fact_check_explanation_title: Child tax credits, cancer tests, and academies: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: At PMQs Harriet Harman and others grilled the Prime Minister on issues from child benefits, cancer diagnosis, and school policy.

fact_check_explanation_title: £21 billion saved? Welfare spending over the last parliament

fact_check_explanation_title: How many lives would early cancer diagnosis save?
fact_check_explanation_summary: There's uncertainty around estimates of how many deaths could be prevented by earlier diagnosis of cancer

fact_check_explanation_title: £1.2 billion saved? The troubled families programme
fact_check_explanation_summary: David Cameron says the government's troubled families programme saved £1.2 billion. But we don't know what the effect of the programme actually was.

fact_check_explanation_title: Foreign nurses: how many are to be "kicked out" due to visa rules?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Independent and the Mirror have reported very different figures on the number of nurses who'll be affected by recent visa changes.

fact_check_explanation_title: When talking about benefit cuts it's unhelpful to refer to the "£220 billion" welfare budget
fact_check_explanation_summary: The £220 billion welfare budget includes pension costs, which aren't going to be cut.

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS waiting times: one of three 18-week targets has been missed in 10 of 12 months
fact_check_explanation_summary: The NHS has missed one of its 18 week waiting time targets in 10 of the last 12 months - what's behind worsening performance on this measure?

fact_check_explanation_title: Will there be a million more over 70s in 2020?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The UK population is ageing, and this is putting considerable pressure on public finances.

fact_check_explanation_title: Election 2015: the most expensive poll on record?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Claims that 2015 election was the 'most expensive' ever are based on donations, but spending during election time is capped, and we don't have figures yet.

fact_check_explanation_summary: Two prisoners occupy a cell intended for one. How many are living in 'crowded accommodation'? Some prisons have been counting only one prisoner.

fact_check_explanation_title: Did the EU misspend enough money to build 10 new hospitals?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The EU misspent €7 billion in 2013. Would that have paid for 10 new hospitals?

fact_check_explanation_summary: What impact are increasing pupil numbers having on infant class sizes? Taking into account both lawfully and unlawfully large classes, there are growing numbers with 31 or more pupils.

fact_check_explanation_summary: Britain does have a structural deficit, but that doesn't just mean that the government spends more than it receives.
